site_title: Funds raised by Catalist companies hit new high
summary: Funds raised by Catalist companies in Singapore reached a record high of S$285 million as of November 27, 2024, with 15 Catalist IPOs launched this year and a total market capitalization of S$1.36 billion.

site_title: Changi Airports International wins Maldives' Male airport consultancy deal
summary: Changi Airports International (CAI) has been hired as a consultant for the expansion and commercialization of Malé international airport in the Maldives. CAI will review and provide recommendations for the existing passenger terminal and help improve the airport's commercial offerings. The goal is to boost the airport's capacity to over five million tourist arrivals by 2018. CAI's managing director, Bandhu Ibrahim Saleem, believes the company will bring world-class planning and operating experience to the Maldives, supporting the successful delivery of the airport expansion.

site_title: Tensions soar after night of clashes in Hong Kong
summary: Tensions escalated in Hong Kong after a night of clashes between police and pro-democracy protesters, who were trying to storm government headquarters. Police used pepper spray and baton charges, injuring several protesters, and making 40 arrests. The clashes marked a significant escalation of violence in the three-month-old protests, which began with mass sit-ins demanding free leadership elections. The protests have been met with resistance from the Chinese government, which insists on vetting candidates for the 2017 election.

site_title: Progress in building inter-ethnic ties
summary: The Assembly of the People of Kazakhstan, established in 1995, promotes inter-ethnic relations harmony in the country. As an advisory-consultative body, it aims to foster stability, friendly relations, and democratic norms among its 350 members. The Assembly has contributed to the development of national schools, newspapers, and cultural institutions, with 23 native languages taught. Former UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has recognized Kazakhstan as a model of inter-ethnic concord, highlighting the Assembly's success in promoting sustainable development.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: The "Remembering Acts of Love - Community Chest Charity Gala 2014" raised over S$2.5 million for Community Chest and adopted charities, including The Salvation Army Prison Support Services - Kids in Play, and Lighthouse School. The event also raised S$400,000 for the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's two adopted charities. Additionally, a pop-up food event will be held on Dec 6 to support the Home Nursing Foundation, with proceeds going towards integrated homecare services for elderly patients.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down 1.29% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.29% at the open on Monday, December 1, 2014, following China's manufacturing activity growth slowing in November. The Hang Seng Index dropped 309.45 points to 23,678.00. This decline occurred amidst official data showing a decrease in China's manufacturing activity in November.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge subdued in November: TDMI
summary: Australia's private inflation gauge, the TD Securities-Melbourne Institute's monthly measure of consumer prices, rose 0.1% in November, edging up from a 0.2% rise in October. The annual pace of inflation slowed to 2.2%, near the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. The Reserve Bank is likely to keep interest rates unchanged at 2.5% at its upcoming meeting, citing subdued inflation.

site_title: S'pore, US looking into trusted traveller programme for faster immigration clearance
summary: Singapore and the US are exploring a trusted traveller programme to speed up immigration clearance for citizens of both countries. The programme, which allows citizens to use automated kiosks at major entry points, is part of a strategic partnership to provide convenience and facilitate travel while keeping borders safe and secure. Interested citizens can apply for the programme, which would complement Singapore's existing arrangements with Malaysia and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Singapore and the US are exploring the development of a trusted traveller programme to speed up immigration clearance for citizens of both countries, the Singapore Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) said in a statement.

site_title: Further cut of private housing land expected
summary: Singapore's government is expected to continue scaling back private housing land supply, with property consultants predicting at least one office site to be released through the confirmed list for H1 2015. The Ministry of National Development is expected to maintain sufficient new supply to meet long-term housing needs, with the private residential market showing an undersupply situation resolved. Retail space supply is also expected to be reduced, with suburban malls seen as a viable option, while office supply may include sites in growth areas like Jurong or Woodlands.

site_title: Black Friday sales down as shopping habits change
summary: US consumers spent less on Black Friday sales this year, with a 2.6% decline compared to last year, according to a National Retail Federation survey. Despite this, 55.1% of shoppers planned to visit stores or shop online over the Thanksgiving weekend, down from 58.7% last year. The decline is attributed to a strengthening economy, changing shopping habits, and a highly competitive environment.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending during America's Thanksgiving weekend dropped compared to last year, but the decline can be attributed to an improving economy and changing shopping habits.

site_title: Indonesia to offer USD sovereign bonds in January
summary: Indonesia plans to issue a USD4bn US dollar sovereign bond in January 2015, marking its return to the global debt markets. The bond, arranged by Citigroup, HSBC, and Standard Chartered, will offer 5.875% coupons for 10 years and 6.75% for 30 years. This is Indonesia's first US dollar sovereign bond issue in 2015, following a similar pattern in 2014. The country is also considering a euro-denominated offering.

images.alt_text: The Republic of Indonesia has mandated Citigroup, HSBC and Standard Chartered to arrange its first US dollar sovereign bond issue of 2015.

site_title: Asian markets mixed, oil prices sink further
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday, with Tokyo reaching a seven-year high and Shanghai adding 0.60% on hopes for more economy-boosting measures from China. However, Hong Kong and Sydney declined, while energy firms fell due to plunging oil prices, which sank to multi-year lows following Opec's decision to maintain oil output levels. The decline in oil prices led to losses for energy firms, but airlines climbed as their biggest cost, fuel, decreased.

images.alt_text: Energy firms in the region fell again as oil prices sank to multi-year lows in reaction to Thursday's announcement by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries that it would not cut production of the black gold.

site_title: HSBC Singapore opens 12th retail branch in affluent Bukit Timah neighbourhood
summary: HSBC Singapore has opened its 12th retail branch in the affluent Bukit Timah neighbourhood, offering services to its HSBC Premier and HSBC Advance customers. The nearly 3,000 sq ft branch provides international banking, investment, and wealth management services. The bank aims to target the affluent market with its expanded presence in prime locations, including the Digital Hub, which offers e-banking services. The new branch coincides with upgrades to existing branches in Marine Parade and Holland Village.

images.alt_text: HSBC continues its push into Singapore's retail banking and wealth management business, opening a new branch in one of the most affluent neighbourhoods in Singapore.

site_title: Analysts say slowing eurozone inflation could pave way for more QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to consider further monetary easing amid slowing eurozone inflation, which slowed to 0.3% in November from 0.4% in the previous month. Analysts predict the ECB may launch quantitative easing (QE) to stimulate the economy, but it may not happen at the ECB's last monthly policy meeting of the year this week. The ECB has already implemented various measures to combat deflation, but medium-term inflation expectations may become permanently de-anchored from its target of 2.0%.

site_title: P99 now a cash company after settlement of dispute with subsidiary
summary: P99 Holdings, a cafe operator, has resolved a dispute with its subsidiary Asia Brand Group and Liu Yanlong, and is now a cash company. Following an arbitration ruling, P99 received S$2.66 million from the 2011 sale and purchase agreement. The company's cash and bank balance now stands at about S$11.07 million.

site_title: EUN's S$1.16 cash offer for euNetworks to close on Dec 29
summary: EUN Holdings' private equity-led consortium will close its S$1.16 per share cash offer for euNetworks Group on Dec 29. The consortium, controlling 59.16% of euNetworks shares, has received irrevocable undertakings from existing shareholders not to accept the offer, ensuring no 90% threshold is crossed. EUN plans to continue euNetworks' business with no major changes. The company will not seek to maintain euNetworks' listing status if the public free float falls below 10%.

site_title: China manufacturing growth at eight-month low: govt
summary: China's manufacturing growth slowed to an eight-month low in November, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 50.3, down from 50.8 in October. This marks the weakest reading since March, signaling further downward pressure on the world's second-largest economy. China's central bank cut benchmark interest rates last month to prop up flagging growth, but the economy still faces challenges, including stagnant factory growth and a weakening property market. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow further, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: UK regulator to be scrutinised over swaps redress scheme
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is under scrutiny for its swaps redress scheme, which was set up to compensate thousands of small firms wrongly sold interest rate hedging products. Over 30,000 cases were ordered reviewed, but nearly a third of businesses were excluded due to being too big or lacking understanding of the products. Despite banks setting aside £4.4 billion for compensation, only £1.5 billion has been paid out. Lawmakers will debate the issue, questioning the effectiveness of the regulator and the fairness of the scheme.

site_title: Merkel behind Air Berlin in Etihad control dispute: report
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is backing loss-making Air Berlin in a dispute with its Abu Dhabi-based partner Etihad over control, according to a report. Etihad owns a 29% stake in Air Berlin and is under investigation by German and European authorities over its partnership. Merkel's support is seen as a bid to counterbalance Etihad's influence and prevent the airline from being taken over. The dispute raises concerns about the impact of foreign ownership on German airlines.

site_title: Japan govt intensifies response to Takata flaws
summary: Japan's government has intensified its response to Takata air bag flaws, forcing carmakers to expand recalls to include driver's-side air bags suspected of faults. The move comes 19 months after a transportation minister's initial response was deemed inadequate. Since mid-November, the safety authorities have made stern announcements and directives to Takata and carmakers, affecting over 14 million vehicles globally. The government's actions are aimed at addressing the deadly air bag flaws, which have been linked to numerous fatalities worldwide.

images.alt_text: Mr Ohta has said that trust in Japanese carmakers could weaken, so the problem must be resolved as quickly as possible.

site_title: India factory output rises in November: survey
summary: Indian factory output rose to 53.3 points in November, the highest figure since February 2013, according to a HSBC survey. This indicates expansion, with consumer goods leading the way. However, inflationary pressures intensified, making it challenging for the Reserve Bank of India to cut its benchmark lending rate, currently at 8%. The data precedes the RBI's monetary policy review, which aims to revive the country's flagging economy.

site_title: Swiss massively reject 'green' immigration cap
summary: The Swiss voted 74.1% against the 'Ecopop' initiative, which aimed to reduce immigration to curb population growth and urban pressure. The proposal was deemed xenophobic and threatening to the economy. The Swiss also rejected proposals to scrap special tax breaks for rich foreigners and to significantly increase the country's gold reserves. The results indicate a strong stance against drastic immigration cuts, prioritizing economic and environmental concerns.

site_title: Taiwan's PMI dips to 15-month low of 51.4 in November
summary: Taiwan's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to a 15-month low of 51.4 in November, signaling a deterioration in business conditions. This is the slowest rate of improvement in the current 15-month sequence. The reading below 50.0 indicates a slowdown in the economy, contradicting expectations of a continued expansion.

images.alt_text: Readings above 50.0 signal an improvement in business conditions while readings below indicate deterioration.

site_title: Japan's November final manufacturing growth eases, still suggests modest Q4 rebound
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity grew at a slower pace in November, easing from a preliminary reading of 52.1 to 52.0, according to a survey. The index remained above the 50 threshold for the sixth consecutive month, suggesting a modest recovery after the economy slipped into recession in the third quarter. New export orders rose for the fifth month, but at a slower pace than in October, while input costs rose at the fastest rate since January due to a yen depreciation. Analysts believe the economy likely resumed expansion in the current quarter, but concerns about the recovery's strength persist.

images.alt_text: The final Markit/JMMA Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) was 52.0 in November, less than a preliminary reading of 52.1 and lower than a final 52.4 in October.

site_title: Australia manufacturing edges into expansion in November: AIG
summary: Australia's manufacturing sector edged into expansion in November, with the Australian Industry Group's performance of manufacturing index (PMI) rising 0.7 points to 50.1. The sector's performance is attributed to the lower Australian dollar, easing energy costs, and moderate wages growth. Despite this, the sector has been in recession for almost five years, with the PMI survey persistently weaker than official measures. The improvement is seen as a positive for the sector, driven by stronger residential construction activity and demand for locally made inputs and components.

site_title: Innovative US salad chain draws tech investors' dollars
summary: US salad chain Sweetgreen has raised $18.5 million in financing from venture capital firm Revolution Growth, led by AOL co-founder Steve Case. The funding is seen as a surprise, given Sweetgreen's focus on farm-to-table salads and wellness-minded consumers. The company is applying online ideals to in-store experiences, featuring open kitchens and local ingredients. Founded by Georgetown University students in 2007, Sweetgreen plans to expand to California and aims to become a national brand, similar to Chipotle.

site_title: Britain's Co-op Bank to fail Bank of England stress test: Times
summary: Britain's Co-operative Bank is expected to fail the Bank of England's stress test due to insufficient buffers to withstand a severe recession. The bank had built 1.9 billion pounds in extra capital in the past year but acknowledged it lacks sufficient reserves to recover from a 35% house price crash and rising unemployment. The results of the stress test, announced on December 16, will also determine the fate of other eight leading lenders. The Co-op bank nearly collapsed last year after a 1.5 billion pound capital shortfall was identified.

site_title: Tanker operators see margin boost as crude prices retreat
summary: Tanker operators are expected to see increased profit margins due to low oil prices, which have dropped by more than a third since June. Current-quarter gains for shipping companies could last until mid-2015 as oil prices remain depressed. The decline in oil prices has led to long-haul arbitrage opportunities, with ships engaging in extended voyages to move cheaper oil to Asia, where it is sold at higher prices.

site_title: Indonesia inflation spikes on fuel hike but central bank seen holding rate
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 6.23% in November, exceeding expectations, due to a 30% fuel price hike. However, economists believe the central bank will not raise interest rates again, citing a temporary spike in inflation. Experts predict inflation will peak at 7.8% in January but expect a rate hike only if inflation rises further. The central bank has predicted an annual inflation of around 7.9% at the end of the year.

site_title: Xbox Japan chief resigns after poor sales
summary: The head of Microsoft's Xbox business in Japan, Takashi Sensui, has resigned, but the move is not attributed to poor sales. Sensui will continue working in the games business at the US head office, and his position will not be replaced. Microsoft stated that Sensui's transfer is unrelated to the decline in Xbox sales, which have been a concern for the company in Japan.

site_title: Australia still working through macroprudential policy options: official
summary: Australia's banking regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (Apra), is still exploring macroprudential policy options to cool the country's unbalanced housing market. Chairman Wayne Byres is examining tools to strengthen mortgage-lending practices, including interest-only loans and long tenure mortgages, in a rising interest-rate environment. While no deadline has been set for implementing measures, Apra aims to temper speculative buying and reduce the risk to the stability of Australia's financial system.

site_title: China refuses British MPs entry to Hong Kong
summary: A group of British lawmakers, led by Richard Ottaway, were denied entry to Hong Kong by China, citing opposition to their inquiry into Britain's relations with the territory. The Foreign Affairs Committee planned to visit Hong Kong to scrutinize the 30-year anniversary of the 1984 Joint Declaration. The move comes amid pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, where demonstrators demand the right to choose leaders without interference from Beijing. The committee chairs said the Chinese government's actions are "overtly confrontational" and an attempt to block their investigation.

images.alt_text: The move comes amid continuing protests by pro-democracy campaigners in Hong Kong who have been demanding the right to choose their own leaders without interference from Beijing.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.75%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.75% to seven-year highs on December 1, 2014, following OPEC's decision not to cut oil output. The Nikkei 225 index reached 17,590.10, while the Topix index rose 0.80% to 1,421.65. The dollar strengthened against the yen in response to the decision.

site_title: Opec refusal means oil industry's weakest will be left behind
summary: Opec's refusal to cut crude output has left the oil industry's weakest producers, including US wildcatters and governments reliant on oil revenues, vulnerable to lower prices. The plunge in oil prices has already affected oil producers, with Continental Resources Inc falling 20% and Exxon Mobil Corp declining 4.2%. Analysts predict that only 4% of US shale production requires $80 or more to be profitable, leading to a slow decline in production growth. Smaller operators and those in emerging fields are expected to be particularly affected, with some facing significant declines in drilling and output.

site_title: US fast-food workers to strike for higher wages
summary: US fast-food workers in 160 cities plan to strike on Dec 4, demanding higher wages and union rights. They aim for a minimum wage of $15 an hour, with current average wages at $9.08. The strike, part of the "Fight for US$15" movement, will highlight the plight of low-paid workers in the industry. The event is expected to be the largest since the movement began two years ago, drawing attention to the issue and giving workers a platform to tell their stories.

site_title: Australian city home prices mixed in November: RPData
summary: Australian home prices varied in November, with a 2.6% drop in Melbourne and a 1.0% gain in Sydney. The national index fell 0.3% from October, and the annual pace of price growth slowed to 8.5%, the slowest for 2014. Despite a cooling market, policymakers have generally tolerated rising prices to encourage home building, which is currently underway. The median home price in Sydney was A$705,000, while in Melbourne it was A$568,500.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall to 7-week low as oil slump hits energy firms
summary: Australian shares fell to a 7-week low on Monday, dropping 44.7 points to 5,268.3, as investors worried about a slide in global oil and commodity prices. Weaker-than-expected Chinese factory growth and weaker-than-expected Australian company profits also contributed to the decline. Energy and mining firms, such as PanAust and WorleyParsons, were among the worst performers, while Qantas Airways rose 11% due to falling oil prices.

site_title: Tokyo tower sale surpasses 2007 peak prices: Credit Suisse
summary: Tokyo's commercial property prices have surpassed their 2007 peak, according to Credit Suisse. Mitsubishi Estate's 159 billion yen sale of a building in Marunouchi to Mizuho Financial Group is the latest example, with a price of 77.4 million yen per tsubo. This is higher than the price paid for an adjacent building in 2007. The sale comes as Tokyo's real estate prices have risen 20% since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office, driven by the weakening yen and foreign buyers seeking higher returns.

site_title: S'pore buyers close 16 M'sia property deals at expo
summary: Singapore investors closed 16 Malaysian property deals worth over S$3.31 million at the STProperty Seminar and Expo 2014, the highest number of deals in 2014. The transactions were valued at more than RM8.6 million.

site_title: Oil prices, Olam buying-in main features this week
summary: Oil prices and Olam buying-in were key features this week. The Straits Times Index (STI) jumped to 3,350 on Friday, bringing its year-to-date gain to 5.9%. The rally was driven by banks and Jardine group stocks, not laggards like Thai Beverage and oil and gas stocks as initially predicted. The STI's performance was largely unaffected by the week's other market news.

site_title: Bullish tone seen this week
summary: US stocks edged higher last week as oil prices plummeted, supporting a surge in holiday sales. The price drop, attributed to Opec's refusal to cut production, has reduced gasoline prices and is expected to boost consumer spending. Analysts forecast a 4.1% increase in holiday sales this year, with investors also looking to the traditionally strong December market performance, known as the "Santa Claus effect." The strong dollar may offset some of the benefits, but overall, the outlook for the holiday season remains positive.

images.alt_text: Every day last week, Walmart offered the kind of "door-buster" deals that were traditionally limited to the Friday after Thanksgiving and, more recently, to the whole Thanksgiving weekend.

site_title: Bank chiefs see mergers of Italian, German lenders
summary: Bank chiefs in Italy and Germany are predicting a wave of mergers among cooperative lenders, with Italy's Intesa Sanpaolo and Commerzbank identifying cooperative banks as likely merger candidates. Italy's banks have the largest combined capital shortfall in the euro region, and some cooperative banks in Germany would have failed stress tests under new Basel regulations. Italian cooperative banks may merge to boost returns, while German cooperative banks could merge to strengthen their positions in the market.

site_title: Sony Pictures hires Mandiant to help clean up after cyber attack
summary: Sony Pictures Entertainment has hired Mandiant's forensics unit to clean up a massive cyber attack that knocked out the studio's computer network last Monday. The attack, attributed to the Guardians of Peace group, displayed a red skull and "Hacked By #GOP" message. Technicians expect to restore email systems by Monday. The incident highlights the growing threat of cyber attacks on major entertainment companies.

site_title: S'pore, US agree on mutual customs fast-track clearance
summary: Singapore and the US have agreed on a mutual customs fast-track clearance system, allowing certified companies to expedite customs clearance of goods. Singapore exporters to the US and US exporters to Singapore will benefit from faster clearance. Both countries have also signed a mutual assistance agreement to exchange information and combat customs offences. The agreements are expected to benefit companies such as Advanced Micro Devices, which will be able to quickly clear time-sensitive shipments.

images.alt_text: Singapore Customs and the US Customs and Border Protection have agreed to fast-track clearance for certified companies from both countries, according to an official statement.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei hits fresh 7-year high on economic data, weak oil prices
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average reached a fresh 7-year high, closing at 17,573.91, driven by strong corporate spending and weak oil prices. The Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose, with the Nikkei up 0.7%, the Topix 0.9%, and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 0.9%. This marks the highest level since July 2007.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly up on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.09% higher on Monday, driven by a weaker yen following OPEC's decision not to cut production, which boosted dollar and euro values. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 17,475.10. A weaker yen is favorable for Japanese exporters, increasing profits when repatriated. This contrasts with a decline in energy-related stocks on Wall Street.

site_title: In fading Japan hinterland, sceptics doubt "Abenomics" will cure ills
summary: In Japan's rural prefecture of Akita, residents are skeptical about Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies, which critics say have mainly benefited big cities and large companies. Many young people, like Mihoko Asaka's 25-year-old son, have left rural areas to find work, contributing to a population decline. Abe's policies, including a hyper-easy monetary policy, have boosted share prices and exporter profits, but failed to address the region's economic woes. Asaka and others question whether the government is listening to their concerns and where the money goes.

images.alt_text: Akita's jobs-applicants ratio hit 0.93 in October, still way below Tokyo's 1.59 but a 22-year high for the prefecture.

site_title: Tough first year raises doubts Australian PM will last full term
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott's first year in office has been marred by missteps and a souring economy, leading to historic low approval ratings. His conservative government faces a collapse in commodity prices, a hostile Senate, and criticism over budget cuts, prompting speculation he may not survive to a second term. Despite some accomplishments, such as free trade deals, Labor has surged ahead, leading the government by 55-45% in a recent poll, and a cabinet reshuffle is likely, with Foreign Minister Julie Bishop seen as a possible leader.

site_title: Raffles Hospital to receive patients sent by SCDF ambulances by mid-2015
summary: Raffles Hospital will start receiving patients sent by Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) ambulances by mid-2015 for non-critical medical conditions. The hospital will provide inpatient care and specialist outpatient clinic follow-up services. This move aims to lighten patient loads at public hospitals, with the arrangement expected to benefit Singapore General Hospital, KK Women's and Children's Hospital, and Tan Tock Seng Hospital. The partnership builds on Raffles' track record of contributing to national healthcare needs and reflects the shift towards ambulatory care, enabling more procedures to be performed in outpatient settings.

site_title: Australia faces budget deficits as far as eye can see: Deloitte
summary: Australia is facing budget deficits "as far as the eye can see" due to plunging export commodity prices and weak wage growth, according to Deloitte Access Economics. The underlying cash deficit will be A$34.7 billion in the year through June 30, and is expected to increase to A$27.2 billion in the following year. The government's efforts to bring the budget under control have been blocked by opposition and independent lawmakers, and income-tax revenue is unlikely to meet projections due to high unemployment.

site_title: CosmoSteel ropes in Japan's Hanwa as a major shareholder
summary: CosmoSteel Holdings Limited, a piping system component supplier, has entered into a strategic alliance with Tokyo-listed Japanese steel trader Hanwa Co Ltd. Hanwa will acquire 26.4 million new shares at S$0.58 each, representing a 10% stake in CosmoSteel, and the CEO will sell 56.22 million shares. The partnership aims to create synergies and enhance marketing efforts. Hanwa will hold 28.45% of CosmoSteel's enlarged share capital, with two board seats. The investment is expected to boost CosmoSteel's financial position and position it for future growth.

site_title: Deadline passes with no Stats-JCET deal; exclusive talks to go on
summary: Exclusive talks between China's JCET and Singapore's Stats ChipPAC over a potential $780 million sale may continue until Dec 20 after no deal was reached by the original deadline. JCET, which has announced plans to make a US offer for the chip assembly and testing company, had until Nov 30 to negotiate terms. Stats ChipPAC, controlled by Singapore Technologies Semiconductors, has 84% ownership and no assurance that JCET's proposal will result in a definitive agreement or transaction.

site_title: Indonesia manufacturing contracts to record low: PMI
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing activity contracted to its weakest level since 2011, according to the HSBC Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) survey. The index fell to 48.0 in November, the lowest reading since 2011, due to weaker output and new orders. This marks the third contraction in four months, with companies cutting staff for the fourth straight month. A fuel price increase and weak external demand contributed to the record-low PMI reading, with conditions likely to remain soft in the coming months.

site_title: China's Xi strikes conciliatory note on foreign policy
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has struck a conciliatory note on foreign policy, calling for the resolution of disputes between nations through dialogue and consultation. In a major policy address, Xi advocated for a "new type of international relations" based on win-win cooperation, and emphasized the importance of peaceful resolution of differences. This marks a shift towards more diplomatic and less confrontational foreign policy tactics, as China seeks to address concerns about its growing economic influence.

site_title: Momo targets US$232m from IPO
summary: Momo Inc., a Chinese social messaging app, is raising up to $232 million in its US initial public offering. The company, which has 60.2 million monthly active users, plans to list on the Nasdaq Stock Market under the symbol MOMO. Momo generates most of its revenue through membership subscription fees, posting $26.2 million in net revenue in the nine months through September. The company is seeking $50 million from existing shareholder Alibaba Group and $10 million from 58.com. Momo is unprofitable, but plans a partnership with Alibaba to share marketing revenue.

site_title: Cutting it as a director
summary: A revised Code of Corporate Governance requires directors to receive regular training and disclose such training. However, many new directors lack adequate orientation and training for the role, often due to a lack of mandatory qualifications. To address this, the Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) has established a Continuing Professional Development (CPD) policy and curriculum, which requires directors to invest in structured training over a three-year period. This aims to ensure directors stay current with changing regulatory expectations and maintain their professional knowledge and skills, ultimately enhancing the quality of directors and directorship.

site_title: India eases gold import regulations to curb smuggling, remove distortions
summary: India has eased gold import regulations to curb smuggling and distortions in shipments. The Reserve Bank of India withdrew a rule requiring importers to sell 20% of shipments to jewellers for re-export as jewellery, effective immediately. This change aims to improve jewellers' stocks, lower costs, and help contain illegal trade. The move is expected to benefit the country, the world's second-largest gold user.

site_title: Kazakhstan, EU set for closer economic ties
summary: Kazakhstan and the EU have completed talks on a new extended Agreement on partnership and cooperation, paving the way for Kazakhstan's accession into the WTO. The agreement aims to simplify visa regimes and strengthen economic ties, with Kazakhstan and the EU accounting for 50% of each other's foreign trade and investment. The new agreement will replace the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in force since 1999, providing a stronger foundation for bilateral relations.

site_title: Crude prices slump as Opec targets US shale
summary: Crude oil prices plummeted to four-year lows after OPEC maintained its production ceiling of 30 million barrels per day, despite global oversupply. US shale energy was seen as a threat by some analysts, leading to a slump in oil prices to US$69.78 a barrel, with Brent oil falling to US$70.15 a barrel. The decline also affected other commodities, including gold, silver, and industrial metals, as investors liquidated portfolios amid economic concerns.

site_title: Hot stock: Ezion leads oil and gas plays lower as crude continues slide
summary: Ezion Holdings, a leading oil and gas charterer, led the decline in the sector on Monday, with its stock plummeting 11.7% amid ongoing crude price weakness. Other blue-chip stocks like Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine also fell, with the FTSE ST Oil and Gas index down 4.5%. The Straits Times Index was down 0.5%. The decline follows a recent slide in crude prices, affecting the oil and gas sector.

site_title: Smart investing in a post-QE world
summary:
The article discusses the post-Quantitative Easing (QE) world and the potential impact on global economies and investments. Key points include:

* The US Federal Reserve's QE program has reached its peak, while Japan's QE is still increasing and the eurozone remains in stagnation.
* Central banks' unconventional monetary policies have led to asset bubbles and increased volatility.
* Experts predict a potential shift in interest rates, with the US Federal Reserve expected to start raising rates, while the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan are likely to maintain or increase their QE programs.
* Investors are advised to consider safe havens, such as the US dollar, gold, and emerging markets, as they may benefit from increased capital flows and lower volatility.
* Some experts warn of an impending financial crisis and market crash, recommending a diversified investment strategy with a minimum of 10% gold allocation to mitigate potential losses.
* The ideal portfolio allocation may include 20% cash, 15% bonds, 15% stocks, 20% land, 10% fine arts, and 20% other funds, with adjustments made before a potential meltdown.

site_title: China home prices fall in November despite rate cut
summary: China's housing prices fell 0.38% in November, marking the seventh consecutive monthly decline. The average price of a new home in major cities dropped to 10,589 yuan per square meter, down 1.57% from the same month last year. Analysts expect the recent interest rate cut to have a positive impact on the market, with some predicting a bottoming out soon. However, high home inventory levels remain a concern, particularly in first-tier and major second-tier cities.

site_title: Taiwan cabinet resigns after massive polls defeat
summary: Taiwan's cabinet resigned en masse after the ruling Kuomintang party suffered a massive defeat in the island's biggest ever local elections. Premier Jiang Yi-huah quit hours after the result, and the 81-strong cabinet formally stepped down on Monday. The KMT lost five of Taiwan's six large municipalities, with the Democratic Progressive Party taking 47.5% of the votes cast. The KMT's Beijing-friendly stance has been a major factor in the party's decline, with growing public fears over increased Chinese influence.

images.alt_text: In the wake of Mr Jiang Yi-huah's resignation, Taiwan's 81-strong cabinet formally stepped down Monday morning.

site_title: Airbus sells part of Dassault back to planemaker
summary: Airbus Group sold 8% of Dassault Aviation back to the French planemaker in a 794 million euro deal, reducing its stake from 46.3% to 42.1%. This move is part of unwinding the 16-year-old link to its defense market rival. Dassault plans to cancel the shares, along with an additional 1% acquired in a separate buyback. The deal marks the first step towards resolving the awkward relationship between the two companies.

site_title: The bearded business leader is becoming more common
summary: Beards are making a comeback among business leaders, with prominent figures such as Google's Sergey Brin and Salesforce's Marc Benioff sporting facial hair. This trend is seen as a reversal of the 20th-century trend of clean-shaven executives, which was associated with a more corporate and faceless identity. Historically, beards have been a symbol of capitalism's vitality, and their resurgence may indicate a shift towards a more individualistic and entrepreneurial capitalism.

site_title: Macau's junket model breaks down as gamblers walk away
summary: Macau's junket model, which connects China's wealthy gamblers to casinos, is experiencing a significant breakdown due to a surge in bad debts as China's economic slowdown and corruption crackdown chase VIP gamblers away. Junket operators are waiting up to a year for repayments, leading to a significant increase in overdue balances. The industry's business model is considered "near-broken" as many gamblers are making monthly instalments rather than paying in full. This could force casino operators to rely on mass-market gamblers or extend VIP credit directly, a practice that has led to write-offs in other countries.

site_title: Coal shortage presents difficult choice for Ukraine
summary: Ukraine is facing a coal shortage, with 3 million tonnes needed for the winter season, due to Russia cutting off supplies to rebel-controlled eastern Ukraine. The country relies on coal for 40% of its power and has a surplus, but reserves are dwindling. Ukraine has three options: importing coal from abroad, buying electricity from Russia, or buying coal from the rebels, but each option is problematic, and time is running out, with shortages expected to start in mid-December and worsen in February.

images.alt_text: Without warning, Russia announced it was stopping coal supplies to Ukraine last week, claiming "force majeure" but offering no explanation.

site_title: Tesco gets flak for disorder at Black Friday sales
summary: Tesco faced criticism for its handling of Black Friday sales, with police attending incidents at seven stores in the Greater Manchester area and three in London due to large crowds. The company's website struggled to cope with high demand, resulting in error messages and delays. Three people were arrested, and a woman suffered a broken wrist. Tesco's chief constable criticized the company's lack of security staff, and the retailer vowed to learn from the experience. The company's online sales were five times higher than last year, with other retailers also experiencing technical difficulties.

images.alt_text: Police attended incidents at seven Tesco stores in the Greater Manchester area after large crowds built outside.

site_title: US property firms jump into Tel Aviv debt issues boom
summary: US real estate firms are capitalizing on low borrowing costs and high demand in Israel, issuing a record $14.6 billion in bonds through the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange's bond trading platform. Companies such as Extell Development Co and Zarasai Group have joined the boom, taking advantage of 0.12 percentage point cheaper borrowing costs compared to issuing bonds directly in dollars. This surge in issuance is driven by investors seeking higher-paying debt securities and institutional investors' thirst for investment, as the government's limited bond issuances and equity listings have led to a shift towards corporate debt.

site_title: Trade group sees tin deficit by 2015 due to rise in demand
summary: The global tin market is expected to fall into a deficit of 5,000 to 10,000 tonnes in 2015 due to increased demand, according to industry group ITRI. Benchmark three-month tin prices on the London Metal Exchange are forecast to average $22,000 per tonne in 2015, up from around $20,075 on Friday. The tin deficit is attributed to a healthy demand for electronics, which accounts for about half of global tin use, despite output from Myanmar and Indonesia. The tin price is expected to be well-supported due to potential Indonesian mine closures.

site_title: Uruguay ruling candidate Vazquez wins presidential vote: quick counts
summary: Uruguay's former leader Tabare Vazquez won the presidential election runoff vote, according to quick counts by polling groups Cifra and Factum. Vazquez secured 53.5-53.9% of the votes, while challenger Luis Lacalle Pou received 41.0-40.6%. The remaining ballots were blank or spoiled. Vazquez's victory marks a second term as president.

images.alt_text: Former leader Tabare Vazquez won Uruguay's presidential election runoff vote on Sunday, two unofficial quick counts by the Cifra and Factum polling groups showed.

site_title: PT Telkom unit clinches Jurong site in Singapore to build data centre hub
summary: PT Telekomunikasi Indonesia's subsidiary, Telin Singapore, has been awarded an 8,000-square-metre site in Singapore's Data Centre Park to build a data centre and telecommunication hub. The facility, expected to start supporting customers in 2016, will strengthen Telin Singapore's infrastructure to support PT Telkom Indonesia's growth and international network expansion. Construction is set to begin in 2015, with a 20,000 square metre purpose-built data centre facility.

site_title: Bricks-and-mortar spending edges lower in US
summary: US shoppers spent $12.29 billion at brick-and-mortar stores on Thanksgiving Day and Black Friday, a 0.5% decrease from 2013. Online sales surged to record highs, reaching $1.33 billion on Thanksgiving Day and $2.4 billion on Black Friday. Despite a decrease in in-store sales, the overall holiday season is expected to see a 3.8% increase in sales, with "Super Saturday" on Dec 20 expected to be the busiest shopping day.

images.alt_text: The data highlights the waning importance of Black Friday, which till recently kicked off the holiday shopping season, as more retailers open their doors on Thanksgiving Day and start discounting earlier.

site_title: Loyz chairman steps down, new deputy chairman named
summary: Loyz Energy chairman Vincent Lien Jown Jing is stepping down due to conflicting responsibilities, effective immediately. He has been replaced by former Premier Oil plc CEO Simon Charles Lockett, who becomes deputy chairman and independent director. Lien's departure follows recent initiatives to expand Loyz's reach and income streams. Lockett expressed confidence in Loyz's future milestones despite the challenging environment, with the company's stock trading at 12 Singapore cents.

site_title: Topping the news in 2014
summary: The most significant news event of 2014 is not listed, but the top news in 2014 is not provided in the article. However, key events mentioned include the US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, Chinese property shares surging, and China unveiling steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: PwC urges SME boosts, innovation in 2015 budget
summary: PwC is urging the Singapore government to include measures in the 2015 budget to boost small and medium enterprises (SMEs), encourage innovation, and address social needs. Proposed measures include reducing burdens on SMEs, easing intellectual property risks, and increasing productivity. PwC also advocates for incentives for overseas training, hiring foreign talent, and alternative pension schemes. The firm suggests removing time limits on incentives for equity investments and expanding tax incentives for real estate investment trusts and asset management businesses.

site_title: Astana to host world religious leaders conference
summary: Kazakhstan's capital Astana will host the 5th Congress of Leaders of World and Traditional Religions from June 10-11, 2015, with the theme "Dialogue of Religious Leaders and Politicians in the Name of Peace and Development". The congress aims to promote dialogue, mutual understanding, and respect among different cultures and beliefs, and to prevent conflicts, intolerance, and radicalism. Representatives from over 140 ethnic and 40 religious groups are expected to attend the event, which is seen as an opportunity for international cooperation and peacekeeping.

site_title: Hong Kong police clash with protesters outside government HQ
summary: Hong Kong police clashed with pro-democracy protesters outside the government headquarters, with officers firing pepper spray at demonstrators trying to surround the building. Hundreds of protesters, wearing helmets and umbrellas, were met with batons and pepper spray, with several injured. The clashes marked a fresh escalation of tensions in a two-month-old protest movement demanding free leadership elections. China's communist authorities insist on vetting candidates, which protesters see as ensuring a pro-Beijing result. Police made 40 arrests overnight, and a police spokesman said the road was "illegally occupied."

site_title: Opec move puts US shale in tight spot
summary: Opec's decision to maintain production levels has sent US oil prices plummeting to a 9-year low, with prices falling over $7 to $66.15 per barrel. The cartel's move is seen as a strategic response to the US shale boom, which has put Opec on the defensive. Analysts predict that US oil producers will cut back production, with some companies expected to reduce their rigs by 200-300 in the coming weeks. Despite the challenge, US industry officials believe the industry will emerge stronger, with improved technology and lower production costs.

site_title: Obamas shop to honour small businesses
summary: US President Barack Obama and his daughters, Malia and Sasha, shopped at Politics and Prose bookstore in Washington on Thanksgiving weekend, honouring Small Business Saturday. The family bought 17 books, including several for children, and engaged with customers. Obama discussed policy topics, including the Guantánamo Bay detention facility, and joked with cashiers. The outing marked a tradition for the first family to support local businesses, in contrast to corporate retailers' push for big spending on Black Friday and Cyber Monday.

site_title: UG Healthcare eyes emerging markets
summary: Malaysia-based UG Healthcare, a maker of latex and nitrile gloves, expects sales from emerging markets such as China, Brazil, and Nigeria to increase over the next few years due to rising demand for medical supplies. The company's revenues from these markets currently account for a small percentage of its total revenues, but are expected to grow as medical glove usage per capita in these markets is relatively low. UG Healthcare plans to expand its production capacity and distribution reach to meet the increasing demand, but faces risks such as regulatory changes, corruption, and poor infrastructure in these markets.

site_title: President's key role in development
summary: Kazakhstan marks its Day of the First President on Dec 1, honoring the country's first and only president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, who won the 1991 presidential election with 98.8% of the votes. The day was established in 2011 to commemorate the 20th anniversary of Kazakhstan's independence. Nazarbayev's leadership has been credited with laying the foundations for the country's growth into a mature state and active member of the international community, providing stability in uncertain times.

site_title: FB change makes it hard for campaigns
summary: Facebook is changing its policy to limit automatic access to users' friends for political campaigns, starting in May. Users will need to explicitly authorize access to their friends, and campaigns will only see those friends who have also signed into the campaign's app. This change aims to reduce unwanted messages and provide more control over user data, but it may also lead to more campaigns advertising on the platform. The move is seen as a step towards more sophisticated tools for advertisers, which may require campaigns to spend more money on advertising.

site_title: Iran calls the shots as foreign carmakers make re-entry
summary: Foreign carmakers, including Mercedes Benz, Volkswagen, Renault, and Toyota, will attend the Iran Auto Show, seeking to tap into the country's vast 77 million population. To attract investment, the Industry Ministry requires 40% of production to be done in Iran, rising to 85% after five years. Iran Khodro, the country's largest carmaker, plans to return to its 2011 production level of 600,000 cars, but with tougher conditions for former joint venture partners, including a 50-50 joint venture ratio. A full nuclear deal is necessary for the car sector to experience a major boost.

images.alt_text: As prospects of better times for the car industry grow, this week's Iran Auto Show may draw global suitors to Teheran.

site_title: Fresh strikes imminent at Lufthansa, warns pilots' union
summary: Lufthansa's pilots' union warned that fresh strikes are imminent due to the airline's refusal to accept a request to allow pilots to retire at 55. Despite a 5% pay rise, the union claims Lufthansa's management has not compromised on demands. The dispute has resulted in repeated strikes this year, affecting thousands of passengers and costing the airline 160 million euros in operating profit. The strikes come amidst increased competition and a stuttering global economy, with passenger transport in Germany also disrupted by train drivers' strikes.

site_title: Cameron's help for first-time UK homebuyers fizzles on demand
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron's expanded Help to Buy home-loan programme failed to boost first-time home ownership, with the number of users falling to almost 3,400 in September from over 4,000 in May. Despite initial optimism, the programme's goal of increasing demand for new homes has not materialized, and property prices have risen faster than earnings, making homes less affordable. The programme's effectiveness in boosting construction is seen as its only success, with 14,000 new homes registered in October.

site_title: Stocks to watch: P99, STATS ChipPAC
summary: P99 Holdings, a Singapore cafe business, has deconsolidated its core business and is now a cash company with approximately 52.04 million yuan in cash and bank balances. STATS ChipPAC will continue negotiations for a potential sale, with a deadline extension to Dec 20. Trading halts have been issued for CosmoSteel Holdings, Jason Holdings, and Memstar Technology pending announcements, amid ongoing disputes and corruption probes.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit buys Fukuoka nursing home for 3.5b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit acquired a nursing home property in Fukuoka, Japan for 3.5 billion yen (S$38.5 million). The property has a 20-year lease term and 92% operational occupancy. Parkway Life will fund the acquisition with a 5-year term loan facility, increasing gearing to 35.1%. The purchase is part of the Reit's efforts to strengthen its stable, defensive foundation in the Japan healthcare sector, according to CEO Yong Yean Chau.

site_title: Singapore to adopt Euro VI emission standards from Sept 1, 2017
summary: Singapore will adopt Euro VI emission standards for petrol vehicles from September 1, 2017, to improve air quality. The stricter standard aims to reduce nitrogen oxides and fine particulate emissions. The National Environment Agency has given the automotive industry sufficient lead time to develop Euro VI compliant vehicles. Petrol vehicles using Port Fuel Injection technology that meet Japanese emission standards (JPN 2009) will be accepted as equivalent to Euro VI standards. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to enhance vehicular emission standards and provide consumers with a range of Euro VI compliant models.

site_title: China's official PMI slips to 50.3 in November, below forecast
summary: China's factory sector growth slowed in November, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 50.3 from 50.8 in October, below forecast. This marks the sector's second consecutive month of contraction. The move underlines the challenges facing China's economy, which is struggling with rising costs, softening demand, and a cooling economy. China's economy grew 7.3% in the third quarter, its slowest pace since the global financial crisis, and risks missing its annual target for the first time in 15 years.

site_title: P&G exploring sale of US$7b Wella hair care unit: sources
summary: Procter & Gamble Co is exploring the sale of its US$7 billion Wella hair care unit, working with Goldman Sachs to consider a potential sale. The company is reviewing all options, including selling the whole or parts of the business. No final decision has been made, and P&G declined to comment. The sale could streamline the company's portfolio and follow a trend of companies looking to divest underperforming assets.

site_title: Slowing inflation paves way for more ECB action: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to consider further monetary easing due to slowing eurozone inflation, which fell to 0.3% in November. Analysts believe the ECB will likely unveil asset purchase programs to pump liquidity into the financial system, potentially leading to quantitative easing. Despite ECB chief Mario Draghi's vow to "step up the pressure," the timing of such action is uncertain, with some council members preferring to wait before considering new stimulus measures.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 2.05 points to 3,352.55. Volume was 84.9 million shares worth S$91.7 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 60.

site_title: Disadvantaged youths get a new arts home
summary: A new arts space, 10 Square @ Orchard Central, has been opened to provide arts training to hundreds of disadvantaged youths in Singapore. Funded by The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and Far East Organization, the 13,000 sq ft space features a theatre auditorium, music and visual arts studios, and a service-training cafe. The space offers free arts training and business fundamentals to youths aged 13-19, with a goal of levelling the playing field in the arts. The initiative aims to champion the arts for the less privileged and promote arts education in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ms Low (with fund beneficiaries) commended the founders of BTBAF in her speech last Saturday for "having the vision to champion the arts for the less privileged and levelling the playing field in the arts".

site_title: Greece considers accepting IMF role in next EU aid deal
summary: Greece is considering accepting a full role for the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in its next aid deal with European Union (EU) authorities, a blow to Prime Minister Antonis Samaras' push for a clean exit. Greece is under pressure to accept further aid and monitoring to ensure a stable transition once its bailout regime concludes at the end of the year. Euro-area finance ministers are set to discuss a credit line of up to 11 billion euros, with IMF participation potentially required for such a line.

site_title: Australia opens door to nuclear energy
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott has opened the door to the use of nuclear energy, citing growing pressure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Despite Australia's abundance of coal and natural gas reserves, Abbott acknowledged nuclear power as a proven, emissions-free option for generating base load power. He expressed openness to nuclear energy, stating that it must be part of Australia's energy future, but warned against government subsidies. This move comes after the US and China announced a climate change deal, shifting global attention to reducing emissions.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Tony Abbott on Monday opened the door to the use of nuclear energy as Australia faces growing pressure to bring down its greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Asian strategy bearing fruit: BTMU
summary: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (BTMU) has reported a 9% increase in net operating profit for the first half of 2014, driven by its overseas strategy and push into Asia. The bank's Asia & Oceania CEO, Go Watanabe, attributes the growth to its extensive business outside Japan. BTMU's overseas loans reached 22.5 trillion yen, surpassing its rivals. The bank plans to increase high-margin fee income from transaction banking services and attract multinational corporations. BTMU's expansion in Asia, particularly in Thailand, aims to capture the business of multinational corporations operating in the country.

site_title: German pilots union says fresh strikes imminent at Lufthansa
summary: The German pilots union VC announced that talks with Lufthansa over early retirement benefits have broken down, leading to possible new strikes at Lufthansa, Lufthansa Cargo, and Germanwings. The dispute, which has resulted in repeated strikes this year, has affected thousands of passengers and resulted in significant losses for the airline, including a 160 million euro loss in operating profit. The union claims Lufthansa's management has not compromised on their demands, and new strikes are expected at any time. This follows a pattern of strikes in Germany, including train drivers' walkouts.

site_title: Dollar continues rise, euro extends losing streak
summary: The US dollar advanced for a fifth consecutive month, rising 5.6% to 118.63 yen, its highest level in seven years. The euro slid 0.6% to US$1.2452, extending its losing streak to 5.6% against the dollar since April 2013. Other currencies, such as the yen, euro, and Chinese yuan, also declined against the dollar. The dollar's rise was driven by the US's potential interest-rate increase and the need for policymakers in Japan, the eurozone, and China to implement further stimulus to support growth.

site_title: S-Reits' performance recovers on expected rate hike delay
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) have recovered this year due to market confidence that interest rate hikes will occur later than expected. The FTSE ST Reit Index rose 9% year-to-date, outperforming the Straits Times Index. While Reits' debt exposure is largely hedged, higher interest rates may lead to lower valuations and decreased unit prices due to increased discount rates in property valuations. Analysts estimate that Reits' distribution per unit (DPU) risks are contained, with a potential 10% decline for every percentage point increase in interest rates.

site_title: China policy in question after KMT's huge poll loss
summary: Taiwan's Beijing-friendly ruling party, the Kuomintang (KMT), suffered its worst-ever poll defeat in local elections, with 40.7% of the ballots cast. The loss may force the KMT to re-examine its China policy and could encourage the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to take a more anti-Beijing stance. China has called for continued efforts for peaceful cross-strait relations, while Taiwan's public anxiety about the closer relationship with China remains high, with many fearing Taiwan will have to do as Beijing orders in the future.

site_title: ECB's Lautenschlaeger rebuffs QE as German opposition grows
summary: ECB executive board member Sabine Lautenschlaeger has expressed opposition to quantitative easing, citing concerns over the policy's costs and benefits. Her comments signal a growing divide among officials, echoing those of Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann, who believes QE diverts attention from structural economic adjustments. Lautenschlaeger argues that the ECB's purchase of government securities is linked to an incentive problem, and that long-term interest rates are already low in the euro area, making further rate cuts questionable. The comments come ahead of the ECB's Governing Council meeting on Dec 4.

site_title: Buy activity falls and selling remains low
summary: Buy activity fell for the fourth straight week in Singapore, with only 16 companies recording purchases worth S$3.68 million, down from 22 companies the previous week. Selling activity remained low, with only two companies disposing of shares worth S$1.69 million. Several companies, including Marco Polo Marine, Jubilee Industries, and ISDN Holdings, resumed buying back shares following sharp drops in their share prices. Meanwhile, substantial shareholder Tan Thiam Chye sold 8 million shares in ISDN Holdings, reducing his holdings by 22%.

site_title: China launches draft rules for insurance of bank deposits
summary: China has issued draft regulations for a bank deposit insurance system, covering up to 500,000 yuan (S$106,000) of deposits for 99.63% of depositers. The system aims to protect depositors and maintain public confidence in the financial markets. Foreign bank branches and Chinese banks' overseas branches will not be covered. The deposit insurance fund will be administered by the central bank and can invest in government bonds and highly-rated financial bonds. The regulations are part of China's efforts to liberalize lending rates and deepen economic reforms.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Land, Lian Beng Group, and Giken Sakata are analyzed by brokers for potential investment opportunities. Keppel Land's subsidiary is set to subscribe to Keppel DC Reit units at a 4.9% stake, while Lian Beng Group's strong property sales and recurring income are expected to drive earnings expansion. Giken Sakata has transformed into an onshore oil field play after acquiring Indonesian assets and is valued at US$191 million, equating to S$0.51 per share.

site_title: Swiss vote on capping immigration 'to save environment'
summary: Swiss voters are set to decide on a referendum to cap immigration growth, aiming to reduce the country's population by 1.4% annually and limit it to 8.5 million by mid-century. The initiative, known as Ecopop, has gained momentum but is expected to fail due to strong opposition from the government, employers, and unions. The decision is seen as potentially xenophobic and economically disastrous, with supporters arguing that the influx of foreigners is crowding the country's landscapes and shrinking its green spaces.

site_title: Sarkozy tipped to lead party in new charge for French presidency
summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's former president, is expected to win the leadership of his right-wing UMP party, a potential step towards his return to the presidency in 2017. Sarkozy has criss-crossed the country to drum up support, slamming the "mediocrity" of the current Socialist government. Despite facing legal woes, pollsters expect him to win the election. A victory would not guarantee him a shot at toppling President Francois Hollande, but could set him up for a 2017 presidential bid against far-right leader Marine Le Pen.

site_title: Greek youth boldly begin their startup odyssey
summary: Greece's youth are turning to innovation and foreign funding to create startups amidst the country's economic crisis. With one in two youths under 25 out of work, many are seeking alternative paths, such as designing "vertical" gardens, taxi-tracking tools, and hiring aids. Innovation incubators like Egg and Openfund are supporting budding entrepreneurs, with EU funds and venture capital backing their ventures. The sector has grown exponentially, with the number of startups increasing nearly tenfold and investment rising from 500,000 euros to 42 million euros over the past four years.

site_title: Understanding property indices
summary: Singapore's residential property market is subject to conflicting price signals from different indices due to varying methodologies and data sets. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) uses a stratification approach, while the Singapore Real Estate Exchange (SRX) employs a hedonic regression method. The NUS Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) uses a hybrid model combining hedonic regression with a fixed basket of properties. Despite the availability of multiple indices, users must understand their limitations and interpret them correctly to make informed decisions. Policymakers and investors rely on property price movements as an indicator of macroeconomic activity and financial system risks, but the complexity of the market and data collection challenges necessitate a nuanced approach to analyzing these indices.

site_title: Taiwan begins vote testing confidence in China-friendly ruling party
summary: Taiwan began voting in a local election on November 29, 2014, which could show waning support for the China-friendly Kuomintang (KMT) party. The election, held two years before a presidential election, saw a record 11,130 seats up for grabs. Opinion polls showed the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) slightly ahead in key battlegrounds, with confidence in the ruling party worn away by anti-China protests and economic issues. The election's results are expected to be announced on Saturday.

site_title: Brazil exits recession with Q3 growth of 0.1%
summary: Brazil's economy exited recession with a 0.1% growth in the third quarter, according to the government. This tepid result is welcomed news for President Dilma Rousseff, who has battled to reignite growth. The industrial sector posted a 1.7% growth, while the services sector started to expand again. However, GDP was still down 0.2% compared to the same period last year. The new economic team, led by market-friendly finance minister Joaquim Levy, aims to put the fiscal house in order and tackle inflation.

site_title: Quality reigns at G-One
summary: G-One, the rebranded restaurant from former kaiseki restaurant Goto, offers high-quality food at more affordable prices. Chef-owner Hisao Goto has scaled down his pricing while maintaining his emphasis on quality and execution. The new menu features a range of dishes, including a $22 chicken karaage set lunch, a $40 seasonal snow crab, and an $8 panna cotta-like custard pudding. The restaurant also offers a $48 sashimi platter for two, which is considered excellent value. With a more casual atmosphere, G-One is now accessible to a wider range of customers, making it a good option for those looking for quality food without breaking the bank.

site_title: Towards greater economic integration
summary: Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev emphasized the importance of promoting financial and economic cooperation through enhanced Europe-Asia connectivity during his address at the 10th Asem Summit in Milan. He highlighted the need to overcome protectionist barriers, increase bilateral trade, and develop an effective model for regulating international capital flows. Nazarbayev also stressed the importance of strengthening transport and transit infrastructure, including the revival of the Silk Road, and access to modern technology and energy resources. Kazakhstan aims to integrate with the global economy through its participation in the Asem forum and the Eurasian Economic Union.

images.alt_text: A statue of Mr Nazarbayev stands in Astana. Mr Nazarbayev has stressed the need to develop new financial bridges.

site_title: Venezuela to slash budget after Opec steadies output
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro ordered a budget cut to address economic woes, with a focus on reducing salaries for senior officials. The country's oil-dependent economy is hit by a third decline in crude prices, which has reduced government revenue. Maduro aims to "deepen economic and financing agreements" with China to cover the revenue shortfall. Opec's decision to maintain output at 30 million barrels per day has sent oil prices plummeting, with US$66.15 per barrel for January delivery, the lowest since September 2009. Maduro believes oil prices should not be lower than $100.

images.alt_text: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro ordered his government on Friday to slash the budget of his oil-dependent and economically-weak nation, as crude prices plunge after Opec held output steady.

site_title: MH17 remains arrive in Netherlands from Ukraine
summary: The remains of six victims from Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which was shot down over Ukraine in July 2014, have arrived in the Netherlands from Ukraine. The victims are part of a total of 298 people killed, with nine still unidentified. The remains were transported by Dutch Air Force C-130 plane to a forensic research facility in Hilversum for identification. The Dutch-led probe team has identified 289 victims, and the wreckage is set to be transported to the Netherlands for further investigation. Recovery work at the crash site is expected to resume in March.

site_title: Cash-rich marine fuel traders to gain from OW's fall
summary: Singapore's marine fuel market is shifting towards cash-rich trading companies and barge operators as a result of OW Bunker's collapse. Marine fuel premiums remain elevated, with buyers locking in prompt supplies. Companies like World Fuel Services, Sentek Marine and Trading, and Searights Maritime Services are expected to expand their market share, benefiting from OW's gap. These companies, which have deep pockets or fleets of barges, can pay cash upfront for purchases, giving them an advantage in the market. OW's collapse has led to a rise in sales for Sentek, Transocean, and Searights, but exact volume increases are difficult to quantify.

site_title: Black Friday gets holiday shopping season in high gear
summary: Black Friday kicked off the US holiday shopping season with early sales and high consumer confidence, driven by lower gasoline prices and a strong economy. Retailers like Walmart, Target, and Macy's opened their doors early, with millions of customers flooding in. Online sales also surged, with Best Buy and other retailers experiencing technical issues. Forecasters predict a 4.2% increase in holiday retail sales this year, up from 3.1% in 2012 and 2013, and a shift towards more exclusive offerings and a "wait-and-see" mentality among consumers.

site_title: Verdict due in murder retrial of Egypt's Mubarak
summary: An Egyptian court is set to deliver a verdict in the murder retrial of former president Hosni Mubarak, accused of involvement in the killing of hundreds of demonstrators during the 2011 uprising. Mubarak, 86, faces charges alongside seven police commanders. The verdict comes after an appeals court overturned his initial life sentence in 2012. If acquitted, he will remain in prison serving a separate corruption sentence. The trial marks a significant milestone in Egypt's transition from Mubarak's rule, with the country's revolutionary fervor largely subsiding.

site_title: BlackBerry gets OK to buy encryptors of Merkel's mobile
summary: Germany has approved BlackBerry's purchase of Secusmart, a data encryption firm that provides secure communications for Chancellor Angela Merkel's mobile phone. The deal was finalized after a "no-spy clause" was agreed upon, ensuring German security officials have access to source codes and no confidential information is passed to foreign intelligence services. The clause was negotiated to alleviate concerns over Germany's security interests following the NSA's revelation of tapping Merkel's mobile phone last year.

site_title: China deposit insurance seen putting small banks at risk
summary: China's planned deposit insurance program may exacerbate liquidity shortages at smaller banks, increasing their risk of failure as savings shift to larger state-controlled lenders. The program aims to limit systemic risks but could fuel competition for deposits, driving up borrowing costs. Smaller banks may struggle to compete with stronger banks offering higher interest rates, potentially leading to a shift of large deposits away from them. The government may cap coverage at 500,000 yuan and set premium levels based on a bank's regulatory rating.

site_title: Britain's power network gets £17b investment jolt
summary: Britain's electricity network is set to receive £17 billion in investment over eight years, with the goal of improving reliability and connecting small-scale renewable power generation. The investment will be spread across five of the "big six" electricity suppliers, with the total cost reaching £24 billion. The regulator, Ofgem, expects the investment to lead to reduced pressure on bills, with the electricity distribution part of customers' bills expected to fall by £11 over the next eight years. Compensation for power failures will also be increased.

site_title: Swiss reject tighter immigration limit, projections show
summary: Swiss voters rejected a referendum to introduce strict immigration quotas, known as Ecopop, by 74% to 26%. The measure, which would have limited annual immigration to 0.2% of the permanent resident population, was deemed xenophobic and ineffective by opponents, including the government and major political parties. The initiative's rejection is seen as a blow to economic growth, as immigration has been a key support for the country's economy. The vote is also significant, as it follows a similar "Mass Immigration" initiative that was rejected in February, and comes as other countries, such as the US and UK, grapple with similar immigration debates.

site_title: Combo outings
summary: Two new establishments in Singapore offer unique dining experiences. The Refinery, a concept restaurant-bar-craft workshop, combines food, drink, and creative activities, while Cloud, a rooftop cafe-cocktail bar, provides a space for good food and socializing. The Refinery, opened on December 5, features a grill restaurant with locally-sourced ingredients and a bar serving classic cocktails. Cloud, opened in August, offers a bistro-style menu during the day and transforms into an ultra-lounge at night, complete with portable chargers and free Wi-Fi.

site_title: Country Garden treading cautiously
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese developer, is cautiously expanding its presence in Singapore's residential market due to headwinds and high stamp duties. The company is focusing on providing "lifestyle" homes and is studying sites in Singapore's city fringes and Indonesia. Despite launching a sales gallery in Singapore, sales are about 40% lower than last year, but the group estimates that first buyers are sitting on capital gains of 10-15%. Country Garden has also faced rumors of a buy-one-get-one-free offer to mainland Chinese buyers, which the company denies as illegal and impractical.

site_title: Plan proposed to counter EU 'stagnation'
summary: French and German economists propose reforms to counter Europe's "stagnation trap". They suggest a trade-off between shaking up France's rigid labour market and boosting German infrastructure investment. However, Germany's economy minister, Sigmar Gabriel, rejected the proposal for a 24 billion euro investment boost, citing a lack of private investment. Both countries' ministers agreed to explore national contributions to the European Commission's 300 billion euro investment plan. The economists also proposed reforms to repair the EU's broken emissions trading system and create incentives for renewable energy investments.

site_title: The trick to being more virtuous
summary: A study on "moral elevation" found that exposure to others' kindness and generosity can increase a person's virtuous behavior. The author recounts how carrying a Brigham Young University briefcase made him act more cheerfully and helpfully. Researchers have also found that watching uplifting content, such as gratitude clips, can elicit a similar response. The article concludes that actively seeking good influences and rejecting negativity is crucial for personal and national improvement, particularly in a polarized political environment where poison and bitterness are increasingly prevalent.

site_title: MAS raps HSBC for breaching Financial Advisers Act
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reprimanded the HSBC Singapore branch for breaching the Financial Advisers Act by allowing unappointed representatives to provide financial advisory services. The breach occurred between 2012 and 2013, and the MAS expects financial institutions to ensure individuals do not provide services on their behalf unless they are appointed or provisional representatives. This is the second reprimand this month, following a similar breach by finexis advisory Pte Ltd.

site_title: Evolve, One FC ready to pump more money into MMA
summary: Evolve MMA and One Fighting Championship (One FC) founder Chatri Sityodtong plans to invest an additional S$50-100 million into the mixed martial arts (MMA) scene in Singapore, expanding the sport across Asia. Evolve will open at least two more academies in Singapore and plans to establish 100 academies in Asia, with Singapore as the group's headquarters. One FC plans to hold a major fight event at the National Stadium in 2015 as part of Singapore's 50th anniversary celebrations.

site_title: US: Stocks gain despite oil stocks' free fall
summary: US stocks closed higher for the week, despite a sharp decline in oil stocks, as investors welcomed a lack of action from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and expectations of lower fuel costs. The Dow and S&P 500 rose modestly, while the Nasdaq Composite Index surged. Petroleum stocks fell, with ExxonMobil and Chevron down 4.5% and 5.5%, respectively. Airlines and retailers gained, with holiday sales predicted to rise 4.1% this year, driven by lower gasoline prices and a boost to consumers' disposable income.

images.alt_text: A free fall in petroleum stocks was the most striking element of an otherwise lackluster week on Wall Street.

site_title: Cutting-edge wins
