This move signals Europe's concern with the growing power of US tech giants. Google has been in the EU's regulatory sights since 2010, facing issues with privacy, copyright, tax controversies, and requests to scrub search results. The resolution is the strongest public signal yet of Europe's concerns.

images.alt_text: European Union lawmakers overwhelmingly backed a motion on Thursday urging anti-trust regulators to break up Google, the latest setback for the world's most popular Internet search engine.

site_title: China's strategic oil reserves seen at 30 days, double official figure
summary: China's strategic oil reserves have been estimated to be nearly 30 days of crude stocks, double the official figure, according to industry and consulting sources. The country aims to reach 90 days of cover in the next few years, equivalent to the target reserves for major oil importers like the US. China's strategic petroleum reserves (SPR) have been built up over the years, with the country having already stockpiled 170 million barrels, and plans to further increase its capacity to around 600 million barrels.

site_title: Selfie sticks could bring jail time in South Korea
summary: South Korea plans to regulate the sale of selfie sticks with Bluetooth technology, which are deemed as communications equipment due to their use of radio waves. Unregistered versions could face a US$27,000 fine or up to three years in prison. The crackdown is largely driven by a technicality, as the weak signals emitted by Bluetooth devices are unlikely to cause disruptions. The Science Ministry aims to test and certify these devices to ensure they do not interfere with other devices using the same radio frequency.

site_title: City Buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Peter Kuruvita's "Seafood from the Heart" seafood buffet is now available at W Singapore - Sentosa Cove, featuring ocean-friendly seafood options and live cooking stations showcasing Asian-inspired dishes. The event runs every Friday and Saturday until November 2015. A food pop-up festival, "Makan Makan at the Sultan," will be held on December 6, featuring a dozen food vendors and raising awareness for charities in Singapore. The 4th Rendezvous with French Cinema film festival is also underway, showcasing 16 contemporary French films, including the critically acclaimed "Clouds of Sils Maria."

site_title: PSA chairman conferred Belgian national honour
summary: PSA International chairman Fock Siew Wah was conferred the Belgian national distinction "Commander of the Order of the Crown" by King Philippe for his merit, dedication, and services to Belgium. The award was presented during a ceremony in Singapore, where Fock has also served as CEO of PSA International since 2005. The recognition is a testament to PSA's significant investments in Belgian ports, including the Antwerp and Zeebrugge terminals, which handled 8 million containers last year. Fock expressed gratitude and deep feelings for the honor, acknowledging the hard work and dedication of PSA's people worldwide.

site_title: Japanese investors in biggest buying spree of Asian stocks, bonds
summary: Japanese investors poured a record 1.82 trillion yen (S$20.1 billion) into Asian stocks and bonds in the first nine months of 2014, a 76% increase from the previous record in 2007. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies have made the yen a lucrative investment vehicle, with borrowing in yen returning an annualized 13% this year. This influx of funds has boosted Asian markets, providing a buffer against potential outflows as the US prepares to raise borrowing costs next year.

site_title: Oil price slide to boost profits at S'pore crackers
summary: Borouge, a joint venture between Adnoc and Borealis, sees a boost in profitability due to falling oil prices, which in turn has reduced the cost of naphtha, a key feedstock for its petrochemical crackers in Singapore. However, if oil prices rise, it would put pressure on these crackers. The company has expanded its production capacity and storage facilities in Singapore to cater to increased demand, and expects the polyolefin market in South-east Asia to grow to 14.2 million tonnes by 2020.

site_title: HK's Pang tries and nails crossover comedy
summary: Hong Kong director Pang Ho-cheung's latest film, Women Who Flirt, is a crowd-pleasing crossover comedy that pokes fun at gender stereotypes. Starring Zhou Xun and Huang Xiao-ming, the film follows a couple's journey as they navigate love and relationships. Pang's satirical sense of humor shines through, with great performances from the lead actors. Although the plot is predictable, the film's lighthearted tone and comedic moments make it an enjoyable watch, showcasing Hong Kong's ability to produce films that cater to both domestic and international audiences.

site_title: Singapore, Brunei sign civil aviation MOU
summary: Singapore and Brunei have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Civil Aviation Cooperation, aiming to enhance collaboration in areas such as safety, security, and training. The agreement was signed by Brunei's Minister for Communications and Singapore's Minister for Transport at the 20th Asean Transport Ministers' Meeting in Mandalay, Myanmar. The MOU seeks to address common challenges and build on shared aviation interests, with the two countries expected to jointly address challenges and opportunities in the aviation arena.

site_title: Post-meeting, Opec has to adjust to a new future
summary: Opec, the 12-nation oil cartel, faces a diminishing influence on global oil prices and production. Its share of total global oil production has decreased from 50% in the 1970s to 43.4% in 2013, largely due to the US shale revolution and economic slowdowns in the eurozone and China. Opec members must adjust to a future where oil prices may fall below $100 a barrel, posing a threat to their economies. The cartel's inability to cooperate on production and manage diverse cost structures may lead to its own demise.

site_title: Finding the swing in a year of highs and lows
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, Singapore's hardest-working jazz musician, releases his first Christmas album in over two decades, "Christmas In Our Hearts." The album features jazz reinterpretations of Christmas carols and hymns, including an original composition "Let's Keep Christmas In Our Hearts," written by Monteiro and Rani Singam. The album marks a high point in Monteiro's career, with his senior management at Universal Music praising the song's timeless quality. The release comes during a bittersweet year for Monteiro, who lost his mother earlier in the year, and will be celebrated with a special concert at the Esplanade Concert Hall.

site_title: PBOC loosens monetary policy further as it scraps repo sales
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, has loosened monetary policy further by not conducting any open-market operations, a move seen as a sign of further interest rate cuts. The seven-day repurchase rate fell 10 basis points to 3.22%, while the overnight loan rate on the Shanghai Stock Exchange dropped 15.38 percentage points to 2.24%. The move comes amid a slowdown in the economy, with industrial profits falling by 2.1% in October, the biggest decline since August 2012. Experts predict further rate cuts and a potential reduction in banks' reserve requirements in 2015.

site_title: Keong Hong posts 10.1% fall in FY14 profit
summary: Keong Hong Holdings, a Singapore-based building construction group, reported a 10.1% drop in FY14 net profit to S$19.7 million, despite an 86.1% increase in revenue to S$272.9 million. The decline was attributed to higher cost of sales and wages, but the company expressed satisfaction with its financial performance. Keong Hong will pay a one-tier tax-exempt final dividend of 1.25 cents per share, bringing the full-year payout to 2.25 cents per share.

site_title: Online grocers in India ringing up good business
summary: India's online grocery market is booming, with e-tailers like Bigbasket.com and Localbanya.com turning in profits as they benefit from low overheads and high margins. The companies store goods in warehouses outside cities, where rents are high, and charge more for certain items than traditional supermarkets. This has helped Bigbasket.com become profitable just three years after its launch, while supermarkets struggle to attract customers. Analysts estimate online sales of fresh produce in China could quadruple in five years, fueled by better web access and an expanding middle class.

images.alt_text: Put off by snarled city traffic and a shortage of parking, more Indians are shopping for groceries online, helping e-tailers like Bigbasket.com and Localbanya.com turn in profits while supermarkets are struggling.

site_title: Mermaid rides on shallow water fields
summary: Mermaid Maritime's net profit for FY2014 trebled to US$45.2 million, driven by strong demand for its services and associate company Asia Offshore Drilling Limited's significant contribution. Despite oil price declines, the company's CEO attributes the performance to the resilience of its shallow-water fields and lower break-even points. The company's order book and revenue grew, with a 15.9% increase in subsea service income and 16.1% rise in group revenue. Mermaid's new-builds are currently under construction, expected to join the fleet in 2016, creating room for further earnings growth.

site_title: UOL's OneKM mall opens officially this Sunday
summary: UOL Group's OneKM mall is set to open officially this Sunday, with over 70% of shops already open. The mall has garnered 93% pre-commitment lease, marking the largest shopping mall in Paya Lebar. Despite retailers facing challenges, the mall's early success is seen as a positive sign.

site_title: To contain Ebola, train caregivers first
summary: A global plan is needed to prepare caregivers for highly contagious diseases like Ebola, which can be easily transmitted through contact with infected patients. The US has 2.5 physicians and 9.8 nurses per 1,000 people, while countries like Liberia and Sierra Leone have virtually zero. Training caregivers is crucial, with safety training sessions typically lasting 3-5 days. The CDC has updated guidelines for the use of personal protective equipment in US hospitals, and hospitals are establishing local patient care protocols and training modules. Trainees, including medical students, residents, and fellows, must receive training before participating in high-risk care, and hospitals must prioritize their safety.

site_title: New visa rules to boost India's tourism
summary: India has introduced new visa rules to boost its tourism industry. Tourists from 43 countries, including the US, Australia, and Japan, can now apply online and receive their visas within four days, with the option to pick up their visas at an airport on arrival. This change aims to make travel to India easier and attract more foreign visitors. The new scheme, which includes nine airports, allows for 30-day visas that cannot be extended and is only valid for recreational purposes. The move is expected to positively impact India's economy.

site_title: Expanding waistlines weigh heavily on M'sia
summary: Malaysia has become the fattest country in South-east Asia, with nearly 45% of its population being overweight or obese. The nation's health minister warns of an "obesity epidemic" and notes that obesity costs the global economy around $2 trillion annually. Childhood obesity rates have also increased, with 14% of children now overweight or obese, and the country expects to see a surge in diabetes cases. The issue is attributed to a combination of factors, including the country's love for rich and unhealthy food, lack of active outdoor leisure pursuits, and cultural emphasis on social gatherings over physical activity.

site_title: More security features for SingPass by Q3 of 2015
summary: Singapore to introduce two-factor authentication (2FA) to its SingPass system by Q3 2015 to enhance security for e-government transactions. The 2FA feature will allow users to access sensitive data using a one-time "second-factor" password delivered through a token or SMS. A one-year transition period will be implemented, with revised security questions introduced in Q3 2015 to improve usability. The move aims to protect users and enable safe online transactions, with the IDA monitoring accounts regularly to deactivate dormant or inactive accounts.

site_title: Private property prices still elevated: MAS
summary: Singapore's private property prices remain elevated, with a 4% decline over four consecutive quarters since 2013. Household wealth rose 1.4% in the third quarter, slower than the five-year average. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) believes the current cooling measures are sufficient to manage potential stresses in the market, despite calls to relax regulations. Housing loan growth slowed to 6% in September, and the banking system's non-performing loan ratio remains low at 0.36%.

site_title: Australia MPs seek higher fines for illegal home-buying
summary: A parliamentary committee in Australia has recommended increasing fines for foreigners who illegally buy homes in the country, with penalties tied to the property's value. The current fine of A$85,000 is seen as "the cost of doing business" and should be replaced. The committee also suggested third parties who help foreigners break the rules should be fined, and gains from illegally purchased homes should be forfeited to the government. The recommendations aim to address concerns that foreign buyers, particularly Chinese, are pricing Australians out of the home market.

site_title: Don't frame self-regulation debate as a binary choice
summary: Singapore's Securities and Futures Commission Authority (SMCCA) is not a frontline regulator, but rather an exchange, the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX-ST), acts as the frontline regulator under the Securities and Futures Act. The SMCCA's role is more aligned with statutory regulation, while SGX-ST operates as a self-regulatory organization (SRO), backed by statute. This model is not unique, with other major jurisdictions adopting similar arrangements. The current arrangement allows SGX-ST to balance regulatory objectives with operational efficiency, while MAS exercises close supervision to ensure competent and responsible performance.

site_title: US carmakers aim for luxury market in China
summary: US carmakers are focusing on China's luxury market, where General Motors (GM) and Ford Motor Company are expanding their presence. GM expects to sell over 5 million vehicles annually in China by 2015, with Cadillac and Lincoln brands gaining popularity. The luxury market in China accounts for 25% of global sales, with German brands holding 80%. Cadillac plans to launch new models, including a full-sized sedan and sports utility vehicle, while Ford aims to sell over 1 million cars in China this year.

site_title: MAS lays out risks for Singapore private debt
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned of potential strains on highly indebted corporates and households in Singapore, citing rising corporate debt as a ratio to GDP to 78% in the second quarter of 2014. However, central bank stress tests indicate that this does not pose systemic risks. The MAS also flagged funding risks for banks, particularly with foreign currency exposures, and highlighted concerns over property market prices, which it believes remain too high. Despite some improvements in household leverage, the MAS warns that highly leveraged households remain a risk.

site_title: Vietnam sees air freight boom as exports boost economy
summary: Vietnam's air freight industry is experiencing a significant boom, driven by a surge in exports that are boosting the country's economy. The growth in airborne shipments has attracted major cargo airlines, including Cathay Pacific Airways and Korean Air Lines, and is expected to continue with a 23% increase in air cargo forecast for 2014. Vietnam has become the leading South-east Asian exporter to the US, with exports rising 13.4% to $123 billion in the 10 months through October, with electronics, garments, and glassware being major contributors.

site_title: Natas and travel agents toil to find common ground
summary: Singapore's National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (Natas) is making changes to its travel fairs, including free admission for the public and reduced fees for exhibitors, in response to concerns from its members. The moves come as 24 travel agencies, including established names, are planning a rival fair in March. Natas president Devinder Ohri hopes to achieve a single fair, but compromise between the two sides remains far off. The changes are part of Natas' SG50 plans and will impact revenue streams for next year.

site_title: Eyes on last trading day of November
summary: Stock markets in Singapore are expected to experience a large push on Friday, the last trading day of the month, as some funds close their books for the year. Thursday's relatively quiet session may be followed by a surge in non-performing or under-performing index counters. Oil and gas stocks were weak, with Maybank Kim Eng upgrading Mermaid Maritime to "buy" and OCBC Investment Research maintaining a "hold" on Ezra Holdings due to concerns over the recent oil price fall. The Straits Times Index ended 8.7 points down at 3,340.96 on Thursday.

site_title: The Federal Reserve's escape from New York
summary: The US Federal Reserve, the world's most important central bank, is in need of reform due to its antiquated governance structure and increasing problems. The Fed's regional structure, with the New York Fed holding disproportionate sway, has led to its officials siding with the interests of large banks. Recent press reports highlight lapses in supervision, particularly in the New York Fed. Reforms proposed by Senator Jack Reed and others aim to address this issue, including nominating the New York Fed president by the president and confirming by the Senate.

site_title: Linc Energy finds evidence of oil in Australia's Arckaringa Basin
summary: Linc Energy, a Singapore-based energy firm, has discovered evidence of oil in the Arckaringa Basin in southern Australia. The company's first exploration well has yielded promising results, with 103 billion barrels of oil equivalent in prospective reserves worth US$10 trillion. Linc Energy plans to drill six to 12 more exploration wells before starting production drilling, which will utilize horizontal drilling and fracking techniques. Analysts caution that the discovery is still in its early stages and further analysis is needed to determine the basin's commercial potential.

site_title: S'pore office market fundamentals top in Asia-Pac
summary: Singapore's office market fundamentals are the strongest in Asia-Pacific, with a projected 10.88% estimated growth in Grade A office rental value this year, the highest among 13 core markets. The city-state's low vacancy rate of 5.74% is expected to dip further to 3.28% by end-2015, making it the lowest in the region. Singapore's diverse economic base and rapid growth as a financial hub are driving the market's fundamentals, surpassing rivals such as Tokyo and Hong Kong.

site_title: America's giant welfare state
summary: The US has the world's second-largest welfare state, with social spending of roughly 19% of its GDP, according to the OECD. Despite claiming to be individualistic and self-reliant, the US ranks 23rd globally in social spending. When including private sector contributions, the US vaults into second position, with a hybrid welfare state that combines government and private market provision. The OECD report highlights the complexity of US welfare systems, with many Americans unaware of the true extent of government social spending, which has remained at historically high levels despite austerity measures in some countries.

site_title: An awakening for Sims Drive?
summary: Sims Drive, a quiet enclave in Singapore, is experiencing a potential awakening with the arrival of new businesses, including a bakery and a vegetarian cafe. Despite initial concerns from friends and locals, owners of Guru Nice Bakery and The REAL Hut are optimistic about the area's potential with the upcoming development of a condominium and James Cook University campus. The businesses plan to capitalize on the influx of new residents and students, with the bakery focusing on online sales and bulk orders, and the cafe introducing new menu items for younger customers.

site_title: Walmart dismisses 30 China executives in restructuring
summary: Walmart has dismissed approximately 30 senior executives in China as part of a restructuring effort, following a similar management shake-up in the US. The move aims to streamline and simplify the business in Asia, amid stiff competition in China and food safety scandals. The retailer also closed stores in Japan and made management changes in India, where it will open its first new wholesale store in two years.

site_title: Post-apocalyptic play questions humanity
summary: A new play, "Paradise," explores a post-apocalyptic world where survivors fight to stay alive on an energy source called orgone. Written by Zizi Azah Abdul Majid, the play raises fundamental questions about humanity's nature, character, and integrity. The story follows a group of survivors, led by Dan, who yearn for a larger purpose despite being trapped in their life-and-death situation. The play, directed by Rizman Putra, is set to premiere at the Drama Centre Blackbox from Dec 4 to 6, asking big existentialist questions about the choices people make in a world where surviving is a triumph.

site_title: Research facility is first 'passive house-certified' lab in the US
summary: The University of Chicago's Department of Ecology and Evolution has completed the first "passive house-certified" laboratory in the US, a 2,131 sq ft facility designed by GO Logic in Maine. The lab, located 112km from campus, was built to be energy efficient, with features such as concrete floors and large metal screens to limit solar gain. Despite initial concerns from neighbors, the building has performed well, maintaining a consistent 21 deg C temperature despite extreme weather conditions. The lab is expected to become a hub for research and has a unique camp-like atmosphere, with rough-hewn sleeping cabins and a 100-inch video display screen.

site_title: Newcomers feature among E50 winners
summary: The 20th annual Enterprise 50 Awards in Singapore honored 50 of the country's top-performing companies, with nearly half of the winners being newcomers. First-time winners included Sunray Woodcraft Construction, Huationg Holdings, and Aalst Chocolate. Trading company Wee Tiong was awarded the 10-year Award for the 10th consecutive year, while Borden Company jumped to top the E50 list this year. The awards recognized productivity growth in export-oriented sectors, but overall productivity was dragged down by declines in domestically oriented sectors.

site_title: Tiger shareholders okay rights issue and sale of Aussie stake
summary: Tiger Airways shareholders approved a rights issue that could raise up to S$234 million and the sale of their remaining 40% stake in Tigerair Australia to focus on Tigerair Singapore. The sale was approved by 99.83% of shareholders, while the rights issue received 98.34% support. The divestment and rights issue will allow Tiger Airways to devote resources to its Singapore operations.

site_title: Passing the torch
summary: OE Manufacturing's founder, James Wong, is preparing his children for succession as he plans to retire by age 70. The company has implemented a succession plan, including documented work procedures, decentralised decision-making, and a shift from "owner-manager" to "owner-mentor" roles. Wong emphasizes the need for SMEs to innovate, work beyond defined boundaries, and find their own support lifeline to supplement government incentives. He advises SMEs to be nimble, have a positive attitude, and keep learning to cope with changes in the dynamic business environment.

site_title: BOJ backs inflation drive with pay rise for its top executives
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has raised the salaries of its top executives, including Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, by 1.3% for the financial year to March 2015. The move aims to counter sluggish wage growth in Japan, a major threat to Abenomics. Despite major increases in export profitability, Japan's corporate sector has raised basic wages only marginally, leading to "strongly negative" real wage growth. The BOJ's inflation target of 2% is now considered "probably out of reach," and economists say the move may not boost consumption and inflation expectations among the Japanese public.

images.alt_text: Mr Kuroda's pay packet will hit 34.7 million yen (S$383,436) a year after the pay hike, the first in nine years for BOJ governors.

site_title: Buy-and-hold strategy in Asian bonds creates resilience
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports that the Asian bond market is likely to be more resilient due to investors' buy-and-hold strategy, despite its relatively low liquidity. A rare "flash crash" in the US bond market in October was averted in Asia, where bond investors tend to hold bonds to maturity. This strategy is also reflected in Singapore, where corporates issued $19.7 billion in bonds in the first three quarters of the year. The MAS notes that while the Asian corporate bond market is less developed, it may benefit from increased liquidity and expertise from Asian financial institutions.

site_title: In brief
summary: Boustead Singapore has executed a £200 million (S$409 million) term and multi-currency revolving facilities agreement with DBS Bank. The funds will be used for the redemption of £138 million in principal amount and accrued interest of GuocoLeisure's 2014 Debenture Stock, as well as general corporate funding and working capital requirements. Boustead Singapore will also host Retail Investor Days on December 10 and 11 for retail investors.

site_title: Mitsubishi Estate to accelerate Marunouchi development
summary: Mitsubishi Estate Co, Japan's largest developer, plans to redevelop a 11,240 sqm area in central Tokyo's Marunouchi business district. The company will sell the former Mizuho Bank head office to Mizuho Financial Group for 159 billion yen and book a 36.5 billion yen gain. Mitsubishi Estate aims to accelerate development in the area, which has seen a 20% rise in real estate prices since 2012, with the average rent 30% higher than in Tokyo. The redevelopment is expected to be completed by March 2017.

site_title: UEM Sunrise hopes Aussie devt will take up slack
summary: UEM Sunrise, a Malaysian property developer, is counting on its inaugural project in Australia, Aurora Melbourne Central, to meet its RM2 billion sales target this year. The company's earnings slumped 61% in the third quarter due to soft buyer sentiment in Iskandar Malaysia. Despite this, 95% of Aurora's 941 residential units were sold during a two-week preview launch, with Australians accounting for a quarter of bookings. The project's gross development value is RM1.6 billion, and UEM Sunrise hopes it can convert bookings to sales before the end of the year.

site_title: Dollar falls on growth doubt as yen rises
summary: The US dollar fell for a third consecutive day against the yen, marking the longest streak in a month, amid concerns that the US economic recovery has plateaued. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dropped 0.1% to 1,096.36, while the yen rose 0.4% to 146.59 euros. Traders are reducing bearish positions, with some speculating that the recent declines were excessive, leading to a modest washout. The US Economic Surprise Index fell to 6.2, the lowest since August.

site_title: Re/Max to tap retirees, housewives for growth
summary: Re/Max Holdings Inc plans to launch its real estate brokerage business in Japan on December 1, targeting retirees and housewives to capitalize on the country's recovering housing market. The company's agents can earn up to 94% of broker fees, and CEO Aki Nakamiya aims to bring innovative business practices to Japan's stagnant real estate market. This move is part of the company's expansion overseas, seeking to boost revenue from franchise fees after an initial public offering last year.

site_title: SME survival tips
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a high mortality rate, but forming alliances with diverse partners can improve their chances of survival and success. SMEs can benefit from alliances with universities, venture capitalists, and corporations, which can provide access to resources, funding, and expertise. A study found that SMEs with alliances achieve better performance, and examples such as Tesla Motors and Stone Apple demonstrate the benefits of strategic partnerships. To implement an alliance strategy, SMEs must identify their strengths and gaps, and choose partners who can help fill those gaps.

site_title: Wanted: professionals and execs to write plays
summary: TheatreWorks, a leading Singaporean theatre company, is holding a playwriting course to attract white-collar professionals and executives to write plays. The one-week course, taught by acclaimed artist and playwright Tony Perez, will be held from Dec 1-6, with a fee of S$200. Participants will learn how to establish a genuine long-term rapport with Perez, who emphasizes the importance of liking and being liked by students. Upon completion, students will write a full-length play, which will be dramatized and performed at TheatreWorks.

site_title: Whole new take on S'pore films
summary: Three Singaporean directors, Sam Loh, Jason Lai, and Han Yew Kwang, are showcasing edgy films at the Singapore International Film Festival. Lang Tong, a raunchy thriller, will premiere on Dec 13, featuring sex scenes and nudity. Director Loh, who made his second feature after 2004's Outsiders, aimed to create a genre film for international audiences. Ms J Contemplates Her Choice, a thriller and social drama, will premiere on Dec 6, exploring the philosophy behind life's choices. Rubbers, a sex comedy, will debut on Dec 12, using condoms as a comedic device. These films challenge traditional Singaporean cinema, pushing boundaries and exploring new themes.

site_title: Demand for SME loans to grow at slower pace in quarters ahead: MAS
summary: Demand for SME loans in Singapore is expected to grow at a slower pace due to challenging economic conditions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) attributes this to increased competition among banks for SME loans, resulting in a narrower net interest margin (NIM) of 1.7% from 2.3% in the previous quarter. Despite this, the credit quality of SME loan portfolios has improved, with non-performing loan (NPL) ratios falling below 1% since 2013. Singapore is also exploring crowdfunding for SMEs, with a focus on developing a regulatory framework to protect retail investors.

site_title: The Flaming Lips here again to enthral its audience
summary: American psychedelic rock band The Flaming Lips is set to return to Singapore with a concert featuring new songs and classic hits, including tracks from their tribute album "With a Little Help from My Fwends" to the Beatles' "Sgt Pepper Lonely Hearts Club Band". Lead singer Wayne Coyne praises the Singapore audience, saying they have a deeper emotional reaction from Asian audiences. The band has previously collaborated with artists such as Miley Cyrus and Tegan & Sara on their tribute albums, and Coyne is excited to see how fans will react to their latest work.

site_title: Uber investors value it at US$40b
summary: Uber investors value the company at $40 billion, nearly doubling its valuation from a previous round, and are considering a $35-40 billion funding round. The valuation is comparable to that of Twitter and Delta Airlines, and would imply $2 billion in revenue. Investors see the potential market size as vast, with every car service and taxi cab worldwide, and are optimistic about Uber's growth prospects.

site_title: Cashflow major challenge to profitability for S'pore firms: poll
summary: A survey by Atradius Group found that 31.7% of Singapore companies cite maintaining adequate cash flow as the main challenge to profitability, with collection of outstanding invoices and falling demand for products and services being the second and third most frequently cited challenges. Singapore's close trading relationship with China and bank lending restrictions are also contributing factors. The country has the highest percentage of overdue receivables and the highest percentage of receivables over 90 days past due among Asia-Pacific economies surveyed.

site_title: Top bid for GLS site with new building rules beats expectations
summary: ASSET Legend has offered S$276.8 million for a 99-year leasehold mixed-use site in Singapore, beating expectations and analysts' predictions. The bid, or S$848.84 per square foot per plot ratio, is 15% higher than the next highest bid. The site, near Kovan MRT station, is expected to yield about 340 housing units, with a breakeven price of at least S$1,300 for residential units. The new requirements for prefabrication and buildability are considered "aggressive" by analysts.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Brokerages initiate coverage on IPS Securex with a target price of S$1.26, recommending a BUY due to increased defence budgets in the region. DMG Research cites PepperBall as a game-changer for IPS. Mermaid Maritime's earnings were slightly below expectations but maintained an Add rating with a lower target price. ComfortDelGro's stability and diversified revenue streams were highlighted by OCBC Research, with a BUY rating and unchanged target price of S$3.03.

site_title: The drive for growth
summary: Aver Asia, a Singapore-based equipment provider, has grown five times in five years to nearly S$100m in revenue. The company, founded in 1999 by Ang Poh Kiang and his brother, has expanded its operations to five branches in Malaysia and set up a subsidiary in Myanmar. Aver Asia rents and sells equipment for the construction, oil & gas, and shipping industries, with a fleet of over 4,000 units. The company faces a manpower crunch due to government measures to slow down foreign worker inflow, but plans to hire apprentices and fresh graduates.

images.alt_text: Mr Ang expects overseas activities to keep him busy for a while.

site_title: Q3 revenue in business services sector up 1.1%
summary: Singapore's business services sector saw a 1.1% increase in revenue in the third quarter compared to the second quarter of 2014, and a 3.3% increase year-over-year. Education reported the highest increase in receipts, followed by health and social services. Financial and insurance services saw a 1.6% increase, while information and communications services rose 0.2%. In contrast, recreational and personal services plummeted 12.2% quarter-over-quarter and 15.5% year-over-year. The health and social services industry recorded the highest growth of 9.7% due to higher receipts from hospitals and Western clinics.

site_title: Toyota to recall 57,000 cars with Takata air bags
summary: Toyota is recalling 57,000 vehicles globally to replace potentially deadly air bags made by Takata Corp, following a Honda Motor Co recall two weeks ago. The affected vehicles include Vitz subcompacts and RAV4 crossover models made between 2002 and 2004. This is part of a larger safety crisis surrounding Takata's air bag inflators, which can explode and spray metal fragments. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has ordered Takata to expand its recall nationwide, potentially adding millions of vehicles to the affected list.

site_title: On Eagle's wings
summary: Borden Company, a Singapore-based pharmaceutical firm, has expanded its presence in the global market, particularly in Asia, with its flagship product, Eagle Brand medicated oil. The company, which has been in operation for over 80 years, has successfully penetrated into two new markets, the Philippines and Taiwan, and has plans to enter India and China in the future. Borden's success can be attributed to its ability to diversify and innovate, with a range of products including eucalyptus oils, disinfectant sprays, and muscle rubs. The company has also implemented measures to increase productivity and reduce costs, including the use of automated machinery and the introduction of new packaging.

site_title: It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas
summary: New York City's commercial landlords are spending lavishly on holiday decorations for the first time since the recession. Companies like the Durst Organization and the William Kaufman Organization are allocating seven-figure budgets to install intricate designs, including 3,000 sugar pine cones, 15,000 red berry branches, and 24-foot-tall Christmas trees. The goal is to create a cohesive look inspired by the Danish concept of "hygge" or warmth and welcome. Landlords are also investing in interactive installations, such as polar bears and penguins, to create a festive atmosphere for tenants and tourists.

images.alt_text: Wreaths and trees being prepped for display at the American Christmas warehouse in Mount Vernon, New York, two weeks ago.

site_title: Indonesia planning fixed petrol subsidy by 2016: official
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry plans to propose a fixed petrol subsidy of 1,000-2,000 rupiah per liter, potentially implemented in 2016, to insulate the government budget from oil-price fluctuations. The proposal would limit the government's cost to 48 trillion rupiah annually, freeing up funds for development spending. A fixed subsidy system would make the fuel subsidy budget more predictable and dependent on consumption, rather than oil prices.

site_title: India GDP growth set to fall; firms prefer reforms over rate cut
summary: India's GDP growth is expected to fall to 5% in the July-September quarter, down from 5.7% in the April-June quarter. The government, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is urging the Reserve Bank of India to cut interest rates, but bankers and company executives say reforms are key to recovery. Reforms on land acquisition, coal supply, and foreign direct investment are expected to be introduced in the current winter session of parliament, with executives citing a lack of progress as a major obstacle to investment.

site_title: How to defeat the impulse buy
summary: During the holiday shopping season, retailers employ tactics to increase impulse buying by exploiting consumers' preference for immediate gratification, known as temporal discounting. To resist these tactics, cultivating gratitude can be an effective strategy. Research suggests that feeling grateful increases financial patience, allowing individuals to delay short-term rewards for long-term benefits. By focusing on what one already has, rather than what's lacking, consumers can develop self-control and avoid impulse buys, ultimately thwarting retailers' enticements.

images.alt_text: Temporal discounting often plays a central role in impulse-buying decisions.

site_title: The DNA of success
summary: The Enterprise 50 Awards, now in its 20th year, honors 50 companies in Singapore that have achieved success through innovation, expansion, and visionary leadership. Winners include Borden Company, Sunray Woodcraft Construction, and Vigcon Construction, with a majority coming from the manufacturing, real estate/construction, and engineering services sectors. A sense of adventure and looking outside Singapore for expansion opportunities are common threads among the award winners, with a presence in 123 countries, including China, Malaysia, and Thailand.

site_title: S Korean derivatives boom as stocks fall short
summary: South Korea's derivatives sales have set an annual record in the first 10 months of 2014, reaching 54.7 trillion won, driven by low equity and bond returns. Structured products tied to global stock markets have seen a surge, with 95% of sales tied to indexes such as the Kospi Index. Regulators are monitoring the sales to control risks, as brokerages use proceeds to buy bonds, affecting their capital ratios and potentially putting downward pressure on yields.

site_title: Staying the course
summary: Sim Koon Lam, founder and director of Mooreast Asia, recounts his journey of taking his company from a struggling marketing unit to a profitable fabrication and supply business. In 2007, he bought out his bosses after feeling they didn't share his vision for growth. The company has since grown to employ 65 people and has become profitable. Lam attributes his success to determination and trust-building with customers, emphasizing the importance of delivering on promises. He also notes that Mooreast Asia has reached a new stage of growth, requiring more professional management, and has established its own brand.

site_title: A firm at the crossroads
summary: Huationg Holdings, a civil engineering and logistics solutions provider, is at a crossroads, requiring realignment of business strategies and internal harmonization to support further expansion. The company faces a labor crunch in Singapore, with equipment operators aging and younger workers hesitant to enter the industry. To address this, Huationg has implemented the Operations Management Innovation (OMNI) program, which empowers employees to improve operational processes and optimize manpower. The company aims to sustain local business while replicating capabilities in regional markets, with revenue from abroad expected to reach half of total annual revenue in the mid-term.

site_title: Solid foundation is key to success
summary: Sunray Woodcraft Construction, a Singapore-based interior fit-out company, has achieved significant success despite a fire in 1999 that destroyed its factory and headquarters. The company, now one of the largest interior builders in Singapore, aspires to be a "family multinational company" (FMNC) that balances its family culture with corporate structure. CEO Connie Wu emphasizes the importance of respecting pioneer staff and providing opportunities for growth. Sunray has incorporated a small structural team, expanded its services, and is poised for growth, prioritizing quality, timely completion, and good value. The company has won its first Enterprise 50 Award and is focusing on consolidating its capabilities before pursuing overseas expansion.

site_title: A reacquaintance with Australia's best Shiraz
summary: A masterclass at The Wine Advocate's "Matter of Taste" event showcased 12 iconic Barossa Shiraz wines, including new gems from Teusner, John Duval Eligo Vineyard, Chris Ringland Dimchurch, and others. The wines, ranging from 2005 to 2010, displayed intense black-red colors, aromas of sweet ripe berries, and complex flavors of fruitcake, chocolate, and spices. Notable wines included Teusner's Righteous 'Fg' Shiraz (96+), John Duval's Eligo Vineyard Selection (98+), and Torbreck's Run Rig (96). The masterclass highlighted the diversity and quality of Australian Shiraz wines, with many considered stand-ins for Penfold's Grange and Hill of Grace.

site_title: OPEC decides not to cut oil output-Saudi's Naimi
summary: Saudi Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi announced that OPEC will not cut its oil output, following a five-hour meeting. This decision was made in response to a question from reporters, with Naimi confirming the decision. The move comes as global oil prices have been affected by US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries.

site_title: Genting outlook boosts bets against gaming firm
summary: Genting Singapore plc, the second-worst performing stock on Singapore's benchmark gauge, has seen its outlook boost bets against the gaming firm. Analysts are the least optimistic about the company, citing a 50% plunge in quarterly profit and a slump in Chinese visitors, the biggest source of revenue. Despite a 12% rally in the stock since a share buyback program began, analysts predict a 12-month average price target of S$1.24, down from S$1.55 a year ago. Genting's valuation is seen as unattractive compared to Macau gaming companies.

site_title: US stock markets closed Thursday
summary: US stock markets closed early on Thursday for the Thanksgiving Day holiday, with the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq Stock Market closing three hours early at 1:00 pm.

site_title: Love triangle with fun-loving females
summary: "Very Good Girls" is a coming-of-age film that explores the trials and tribulations of two best friends, Lilly and Gerri, over a transformative New York summer. The movie follows Lilly's vulnerability as she navigates a love triangle with a photographer and her own desires, while her parents' marriage and Gerri's family dynamics add complexity to the story. However, the film's execution falls short, with poorly drawn characters and an inconsequential ending that reinforces the idea that "girls just wanna have fun." The film receives a mediocre rating of C+.

site_title: Charting success in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar is opening its doors to foreign investment, with major companies including TA Corporation, Transworld Group, Soilbuild Group, and OCBC Bank expanding their presence in the country. The country's reforms and economic growth have attracted investors, with opportunities in infrastructure, property development, and agriculture. Companies see Myanmar as a strategic location for expansion into China and the Indian subcontinent. Despite challenges, investors remain committed to the country, citing the potential for long-term growth and the need for a physical presence to support business relationships.

site_title: Samsung heir makes his mark
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae Yong is putting his stamp on the company after his father's hospitalization, making $8 billion in proposed deals, including a $2 billion stock buyback. The company's shares surged 7.7% to their highest gain in almost 6 years. Lee Jae Yong is trying to find a way forward for the over 70 companies controlled by the family amid slumping earnings at the world's biggest smartphone business and government curbs on chaebols. He may be elevated to chairman of Samsung Electronics, which contributes 70% of the group's total revenue.

site_title: Riding on productivity
summary: Singapore's productivity drive has led to an increase in sales for AllAlloy, a welding equipment and solutions provider, with local sales contributing half of its revenue. The company's general manager, Victor Khaw, attributes this to the incentives to invest in technology and the tightened foreign manpower policies pushing companies to maximize efficiency. AllAlloy has designed and sold semi-automatic welding systems and mini submerged arc systems to help companies increase productivity and reduce reliance on foreign workers. The company plans to expand into new markets, including Vietnam, Jakarta, and China, and may also shift its non-core business to a more consumer-facing model.

site_title: Juncker survives European Parliament vote over Luxleaks scandal
summary: The European Parliament voted to reject a no-confidence motion against Jean-Claude Juncker's European Commission over the Luxleaks tax scandal. 101 MEPs approved the censure motion, while 461 voted against and 88 abstained. This decision means Juncker will continue to lead the European Commission.

site_title: SMEs see brighter 2015
summary: Nearly six in 10 Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) expect their business to grow in 2015, according to a survey by CPA Australia. The optimism is more pronounced than in the last four years, with 61% of SMEs expecting the Singapore economy to continue growing. The survey suggests that SMEs can capitalize on opportunities by reviewing costs, improving staff productivity and skills, and preparing for the Asean Economic Community. The government's projections of a modest economy growth next year presents a challenge, but SMEs can create their own opportunities by seeking out new markets and being properly funded.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Thursday, closing at 1,829.91 after 1.55 billion lots were traded, with 252 gainers and 567 losers.

site_title: Lines versus lines
summary: A blogger discusses the importance of indexing lines in data visualization, particularly when comparing time series data. Indexing allows for a fair comparison by scaling the data to the same units, making it easier to understand trends and performance. However, the blogger argues that indexing should be done judiciously, as it can sometimes obscure meaningful information. Two laws of indexing are proposed: index only if the data has a similar nature and the comparison is meaningful, and index only if the data has a similar scale.

site_title: PwC study says planned EU bank trading curbs harmful
summary: A PwC study commissioned by the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME) warns that EU plans to curb risky trading at banks would increase the cost of debt financing, affecting 45 banks, including Barclays and Deutsche Bank. The study estimates a 5 billion euro rise in debt financing costs across the EU, potentially cutting the number of viable capital market banks and increasing industry concentration. The proposed reforms are at odds with the goal of creating deep, liquid capital markets, and some countries, including Britain and Germany, are already introducing curbs on risky trading.

site_title: Scotland to be granted greater autonomy: commission
summary: A UK government-appointed commission has recommended sweeping new powers for Scotland, including setting its own income tax rates, controlling welfare payments, and air passenger duty. The plan aims to give the Scottish parliament greater autonomy ahead of an independence referendum in September. British Prime Minister David Cameron has welcomed the plan, saying it is a "good day for the UK." Devolution laws are to be drawn up by January, with the right to full control over income tax rates backed by the Conservatives and SNP, but opposed by the Labour Party.

site_title: German labour market unfazed by economic weakness
summary: Germany's labour market remains strong, with unemployment at its lowest level since unification, standing at 2.872 million in November. The jobless rate of 6.6% has remained unchanged since October, despite economic weakness. Analysts attribute the labour market's resilience to private and government consumption, and low inflation. Experts predict the labour market will continue to support wage growth and private consumption, helping the economy reach trend growth rates from 2015 onwards.

site_title: ECB's Draghi calls for wage cuts to help the euro
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi has called for wage cuts in the eurozone to strengthen the single currency. He emphasized the need for flexible economies to find and exploit their comparative advantages, and for efficient allocation of resources to attract capital and generate jobs. Draghi also highlighted the need for permanent mechanisms to transfer wealth from richer nations to poorer ones, and for cross-border mobility of the unemployed. This comes as the eurozone faces challenges from structural reforms and potential economic divergence among member states.

site_title: Exploring new frontiers
summary: Asian firms are expanding globally amid an uncertain economic climate, with E50 companies identifying China, Malaysia, and Thailand as top destinations for internationalization. China's rapidly opening economy, low market barriers, and tax incentives make it an attractive location. Thailand offers a low-cost business environment, a transparent system, and access to neighboring countries. Malaysia provides a fuss-free business setup, numerous tax incentives, and a competitive tax regulatory system. Companies must balance pros and cons, tackling challenges such as an uncertain legal landscape and inconsistent regulations to succeed in these markets.

images.alt_text: As part of China's rapidly opening economy, companies looking to enter can expect to lower market barriers for private and foreign participation.

site_title: More than just a paint job
summary: Vigcon Construction, a Singapore-based company, has grown from a small paint job business in the late 1980s to a $90 million turnover company with 230 staff. The company's construction business has become one of its core pillars, alongside additions and alteration arm, which contributes over 50% of its revenue. The company's managing director and executive director, Teo Yeow Soon and Teo Tiow Guan, respectively, attribute their success to adapting to government policies, such as the man-year entitlements policy, and implementing productivity initiatives, including technology and close supervision. Despite potential slowdown in the construction sector, the company expects to maintain its turnover.

images.alt_text: Mr Teo Yeow Soon (left) and Mr Teo Tiow Guan (right) are looking to move into residential or industrial property development here or overseas in the coming years.

site_title: Timing it just right
summary: Wee Tiong, a leading physical commodities trading company, has achieved its 10th consecutive E50 award, marking a decade of success. Director Tan Wee Beng attributes the company's success to a combination of luck, hard work, and strategic decision-making. Wee Tiong transformed from a local rice and sugar importer to a major commodities trading company by forming a team of traders to conduct research on global supply and demand. The company has maintained a profitable mantra, focusing on playing within its means and avoiding excessive risk. With a new sugar refinery set to open in Indonesia in 2015, Wee Tiong is optimistic about its future prospects.

site_title: China Internet giants in tit-for-tat battle for users
summary: China's Weibo has effectively banned users from promoting WeChat, a popular messaging app, on its platform. The move is seen as an escalation in the rivalry between the two internet giants. WeChat has 468 million monthly active users, while Weibo has seen a 9% decline in users to 281 million. The ban targets accounts promoting WeChat using QR codes and other marketing information. This follows a previous move by WeChat blocking promotion of Alibaba's taxi hailing service. The rivalry between Tencent, WeChat's owner, and Alibaba, Weibo's owner, has intensified.

site_title: Taking a long-term view
summary: Rotating Offshore Solutions (ROS), a Singapore-based company, remains optimistic about the long-term prospects of the offshore and marine sector despite a short-term downturn in oil prices. The company plans to diversify into new areas of business, expand its engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) capabilities, and increase its footprint in the FPSO market. With a new facility in place, ROS aims to keep costs low and deliver high-quality products faster than competitors. The company's strategy is to take on as many projects as possible to weather the short-term storm, driven by a long-term trend of increasing oil and gas demand.

site_title: WTO clinches first global trade deal in its history
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) adopted its first global trade reform, a 19-year wait, after a compromise on wording reached by the US and Indian governments. The agreement introduces new standards for customs checks and border procedures, expected to add $1 trillion and 21 million jobs to the global economy. The deal was reached after a four-month standoff caused by India's veto of the reform package, which was eventually agreed upon on December 2014. This marks a significant step towards further global negotiations, with the next round set to begin by July 2015.

site_title: Added security measures for SingPass by Q3 2015
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore announced that a two-factor authentication (2FA) feature will be introduced to SingPass by the third quarter of 2015 to enhance security for e-government transactions. This feature will require a one-time "second-factor" password, either delivered through a token or via SMS. The IDA will also roll out revised security questions to make it easier for users to reset their passwords online. The move aims to protect users and enable safe online transactions.

site_title: US cruise liner taps into growing Southeast Asian market
summary: US-based Princess Cruises launched its first Singapore-based service, marking its entry into the growing Southeast Asian cruise travel market. The 11-day voyage on the Sapphire Princess will cater to over 2,500 guests, including 30% Asians, before returning to Singapore in March. Industry players expect the region's emerging middle class to drive demand, with Princess Cruises aiming to carry 40,000 passengers annually. The company aims to capitalize on the region's vast 25,000 islands, surpassing the Caribbean's popularity.

site_title: Building a strong presence
summary: The construction sector in Singapore is facing headwinds due to a shortage of manpower, rising labor and materials costs, and cooling measures in the real estate market. Three E50 winners, Vigcon Construction, Link (THM) Group, and Huationg Holdings, discussed how they overcome these challenges. Vigcon uses technology and CoreTrade training to boost productivity, while Link diversifies into other property segments and focuses on design innovation. Huationg emphasizes employee ownership and a sense of family to retain staff. Despite challenges, the companies remain optimistic about their long-term prospects, with Vigcon focusing on local market growth and Link and Huationg exploring overseas opportunities.

site_title: Investor complacency could breed systemic risks, ECB warns
summary: The European Central Bank warned of potential financial stability risks due to investor complacency and 'frothy' property prices. The report noted that during periods of weak returns, investors may hunt for yield, leading to systemic risks. Additionally, property markets in some countries have been overvalued, leaving them vulnerable to correction. The report also highlighted the challenges of sustaining high public debt, stating that restoring soundness of public finances is unfinished.

site_title: Government land sales site at Upper Serangoon Road draws 11 bids
summary: ASSET Legend Limited has clinched the highest tender price of S$276.8 million for a 99-year leasehold mixed-use site at Upper Serangoon Road, with S$848.84 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The site attracted 11 bids, with SL Capital Ventures Pte Ltd and a consortium of Verwood Holdings, Intrepid Investments, and TID Residential placing second and third highest bids, respectively. The URA extended the tender closing date to November 27 to account for new prefabrication requirements for government land sales sites.

site_title: India central bank releases final rules for niche bank licensing
summary: India's central bank has released final guidelines for niche bank licensing, allowing companies to set up payments banks and small finance banks to expand banking services. Payments banks can accept deposits and remittances but cannot provide loans. Small finance banks aim to lend to unserved and underserved sections, including small businesses. Companies must apply by Jan 16, 2025, and meet statutory reserve requirements. Large state-run entities and business houses are barred from setting up small finance banks, and the central bank will consider additional applications at a later stage.

site_title: German GfK consumer sentiment picks up heading into December
summary: German consumer sentiment improved for the second month heading into December, with GfK's forward-looking consumer sentiment indicator rising to 8.7 from 8.5 in November. This suggests a brighter year-end for Europe's largest economy, narrowly avoiding a recession in the third quarter. Uncertainty over geopolitical tensions had a limited impact on income outlooks and willingness to spend. The results match the highest estimate in a Reuters poll of 19 economists, indicating a possible year-on-year growth in private consumption.

site_title: Lending to euro zone private sector shrinks again Oct: ECB
summary: Lending to the euro zone private sector contracted 1.1% in October, according to ECB figures, amid economic pressure. Euro zone banks have tightened lending due to tougher capital requirements and uncertainty. The European Central Bank is under pressure to deliver further stimulus measures, with possible quantitative easing on the horizon. The ECB has already started offering cheap loans and buying covered bonds to ease bank burden. The euro zone economy remains sluggish, with inflation at 0.4% and business growth weaker than expected.

site_title: OPEC set for pivotal meet as oil price hits fresh low
summary: OPEC ministers are meeting in Vienna to discuss a possible production cut, amid a 30% decline in oil prices over five months. The cartel's powerful Gulf members reject calls to reduce output unless guaranteed market share, while poorer nations like Venezuela and Ecuador push for cuts. The US benchmark oil price fell to a four-year low, and analysts expect OPEC to trim its production limit rather than cut it, potentially conceding market share to shale oil producers.

site_title: SABMiller, Coca-Cola and local firm to create African bottler
summary: SABMiller, Coca-Cola, and local firm Gutsche Family Investments are forming a new African bottler, Coca-Cola Beverages Africa, with US$2.9 billion in revenue across 12 markets. The new company will be headquartered in South Africa and owned 57% by SABMiller, 31.7% by GFI, and 11.3% by Coca-Cola. As part of the deal, Coca-Cola will acquire SABMiller's Appletiser brands globally for US$260 million. The company aims to capitalize on Africa's growing consumer spending, which is expected to reach US$978 billion by 2020.

site_title: China's COFCO to control state food firm Huafu in efficiency drive
summary: China's COFCO will take control of state-owned firm Huafu as part of Beijing's reforms to boost state sector efficiency. COFCO, a market-oriented firm, will manage Huafu, which manages Chinese food reserves, after the merger is approved by the cabinet. The move is part of China's broader efforts to reduce state food stockpiles and shift to other policy tools to support domestic growers. The reform aims to increase transparency and efficiency in state-owned enterprises, with COFCO being described as a "role model" for SOEs.

site_title: India cbank eases rules for low-cost home loans
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has eased rules for low-cost home loans by allowing banks to extend loans against long-term infrastructure bonds, but with certain restrictions. Banks can now lend up to $16,170 against such bonds, with a loan ceiling of $100,000 and a loan tenure equal to the bond's maturity period. This move aims to fund low-cost housing, following a previous exemption of infrastructure bonds from mandatory reserve requirements in July.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall on scepticism about China market rally
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.5% on Thursday, amid skepticism about China's economy, as investors hesitated to follow mainland gains. The Hang Seng index closed at 24,004.28, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.3% to 11,013.87 points. Chinese investment flowed into Hong Kong, but trading volume was high at 141.7 billion shares, indicating cautious market sentiment.

site_title: Banking tricks blunt China's drive to increase lending
summary: China's efforts to increase lending to boost economic growth have been hindered by banking tricks used to manipulate figures. Following the interest rate cut, banks may extend loans with borrowers using a portion to purchase wealth-management products, or return a portion of the loan as deposits to earn interest. Despite the regulator's warnings, these practices are still common among banks, making it difficult to accurately measure lending growth. China's economy is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

images.alt_text: China hopes that last week's interest rate cut will increase lending into the economy to shore up flagging growth, but measuring any rise will be impeded by a number of tricks the country's bankers use to manipulate the figures.

site_title: Singapore services sector's sales revenue up 1.1% in Q3; education sector tops growth in receipts
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 1.1% increase in sales revenue in Q3, with education sector experiencing the highest growth in receipts at 14.2% quarter-over-quarter. Business services excluding real estate and health & social services also saw growth of 3.3% and 2.2% respectively. This marks a year-over-year increase of 3.3%.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 8.70 points to 3,340.96. The trading volume was 1.23 billion shares, valued at S$1.02 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 174-238. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain, as investors seem to be cautious amid tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Broker's Take: 'Add' call on Wing Tai, valuation cheap, says CIMB
summary: CIMB Research has upgraded its "hold" call to "add" for Wing Tai Holdings, citing a cheap valuation and strong balance sheet. The research house sets a target price of S$2.09, 44% below revalued net asset value. Wing Tai's balance sheet is expected to support its share price, and the company is likely to benefit from potential policy tweaks that favor high-end developers. CIMB also cut its earnings per share forecast for FY2015-2017 due to delayed earnings recognition for high-end projects.

site_title: Towers Watson names Asia-Pac director of insurance management consultancy
summary: Towers Watson has appointed Keith Brooks as Asia-Pacific regional director of its insurance management consultancy. Brooks, with 28 years of insurance experience, will lead the division based in Hong Kong. He has worked in Asia since 1998 and previously held senior management positions, including CEO of a multinational insurance company's Thai operations.

site_title: German annual inflation set to fall in November, state data suggests
summary: Germany's annual inflation is expected to fall in November, reaching its lowest rate in up to five years, according to state data. The inflation rate in North Rhine-Westphalia decreased to 0.7% from 1.0% in October, and economists predict a national rate of 0.6% in November, the lowest since February 2010. This could put pressure on the European Central Bank to provide more policy support to revive the eurozone economy, which has been experiencing deflation.

images.alt_text: Annual inflation in Europe's largest economy looks set to sink in November to the lowest rate in up to five years, according to data from some German states on Thursday.

site_title: Broker's Take: Ascendas Hospitality Trust gets 'hold' call on upside from rebranding
summary: DBS EQUITY Research maintains its "hold" call on Ascendas Hospitality Trust, citing upside from rebranding and asset enhancement initiatives. The trust's current yield is 8-9% and management is exploring rebranding its Osaka property and studying AEI opportunities in Australia. The trust's distribution per unit is expected to rise 3.5% year-on-year excluding the impact of a cross currency swap unwind. DBS also highlights the trust's hedging of 50% of its expected distributable income and its efforts to diversify its portfolio into China and Japan.

site_title: Japan volcano eruption hits flights
summary: A cloud of ash and smoke from Japan's Mount Aso volcano has forced the cancellation or diversion of flights in Japan, particularly at Kumamoto airport. The eruption, which is the volcano's first in 19 years, has prompted warnings of volcanic stones and ash falling within a one-kilometre radius. Several airlines, including Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, have cancelled or diverted flights to avoid the ash cloud, with more potential disruptions if the eruption worsens.

site_title: Broker's Take: 'Add' call on CosmoSteel on positive Q4 results, target price S$0.63
summary: VOYAGE Research has issued an "add" call on CosmoSteel Holdings with a target price of S$0.63, following the company's positive Q4 FY2014 results, which saw revenue and net profit grow 23% and 74% year-on-year, respectively. The company's gross margin also improved to 20.1%. The research house plans to roll forward forecasts to FY2019 and maintain its valuation at S$0.63 per share.

site_title: Australia: Shares held back by energy sector as oil slides
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing 0.09% higher at 5,400.90, despite a 3.1% drop in oil and gas producer Santos and a 2.8% decline in Woodside Petroleum. Brent crude fell to a four-year low, with some commodity fund managers predicting oil prices could slide to $60 per barrel if OPEC does not agree a significant output cut.

site_title: Fashion + property = avant-garde buildings
summary: Link (THM) Group, led by CEO Kenny Tan, is developing an S$1-billion integrated development, One World Medini, in Medini, Iskandar. The project features a "seven wonders" retail segment, offices, and residential units. Tan's design expertise, honed in the fashion industry, is evident in the project's unique architecture. The development aims to become a celebrity town, attracting film studios and tourists. With a strong cash flow and diversified business, the group is targeting to list on the Singapore Exchange by 2015. Tan also plans to expand into Myanmar and other Southeast Asian markets.

images.alt_text: The next leg of growth for Link (THM) is likely to come from overseas expansion, and not just in Malaysia, says Mr Tan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.78%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.78% on Thursday, November 27, 2014, due to a stronger yen ahead of the US Thanksgiving holiday. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 135.08 points to finish at 17,248.50, while the Topix index fell 1.03% to 1,391.90.

site_title: Net capital flows to Asia turn negative: MAS
summary: Net capital flows to Asia turned negative in 2014, reversing years of inflows, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Financial Stability Review. This reversal was driven by retail fund exits and institutional fund increases in response to global volatility. The MAS warns of potential greater volatility in Asian capital flows due to uncertainty over US interest rate hikes, affecting the Asia-10 economies, including Singapore, China, and others.

site_title: Indonesia giving private sector first dibs for infrastructure projects
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has ordered his ministers to prioritize private investors for infrastructure projects, shifting the focus from state-owned enterprises. The move aims to address the country's $450 billion infrastructure funding gap by 2019. Private investors will be given first dibs for projects, while state agencies will be relegated to secondary choice. However, resistance from old-school politicians and bureaucrats may hinder the implementation, and critics argue that the projects themselves must be viable to attract private investment.

site_title: Indonesia's finance ministry signs MOU to join China-backed Asian bank
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry has signed a memorandum of understanding to join the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), which has a proposed $50-billion budget. The move was agreed upon by Indonesian President Joko Widodo and is pending two requests, including placing the bank's headquarters in Jakarta and increasing Indonesia's role in the institution. The US views the AIIB as a challenge to Western-dominated financial institutions, and Indonesia's participation is seen as a significant development in the region's economic landscape.

site_title: Singapore banking system sound, resilient to external shocks: MAS
summary: Singapore's banking system remains sound and resilient to external shocks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The MAS annual Financial Stability Review found that asset quality is healthy, capital adequacy positions are well above regulatory requirements, and liquidity positions are sound. The banking system can meet regulatory capital requirements even under severe stress conditions. However, the MAS warned that a potential tightening in foreign currency funding and liquidity could pose risks that require close monitoring. The central bank will continue to assess risks and take action as needed to maintain financial stability.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime triples net profit to US$45.3m for FY2014
summary: Mermaid Maritime reported a tripled net profit of US$45.3 million for FY2014, driven by strong demand for its services and a significant contribution from associate company Asia Offshore Drilling Limited. The company's order book reached US$470 million, with revenue increasing 16.1% to US$313 million. Net asset value per share rose to 0.40 US cents, and a final dividend of US$0.0047 per share was declared. CEO Chalermchai Mahagitsiri attributed the success to the company's focus on shallow-water fields, which are less affected by oil price volatility.

site_title: Malaysia to retain and prop up Sedition Act, says PM
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that the Sedition Act, a law criticized for inhibiting freedom of speech, will be retained and strengthened. The 1948 law, intended to prevent racial tensions and social unrest, will now defend Islam's sanctity and penalize those criticizing the sultans. The decision reverses a 2012 pledge to repeal the law, sparking criticism from rights groups and lawyers. Najib's move is seen as an attempt to silence opposition and undermine the ruling coalition, which has lost power in two consecutive elections.

site_title: S-Reits in better position now to withstand funding shocks: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) states that S-Reits are better equipped to withstand funding shocks due to improved debt management. Unlike during the 2009 Global Financial Crisis, S-Reits have increased their debt maturity to 3.2 years, spread out over a longer period, and used derivatives to convert floating-rate borrowings to fixed rates. Bank loans to S-Reits are less than 3% of total non-bank lending, and the risk of indirect spillovers through S-REIT sponsors is considered low. MAS will continue to monitor the sector's resilience.

images.alt_text: S-REITS, or Singapore's real estate investment trusts, are better placed to withstand funding shocks today than during the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) period, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said in its annual Financial Stability Review on Thursday.

site_title: Australia mulls tighter foreign property investment rules
summary: Australia's parliamentary committee recommends strengthening foreign property investment rules amid concerns that local buyers are being squeezed out by foreign investors, particularly Chinese. The current framework's enforcement is deemed "severely lacking." The committee proposes 12 recommendations, including removing barriers for auditing, new penalties for breaching rules, and amending migration laws to inform the FIRB of temporary residents' departure. Chinese investment is estimated to reach Aus$40 billion over the next seven years, pushing up prices in the already expensive housing market.

site_title: Aluminium maker Norsk Hydro to up capex, sees higher metals prices
summary: Norsk Hydro, a leading aluminium producer, plans to increase its capital expenditure by 86% in 2015, driven by higher metal prices. The company expects earnings to rise due to the increasing prices, which have surged 53% this year. Aluminium prices have risen to over $2,100, and the premium for physical commodity has reached record levels. Hydro aims to cut costs further, with a total reduction of 5.2 billion Norwegian crowns over the next two years, and expects global demand growth of 3-4% in 2015.

images.alt_text: Norsk Hydro, one of the world's largest aluminium producers, will increase its capital expenditure by 86 per cent next year, and said it expected higher metal prices to lift earnings for aluminium producers.

site_title: Thai elections may be delayed until 2016: report
summary: Thailand's elections may be delayed until mid-2016, according to Finance Minister Sommai Phasee, citing a need for at least 18 months of peace and order. The junta, led by Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha, initially planned to hold polls in October 2015, but Sommai's comments suggest a possible delay. Critics accuse the military of using the protests as an excuse for a power grab, while the junta has stated martial law will only be lifted when the country has peace and order.

site_title: Active reforms seen helping Asian economies to stay resilient: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reports that Asian economies are expected to remain resilient due to active reforms and improved economic fundamentals. The MAS notes that external demand from the G3 (eurozone, UK, Japan, and US) has lifted Asia's economy, but downside risks remain. The outlook is mixed, with structural reforms and policy tightening constraining domestic demand. Sustained recovery in the G3 and economic stabilization in China are key drivers of Asia's economic momentum.

images.alt_text: ASIAN economies are expected to remain resilient amid active reforms by policy makers and improved economic fundamentals, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said in its annual Financial Stability Review on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 2.15 points to 3,347.51. Volume was 69.3 million shares worth S$96.0 million. The index had previously rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Update: Thai election pushed back to 2016: deputy PM
summary: Thai general election initially planned for 2015 has been delayed until 2016, according to Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan, citing opposition groups as the reason. The delay is part of a year-long reform plan aimed at ending the influence of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The military coup in May was followed by the scrapping of the constitution and the drafting of a new one, which is expected to be completed by the start of 2016. The delay has sparked criticism from human rights groups, who say Thailand has "fallen into an apparently bottomless pit" since the coup.

site_title: South Korea current account surplus expands in October
summary: South Korea's current account surplus increased to $9 billion in October, driven by rising exports of ships, memory chips, and steel. The country's accumulated surplus reached $70.6 billion, on track to meet or exceed the central bank's target of $84 billion for the year, a record high. Exports rose to $52.2 billion, while imports stood at $43.5 billion, resulting in a surplus of $8.7 billion in the goods account. The services account saw a deficit shrink to $250 million.
