summary: Japan's coal consumption is expected to remain near a record high in the year through March 2015 due to the prolonged shutdown of nuclear plants and a softer economy. Power utilities are stocking up on coal as cheaper fuel to meet demand, despite the country's efforts to reduce its reliance on the dirty fuel. Japan's coal consumption is expected to rise slightly in 2015, with a drop in 2016, but analysts predict it will remain high at around 30% of the country's electricity.

site_title: MetLife rolls out new digital platform in China as part of growth strategy
summary: MetLife Inc, the US' largest life insurer, launched a new digital platform in China as part of its growth strategy. The platform, called MetLife's Digital Ecosystem, integrates online and offline sales, service, and social channels, allowing consumers to easily purchase life insurance and protection products. The move is part of MetLife's plans to aggressively grow its business in Asia, where e-commerce is expected to reach $275 billion by 2016. The platform will be rapidly deployed across other Asian markets, making it a key differentiator for MetLife in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Shares flat; won firmer on weak US consumer sentiment
summary: South Korean shares remained flat on Wednesday, trading within a tight range, as market players weighed US consumer sentiment. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed 0.03% higher at 1,980.84 points. The won strengthened against the dollar, closing at 1,106.5 to the dollar, due to exporter demand for month-end settlements. Samsung Techwin shares plummeted 15% after the group sold its defense subsidiary and affiliates to Hanwha Group for $1.72 billion.

site_title: Japan's central bank hikes governor's pay for the 1st time in 9 years
summary: The Bank of Japan has given its governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, a 1.3% pay raise, the first in nine years, to 34.67 million yen (US$294,638) per year. The move is seen as part of the government's efforts to implement "Abenomics" and boost economic growth, as wages have been slow to rise at private-sector firms. The central bank cited the "general social situation" in setting the salary standards, aiming to make the policy work despite Japan's 15-year deflation period and 1% core consumer inflation.

site_title: New diagnostics development hub launched to improve healthcare treatment outcomes
summary: Singapore has launched the Diagnostics Development (DxD) Hub to improve healthcare treatment outcomes through rapid diagnosis and development of medical diagnostics devices. Led by A*STAR, the hub brings together clinicians, researchers, and industry professionals to develop clinically-proven diagnostic tools and solutions. The hub has partnered with public and private sectors, including multinational companies and start-ups, to accelerate the development of market-ready diagnostic devices. The launch marks a major boost to Singapore's biomedical research and aims to improve healthcare through the development of related solutions.

site_title: Singapore Oct factory output below forecast, up just 0.2%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded 0.2% in October, driven by a 22.5% increase in pharmaceuticals production. This offset contractions in electronics and transport engineering. Economists had expected a 0.6% rise, but the actual output fell short. The biomedical cluster grew 22.5%, while other clusters, such as precision engineering and chemicals, also saw significant growth. The general manufacturing cluster contracted 3.3%. The expansion was smaller than forecast, with industrial production up 2.6% month-on-month, excluding biomedical manufacturing.

site_title: HP fourth-quarter revenue drops on weak enterprise demand
summary: HP's fourth-quarter revenue dropped 2.5% to $28.41 billion, with declines in enterprise services, enterprise group, and printer business. The company's personal computer division grew 4%, but profit declined 5.7% to $1.33 billion. HP plans to split into two companies, separating its computer and printer businesses from its corporate hardware and services operations, and will eliminate 5,000 jobs. This move questions its ability to drive growth through the planned separation.

site_title: Dotcom claims he is broke, facing New Zealand jail
summary: Internet mogul Kim Dotcom claims he is broke and facing jail in New Zealand due to US$175 million in alleged piracy charges. He has spent US$10 million on legal costs and says he has no money left to defend himself at a bail hearing on Thursday. Dotcom's Megaupload operation has been shut down, and he is wanted for extradition to the US, where he faces internet piracy charges. He regrets his involvement in politics and admits his flamboyant lifestyle made him an easy target for prosecution.

site_title: Bank of England's Haldane: rates might stick at 3% : paper
summary: Bank of England chief economist Andrew Haldane said interest rates in Britain might stick at 3% after rising, below the pre-crisis levels of 5-6%. This is in line with previous statements from the Bank of England officials, who mentioned 3% as the normal level of the benchmark interest rate. Haldane attributed the potential rate cap to a gradual and limited increase in rates, and a slowdown in the euro zone and some businesses in the southwestern English city of Bristol.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Wednesday, following a lackluster lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 10.72 points to 23,833.19. The US economy's stronger-than-expected growth failed to stimulate buying, leading to a muted trading session.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened flat Wednesday, following a tepid lead from Wall Street with news that the US economy had grown more than expected unable to spur buying.

site_title: Asian countries need to focus on skills, scale and sustainability: Iswaran
summary: Asian countries need to focus on skills development, market scale, and sustainable economic policies to boost competitiveness. Minister S Iswaran emphasized the importance of investing in workforce skills, innovation, and global supply chain integration to achieve long-term sustainability. He also highlighted the need for sound environmental, social, and fiscal policies to ensure growth is sustainable and benefits the people. Benchmarking efforts, such as the SME productivity benchmarking exercise, can help policymakers formulate targeted policies to encourage firms to be more efficient.

site_title: Swiss to vote on immigration cut 'to save environment'
summary: The Swiss will vote on Sunday on an initiative to cut immigration numbers, citing environmental concerns. The Ecopop initiative claims the influx of foreigners is harming the country's landscape and green spaces, with nearly a quarter of the population being foreign nationals. The proposal aims to reduce the annual population growth rate to the European average, but the government and most parties have rejected it, labeling it xenophobic. A poll suggests 56% of voters will reject the initiative, but supporters believe it may underestimate support.

images.alt_text: The Swiss will once again head to the polls this weekend to decide whether to dramatically slash immigration numbers, this time in the name of saving the environment in a proposal opponents have labelled xenophobic.

site_title: India seeks to bolster regional power as South Asia leaders meet
summary: India is seeking to bolster its regional power as South Asian leaders meet in Kathmandu, amid growing Chinese influence in the region. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is holding talks with Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani, while his government has signed a $1 billion agreement to build a hydropower plant in Nepal, a move seen as a counter to China's investment in the region. However, tensions between India and Pakistan, a major obstacle to regional integration, are unlikely to be resolved, with Modi's government adopting a more aggressive stance on Pakistan.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened down 5.90 points on Wednesday, closing at 3,339.09. Volume reached 101.8 million shares worth S$208.0 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 71 to 54. This marks a reversal from the 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Australia working on new drift modelling for MH370 wreckage
summary: Australia is working on new drift modelling to expand the search area for MH370 wreckage. The initial analysis suggested debris could come ashore on Indonesia's Western Sumatra after 123 days, but current reports indicate debris may also wash up on the Australian coastline. The research aims to provide a wider area for debris to be discovered. An ongoing search, including surface and underwater efforts, has so far found no confirmed debris from the missing aircraft. The search area is focused on the "7th arc" near Exmouth, Western Australia, with over 6,900 sq km of sea floor already searched.

site_title: Broker's Take: DMG issues 'buy' call on Suntec Reit, target price S$2
summary: DMG Research has issued a "buy" call on Suntec Reit with a target price of S$2.00. The research house attributes the surge in trading volume to the Reit's inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Index from Wednesday onwards. Suntec Reit has seen a 25.6% year-to-date increase and is the best-performing Reit this year. DMG is optimistic about the Reit's asset enhancement initiatives and forecasts a 3.4% compound annual growth rate in distribution per unit over the next three years.

site_title: Broker's Take: Ezra's risks tilted more to the downside, says OCBC
summary: Ezra Holdings, a provider of offshore support services, has seen its share price drop by about 30% since September due to the decline in global oil prices. Despite delivering improved core earnings, the company faces more downside risks, including delays in project awards and repair and maintenance issues. Analysts from OCBC Investment Research believe Ezra needs to demonstrate sustained utilisation levels in its OSV division and secure order wins for its subsea segment to recover. The company's fair value estimate is set at S$0.77 per share, currently trading around S$0.76.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up after US data
summary: Asian markets were mostly higher on Wednesday following better-than-expected US economic growth data and news that Germany narrowly avoided recession. The US Commerce Department reported third-quarter growth of 3.9%, beating expectations, while Germany's eurozone economy expanded 0.1% in July-September. Despite a weak lead from Wall Street, Tokyo fell 0.27% due to a stronger yen, while Hong Kong, Sydney, and Shanghai rose. Analysts expect the dollar-yen pair to consolidate soon, with some predicting a pullback.

site_title: China considers suing "economic fugitives" in the US, official says
summary: China is considering suing individuals suspected of committing economic crimes who fled to the US and elsewhere, amid its anti-graft campaign. The move, led by President Xi Jinping, aims to recover billions of dollars in illicit funds. China tried to persuade the US to sign an extradition treaty but was met with resistance due to concerns over human rights and torture. China will instead prosecute suspects in the US or repatriate them through illegal immigration. The US has refused to sign an extradition treaty, citing concerns over China's judicial system and human rights record.

site_title: Parkway Pantai announces new senior staff appointments
summary: Parkway Pantai has announced the appointment of Kelvin Loh as senior vice-president of Parkway Hospitals Singapore, overseeing Gleneagles and Parkway East Hospitals to promote synergies. Loh will continue as CEO of Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital, with Choy Shook Yee promoted to COO.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, Olam, Accordia Golf Trust
summary: Suntec Reit joins the MSCI Singapore Index, replacing Olam International, which saw its shares surge to a seven-week high before being pared. Olam's shares climbed 7.1% to S$2.41 on November 13 after the Singapore Exchange queried the company about unusual trading activity. The company denied certainty on possible acquisitions or sales.

site_title: Australia: Shares outperform, NZ index moves off 2-week low
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Wednesday, rebounding from a two-week slump, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 47.8 points to 5,382.6. The technology and industrial sectors led the gain, with Resolute Mining and Karoon Gas Australia being top performers. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark NZX50 index rose 0.4%, climbing off a two-week low. The Australian market is expected to continue its recovery, with analysts attributing the recent sell-off to "bargain hunters" and no particular reason for the downturn.

site_title: Hanwha Group to acquire Samsung chemical, defence unitsL: source
summary: Hanwha Group will acquire Samsung Techwin Co Ltd and three other Samsung Group affiliates, including Samsung Total Petrochemicals, Samsung General Chemicals, and Samsung Thales, a joint venture with Thales. The acquisition is valued at more than 2 trillion won (S$2.34 billion). The deal is part of Hanwha's expansion into the defence sector and chemical industries. No further details on the acquisition were provided by the companies involved.

site_title: Singapore economy seen having 'continued sub-par performance': ANZ
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a "continued sub-par performance" due to a lack of visibility for domestic demand growth, according to ANZ's chief economist Glenn Maguire. Consumer confidence rose 0.7 point to 120.9 in November, with 45% expecting "good times" financially over the next five years. However, respondents expressed concerns about supply-side restructuring and its impact on their personal finances, with 29% expecting their families to be "better off" financially in a year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.34%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.34% lower on Wednesday, following a brief advance of the dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 59.65 points to 17,347.97. Traders expect the benchmark index to trade in a narrow range. Despite the yen's fall against the dollar, which has boosted Japanese exporters, analysts predict a consolidation point in the currency markets, potentially leading to a pullback in the dollar-yen pair.

site_title: YuuZoo says constantly in talks on potential tie-ups in reply to query on price surge
summary: YuuZoo Corporation attributed its sudden share price surge to ongoing discussions on potential partnerships, despite being unaware of any undisclosed information. The social media and e-commerce company reported a 38% revenue growth and a positive outlook for Q4 and beyond. YuuZoo's chairman and CEO, Thomas Zilliacus, stated that existing agreements and new discussions with clients could generate growth and recurring income. The company's shares rose 9% to S$0.60, with over 36 million shares traded, making it the fifth most actively traded stock on the Singapore bourse.

site_title: BlackBerry courts iPhone users with cash
summary: BlackBerry is offering up to $400 cash back and a $150 gift card to customers trading in their iPhones for its new Passport smartphone, available in Canada and the US until February 13. This promotion marks BlackBerry's first attempt to compete with Apple since launching a turnaround plan last year. Analysts describe the move as "desperate," while investors seem pleased with the boost to the company's share price. The move aims to win back key corporate users after BlackBerry was largely knocked out of the consumer smartphone market.

site_title: Samsung sells defence, petrochemical units for US$1.7b
summary: Samsung Group sold stakes in four affiliates, including Samsung Techwin and Samsung General Chemicals, for $1.7 billion to the Hanwha conglomerate. The sale is part of Samsung's restructuring efforts ahead of generational ownership succession. This marks the first sale of Samsung affiliates since 1997 and aims to focus on key profit-making units such as electronics and finance. The deal is expected to be finalized in the first half of next year.

site_title: Discover Financial sues Visa over anti-competetive card practices
summary: Discover Financial Services Inc. sued Visa Inc. on Tuesday, alleging anti-competitive practices in its debit card business. Discover claims Visa has undermined competition, harming rival debit networks, merchants, and consumers, and seeks compensation for lost profit. The lawsuit, filed through Pulse Network LLC, requires debit cardholders to authorize transactions with a personal identification number (PIN), while most Visa transactions use customer signatures. Visa representatives were unavailable for comment outside regular business hours.

site_title: Tesco shareholders sue over profits overstatement
summary: Tesco shareholders plan to sue the British supermarket giant for £263 million in compensation over profit overstatements, which sent its stock tumbling. Directors and senior management are accused of being "reckless" about the overstatement. The lawsuit will be issued in the High Court in London within six months, despite a pending Serious Fraud Office investigation. The move follows a series of troubles for Tesco, including a chair resignation and a significant share price drop, with US investor Warren Buffett describing his investment as a "huge mistake".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.95 points to 1840.52. The index saw 30.95 million lots traded worth RM11.72 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 99 to 61.

images.alt_text: Malaysia share prices opened higher on Wednesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 1.95 points to 1840.52.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Reit, Triyards Holdings, and Riverstone Holdings received updates from brokers. Keppel Reit will acquire a one-third interest in MBFC Tower 3 for S$1.248 billion, increasing gearing to 43.8%. Triyards' orderbook is boosted with the recent Ezion warrant subscription, potentially adding US$150 million. Riverstone Holdings maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.21, citing the potential for higher-than-expected cleanroom glove volume and ASPs.

site_title: British banks' rotten culture will take a generation to fix: think tank
summary: A British think tank report states that the rotten culture within British banks will take a generation to fix, costing them 38.5 billion pounds in fines and compensation over 15 years due to scandals such as mis-selling of loan insurance and complex interest-rate hedging products. The aggressive sales culture, which led to 27 billion pounds in losses from mis-selling payment protection insurance, must be addressed from the top down to correct the toxic culture. Recommendations include the Banking Standards Review Council reporting annually to parliament's Treasury Committee.

site_title: Sony Pictures network reportedly hit by hackers
summary: Sony Pictures' computer network has been hit by a cyberattack, with hackers threatening to release key information from the entertainment division. The attack allegedly started with a single server being compromised, and the hackers have demanded unspecified demands from Sony. A large file containing spreadsheets and passwords was leaked, and the hackers warned that if demands aren't met, the data will be released. Sony's website appears to be functioning normally, and the company has confirmed the breach but is working to resolve the issue. The hackers claim to be affiliated with the group "Guardians of Peace."

site_title: US senators call for airbag data from embattled parts maker Takata
summary: US Senators Jay Rockefeller and Bill Nelson have called on Takata, a Japanese car parts maker, to provide 14 years of records and data on its faulty airbags. The senators expressed dissatisfaction with the company's top official, Hiroshi Shimizu, after he gave insufficient answers during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing. The senators' request comes amid ongoing investigations into Takata's airbag recalls and potential safety risks.

site_title: South Korea Nov consumer sentiment index slips to 14-month low
summary: South Korea's key consumer sentiment index dropped to its 14-month low of 103 in November, according to the Bank of Korea. This is the second consecutive month of decline, illustrating the struggle to lift domestic consumption. The index, which measures consumer sentiment, fell below the neutral line, indicating a decrease in positive sentiment. Retail sales data also showed a decline in October, with consumers showing little reason to spend. Policymakers attribute low inflation to supply-side factors, but the data suggests ongoing challenges in boosting consumption.

site_title: EU unveils details of Juncker investment plan
summary: The European Union unveiled a 300-billion-euro investment plan to boost its flatlining economy, with the European Fund for Strategic Investment receiving 21 billion euros. The plan, led by new Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker, aims to increase the economy's net effect to 315 billion euros. The plan relies on re-engineering existing funds without new money, focusing on private-sector driven projects with a "real added value" for the European economy. The fund is expected to be operational by mid-2015, with a team of financial experts deciding projects based on their advancement and likelihood of attracting private investors.

site_title: HSBC unit fined US$12.5m for unregistered US services
summary: HSBC's Swiss private banking arm, HSBC Private Bank, agreed to pay US$12.5 million for violating US rules requiring registration of cross-border brokerage services. The unit amassed 368 US clients and collected fees for conducting securities transactions without registered investment advisers or broker-dealers. This settlement follows a formal investigation and comes amid other financial issues, including a French tax fraud probe and charges in Brussels for fraud and money-laundering.

images.alt_text: A Swiss unit of British bank HSBC has agreed to pay US$12.5 million (S$16.26 million) for flouting US rules requiring registration of cross-border brokerage services, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Tuesday.

site_title: Indonesian smallholders hit hard by palm oil prices at 5-year low
summary: Indonesian smallholder farmers, who account for 40% of the country's palm oil output, are facing significant challenges due to a 5-year low in palm oil prices. The low prices are forcing farmers to cut back on fertilizers, pesticides, and replanting, which will reduce output by around 5% from next year. This could lead to sell-outs to major producers, further exacerbating the issue. The impact of reduced smallholder output could also shave 5% from total production.

site_title: Mexico hit by slow growth despite its booming car industry, rising exports
summary: Mexico's booming automobile industry is generating significant export revenue, but it has failed to improve the living standards of workers, such as 37-year-old Esmeralda Velazquez, who earns $295 per month. Despite the industry's growth, pay raises have barely kept pace with inflation, leaving workers struggling to afford basic necessities. The country's slow economic growth is a concern, particularly for workers in the industry who are not benefiting from the sector's success.

site_title: India, US hold first formal trade talks in four years
summary: The US and India held their first formal trade talks in four years, focusing on agriculture, services, manufacturing, and intellectual property rights. No breakthroughs were reported, but a work schedule was set to follow up on talks, with US Trade Representative Michael Froman expressing cautious optimism. The talks aimed to capitalize on the resolution of a global trade dispute and welcomed India's "Make in India" drive, while urging the country to keep its market open and ensure transparency for foreign investors. A robust work plan was set for the year ahead.

site_title: Jakarta banking on FDI for economic growth
summary: Indonesia's government is relying on foreign direct investment to boost economic growth, driven by efforts to roll back expensive entitlements and massive spending on infrastructure projects. Finance Minister Bambang Brojonegoro stated that investment will drive growth, rather than relying on consumers and foreign markets. The government has unveiled plans to expand power production, build new ports, and improve social services, which are expected to attract foreign capital and drive growth.

images.alt_text: The price hike was met with a swift increase in interest rates by 25 basis points to 7.75 per cent, the highest since 2009.

site_title: Troop force tripled in Ferguson as Obama condemns violence
summary: The US President Barack Obama condemned violence in Ferguson, Missouri, after a grand jury declined to charge a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager. In response, Missouri Governor Jay Nixon tripled the National Guard force to 2,200 to quell the unrest. The city experienced looting, arson, and racially-charged unrest, with fresh protests taking place nationwide. Obama's comments aimed to reassure the community, stating that "lives and property must be protected."

site_title: Yen gains as BOJ policymakers fret about QE costs
summary: The yen rose against the US dollar after Bank of Japan minutes showed concerns over expanding quantitative easing, which could increase the risk of financing the government deficit. Japanese exporters sold US dollars, while investors trimmed bearish yen positions. The yen has been under pressure since the BOJ expanded its stimulus program, but officials are voicing concern over its rapid depreciation. The euro also fell, with German growth data failing to boost sentiment.

site_title: How cloud computing will change the way people work
summary: Cloud computing is expected to significantly change the way people work, with increased collaboration and outsourcing, and companies specializing in their core strengths. Middle managers may face redundancy as companies adopt cloud computing, which enables easier sharing and data analysis. Big companies like Microsoft, Google, and Amazon are already adopting this model, with a focus on data-driven decision-making, rapid experimentation, and autonomous teams. To succeed, companies will need to balance specialization with customer focus and local partnerships, and will need to adapt to a faster-paced, data-driven work environment.

site_title: Global headwinds may slow Singapore's growth
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to face headwinds in 2015, despite a surprise 2.8% Q3 GDP growth, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). The government's 2015 growth forecast of 2-4% may be lower than projected due to external risks, including a weak eurozone, US interest rate uncertainty, and a potential correction in China's real estate market. MTI expects Q4 growth to slow to 2.2% year-on-year, and economists warn of more downside risks than upside potential.

site_title: US: Wall St ends little changed after mixed data batch
summary: US stocks ended little changed on Tuesday, despite a stronger-than-expected third-quarter GDP growth, as soft consumer confidence and house price data tempered market gains. The US economy showed resilience, but the mixed data batch kept major indexes in a tight range, with low volume trading.

site_title: 'Casablanca' piano sold for US$3.4m
summary: A piano from the iconic 1942 film "Casablanca" was sold at auction for $3.4 million, including a 12% commission. The short, black-and-white upright piano, which was used in Rick's Café Américain, was sold alongside other movie memorabilia, including a Cowardly Lion costume and posters from "Do the Right Thing." The piano, which features a unique hinged lid and a wad of chewing gum, was deemed significant due to its central role in the film and its enduring popularity.

site_title: ECB easing prospects push eurozone yields to new record lows
summary: Eurozone bond yields reached new record lows on Tuesday, driven by European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's vow to lift inflation. Spanish 10-year yields fell below 2%, Irish yields below 1.5%, and Portuguese yields under 3%. Investors expect the ECB to expand asset buying to include sovereign debt, potentially pumping 1 trillion euros into the economy. Analysts predict significant falls in European high-yield debt, with some 20% trading at negative yields.

site_title: CapitaLand, KepLand likely to benefit from Beijing's rate cut
summary: Singapore developers CapitaLand and Keppel Land are expected to benefit from Beijing's latest lending rate cut, given their exposure to the Chinese residential market. The rate cut and relaxed mortgage restrictions could make housing more affordable and boost buyer sentiment. Analysts predict this could lead to increased demand for housing, benefiting the developers.

site_title: Sustainable strategies: Building businesses for the future
summary: The article emphasizes the need for businesses to adopt sustainable practices to ensure long-term growth and survival in the face of climate change and environmental scarcity. Singapore is cited as a leader in sustainability, with a 2030 goal of 80% of buildings certified as green and a target of water self-sufficiency by 2060. To achieve this, businesses must adopt a "triple bottom line" approach, considering social, ecological, and financial outcomes. The article concludes that sustainability must be embedded at the heart of every business operation, not just seen as a separate section, and that finance professionals have a key role in leading this shift.

site_title: Jokowi needs to deliver on promises about allocation of tax savings
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has implemented several cost-cutting measures since taking office, including slashing the Cabinet's travel and meeting budget by 40% and increasing retail gasoline and diesel prices by nearly 31%, saving around $11.5 billion in subsidies. The move, which aims to free up funds for infrastructure, education, and healthcare, has been largely accepted by the public, despite potential risks of strikes and protests. Widodo campaigned on a pledge to reduce fuel subsidies, which cost Indonesia over $20 billion annually, and has largely weathered the backlash, despite potential criticism and political attacks.

site_title: Pacific Andes shares hit by news of 4-for-5 rights issue
summary: Shares in Pacific Andes Resources Development plummeted 26% to S$0.08 after the company proposed a 4-for-5 rights issue to raise S$192.3 million. The proposed issue, fully underwritten, will use net proceeds for general working capital, reducing borrowings, and supporting a loan redemption. Pacific Andes chairman Ng Joo Siang said the funding will strengthen the company's equity base without increasing borrowings or interest expense.

site_title: Weak eurozone threatens global growth: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has warned that the weak eurozone economy poses a threat to global growth, urging more flexibility in fiscal rules for struggling EU members like France and Italy. The OECD cautioned that forcing these economies to meet the EU's deficit criteria could depress activity further and risk another recession. It also called for further stimulus in the eurozone to prop up growth, while lowering its forecast for global growth this year to 3.3% and for 2015 to 3.7%.

site_title: GIC and Indonesia's Rajawali Group to form property JV
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) and Indonesia's Rajawali Group are partnering to invest up to $500 million in joint property projects in Indonesia's Central Business District. The partnership, announced last year, has already led to the development of a 47-storey office tower, Capital Place. GIC is confident in Indonesia's long-term growth potential and sees this as a strategic move to deepen its relationship with Rajawali.

site_title: Sapphire acquiring China-based railway infrastructure firm
summary: Sapphire Corporation, a loss-making Singapore-based firm, is acquiring China-based railway infrastructure firm Ranken Infrastructure for 360 million yuan (S$75.9 million). This acquisition is part of Sapphire's turnaround strategy to grow through railway infrastructure and engineering projects, a sector seen as promising. The deal aims to help Sapphire achieve profitability.

images.alt_text: "We have been quietly working and meeting the local SOEs' managements to explore how we can participate and undertake the projects... via a public-private partnership (PPP) model." - Teh Wing Kwan

site_title: Economy expands 3.9% in Q3, exceeding previous forecast
summary: The US economy expanded 3.9% in Q3, exceeding previous forecasts, driven by gains in consumer spending and business investment. This marks the strongest six-month growth in a decade. Consumer spending grew at a 2.2% annualized rate, while corporate profits rose less than in the prior three months. However, a decline in consumer confidence and a drop in the Conference Board's index to a five-month low may indicate that the economy's momentum is slowing.

site_title: Zhou's PBOC past shows multiple policy moves
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has cut interest rates for the first time in four years, lowering the one-year lending rate to 5.6% and the one-year deposit rate to 2.75%. Governor Zhou Xiaochuan has a history of consecutive policy moves, and experts predict further rate cuts ahead. Economists forecast the lending rate to fall to 4.5% by the end of next year, while the deposit rate may drop to 2.45%. The move signals deeper concern over China's economic outlook, which is struggling with a property slump and factory-gate deflation.

site_title: Brazil bribery probe hits major builders economy depends upon
summary: Brazil's corruption scandal at state-owned oil company Petrobras is threatening to derail the country's economy, which is already in recession. The scandal, dubbed "The Car Wash," has led to investigations and arrests of major builders, including Odebrecht and Queiroz Galvao, which hold billions of dollars in Petrobras and government contracts. Delays to infrastructure projects could hurt industries such as manufacturing and farming, making it harder for Brazil to boost growth. Experts warn that a slowdown in projects could have a significant impact on GDP, potentially cutting growth by 0.5 percentage points.

site_title: Russian economy seen expanding 0.7-0.8% in 2014
summary: Russia's economy is expected to grow 0.7-0.8% in 2014, but next year's 1.2% growth forecast may need revision, according to Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev. The minister attributes the potential revision to external factors, including the Ukraine crisis and a slump in oil prices. The Russian central bank expects 0.1% growth next year, citing economic damage from Western sanctions. The government is also considering limiting state support to oil producer Rosneft and opposing the sale of rival oil company Bashneft to Rosneft.

site_title: Xiaomi delays overseas push amid plans to boost production
summary: Xiaomi delays plans to expand into five more countries, including Thailand, Russia, Mexico, Brazil, and Turkey, to boost production and focus on its largest overseas market, India. The Chinese smartphone maker is discussing manufacturing partnerships with Foxconn Technology Group in India and Brazil. Xiaomi aims to increase its production capacity in India to support its goal of reaching 200 million users globally. The company may also consider manufacturing in Indonesia, but for now, it will prioritize adding market by market, one at a time.

site_title: Honda may face record fine for under-reporting US claims
summary: Honda Motor Co may face a record fine of US$35 million for under-reporting over 1,700 claims of injury or death involving its cars to US regulators, according to an internal review. The company blames "inadvertent data entry or computer programming errors" for the failure, which spans 11 years. Honda has agreed to retraining and staffing changes, and will voluntarily include both written and oral claims in future early-warning reports. The investigation is ongoing, with no timetable for an agency decision, and experts predict a significant fine for Honda's failure to comply with US law.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust added to MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index
summary: Accordia Golf Trust has been added to the Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) Singapore Small Cap Index, replacing Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Stamford Land Corporation, Suntec Reit, and Swiber Holdings. The addition aims to enhance AG Trust's corporate profile and increase investors' familiarity with the Japan golf market. AG Trust's initial portfolio comprises 89 golf courses in Japan, with 86.4% located in the three largest metropolitan areas. The MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index represents approximately 14% of the free float-adjusted market capitalization of the Singapore equity universe, with a total return of 4.6% year-to-date.

site_title: DBS Vickers wins big in AsiaMoney's brokers poll
summary: DBS Vickers has been named the top broker in Singapore by Asiamoney's annual brokers survey. The firm outranked CIMB and RHB-OSK-DMG in terms of overall country research, execution, sales services, and events. CLSA took top spot for most independent research, while UBS, CLSA, and CIMB dominated the top three spots for best in sales trading. Notable research analysts from DBS Vickers, RHB-OSK-DMG, and CLSA won awards for market strategy, macro economics, and sector-specific coverage.

site_title: Kuroda defends aggressive monetary policy against critics
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's aggressive monetary easing policy, stating it will continue to pursue its 2% inflation target despite concerns about its impact on the yen and potential criticism of "monetizing" Japanese government debt. Kuroda emphasized the need to overcome Japan's deflationary mindset, citing the OECD's view that 2% annual inflation is optimal for economic growth. The BOJ's decision to expand its monetary easing operations was made despite some members' concerns about increasing the risk of the central bank financing the government's debt.

site_title: Blackstone plans factory homes for Aussie retirees
summary: Blackstone, the US's largest private-equity property investor, plans to invest A$150 million in National Lifestyle Villages Pty, a Perth-based company that develops manufactured retirement communities in Australia. The investment aims to tap the country's ageing population, where 10% of people live in these communities compared to less than 1% in the US. Blackstone's investment will significantly expand by the end of 2015, with opportunities to consolidate assets in the industry.

site_title: Civil servants to get 0.8-month year-end bonus
summary: Singapore's 82,000 civil servants will receive a year-end annual variable component (AVC) bonus of 0.8 month, totaling 2.3 months for the year, in addition to the traditional 13th-month bonus. The bonus is slightly lower than last year's package but higher than 2012. A minimum AVC payout of S$1,200 will be given to lower-wage officers, a signal of the government's commitment to helping this group of workers. The decision comes after close consultations with public sector union representatives and follows Singapore's forecasted 3% economic growth in 2014.

site_title: ADB warns of volatility in Asian financial markets
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) warns of potential volatility in Asian financial markets, urging governments in the region to prepare for a possible shift in US monetary policy. Emerging East Asian countries, including China, Indonesia, and the Philippines, are vulnerable to market fluctuations, which could affect asset prices and the health of financial firms. Despite this, local currency bond markets have expanded, with growth led by Indonesia, the Philippines, and China, and a 3.1% quarterly increase in bonds outstanding. The ADB advises governments to use the slow pace of US monetary tightening to make needed reforms and build resilience.

site_title: Mining malaise fuels world's worst junk bond losses
summary: Australia is experiencing the worst junk bond losses among major nations, with iron ore and coal prices plummeting to five-year lows due to a global supply glut and slowdown in Chinese demand. This has led to a 4.4% loss for Australian speculative-grade notes since December, with debt in Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, Australia's third-largest iron ore miner, falling 6.3%. Companies are cutting costs and reducing capital investment, affecting services providers and single-product miners.

site_title: Battle of the sexes: Bank of Thailand way ahead of Fed
summary: The Bank of Thailand, the central bank of Thailand, boasts a significant number of women in senior positions, with 31 out of 60 top executives and over half of its staff being women. This is attributed to a half-century policy of hiring and promoting women, starting in 1966. The bank's success in gender equality is also linked to education and family support, with women making up 54% of its employees and 52% holding PhDs. This contrasts with other central banks in developed nations, where women are underrepresented in senior roles.

site_title: Natas fair faces challenge from new rival event
summary: The National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (Natas) is facing a challenge from 24 travel agencies pulling out of its upcoming fair in March 2015, citing concerns over sliding visitorship, high exhibition fees, and lack of transparency. The agencies plan to launch a rival Outbound Travel Fair at the Marina Bay Sands Expo & Convention Centre, which will offer free admission and lower exhibition fees. The rival fair's organizers aim to attract 80% of Natas' sales, and the event's dates coincide with Natas' fair due to venue availability.

site_title: Malaysia's green sukuk gets Khazanah's debut boost
summary: Malaysia's state-owned sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd plans to issue the nation's first sukuk under socially responsible investment (SRI) guidelines, boosting the government's green financing initiative. The ringgit-denominated Islamic bond is expected to be issued in the second half of 2015 to finance expansion in education or renewable energy businesses. This move is seen as a positive development for the Islamic finance industry, which is now the world's biggest Syariah-compliant debt market, and is expected to introduce a new asset class.

site_title: Customer satisfaction declines for S'pore tourism and F&B sectors
summary: Singapore's tourism and food & beverage sectors saw a decline in customer satisfaction, with the F&B sector dropping 6.5% to 65.8 points and the tourism sector falling 7.3% to 69.1 points between 2013 and 2014. The decline was attributed to tourists and locals adapting to new business models, with tourists experiencing a significant decline in satisfaction, particularly in hotels and restaurants. The sectors' scores remained stable for locals, with a 6% slump in the tourism sector and a 0.6% dip in the F&B sector.

site_title: Bankers doubt Indonesia's liquidity rules will have desired effect
summary: Indonesia's new liquidity rules for banks may not boost lending growth as expected due to rising interest rates and a slowing economy. The central bank's decision to include bonds and securities in a lender's loan-to-deposit ratio aims to assess bank risk, but could instead curb credit demand. Experts doubt the rules will achieve their intended effect, citing the challenging economic environment.

site_title: India seeks private cash for rail lines
summary: India aims to attract up to $1 billion in private investment by 2017 to build vital rail links to ports, easing congestion that has delayed coal imports and contributed to a power supply crisis. This investment would more than double the $400 million attracted by the state-owned railways in the past decade. The government is allowing private companies to part-own rail lines for variable periods and taking on more financial risk, with the goal of reducing bottlenecks on the network and increasing capacity to meet rising imports.

site_title: Hagel's departure does not portend broader shake-up
summary: US President Barack Obama announced the resignation of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, but it does not signal a broader shake-up in his administration. Instead, it may represent the final triumph of a White House-centric approach to national security. Key figures, including National Security Adviser Susan Rice and Chief of Staff Denis McDonough, are expected to remain in their positions. The administration's focus on diplomacy, particularly in Iran talks, has strengthened the standing of Secretary of State John Kerry, who will play a central role in negotiating an Iran deal.

site_title: US airlines waive rebooking fees, winter delays set in
summary: US airlines have waived rebooking fees for flights affected by winter weather, including United, American, and Delta. United waived fees for travel through 23 northeastern airports, while American and Delta waived fees for 18 and 19 airports, respectively. The waiver applies to travel on Nov 26 and allows for rebooking flights through Nov 27. The move comes as a winter storm is expected to impact the north-east, with snowfall predicted for Chicago and other areas. This move aims to alleviate travel disruptions during the busy Thanksgiving holiday period, which is expected to see a 3% increase in air passengers.

images.alt_text: US airlines have waived their rebooking fees as winter weather struck the Chicago area and threatens the north-east as the Thanksgiving travel season approaches.

site_title: Barclays Wealth aims to double revenue in Asia by 2019
summary: Barclays Wealth aims to double its revenue in Asia by 2019, targeting markets such as Japan, China, and Indonesia. The bank plans to boost its sales force in the region by 25% over the next 12-18 months. Despite a 30% growth in revenue over the past six years, Barclays expects the Asian private banking space to consolidate, with fewer players in the market. The bank is cautious about acquisitions due to cultural clashes, and instead focuses on differentiating its services and increasing recurring revenues.

site_title: Fight fraud with six levels of authentication
summary: Singapore's financial markets could benefit from six levels of authentication to detect and prevent corporate fraud, similar to what is used in e-commerce. The current system is inadequate, with major cases like China Aviation Oil and OW Bunkers highlighting the need for stronger controls. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is urged to make six-party automatic authentication mandatory to ensure confidentiality and transparency in financial transactions. This measure could prevent future white-collar fraud and protect investors' hard-earned money.

site_title: Iranian nuclear talks process still precarious despite extension
summary: Iran and the P5+1 nations have agreed to extend their nuclear talks until end-June 2015, despite a failure to reach a landmark agreement before the November 24, 2014 deadline. Progress was made in Vienna, but prospects for a permanent agreement remain uncertain due to gaps between parties and opposition from conservatives in the US and Iran. The US Republican-controlled House of Representatives has passed legislation to levy additional sanctions, which could potentially torpedo the negotiating process. A deal could significantly disable Iran's potential to build nuclear weapons, but critics, including Israel and Canada, are likely to become more emboldened.

site_title: China mulls stricter tobacco control
summary: China is considering stricter tobacco control measures, including fines of up to 500 yuan for smoking in indoor public areas. The proposed law would require designated smoking areas, with exceptions for certain hospitals and social settings. The government is seeking public opinion on the draft law, which aims to curb smoking and reduce health costs. Over 90% of surveyed respondents support smoking bans in public places, and the tobacco industry generates billions in annual tax revenue. China's efforts to curb smoking come as the country faces rising health costs and increasing public support for tobacco control.

images.alt_text: SMOKERS who light up at indoor public areas could be fined as much as 500 yuan (S$106) and operators who don't stop them may have licences revoked under a proposed law as China considers stricter tobacco control.

site_title: Sony may sell camera parts to smartphone competitors
summary: Sony Corp plans to sell camera components to smartphone competitors, boosting revenue to 1.3-1.5 trillion yen (S$14.4 billion) by March 2018. The business will focus on sensors, camera modules, and memory storage, surpassing its current forecast of 890 billion yen. This move aims to capitalize on the growing smartphone market and maintain profit margins despite declining sales of its own Xperia models.

images.alt_text: Sony's chief executive officer Kazuo Hirai is culling the number of Xperia smartphones the company produces as it struggles to compete with Apple Inc and Samsung Electronics Co.

site_title: Westports shares surge over 4% after CIMB report cites catalysts
summary: Westports Holdings shares surged over 4% to RM3.42 apiece after CIMB released a report citing three catalysts: the start of the Ocean Three alliance, renewal of Investment Tax Allowance, and government approval to raise port tariffs. CIMB valued Westports' shares at RM4.57 each and predicted a 10% compounded annual growth rate in core earnings if port tariffs are raised 30% in 2016. The report also highlighted the port operator's growing interest and defensive stock with reasonable growth rates.

site_title: GM's top executives, staff scour social media seeking car defects
summary: General Motors is taking a proactive approach to addressing safety concerns by scouring social media for customer complaints and quality issues. The company's top executives and staff are monitoring social media 24/7 to identify potential defects before they become widespread. This is a change from the past, where GM's engineers tried to avoid issuing a safety recall for a faulty ignition switch. GM has encouraged employees to alert management if they see possible recalls and has even called customers to gather feedback.

site_title: More protests feared in St Louis after jury clears policeman in teen's shooting
summary: Protests erupted in St Louis, Missouri, after a grand jury cleared a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. Rioting led to the burning of about a dozen buildings, with 61 people arrested. Protests also occurred in several other cities, including New York, Chicago, and Washington, DC. Despite calls for calm from officials, the violence continued, with police using tear gas and flash-bang canisters to disperse protesters. The grand jury's decision has sparked widespread outrage and calls for accountability, with the Brown family expressing disappointment and a desire for equal justice.

site_title: China state firms' profit growth quickens slightly in Jan-Oct
summary: China's state-owned firms saw a 6.1% increase in combined profits to 2.1 trillion yuan (S$445.64 billion) from January to October 2014. Despite a slight profit growth, factories continue to struggle with falling prices and sluggish demand. The Ministry of Finance attributed the increase to improved cost control and better management. However, the growth is unlikely to be sustained, and policymakers face pressure to address the country's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Arrests, scuffles as Hong Kong police try to clear protest site
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 80 protesters, including veteran dissident Leung Kwok-hung, as they tried to block authorities from clearing a pro-democracy protest site in Mongkok. The arrests came after scuffles broke out as protesters refused to leave the area, which has been the scene of violent clashes since September. The arrests follow a court injunction allowing authorities to dismantle sections of the camp, and public support for the movement has been waning. The protesters, who demand free leadership elections, are split on their next move amid fruitless talks with officials.

site_title: Remisiers must up their service to remain of value
summary: Remisiers in Singapore are facing declining business due to the rise of online trading, with more than 50% of trades now done via the internet. This shift has led to a decrease in phone calls to dealing rooms, but remisiers need to adapt to remain valuable. They should focus on guiding clients on a wider range of investment products, including those that are not just plain vanilla equities, to add value and stay relevant in the market. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has already addressed some of these issues through a Consultative Paper, and remisiers should move on from debating these topics.

site_title: Profiting by going against bullish market
summary: A hedge fund called Universa Investments, founded by Mark Spitznagel, has reportedly earned strong returns despite the stock market's prolonged bull run. The fund's strategy involves betting against the market in anticipation of an economic and financial collapse, which Spitznagel believes will occur when the Federal Reserve stops supporting the economy. Universa's strategy involves pairing bearish bets with broad holdings of stocks, resulting in gains of 10% this year and a 30% return last year, outperforming the S&P 500.

site_title: Sabana Reit granted S$243m murabaha facilities
summary: Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Reit has secured S$243 million in murabaha facilities from several banks to refinance and roll over existing debt. The new facilities will fully utilize existing debt of S$120 million, a five-year commodity murabaha contract of up to S$75 million, and a three-year revolving commodity murabaha facility of up to S$48 million. This financing arrangement aims to provide stability and liquidity for the firm.

site_title: Labour costs up again, productivity still falling
summary: Singapore's overall unit labour cost rose 4.4% in Q3, its fastest pace in over a year, as restructuring policies continue to impact the economy. Labour productivity contracted 0.8% from a year ago, but export-oriented sectors saw productivity gains. Domestically-oriented sectors such as retail, construction, and food services saw declines, with lower consumer spending potentially constraining growth. Private consumption expenditure growth slowed to 1.2% in Q3, a near two-year low.

site_title: Net buys notch up S$1.9b
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore stocks in the three months to Nov 19, with net buys of S$1.9 billion compared to net sells of S$733.4 million. In the consumer goods sector, net buys of S$335.2 million outweighed sells of S$63.4 million, with Thai Beverage Public Company being the top buy at S$298.1 million. The data provides insight into where fund managers are focusing their attention and can help analyze market trends.

site_title: Forecast drop in non-oil domestic exports for 2014 narrowed to 1-1.5%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are expected to drop 1-1.5% in 2014, narrowing from an initial forecast of 1-2%. However, NODX is forecast to grow 1-3% in 2015, driven by higher global economic and trade growth. The third quarter saw a 1.1% year-on-year increase, driven by non-electronic shipments. Oil domestic exports are expected to fall 3.3% in 2014, while oil re-exports are expected to decline 19.4%. Total trade is projected to expand 0-2% in 2015.

site_title: Securing growth through talent is key for Lockton Inc
summary: Lockton Inc, the world's largest privately-owned insurance broker, attributes its success to attracting the right talent. Since joining in 1997, CEO John Lumelleau has grown the company from six US offices and 700 associates to 64 global offices and 5,300 associates. Lockton aims to expand its digital commerce capabilities, including its e-commerce platform, Lockton Marketplace, and plans to add talent in Asia to boost its cyberspace and executive risk financial services capabilities. The company expects to generate close to $1 billion in revenue from its US business and $250 million from other countries, with a growing presence in Asia, Australia, Latin America, and South America.

site_title: 7,500 HDB flats launched, including the first ones in Tampines North
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched its last Build To Order (BTO)-cum-Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercises for 2014, offering 7,568 flats in mature and non-mature towns. The launch includes Tampines North's first 3Gen flats, with priority for first-timers and eligible couples. The HDB also introduced the Enhancement of Married Child Priority Scheme, reserving 30% of BTO flats for first-timer families and 15% for second-timer families. This exercise brings the total BTO flat supply in 2014 to 22,455 units, with a total of 29,129 flats offered for sale to Singaporeans.

site_title: Top Twitter official suffers a 'DM fail' moment
summary: Twitter CFO Anthony Noto accidentally tweeted about a plan to buy a company, including a meeting in mid-December, before deleting the message. The intended recipient and company are unclear. The incident, known as a "DM fail," highlights Twitter's struggles with private and public messaging. Noto, an early Twitter adopter, had previously joined the platform in 2009. The slip-up comes as Twitter aims to improve its messaging system, which was previously criticized for mistakes like this in 2010.

images.alt_text: Twitter has no further comment on the subject of Mr Noto's inadvertently publicised tweet

site_title: JTC releases 3 industrial sites in Tuas, Tampines for Business-2 development
summary: JTC Corporation has released three industrial sites in Tuas and Tampines for Business-2 development. The sites, totaling 1.6 hectares, were launched as part of the second-half 2014 industrial government land sales (iGLS) programme. The sites, on Tuas South Street 11 and Tampines Industrial Drive, are expected to attract average-size industrialists and contractor-developers, with top bids ranging from S$65-100 per square foot per plot ratio. The move aims to make industrial property more affordable and reduce speculation.

site_title: China stock market being held hostage by a few IPO plans
summary: China's $4.3 trillion stock market is being held hostage by a few IPO plans, with investors chasing $1.3 billion in funding. The Shanghai Composite Index has fallen 0.7% in the run-up to bidding, but risen 3.3% after each of the six previous IPO periods. Mainland investors are placing 1.6 trillion yuan in bids, driving up interest rates and prompting the central bank to inject cash into the banking system. The pattern of restrained performance before bidding and subsequent rally is expected to repeat, with investors borrowing money to amplify their bids.

images.alt_text: As brokers take orders this week for the next 11 IPOs, investors are bracing for short-term swings in shares.

site_title: Obama's foreign policy goals more distant now
summary: US President Barack Obama's foreign policy goals have become more distant due to the rising power of ISIS, Russia, and China, and the erosion of US global positions. His initial aim to remake the Middle East and improve ties with the Muslim world has stalled, with negotiations with Iran reaching a deadlock. The Republicans now control both the House and Senate, making it harder for Obama to achieve his foreign policy goals, including a diplomatic detente with Iran. The Republican-led Senate may pass resolutions imposing new economic sanctions on Iran, potentially sabotaging Obama's Iran policy.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals down in Oct
summary: UK mortgage approvals for house purchase fell to 37,076 in October, the lowest number since May last year, according to the British Bankers' Association. This represents a 16% decline from the same period last year and a quarter below the peak reached in January. Despite this, unsecured consumer credit lending grew at an annual rate of nearly 3%, its fastest since the 2008 financial crisis, indicating consumer confidence in the economy.

site_title: China options traders more bullish
summary: China's options traders are the most bullish on record, driven by a surprise interest-rate cut and the debut of the Shanghai-Hong Kong exchange link. The People's Bank of China reduced the one-year lending rate by 0.4 percentage point to 5.6% percent, effective Nov 22. This move is expected to be followed by further reductions to shore up growth in the world's second-largest economy. The Shanghai Composite Index is set to post a seventh straight monthly gain, the longest winning streak since 2009, and ETFs are seen as a better way to bet on Chinese stocks than the Hong Kong-Shanghai bourse program.

site_title: Surprise late surge in Suntec Reit trading volumes
summary: Suntec Reit's trading volumes surged on Tuesday, with 180.2 million units changing hands, a nine-fold increase from Monday. The unit price rose three cents to reach a one-year high of S$1.935. Analysts attributed the surge to the Reit's inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Index, prompting funds to rebalance their portfolios. The unusual trading volume has raised questions, but the explanation is likely due to the Reit's new inclusion.

images.alt_text: Fountain of Wealth at Suntec City Mall. Some dealers were taken aback on Tuesday when transactions involving a huge volume of 129.3 million units in Suntec Reit took place just minutes after the 5pm normal closing, sending the counter to the top of the most active stock list.

site_title: Bayer considering sale of its diabetes device business
summary: Bayer is exploring the sale of its diabetes device business, working with Credit Suisse Group AG, as the company focuses on faster-growing medicines. Private-equity firms such as Cinven Ltd, EQT Partners AB, and Triton Advisers Ltd may consider bidding for the unit, valued between $1.62 billion and $2 billion. Bayer CEO Marijn Dekkers is selling peripheral units to focus on life-sciences businesses, including a planned listing of its plastics unit and potential acquisitions in veterinary medicines.

site_title: Hong Kong police spray protesters, arrest 80 in bid to clear street
summary: Hong Kong police used pepper spray to disperse protesters, arresting 80 people on Tuesday as they attempted to clear a city street blocked for nearly two months. The protesters, who are protesting against China's restrictions on who will be allowed to stand in the city's 2017 leadership elections, were ordered to disperse but refused. The arrests were made for criminal contempt of a court order, assaulting police, and unlawful assembly. The move comes after a high court granted injunctions to allow authorities to start dismantling sections of the protest camps.

site_title: WeChat uses Chinese students in US to spread its usage
summary: WeChat, a popular Chinese mobile-messaging app, is leveraging thousands of US-based Chinese students to promote its usage in the country. The app has seen a significant increase in US users, from 50,000 in 2013 to 3 million, with some students using it to connect with friends and promote church events. WeChat's efforts have been bolstered by targeted marketing campaigns, including a two-week program at the University of California at Los Angeles, which resulted in increased downloads and brand awareness.

site_title: US household debt edges higher in Q3: survey
summary: US household debt rose 0.7% to $11.7 trillion in Q3, driven by auto and student loans, and credit card balances. This marks a reversal of the "deleveraging period" since 2010, according to New York Fed economist Wilbert van der Klaauw. Mortgage originations increased to $337 billion, while auto loan originations hit a 20-year high. Household debt remains 7.6% below its peak six years ago, when the financial crisis occurred.

site_title: Designers lauded for cutting-edge works
summary: Three Singaporean designers, Larry Peh, Tan Kok Hiang, and Peter Tay, have been awarded the nation's highest honor, the President's Design Award, for their cutting-edge works. The award ceremony recognized their contributions to architecture, design, and social commentary. Peh's work includes commercial and personal projects, such as the Smoking Table, which parodies public smoking zones. Tan and Tay were praised for their versatility and ability to incorporate local design elements into their architecture. The awards also honored 11 other projects, including the Sandcrawler building and the SUTD Gridshell pavilion, which were selected from 133 nominations.

site_title: Taking precautions and carrying on despite Ebola
summary: The global shipping industry has taken precautions to combat the Ebola virus in West Africa, with the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) working with the World Health Organization (WHO) to monitor the situation and provide timely information. IMO recommends that ships continue to operate as normal, with no general ban on international travel or trade. However, some countries have taken a harder line, refusing access or medical assistance to merchant ships suspected of having Ebola symptoms. Shipping companies and organizations have provided direct assistance, including medical supplies and training programs, to help combat the spread of the disease.

site_title: Singapore leads emerging East Asia in Q3 bond market growth
summary: Singapore's local currency bond market led emerging East Asia in Q3 growth, expanding 4.7% quarter-over-quarter and reaching S$322 billion. The region's cross-border issuances remained active, with China-based corporates selling debt in Hong Kong dollars and Singapore dollars. The ADB warned of rising risks, citing a stronger dollar and US interest rate hike, which could pose problems for emerging East Asia's local currency bond markets. The region's local currency bond market expanded to US$8.2 trillion, with government bonds recording modest gains of 2.8% quarter-over-quarter.

site_title: United States says EU's Google case should not be politicised
summary: The US has expressed concern over a draft EU plan to break up Google, stating that politicians should not influence the antitrust inquiry into the world's most popular internet search engine. The US Mission to the EU said the process should be based on objective and impartial findings, not politicization. The European Commission has been investigating Google for four years, with no conclusion yet reached.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.79 points to close at 1,838.56, driven by gains in the market. 2.09 billion lots valued at RM2.46 billion were traded, with 308 gainers and 476 losers.

site_title: Cost pressure rising on German banks: Moody's
summary: German banks face intense pressure to cut costs, with Moody's stating they may avoid layoffs by increasing efficiency through reorganisation and automation. Despite being some of Europe's least efficient banks due to high fixed costs and weak IT infrastructure, German banks may catch up with peers in countries like France and Belgium. Moody's warns downgrades for German bank debt are likely in the coming year due to government bailouts being less likely. However, improving financial conditions are attributed to Germany's economic performance.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks rise on strong US growth
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday after the Commerce Department raised its estimate for third-quarter US economic growth to 3.9%, stronger than the initial 3.5% estimate. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all gained, with the Nasdaq jumping 1.20% to a record high. Analysts had expected a revised downward estimate, and Tuesday's gains added to records set on Monday. The strong economic growth is attributed to business investment and consumer spending picking up.

site_title: US housing seen steady in early 2015; price gains slower
summary: US home sales are expected to grow moderately in early 2015, driven by a slowdown in price rises and a strengthening labor market. However, sales remain constrained by slow household formation. Housing activity is regaining ground after stalling in 2013, but it's not yet a strong market, with young people delaying household formation.

site_title: Tourist satisfaction dives for Singapore's tourism and F&B sectors
summary: Customer satisfaction in Singapore's food & beverage and tourism sectors has declined, with the F&B sector's score dropping 6.5% to 65.8 points and tourism sector's score falling 7.3% to 69.1 points, compared to the same period last year. The decline is attributed mainly to lower tourist satisfaction, with scores dropping from 81.1 to 71.1 points. The lower scores may be a correction as companies transition to new business models, and consumers adapt to new norms in service delivery.

site_title: US-China climate change pact: Is it really significant?
summary: The US-China agreement on climate change, signed in 2014, has been hailed as a significant political triumph, but its impact on the world's climate is uncertain. China has pledged to reach peak emissions by 2030 and increase non-fossil fuel use to 20%, while the US committed to reducing emissions by 26-28% by 2025. Environmentalists see the agreement as a major step forward, but critics argue that it is voluntary and lacks enforcement mechanisms, making it unclear whether China's emissions will actually decrease. The agreement also fails to address the root cause of climate change, which is the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and does not provide a clear path to transitioning away from fossil fuels.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls in November to lowest since June
summary: US consumer confidence fell to its lowest level since June, dropping to 88.7 in November, according to a private sector report. Economists expected a reading of 96.0. Optimism waned in the short-term outlook for business conditions and jobs, with the "jobs hard to get" index rising to 29.2% and the "jobs plentiful" index falling to 16.0%. The drop is attributed to consumers' less positive views of the job market and their short-term outlook.

site_title: China's Tencent partners with HBO for TV show streaming
summary: Chinese Internet firm Tencent Holdings Ltd partners with HBO to stream its TV shows, including "Game of Thrones", "True Detective", and "Boardwalk Empire", in China. The partnership enables Tencent to distribute groundbreaking programming through its robust technology platform. However, the move comes as Chinese government regulators have stepped up oversight of the industry, ordering TV shows to be taken down and imposing limits on foreign content. The TV series and films are subject to approval from regulators and may need to be censored before broadcast.

images.alt_text: Chinese Internet firm Tencent Holdings Ltd is partnering with Time Warner Inc's HBO network to stream its TV shows, which are known for their provocative content and may draw scrutiny from the country's authorities.

site_title: India needs to grow at 7-8% a year: junior finance minister
summary: India's junior Finance Minister Jayant Sinha stated the country needs to grow at 7-8% annually to create more jobs and strengthen the rupee currency. India's economic growth likely slowed to 5% in the three months to September, putting pressure on the central bank to cut interest rates. This comes as the country faces challenges in achieving its growth targets, with slower growth rates in recent quarters.

site_title: Gap in China-Hong Kong trade numbers narrows, but still high
summary: China-Hong Kong trade numbers narrowed in October, with imports rising 4.4% to HK$179 billion and exports increasing 24% to US$32.74 billion. The gap between the two figures narrowed to US$9.67 billion, still above the average for the year. Analysts say speculative money disguised as trade remains rampant, fueled by interest rate differences and China's drive to promote its currency in global trade. Authorities are stepping up investigations into fake trade practices, but the gap is expected to remain.

site_title: China to invest US$10.8b on four new railway lines
summary: China has approved construction of four new railway lines worth US$10.8 billion, as the government aims to boost investment and tackle slowing economic growth. The projects, valued at 66.2 billion yuan, will run in four provinces: Jilin, Chongqing, Shaanxi, and Inner Mongolia. This is the third new railway investment approved by the government this month, following a rate cut by China's central bank to support the economy. The move is seen as a key step to stimulate investment and drive growth in the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: China has approved construction of four railway lines worth 66.2 billion yuan, or US$10.8 billion, the country's top economic planning agency said on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.21% down
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.21% on Tuesday, following a previous day's rally triggered by China's interest rate cut. The Hang Seng Index fell 49.23 points to 23,843.91 on HK$89.04 billion in turnover. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.37% to 2,567.60, its highest level since August 2011.

site_title: Suntec Reit lifts market volume to S$1.8b
summary: The Straits Times Index closed 4.46 points higher at 3,344.99, driven by rebounds in three banks, outweighing losses in the Jardine group. Suntec Reit lifted market volume to S$1.8 billion with a large trade, possibly due to its replacement in the MSCI Singapore Index. Sentiment was slightly weak, with the advance-decline score excluding warrants at 172-233.

site_title: US urges India to toughen patent laws to draw investors
summary: US Trade Representative Michael Froman urged India to strengthen its intellectual property laws, including patents, to attract vital investment and spur its sputtering economy. He said India's current laws, which prioritize "genuine drug innovation" over patent protection, hinder the development of a knowledge-based economy. Froman's call came as international charity Medecins Sans Frontieres accused the US and pharmaceutical industry of pressuring India to change its laws to prioritize corporate profits over people's health.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 4.46 points to 3,344.99. Trading volume reached 1.78 billion shares, valued at S$1.83 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 172-233. The market's 5-day rally continues ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Santander names new CEO as chairwoman Botin injects new drive
summary: Santander, the euro zone's largest bank, announced a new CEO and management shake-up. Current CEO Javier Marin will be replaced by CFO Jose Antonio Alvarez, effective January 1. Chairwoman Ana Botin aims to give the bank a younger, more international profile. Investors responded positively to the changes, with shares rising 1.7%. Botin has also appointed new independent directors and created a lead independent director role. The changes are part of Botin's effort to drive the bank's expansion in new markets and recovery in its home market.

images.alt_text: The euro zone's biggest bank Santander announced a new chief executive and a major management shake-up on Tuesday - chairwoman Ana Botin's much-anticipated first move towards giving the bank a younger and more international profile.

site_title: Singapore civil servants to get 0.8-month year-end bonus
summary: Singapore civil servants will receive a 0.8-month year-end bonus, in addition to the traditional 13th-month bonus, totaling 2.3 months. This is less than last year's 2.5 months but higher than 2012's 2 months. Lower-wage officers will also receive an AVC of at least S$1,200. The payouts are a result of close consultations between public-sector union representatives and the Public Service Division, taking into account the country's economic performance.

site_title: Volvo makes 400m euros provision for EU antitrust probe
summary: Volvo has set aside 400 million euros (US$497 million) to cover a potential antitrust fine from the European Union, following a formal suspicion of operating an illegal cartel to rig prices. The European Commission, along with MAN and Daimler Benz, is investigating the companies, which includes Sweden's Scania and Italy's Iveco, after raids in 2011. A fine of up to 10% of annual worldwide sales could result from a guilty verdict. The provision will impact Volvo's operating income in the final quarter of 2014, with the outcome of the commission's investigation still uncertain.

site_title: Stagnant eurozone poses 'major risk' to world growth: OECD
summary: The OECD has warned that the stagnant eurozone poses a major risk to global growth, urging more flexibility in fiscal rules for struggling EU members like France and Italy. The organization calls for slower structural budget consolidation to reduce the drag on growth, and recommends further stimulus in the eurozone to prop up growth. This assessment comes as the European Commission reviews member states' budgets, with France and Italy under fire for budget deficits above EU ceilings. The OECD forecasts 3.3% global growth this year, down from a previous estimate, and 3.7% growth in 2015.

site_title: Singapore bond market fastest-growing in emerging East Asia in Q3: ADB
summary: Singapore's bond market experienced the fastest growth in emerging East Asia in Q3, expanding 4.7% quarter-over-quarter, reaching S$322 billion. The market grew 6.1% year-over-year. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) notes that while the region's bond markets are resilient, rising risks, including a stronger US dollar and faster-than-expected US interest rate hikes, could pose problems for local currency bond markets. The ADB attributes the growth to cross-border bond issuances, particularly by China-based corporates.

site_title: India, Nepal to sign US$1b power deal
summary: Nepal and India are set to sign a US$1-billion hydroelectricity project, allowing India's state-owned company to construct a 900-megawatt hydropower project on Nepal's Arun river. The deal will boost Nepal's power supplies and enable the export of electricity to India, with Nepal receiving 22% of the generated power for free. The project is the latest in a series of energy agreements between the two countries, with India seeking to deepen their energy ties since coming to power. The project is expected to generate electricity from 2021.
