site_title: Sapphire buys rail infrastructure firm for 360m yuan in turnaround strategy
summary: Sapphire Corporation, a loss-making firm, is acquiring a China-based EPC business for 360 million yuan (S$75.9 million) as part of its turnaround strategy to grow via railway infrastructure and engineering projects. The company will issue new shares worth S$16.5 million to fund the acquisition. This move follows the disposal of its loss-making steel business, aiming to shift focus to more profitable sectors.

site_title: OECD sees gradual world recovery, urges ECB to do more
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has revised its global economic outlook, predicting a gradual recovery over the next two years. The global economy is expected to grow 3.3% this year, 3.7% in 2015, and 3.9% in 2016. However, Japan's forecast has been downgraded due to its unexpected recession in the third quarter, while the eurozone is at risk of deflation and stagnation. The OECD urges the European Central Bank to implement quantitative easing to boost growth.

site_title: China to offer aid for India high-speed rail study
summary: China will conduct and pay for a feasibility study in India for a high-speed rail line linking Delhi to Chennai, a 1,750 km route. This move follows China's aggressive export of high-speed rail technology to countries like Malaysia and Myanmar. The study will be the first rail agreement between China and India since 2013, with Indian officials and Chinese officials set to sign an agreement this week. The proposed project aims to modernize India's creaking rail infrastructure, which has been criticized for being slow, congested, and inadequate.

site_title: Consumer epending helps Germany skirt recession in Q3
summary: Germany's economy avoided a recession in the third quarter, expanding 0.1% from July to September, according to official data. Higher household and government spending, along with increased exports, contributed to the growth. In contrast, falling investment acted as a drag on recovery. This marks a reversal of the preceding three months, where the economy shrank 0.1%. Germany's GDP growth was primarily driven by private consumer spending, which increased 0.7%, and government spending, which rose 0.6%.

site_title: Dutch bank ING says to slash 1,700 jobs
summary: ING, a leading Dutch bank, announced plans to slash 1,700 local jobs over three years as it upgrades its automated online banking services. The cuts will mainly target its Amsterdam-based headquarters, IT department, and call centers. In addition, 1,075 external contract jobs will be scrapped. Despite the job losses, ING expects a total gross cost saving of around 270 million euros from 2018 onwards. The bank aims to create a consistent customer experience by integrating its service channels and simplifying its IT systems, with a cost of 200 million euros.

site_title: 24 travel agencies to skip March Natas fair and launch own travel event
summary: 24 travel agencies are skipping the March 2015 Natas travel fair and launching their own event, the Outbound Travel Fair, at the Marina Bay Sands Expo & Convention Centre. The rival event will offer free admission and cater to the same target audience. The agencies, which account for 80% of sales at previous Natas fairs, cited issues such as declining visitorship, high exhibition costs, and lack of transparency as reasons for leaving the Natas fair. The Outbound Travel Fair is set to take place on March 27-29, 2015.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Malaysia gains to near 3-wk high; others mixed
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index rose 0.3% to its highest in nearly three weeks, driven by Petronas Gas's 2.9% gain. The country will scrap fuel subsidies, expected to save $5.97 billion annually. The move boosted sentiment, with the IMF projecting a 3.5% deficit target for 2014 and a potential decline below 3% of GDP in 2015. Other Southeast Asian markets traded mixed, with Singapore's Straits Times Index steady and Thai, Indonesian, and Philippine indices down, while Vietnam's benchmark VN Index rebounded 0.9%.

site_title: South Korea government think-tank calls for further rate cut
summary: South Korea's top state-run research institute, the Korea Development Institute, has urged the Bank of Korea to cut interest rates further due to the country's risk of falling into deflation. The institute cited the GDP deflator's slower growth compared to the CPI, and warned that the 2.0% base rate may not be sufficient to combat inflation. This comes after China's surprise interest rate cut and amid concerns that South Korea's economy may slow down, putting pressure on the Bank of Korea to act.

site_title: UK credit card market not working for some: Regulator
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has expressed concerns over the credit card market, citing issues with high interest rates and unaffordable debt for some customers. The regulator will study the market, focusing on shopping around, cost recovery, and unaffordable debt. With 30 million customers and 56.9 billion pounds in outstanding debt, the FCA aims to understand consumer choices and how firms develop their services. The study will specifically look at banks and mono-line issuers.

site_title: Sony to end FIFA sponsorship contract: report
summary: Sony is ending its 8-year, $280 million sponsorship contract with FIFA, reportedly due to concerns over increased costs. The electronics giant, which has been an official sponsor of FIFA's 40+ tournaments, is undergoing a restructuring and aims to slash costs. Samsung is rumored to be Sony's successor in the sponsorship, but a Sony spokeswoman declined to comment. The decision comes as Sony faces a significant net loss of nearly $1 billion for the April-September period.

site_title: Bumi Resources units get court moratorium to help restructure debt
summary: Bumi Resources' three subsidiaries have secured a six-month moratorium in a Singaporean court to restructure their debt. The move aims to facilitate discussions with noteholders and bondholders. The moratorium follows Bumi Resources' struggles to service its debt amid depressed coal prices. The news led to a 7% increase in Bumi Resources' shares on the Jakarta stock exchange. The company has been delaying a coupon payment due in October. The restructuring process is part of Bumi Resources' efforts to address its financial challenges.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.29%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.29% on Tuesday in post-holiday trading, following a record close on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index gained 50.11 points to 17,407.62, while the Topix index climbed 0.64% to 1,409.15. The yen remained weak against the dollar, contributing to the Tokyo market's gains.

site_title: US third-quarter growth rate revised up to 3.9%
summary: US economic growth was revised up to a 3.9% annual pace in the third quarter, stronger than initially thought, indicating firming fundamentals that may support the economy for the rest of the year. This is the second strongest back-to-back quarter of growth since 2003, surpassing economists' expectations of a 3.3% pace. The revised estimate includes higher business and consumer spending, stronger business investment, and a reduced trade deficit. This growth could boost expectations for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in mid-2015, supporting the US as a bright spot in a gloomy global economy.

images.alt_text: US economic growth was far stronger than initially thought in the third quarter, pointing to strengthening fundamentals that should support the economy for the rest of the year.

site_title: BoJ policymakers divided over extra stimulus: minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers were divided over expanding its easing plan by up to 80 trillion yen (US$676 billion) annually, with opponents warning the risks outweigh benefits. The move was narrowly passed 5-4, following the US Federal Reserve's stimulus unwind. Critics questioned the plan's sustainability and potential squeeze on liquidity, with one member warning of soaring import costs for small domestic firms. Despite this, one supporter said the measures would produce stronger effects on corporate profits, employment, and wages.

images.alt_text: Policymakers were sharply divided over expanding the Bank of Japan's huge easing plan last month, with opponents of the move warning that the risks far outweighed any benefits, minutes from the meeting showed Tuesday.

site_title: Riot after US jury fails to indict Ferguson policeman
summary: Protesters in Ferguson, Missouri, erupted in violence after a grand jury declined to indict a white police officer for fatally shooting an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. The decision sparked widespread outrage, with protesters setting buildings ablaze, looting stores, and clashing with police. President Barack Obama appealed for calm, but his words fell on deaf ears. The shooting had sparked weeks of protests and debate about police force and race relations in the US. The grand jury found that Officer Darren Wilson acted in self-defense, but the Brown family and many others were disappointed by the decision.

site_title: Singapore's GIC to invest in Indonesia property with Rajawali
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has agreed to jointly invest up to $500 million in property projects in Indonesia with Rajawali Group, a privately-owned investment company. The joint venture will focus on sectors such as office, retail, and residential projects in Jakarta. This investment marks a significant expansion of GIC's presence in Indonesia, where it aims to capitalize on the country's growing property market. The deal is seen as a strategic move to diversify GIC's portfolio and tap into Indonesia's economic growth.

site_title: Norway oil fund's coal exposure bigger than claimed: environment groups
summary: Norway's $860 billion sovereign wealth fund has more coal exposure than claimed, with environmental groups arguing it should sell out. The fund had 82 billion crowns in coal-related investments, despite claiming only 2.6 billion crowns. The groups criticized the fund for including major coal producers and consumers, such as BHP Billiton and RWE, and called for a re-evaluation of its portfolio. The Labour party had previously proposed banning coal investments, but backed off after the government agreed to review the fund's investments.

site_title: Protests over Ferguson ruling spread across US
summary: Protests over the grand jury decision not to indict a white cop who shot an unarmed black teen, Michael Brown, spread across the US. Demonstrators gathered in cities such as New York, Seattle, and Chicago, chanting slogans and waving banners. The protests were largely peaceful, but in Ferguson, Missouri, police responded with tear gas and a police car was torched. The rallies were sparked by President Barack Obama's appeal for calm, and the demonstrations highlighted concerns about police brutality and racism.

site_title: Top K-pop agency denies Alibaba investment report
summary: South Korea's top K-pop entertainment firm SM Entertainment denied a report that it was the target of a major investment deal worth at least US$90 million from Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba. The company stated it is discussing potential partnerships to diversify its businesses in China, but the investment report is "not true." SM Entertainment is valued at around 788.7 billion won and includes popular acts like EXO and Girls' Generation.

images.alt_text: South Korea's top K-pop entertainment firm on Tuesday denied a report that it was the target of a major investment deal worth at least US$90 million from Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba.

site_title: StarHub, Japan's KVH team up to offer DCNet in Singapore
summary: StarHub and Japan's KVH Co Ltd have partnered to offer KVH's DCNet in Singapore, utilizing StarHub's metropolitan fibre network. DCNet is a pre-wired elastic data centre to data centre Ethernet interconnection solution, linking over 100 leading data centres across Asia. The service is available in bandwidths from 100Mbps to 10Gbps and offers a low entry point for connectivity, reduced TCO, and the ability to opt for new data centres as business grows. Plans to expand to additional data centres in Singapore are underway.

site_title: JTC releases 3 industrial sites in Tampines and Tuas for sale
summary: JTC Corporation has released three industrial sites in Tampines and Tuas for sale under the second half 2014 industrial government land sales programme. Two confirmed list sites, totaling 1.5ha, are zoned for Business-2 development with 20-year tenures and maximum permissible gross plot ratios of 1.0 and 1.4, respectively. A third 0.6ha reserve list site is also available for application. The sites are aimed at meeting demand for custom-built industrial facilities and provide more location options for industrialists. Tenders for the confirmed sites close on January 20, 2015.

site_title: India's July-Sept GDP growth seen around 5% y-o-y: govt sources
summary: India's economic growth for the three months to September is expected to be around 5% year-over-year, a slowdown from 5.7% in the previous quarter, according to government sources. This puts pressure on the central bank to soften interest rates. The official GDP data for the second quarter will be released this Friday.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda, unfazed by yen falls, signals readiness to ease more
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled readiness to ease monetary stimulus further to meet its price goal, despite criticism that recent easing has accelerated yen falls. Kuroda defended last month's easing as necessary to boost investment and hiring, but some policymakers oppose further easing, citing concerns about credibility and debt monetization. The yen has fallen to a seven-year high, but Kuroda said the bank will carefully watch market moves and their effect on the economy.

site_title: Saudi sights set on US shale at crucial OPEC meeting
summary: Saudi Arabia is expected to resist pressure to cut oil production at an OPEC meeting, prioritizing defending its market share in the US and maintaining its advantage over US shale oil producers. Despite a sharp decline in oil prices, Saudi Arabia is confident in its fiscal strength, with analysts suggesting it can withstand lower prices for two to three years. Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi has not commented on the kingdom's intentions, fueling speculation that it will maintain its current output levels.

site_title: Changi Airport's passenger traffic up 1.9% in Oct on strong South Asia growth
summary: Changi Airport's passenger traffic increased 1.9% in October to 4.49 million, driven by strong growth in South Asia, with 14% year-on-year growth in traffic to and from the region. Passenger movements between Singapore and China rose 5%. However, aircraft landings and takeoffs fell 3.7% and airfreight movements rose 2.1%. For the first 10 months of the year, Changi Airport saw a 1% increase in passengers to 44.58 million and a 0.5% increase in cargo shipments to 1.53 million tonnes.

site_title: No charges for US policeman who shot black teen
summary: A US grand jury has declined to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson, who shot and killed unarmed black teenager Michael Brown in August. The decision has sparked widespread protests and anger, with Brown's family expressing profound disappointment. The grand jury found that Wilson acted in self-defense during a physical altercation, but the Brown family and many in the community believe the verdict is unjust. Protests in Ferguson have remained peaceful so far, but the situation remains tense and volatile.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nan Fung, Noble Group
summary: Nan Fung International Holdings raised its offer price for Forterra Trust to S$2.25 per unit, up from S$1.85. The Hong Kong-based property developer acquired 53.89 million units, increasing its stake to 51.76% of total issued units. Meanwhile, Noble Group acquired San Juan Fuels for US$10 million, with its subsidiaries acquiring 200 membership units. Both companies' counters closed higher on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open 0.22% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.22% lower on Tuesday, following a sharp rise in the previous session driven by China's interest rate cut. The Hang Seng Index fell 51.98 points to 23,841.16.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed China-fuelled rally
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, following a Chinese rate cut that fueled a rally in the previous session. Tokyo rose 0.34%, while Seoul was flat and Sydney lost 0.76%. Hong Kong slipped 0.27% and Shanghai added 0.24%. The rally was short-lived, with traders taking profit after the surprise interest rate cut. The Dow and S&P 500 also reached record highs, despite losses in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: China state firms' profit growth quickens slightly in Jan-Oct
summary: China state-owned firms reported a 6.1% profit growth in the first 10 months of 2014, with combined profits reaching 2.1 trillion yuan ($342 billion). The pace of growth picked up slightly from 5.9% in the previous period, but still trailed the 8% rise in the previous two months. Despite efforts by the central bank to support the economy, manufacturers continue to struggle with factory-gate deflation and elevated borrowing costs. Total assets of state firms rose 11.9% to 100.4 trillion yuan ($16.35 trillion) at the end of October.

site_title: Quiet Korean cash registers disappoint again as consumption sags
summary: South Korea's top department stores experienced weaker-than-estimated sales in October, with combined sales dropping 2.2% from a year earlier. This marks the second consecutive monthly decline, fueling concerns over weak domestic consumption. The drop was attributed to fewer discount events during the month.

images.alt_text: Sales at South Korea's top department stores were weaker than estimated, government data showed on Tuesday, as they fell for a second straight month in annual terms and added to concerns over weak domestic consumption in Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Hong Kong authorities begin clearing part of Mong Kok protest site
summary: Hong Kong authorities began clearing part of a pro-democracy protest camp in Mong Kok, following a court order to reopen a road. Hundreds of police and workers in white helmets enforced the order, clearing wooden blockades and dismantling tents. Protests continue, with hundreds remaining camped out along nearby Nathan Road. The move comes after a partial clearance of the largest protest site in Admiralty last week, as the protests dwindle in public support.

site_title: CPF Ordinary Accounts to continue earning interest rates of up to 3.5% in Q1 '15
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) announced that members will continue to earn interest rates of up to 3.5% per annum on Ordinary Account (OA) monies, up to 5% per annum on Special and Medisave Accounts, and up to 5% per annum on Retirement Account monies in the first quarter of 2015. The interest rates include an additional 1% on the first $60,000 of combined balances. The rates will remain unchanged until March 31, 2015.

site_title: Japan transport min sets up task force to deal with air bag recalls
summary: Japan's transport minister has set up a task force to deal with air bag recalls, particularly those made by Takata Corp. The recall affects 2.54 million vehicles in Japan, with about 1.54 million already brought in for replacement. The recall is linked to at least five deaths on Honda vehicles. The ministry has urged automakers to speed up the replacement process.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 1.79 points to 1833.49. Volume reached 54.6 million lots worth RM20.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 55.

site_title: South Korean government think-tank warns of deflation risk
summary: South Korea's top state-run research institute, the Korea Development Institute, warned the Bank of Korea against underestimating the risk of deflation in the economy. The institute noted that the gross domestic product deflator growth has been slowing, potentially foreshadowing a decline in consumer price index growth. The report calls for the central bank to take pre-emptive action, but does not specify immediate interest rate cuts. This comes as the Bank of Korea has cut its policy rate three times since last year.

site_title: Japan govt cuts view of job market, cautious on consumption in Nov report
summary: Japan's government has downgraded its view of the job market in its November economic report, citing a blow to demand from a sales tax hike. The economy is expected to continue recovering despite weak consumer spending and factory output. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has called a snap election next month, but his party's prospects are uncertain. The report notes that the economy remains in recovery, with the government assessing that consumption and some other parts of the economy are weak.

site_title: Hot stocks: Oil companies in the spotlight on uncertain Opec meeting outcome
summary: Oil prices could plummet another 20% to $60 a barrel if OPEC doesn't agree to a significant output cut. Brent crude futures have fallen 34% since June, reaching a four-year low of $76.76 a barrel. Commodity fund managers expect a minimum 1 million barrels per day (bpd) cut to stabilize prices. The oil price has fallen due to abundant supply and low demand growth, particularly in Europe and Asia, with OPEC's meeting in Vienna this week set to determine the outcome.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's economic outlook in 2014 and 2015
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.8% year-on-year in Q3 2014, beating market expectations, with the manufacturing and services sectors contributing to the growth. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) narrowed its GDP growth forecast for 2014 to 3% and 2015 to 2-4%. Private-sector economists are cautious, with Mizuho Bank's Vishnu Varathan predicting slightly more support from global stimulus, while Bank of America Merrill Lynch's Chua Hak Bin expects weaker growth due to restructuring and tight labour constraints. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintains its policy stance as 'appropriate'.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore government said Tuesday morning that the economy grew 2.8 per cent year-on-year in Q3, thanks to both the manufacturing and services sectors. This was better than the 2.4 per cent flash estimate and market expectations for a slight upgrade to 2.5 per cent.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Tuesday with the Straits Times Index down 0.94 points to 3,339.59. Volume was 83.2 million shares worth S$107.1 million. The rally that began on Wednesday of last week continued with the index up 0.4% on Thursday. Despite the lack of significant news, investors remained positive.

site_title: Sony sees 70% jump in devices revenues in 3 years
summary: Sony Corp expects revenue for its electronic devices division to rise 69% over the next three years, reaching 1.5 trillion yen ($12.7 billion), as part of its restructuring plan. The forecast follows a smaller-than-expected operating loss in the second quarter, driven by robust sales of image sensors. The company did not provide business targets for its smartphone division, but plans to issue guidance by the end of March 2015. Sony aims to lift movie and TV programming revenues by a third over the next three years.

site_title: South Korea: Shares edge lower as China-induced rally fades
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.15% on Tuesday, following a China-inspired rally in the previous session. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) touched a seven-week high on Monday after China cut interest rates. Chipmaker SK Hynix rose 2.4% and K-Pop talent agency SM Entertainment Co climbed 4% on reports of potential investments. Defensive plays outperformed the broader market, while foreign investors supported the market with a net buying of 76.5 billion won.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports seen growing between 1-3% next year: IE
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports are forecast to grow between 1-3% in 2015, reversing a dip this year, according to International Enterprise Singapore. Total trade is expected to grow moderately, between 0-2%, after a 3.5% decline in the third quarter. Non-oil re-exports also dropped 1% in the third quarter, following a 2.9% increase in the second quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.77%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.77% higher on a post-holiday Tuesday, following record-setting gains on Wall Street and the dollar's rise against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 132.88 points to 17,490.39. Strong earnings reports and a historically good month for the market have kept price-to-earnings levels reasonable, with the dollar's rise benefiting Japanese exporters.

site_title: DOS unveils mobile app on key Singapore official statistics
summary: The Department of Statistics (DOS) in Singapore has launched a mobile app called SingStat, providing users with easy access to key official statistics, including 200 charts from 25 data categories. The app is free and available for download on Apple App Store and Google Play. Users can customize the viewing of statistics to display information of their choice. The app uses the Agile development approach, allowing for rapid prototyping and improvements based on user feedback.

site_title: Alibaba to invest in top K-pop agency SM Entertainment: report
summary: Alibaba is planning to invest at least 100 billion won (US$90 million) in SM Entertainment, South Korea's top K-pop agency, according to a report. Alibaba is conducting due diligence on the company in preparation for the investment. A South Korean accounting firm hired by Alibaba is carrying out the due diligence. The investment marks a significant move by Alibaba into the K-pop market, which has gained immense popularity globally. Details of the investment deal are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Broker's Take: 'Hold' rating kept on Keppel Reit
summary: DMG Research maintains its "hold" rating on Keppel Reit with a target price of S$1.18, citing the acquisition of a one-third interest in Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 3 for S$1.248 billion. The acquisition price works out to S$2,680 psf, excluding rental support, and Keppel Reit will fork out S$725 million. The research house notes that the acquisition will increase gearing to 43.8% and give Keppel Reit a youngest office portfolio, but occupancy and passing rents are expected to rise.

site_title: China blasts 'irresponsible' US comments on island project
summary: China has dismissed US criticism of its construction of an artificial island in the South China Sea, calling the comments "irresponsible." The island, reportedly large enough for an airstrip, is part of China's land reclamation project on the Spratly Islands, which also claims by other countries including the Philippines, Malaysia, and Vietnam. China claims the island is for improving living conditions for personnel stationed on the islands, while the US urges Beijing to stop the project, citing potential escalation of tensions.

site_title: Pacific Andes Resources Development plans to raise S$195.5m through rights issue
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development Limited plans to raise S$195.5 million through a fully underwritten rights issue, issuing over 3.83 billion new ordinary shares at S$0.051 each. The company will use the funds for general working capital and/or reducing borrowings, mainly supporting China Fishery Group's Copeinca Notes redemption. The rights issue is expected to raise S$192.3 million after deducting estimated expenses, and is seen as a step to strengthen the group's equity capital base.

site_title: Further easing seen as China rate cut signals policy shift
summary: China's central bank cut benchmark interest rates by 0.40 percentage points to 5.60% and trimmed deposit rates by 0.25 percentage points to 2.75%, signaling a policy shift. This move follows months of modest stimulus actions to boost the economy. Despite the rate cut, analysts predict it won't be enough to arrest China's slowing growth. The move sent Asian and European stock markets higher, but experts expect more easing is on the way. The rate cut is seen as a strong signal of China's efforts to stimulate its economy.

site_title: Medibank debuts in Australia's biggest float this year
summary: Medibank, Australia's largest health insurer, listed on the stock market with a premium, raising A$5.7 billion (US$4.9 billion) for the government's asset recycling fund. The IPO was the country's most anticipated this year and largest since Telstra Corp's 1997 sale. Shares opened at A$2.22, 40% higher than the initial range of A$1.55-2.00, with institutional investors paying A$2.15 and mum and dad investors A$2.00. The government had forecast A$4.7 billion but exceeded expectations.

site_title: UK service sector grows steadily in 3 months to November: CBI
summary: The UK services sector, accounting for the bulk of the country's economy, grew steadily in the three months to November, according to a CBI survey. Profits and employment increased, while expenditure on staff training reached a 15-year high, possibly due to skill shortages. However, optimism among firms fell at its fastest rate since 2013, and selling price inflation reached its highest rate since 2010 in consumer services. The economy is expected to slow in the fourth quarter, but growth is expected to remain robust, with the CBI predicting continued growth into the New Year.

site_title: Defending the home turf
summary: FCL group CEO Lim Ee Seng emphasizes Singapore as a core market, despite overseas ventures. He outlines the developer's strategy to navigate Singapore's challenging property market, though no specific details are provided. The article does not contain any other relevant information.

site_title: Malaysia budget deficit could fall below 3% of GDP in 2015: IMF
summary: Malaysia's budget deficit could fall below 3% of GDP in 2015, according to the International Monetary Fund. The country narrowed its fiscal deficit to 3.9% in 2013 and aims to trim the gap to 3.5% in 2014 and 3% by 2020. To achieve this, Malaysia will remove fuel subsidies starting December 1, which is expected to lock in the impact of lower oil prices and reduce the deficit. The IMF projects the deficit could decline below 3% of GDP in 2015.

site_title: Asian shares wobble, oil skids ahead of OPEC
summary: Asian shares declined slightly, reversing previous gains after China's interest rate cut, while oil prices slid ahead of the OPEC meeting. Japan's Nikkei stock average rose 0.6% and the US S&P 500 reached a fresh record high. Oil prices dropped 0.2% to $75.65 a barrel, with strategists predicting caution from OPEC due to non-OPEC production growth. The euro edged down, and the euro zone's growth concerns led to warnings of potential ECB quantitative easing obstacles.

site_title: US senators call for airbag data from Takata
summary: US senators Jay Rockefeller and Bill Nelson have called on Japanese auto parts maker Takata to provide 14 years of records and data on its faulty airbags. The senators were dissatisfied with the company's responses to Senate Commerce Committee questions, citing insufficient answers on the airbag manufacturing and distribution issues. The senators requested detailed company records, including communications on the airbag problems, which have been linked to several deaths and injuries, and asked for these records by December 12.

site_title: Singapore Q3 labour productivity falls 0.8% y-o-y: MTI
summary: Singapore's Q3 labour productivity fell 0.8% year-on-year, slightly improving from the 1.4% drop in Q2 2014. The finance & insurance sector showed a 5.8% gain, while manufacturing experienced a 2.1% increase. Labour-intensive sectors, such as accommodation & food services and construction, reported declines of 3.5% and 2.9% respectively. The decline is attributed to the decline in the manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S Q3 labour productivity fell 0.8 per cent from a year ago, slightly improved from the 1.4 per cent year-on-year drop in the second quarter of 2014.

site_title: The Reit market that defied the odds
summary: The Singapore Reit market has defied expectations, growing from S$24 billion in 2007 to S$68 billion in 2025, making it the second-largest Reit market in Asia after Japan. With 39 property trusts now listed, the market has expanded beyond Singapore's shores, with many trusts holding properties worldwide. This growth is attributed to the island nation's unique market dynamics, allowing it to flourish despite its small size.

site_title: Aquis to review Cairns project after casino bid falls through
summary: Aquis Group, a Hong Kong developer, has put its Cairns project on review after a casino takeover bid fell through. The project, valued at A$8.15 billion, includes a 7,500-room hotel, golf course, and water park. Aquis will undertake a strategic review of its plans and development timetable over the coming months. The project's related casino takeover bid has not received all necessary regulatory approvals and will likely lapse on November 28. Aquis may consider a new bid for the Reef Casino Trust next year, but no certainty exists for this transaction.

site_title: US sets import duties on Chinese car and light truck tires
summary: The US is imposing duties on imports of Chinese car and light truck tires, with rates ranging from 12.50% to 81.29% due to unfair government subsidies. The decision affects tires from companies including Cooper Tire & Rubber Company and Giti Tire. The preliminary rates were set by the Department of Commerce, with a final ruling due in April and a review by the International Trade Commission in May. This move aims to protect US industries from subsidized Chinese imports, which in 2013 were valued at around $2.1 billion.

site_title: China rate cut fuels Asian equity rally
summary: China's central bank cut interest rates by 40 basis points to curb high borrowing costs, marking its first rate cut in nearly two years. The move boosted Asian equity markets, with the Shanghai Composite Index jumping 1.85% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 1.95%. However, analysts caution that the rally may be short-lived, as China's fundamentals remain unchanged and excess manufacturing capacity weakens demand for credit. The renminbi weakened against the US dollar, and the rate cut is seen as a temporary boost to sentiment, with economists predicting more volatility in the coming year.

site_title: Internet access should be a human right: survey
summary: A survey of 23,376 people in 24 countries found that internet access should be a human right, with 80% of respondents believing it's key to economic future and free speech. Users are concerned about online privacy and government censorship, with 64% worried about hacking and 50% fearing government spying. The survey suggests a global shift towards decentralized internet governance, with 57% supporting a combination of technical experts and non-governmental groups. The United Nations and non-US organizations are preferred to manage the internet, with 50% and 36% respectively supporting the UN's role.

site_title: US seeks to revive trade with India after WTO row
summary: The US is seeking to expand trade with India after a recent WTO row, with two-way trade currently valued at $100 billion. US Trade Representative Michael Froman announced plans to boost the figure to $500 billion, with the countries aiming to finalize a Trade Facilitation Agreement. The breakthrough has improved relations between the US and India, with President Barack Obama set to visit India in January. The agreement's success has been attributed to the personal engagement of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Mr. Obama, who have struck up a good rapport.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 at new records; Apple lifts Nasdaq
summary: US stocks reached new records on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 7.84 points to 17,817.90 and the S&P 500 rising 5.91 points to 2,069.41. Apple's nearly 2% rise in shares drove the Nasdaq Composite Index to a record high of 4,754.89. Economic data releases, including third-quarter US growth and consumer confidence, will be released in the coming days. Meanwhile, United Technologies fell 1.4% after CEO Louis Chenevert's surprise resignation, and Prosensa Holding surged 62.6% after announcing a $680 million acquisition.

site_title: Broker's Take: CIMB keeps 'hold' call on Golden Agri-Resources, 'overweight' call on Reits
summary: CIMB Research maintains a "hold" call on Golden Agri-Resources due to its fairly valued stock, despite concerns over oilseeds losses and poor downstream operations. The research house keeps its earnings forecasts and target price of S$0.50. In contrast, CIMB prefers First Resources in the plantations space. The research house also maintains an "overweight" call on Singapore Reits, citing an improving hospitality market and expected 2-4% rise in visitor arrivals in 2015. CIMB's preferred picks include CDL Hospitality Trusts and OUE Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Some property stocks defying odds
summary: Singapore property developers have experienced varying year-to-date performances, with some outperforming the market by significant margins. Companies with diversified portfolios, such as CapitaLand and Keppel Land, have shown resilience, driven by strong execution in investment property segments and regional diversification. In contrast, those with largely Singapore-centric residential operations have underperformed, with some experiencing significant declines. Analysts are divided on whether to buy into or steer clear of developer stocks, citing both fundamental value and uncertainty about near-term catalysts.

site_title: China, Europe need to work on climate treaty
summary: China and Europe are working together to boost prospects of a global climate treaty in 2015. China's planned investments in the green economy, totaling over £200 billion, and its commitment to reducing carbon intensity by 40-45% by 2020, signal a shift towards a low-carbon economy. European companies, particularly in renewable energy and smart grids, are well-positioned to collaborate with China. However, EU targets may not be ambitious enough, and cooperation between the two powers could help align Europe with China's growing economy and drive economic growth.

site_title: Singapore economy to grow by 3% in 2014; Q3 GDP up 2.8%: MTI
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by 3% in 2014, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). The Q3 GDP growth rate was 2.8%, beating initial expectations. The manufacturing sector expanded 1.9% and the services sector accelerated to 3.4% year-on-year. MTI expects growth to "ease slightly" for the rest of the year due to a global slowdown. The country's economy has grown 3.3% year-on-year for the first three quarters of 2014.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore government now expects the economy to grow by 3 per cent this year - at the mid-point of its earlier official forecast of 2.5-3.5 per cent, which had been kept unchanged since August.

site_title: Ghana inks US$6 billion deal with Italian oil giant Eni
summary: Ghana has signed a $6 billion deal with Italian oil giant Eni to develop its offshore oil and gas resources, specifically the Cape Three Points field. The agreement aims to boost Ghana's energy sector and increase oil production, with expected commercial production starting by mid-2017. The deal also includes gas production, which will help address power supply issues. The agreement comes after Ghana struggled to hit its production targets and attract foreign investment, with energy minister Emmanuel Armah Kofi Buah citing investment risk as a major hurdle.

site_title: Countdown to the EU's missed opportunity begins
summary: European Union leaders are set to meet on December 18-19 under new management, but the economy is expected to remain stagnant, with inflation and growth hovering below one percent and unemployment at 11.5 percent. The eurozone is struggling to recover from its debt crisis, with France's economy flatlining and Italy's in recession. The European Central Bank has proposed a New Deal for Europe, but opposition from Germany's Bundesbank chief may hinder its implementation. A summit agreement is unlikely, leaving the ECB to act alone to combat low inflation.

site_title: Unibail seeks another mall to satisfy Berlin's shopping appetite
summary: Unibail-RODAMCO SE plans to add a second mall in Berlin, capitalizing on the city's growing retail market. The company is increasing investment in its existing Gropius Passagen mall and exploring opportunities to acquire or build a second centre in the city. Unibail is targeting Germany's largest cities, including Hamburg and Munich, with a focus on malls that meet its size, customer, and return on investment criteria. The move is part of the company's expansion strategy outside France, where it aims to tap into rising wages and retail sales in Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Sunac may revise purchase of Greentown stake
summary: Sunac China Holdings Ltd is reconsidering its $1.1 billion purchase of a 24% stake in Greentown China Holdings Ltd after the target's founder rescinded his wish to sell. The payment was made prior to completion to prevent "negative impact" to Greentown's operations, but the founder now claims the two companies "don't blend" and is considering keeping the stake. If completed, Sunac would hold the largest stake in Greentown alongside Wharf Holdings Ltd, controlled by Hong Kong billionaire Peter Woo.

site_title: EU regulators may find it tough to target Google
summary: European Parliament lawmakers propose legislation to break up Google Inc, a move that may deter EU regulators from approving a settlement with the search giant. This move follows a successful attack on bankers' bonuses and signals EU antagonism towards Google's dominance. The proposed legislation could target Google's search engine and other business areas, posing a significant challenge for the company's future.

images.alt_text: German and French legislators have voiced concern over Google's control of the search market.

site_title: Soyuz rocket delivers three new crew members to space station
summary: A Russian Soyuz rocket successfully launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan on November 24, 2014, delivering three new crew members to the International Space Station. The crew includes US astronaut Terry Virts, Russian cosmonaut Anton Shkaplerov, and Italian astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti, who became Italy's first female astronaut. The crew will spend six months in orbit, including spacewalks to prepare the station for new commercial space taxis. The station, owned by 15 nations, serves as an orbiting laboratory for various experiments and research.

site_title: Singapore economy to grow 2-4% in 2015: MTI
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 2-4% in 2015, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). This forecast aligns with a 3.45% median growth prediction from 22 economists polled by Bloomberg. The economy is expected to benefit from a pick-up in external demand but will be weighed down by labor constraints in sectors like construction, retail, and food services. The forecast also reflects a narrowing of Singapore's GDP growth for 2014 to 3%. Risks to growth include the eurozone's potential deflationary spiral and uncertainty over US Federal Reserve rate hikes.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore government expects the economy to grow 2-4 per cent in 2015, as a pick-up in external demand benefits externally-oriented sector but labour constraints continue to weigh down the construction, retail and food services sectors.

site_title: Lessons in leadership
summary: LIM Ee Seng, a property business expert, shares key lessons learned from his career. He emphasizes the importance of being a good leader, not just a supervisor or mentor, and being prepared for the down cycles of a cyclical business like real estate. LIM notes that having a strong business philosophy and integrity is crucial, and that deep pockets can also be beneficial. He highlights the need to be nimble and alert to succeed in the long term.

site_title: PocketMath secures US$10m from Rakuten Ventures
summary: PocketMath, a mobile advertising firm, has secured US$10 million in funding from Rakuten Ventures, marking the largest first-round funding for a Singapore startup. The Series A round will aid hiring, product development, and expansion of its global sales presence. PocketMath optimizes ads through real-time bidding, targeting one of the most margin-rich adtech segments for mobile. The investment gives Rakuten a strong stake in the mobile advertising game, with plans to explore how PocketMath can contribute to growing the Rakuten Marketing ecosystem.

site_title: Super cyberspying tool in use since 2008, says Symantec
summary: A highly sophisticated cyberspying tool called Regin has been used since 2008 to steal information from governments, businesses, and individuals. Developed by a nation state, the malware was seen in systematic spying campaigns against international targets, including governments, researchers, and private individuals. Regin shares characteristics with the Stuxnet worm and is considered a multi-staged threat. The malware was most prevalent in Russia and Saudi Arabia, with infections discovered in 2008-2011 and resurfacing in 2013. It allowed attackers to capture screenshots, steal passwords, and recover deleted files, with some targets tricked into visiting spoofed websites.

site_title: Global warming could worsen poverty: report
summary: The World Bank warns that global warming could worsen poverty by cutting crop yields and water supplies, potentially undermining efforts to eliminate extreme poverty. A new report predicts that sharp temperature rises could lead to significant poverty increases in multiple regions, with warming exceeding 1.5-2 degrees Celsius by the end of the century. Without concerted action, the bank warns that temperatures could rise to 4 degrees Celsius, making it difficult to achieve goals of ending poverty and increasing global prosperity.

site_title: Iran nuclear talks, Opec meeting may well roil oil markets
summary: Iran nuclear talks with the US and other P5+1 nations are nearing a deadline, with both sides making progress but still having significant issues to resolve. A deal would likely benefit Iran, which is under financial pressure due to falling oil prices, but hardliners in both countries could work to prevent an agreement. Meanwhile, Opec's meeting on November 27 will decide on oil production targets, with Saudi Arabia showing no willingness to cut production unless oil prices drop below $70 per barrel. The outcome of both events will have significant implications for energy markets.

site_title: Firms cut packaging to save environment, costs
summary: Companies worldwide are cutting packaging waste, with British supermarkets selling lighter beer bottles and Unilever aiming to reduce packaging by a third by 2020. Dell is using wheat straw and mushroom-based materials instead of Styrofoam, while Cisco Systems has eliminated 1.9 million pounds of packaging. Despite the efforts, packaging remains a significant problem, with 207 million tonnes used globally each year. Experts say reducing packaging can lower costs, reduce carbon emissions, and minimize waste, but more needs to be done to address the issue.

site_title: Medibank IPO raises A$5.68b
summary: Australia raised A$5.68 billion from the sale of 2.7 billion shares in Medibank Private Ltd, the nation's biggest health insurer, in its second-largest IPO. The sale brought the total amount raised by Australian IPOs in 2014 to A$15.9 billion, the highest since 1997. The government sold shares at A$2.15 apiece for institutional investors and A$2 for individuals, valuing Medibank at 22.9 times estimated earnings. The sale will allow Medibank to pursue growth opportunities without government restrictions.

images.alt_text: The Australian government sold about 2.7 billion shares in the nation's biggest health insurer at A$2.15 apiece for institutional investors and A$2 for individuals, according to Finance Minister Mathias Cormann.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) acquired Smart Logistics Centre in Korea for KRW21.4 billion (S$25.2 million), an initial yield of 7.8% and earnings accretive. The acquisition diversifies earnings and compensates for expected rental dip in Singapore operations. DBS Group Research maintains a target price of S$1.25. In contrast, Biosensors International Group's share price dropped due to unclear restructuring efforts and sales strategy, prompting a downgrade from "hold" to "reduce" with a target price of S$0.53.

site_title: Realising global ambitions
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) has achieved significant growth under CEO Lim Ee Seng's leadership, with assets expanding from S$5 billion in 2004 to almost S$17 billion this year. The company's attributable profit before fair value changes and extraordinary items has grown at a compounded annual growth rate of 11% over the same period. FCL's overseas strategy, particularly in Australia, has contributed to its growth, with the acquisition of Australand in 2014. The company plans to deepen its roots in Australia and accelerate growth in the market, which it believes will offer long-term prospects.

site_title: China execs to reveal pay: report
summary: China is set to make its top executives publicly reveal their salaries as part of a series of reforms aimed at boosting corporate efficiency and transparency. The payment disclosure system, set to be implemented in January, will require central government-controlled state-owned enterprises to disclose executive compensation levels. The new rules will reduce the ratio of executive pay to average employee salaries from 12 times to 7-8 times, with some executives facing pay cuts of up to US$162,997. The first round of pay cuts will involve 72 central SOEs, including major conglomerates.

site_title: Dalian Wanda Group plans 150 premium hotels
summary: Dalian Wanda Group plans to build over 150 premium hotels globally by 2018, targeting European, US, and Australian markets. The expansion comes as the company prepares for a potential $6 billion Hong Kong IPO. Founded in 1988, Dalian Wanda operates in four major industries, including luxury hotels. The IPO, if successful, could be worth more than $6 billion. The company's chairman, Wang Jianlin, is one of China's richest men.

site_title: US Gulf Coast expanding coal export facilities
summary: The US Gulf Coast is expanding its coal export facilities, with a new $300 million facility in Louisiana and investments totaling $898 million in the Gulf of Mexico. This expansion will increase capacity by 66% by 2017, benefiting from cheap coal prices and environmental opposition to West Coast terminal projects. Despite a 23% decline in US coal exports since 2012, foreign sales are expected to rebound due to a supply glut and low prices. Exports are forecast to increase 33% to 128 million tonnes by 2020 and 148 million by 2030.

site_title: Smart Nation will be next goal for Singapore
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the country's goal to become a "smart nation" within the next decade, aiming to integrate information technology to transform daily living, communities, and the future. The Smart Nation Initiative will be launched, with the establishment of a Smart Nation Programme Office to coordinate efforts from the government, businesses, and citizens. The Virtual Singapore project will develop an integrated 3D map of the city, and the government will focus on cyber security, skills development, and innovation to achieve this vision.

site_title: Inflation slows to 0.1% in Oct, lowest since Dec 2009
summary: Singapore's headline inflation eased to 0.1% in October, its lowest since December 2009, due to base effects from fluctuations in car COE premiums and declines in accommodation and oil-related costs. Core inflation, however, remained firm at 1.7%, driven by restructuring costs. Economists expect the divergence between core and headline inflation to continue, with some predicting headline inflation could fall into negative territory. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) remain cautious, with no immediate easing of monetary policy expected.

site_title: Petrobras debt financing plans in doubt
summary: Petrobras, Brazil's state-controlled oil company, faces uncertainty in its debt financing plans due to a corruption probe. The company's ability to borrow in international debt markets is threatened until it provides audited results, which has delayed its third-quarter earnings release. Petrobras relies heavily on overseas bond buyers for financing, but its funding costs have reached a 14-month high. The company's funding costs are expected to remain high until it provides audited results, potentially affecting its ability to fund its $12 billion annual financing needs.

site_title: Employers in Malaysia urged to plan for succession ahead of retirement wave
summary: Malaysia's aging population is expected to create a crisis, with nearly 7 in 10 retirees having insufficient savings. The country's talent-management firm, Kelly Outsourcing & Consulting Group, urges employers to plan for succession ahead of retirement. The firm projects the proportion of those aged 60 and up will double by 2030. To address this issue, organizations are advised to facilitate knowledge transfer and re-employ retirees on a flexible basis, creating employment opportunities for senior employees. The Malaysian government also faces pressure as health and welfare costs are expected to skyrocket.

site_title: Promoting better governance in Asia
summary: Singapore ranks first in corporate governance standards in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a joint study by ACCA and KPMG. The country's corporate governance requirements are clear, enforceable, and flexible, making it well-positioned to support its neighbors when a single Asean market becomes a reality next year. Singapore ranks third globally, behind the UK and US, and faces challenges in balancing rules and flexibility in its governance standards.

site_title: Amer Group to split into two to max out growth, liquidity
summary: Amer Group, an Egyptian real estate company, plans to split into two companies: Amer Holding Group and Porto Holding. The division aims to boost trading in its shares and maximize development opportunities. Amer Holding Group will manage real estate and hotel investments, while Porto Holding will oversee the company's "Porto" projects, including resorts and spas. The reorganization is subject to shareholder approval and will be conducted at book value. The company has a portfolio of 5.5 million sq m of land under development.

site_title: Project agreements worth more than S$3b signed at 10th Singapore-Zhejiang council meeting
summary: Singapore and Zhejiang have signed 15 project agreements worth over S$3 billion, the highest number since the council's inception in 2003. The agreements cover education, environmental services, and financial services, and are aligned with Zhejiang's 12th Five Year Plan. Two special collaborations, including a township project in Shaoxing and a modern services park in Ningbo, have been inked, which could be replicated in other Zhejiang cities or Chinese cities. The agreements aim to promote economic transformation and cooperation between the two regions.

site_title: Market shrugs off China rate cut
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 4.79 points weaker at 3,340.53 on Monday, despite a 2% gain in the Hang Seng Index due to China's interest-rate cut. The market saw a quiet session with churning and rotational plays, with penny stocks and blue chips leading the way. Bank stocks pulled back, and the upward momentum in the three banks that drove the STI up 30 points last week slowed down. Analysts from Credit Suisse and Bank of America-Merrill Lynch expect the rate cut to have a muted impact on the market, with some predicting a temporary boost to sentiment.

site_title: Nan Fung raises Forterra Trust bid to S$2.25 per unit (Amended)
summary: Nan Fung International Holdings has raised its bid price for Forterra Trust to S$2.25 per unit from S$1.85, a 32.4% premium over the closing price of S$1.70 on November 3. The offer, made through its indirectly wholly owned New Precise Holdings, now represents 51.76% of the total issued units and 56.73% of the maximum potential total units. The offer has been extended to January 5, and if successful, Nan Fung does not intend to pursue the delisting of Forterra unless the public float falls below 10%.

site_title: China's rate cut won't have desired effect
summary: China's recent interest rate cut failed to achieve its desired effect, as the country's complex financial system continues to defy central bank orders. The rate cut, intended to benefit most borrowers, was largely ineffective due to the proliferation of alternative lending channels, such as trust companies and inter-company loans. Online savings products have also become increasingly attractive, discouraging people from taking out loans. The move may even have unintended consequences, including a potential weakening of the yuan, as companies continue to find ways to circumvent interest rate controls.

site_title: Harnessing the power of data with management accounting
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in managing data and making informed decisions due to limited resources and expertise. Management accounting (MA) can empower SMEs to overcome these challenges by providing a structured framework for data analysis and decision-making. The Global Management Accounting Principles framework, launched by the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (CIMA) and the American Institute of CPAs (AICPA), aims to improve decision-making in organizations struggling with data overload. By adopting a robust MA system, SMEs can overcome everyday challenges, enhance productivity, and maximize cost efficiency, ultimately positioning them for long-term growth.

site_title: Feeble economic data could tip the scales for an ECB QE
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to receive feeble economic data on November 28, which could tip the scales for an ECB quantitative easing (QE) move. Economists forecast weak price growth, matching the weakest since 2009, and inflation data showing a dip to 0.3% from 0.4%. This could prompt Draghi to take action, with speculation on sovereign debt purchases driving down yields in Spain and Italy. However, some officials are unconvinced of the need for QE, and Draghi's vice-president has suggested a possible delay until 2015.

site_title: EU refining industry needs to shrink by 40%: ING
summary: The European oil refining industry needs to shrink by 40% to be more efficient, according to a report from ING. Currently, there are nearly 22 closed refineries since 2009, equivalent to 2.3 million barrels per day of capacity. The report suggests that 60 plants would be a better number, but the risk of inefficient refineries staying open is high, prolonging the industry's pain.

site_title: British banker fit to stand trial in HK murders
summary: A British banker, Rurik Jutting, has been ruled mentally fit to stand trial in Hong Kong for the murders of two Indonesian women. The trial will be delayed until July 6 as prosecutors examine forensic evidence found at Jutting's apartment. Jutting, a former Bank of America Merrill Lynch employee, was examined at the Siu Lam psychiatric centre after two weeks of evaluations.

site_title: Rock-bottom economics - when the rules no longer apply
summary: The US economy has been stuck in a "liquidity trap" since 2008, with interest rates at or near zero, defying conventional economic policy. Despite mainstream analysis predicting this outcome, policymakers have been slow to adapt, often relying on gut feelings and ignoring expert warnings. This has led to flawed economic decisions, such as increased fiscal austerity and monetary policy mistakes, which have cost millions of jobs and damaged infrastructure. As the economy shows no signs of recovering, experts warn that influential people must understand the realities of policy at the zero lower bound to avoid future mistakes.

site_title: Slowdown in property, manufacturing help curb China's risky 'shadow banking'
summary: China's shadow banking sector, which includes off-balance-sheet forms of bank finance and lending by non-traditional institutions, has seen a slowdown in growth due to tightening regulations and economic slowdown. The sector contracted for the first time on a quarterly basis since the 2008/09 financial crisis, with loans extended by trust companies and bankers' acceptances dropping significantly. Regulations issued in April have increased risk aversion among trusts, and the industry is expected to face further challenges in finding funding for smaller companies.

site_title: Flying car set to take off within next three years
summary: A flying car prototype, Terrafugia Transition, is nearing completion and expected to be mass-produced within the next three years. The vehicle, priced at $279,000, can travel 70 mph on the road and 100 mph in the air, with over 100 people paying deposits of $10,000 each. The company's founder, Carl Dietrich, aims to expand the definition of a plane and solve problems with small planes in inclement weather, making it ideal for weekend jaunts and sales trips.

site_title: More nuanced approach to fixing inequality needed, says Denmark's FM
summary: Denmark's Finance Minister Bjarne Corydon says a more nuanced approach is needed to address income inequality in the country. The nation experienced Europe's largest leap in income disparities during the debt crisis, with a 12% increase from 2008 to 2012. Despite having a well-established welfare system, Denmark is now the most unequal nation in the Nordic region. Corydon suggests focusing on improving conditions for both the least and most affluent, rather than placing caps on wealth. Denmark's tax burden is high, with over 49% of GDP going towards taxes, but the issue remains a point of debate ahead of the country's election year.

site_title: EU plans 21b-euro fund to share risks
summary: The European Union plans a 21 billion-euro fund to share project risks with private investors, aiming to anchor its 300 billion-euro investment programme. The fund will have a 15 times leverage rate, with the European Commission pledging up to 16 billion euros in guarantees and the European Investment Bank contributing 5 billion euros. The goal is to stimulate private risk-taking and jumpstart stalled projects, as Europe struggles with slow economic growth and high unemployment.

site_title: US funds looking into liquidity of bond holdings
summary: US fund managers are taking extra measures to ensure they don't get stuck holding hard-to-sell bonds as interest rates rise. Many firms, including Neuberger Berman and T Rowe Price, are building cash cushions and diversifying their portfolios with shorter-duration bonds and higher-quality securities. This comes as investors rush to sell bonds in a rising interest rate environment, making it harder for firms to sell their holdings. Fund managers expect the Federal Reserve to begin raising rates next year, with some predicting the first rate hike by June 2015.

site_title: German business confidence stabilises in November
summary: German business confidence stabilises after a seven-month decline, with the Ifo business climate index rising to 104.7 points in November, beating expectations. The increase is seen as a positive sign for Europe's largest economy and the eurozone. Eurozone stock markets rose, and the euro strengthened against the US dollar. Analysts are cautiously optimistic about the German economy's prospects, with some predicting slow growth and others seeing a potential acceleration in the final quarter of the year.

site_title: Beware initial euphoria over headline-grabbing deals
summary: A year of unimpressive growth for the local stock market has seen second-line firms benefit from large, headline-grabbing deals. These announcements injected much-needed interest and volatility, but often have little lasting impact. As a result, traders and shareholders should be cautious and not get caught up in the initial euphoria. The window of opportunity is small, and it's essential to consider the long-term implications of these deals before investing.

site_title: How Lionsgate punches above its Hollywood weight
summary: Lionsgate, a small Hollywood studio, has successfully marketed its "Hunger Games" series, selling an estimated $123 million in tickets for "Mockingjay Part 1" in North America. Despite having a much smaller marketing department, Lionsgate spent roughly $50 million on US and Canadian marketing, compared to $100 million by major studios like Universal Pictures and 20th Century Fox. The studio's forward-thinking approach, led by chief marketing officer Tim Palen, has allowed it to break conventional marketing norms and reduce costs, while maintaining creative credibility with filmmakers.

site_title: Top tennis players coming to S'pore for inaugural event
summary: Tennis stars, including Andre Agassi and Mahesh Bhupathi, will compete in the inaugural International Premier Tennis League (IPTL) in Singapore from Dec 2-4. The league features a unique format with time-outs, power points, and Hawk-eye technology, allowing fans to catch up to 24 players in a single day. The DBS Singapore Slammers, led by Serena Williams, will face off against teams from Manila, Mumbai, and Dubai in a round-robin competition. The winning team will receive a $1 million prize purse and a life-size tennis racquet trophy.

site_title: Not too rosy for China banks, but investors bullish
summary: China's banks face sagging profit growth due to an interest-rate cut that slashed their loan margins, but some investors remain bullish on the industry's shares. Key investment firms, including Robeco and Baring Asset Management, see banks as undervalued and poised for a rebound, driven by sustained monetary easing and economic growth. Chinese banks are trading at an average 4.8 times estimated earnings, the lowest globally, and some analysts predict a 10% decline in profit growth next year.

images.alt_text: Fund managers are getting more optimistic about the outlook for China banks' shares. ICBC led gainers in Hong Kong trading on Monday.

site_title: Turkey home sales accelerate as interest rates stabilise
summary: Turkey's home sales surged 25% in October to 95,645, with mortgage sales rising 31% due to stabilised interest rates. The average home loan cost was 10.7%, 3 percentage points lower than its peak in April. The interest rate stabilisation followed a sell-off in Turkish markets and a probe into alleged government corruption.

site_title: UN should lead global search for new energy sources
summary: The UN has pledged to lead a global search for new energy sources with a $10 billion Green Climate Fund, totaling $100 billion if all countries contribute $500 million each. The UN aims to research unlimited energy sources, including geothermal power, lightning, and space-based energy, to combat global warming and climate change. The move is seen as a necessary step to counter the influence of oil and gas majors who may resist the shift towards clean energy. The UN's initiative is deemed crucial, with time being of the essence in addressing the pressing need for sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: BHP Billiton outlines plans to cut costs further
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, plans to cut costs further by saving $4 billion a year by 2017 through a demerger of underperforming assets. The company aims to simplify its business, reducing costs by $500 million more than previously announced. The demerger will allow BHP to better organize operations and create a more productive company, with core assets generating 96% of its operating profit. A vote on the demerger is expected in May, with productivity gains expected to include reduced cash costs and exploration expenses.

site_title: HKEx working with regulators, brokers to boost southbound trade
summary: The Hong Kong stock exchange (HKEx) is working with regulators and brokers to boost southbound trade through the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect. Despite the current restriction requiring mainland investors to have at least 500,000 yuan (S$106,000) in their account balance, HKEx aims to lower or eliminate this barrier. The exchange is also promoting the scheme through research and education to attract more investors, with plans to expand to smaller stocks initially through index products.

site_title: US seeking more India trade talks after WTO breakthrough
summary: The US is seeking to intensify trade talks with India, following a recent World Trade Organization (WTO) breakthrough that paved the way for President Barack Obama's visit to India. Trade Representative Michael Froman expressed hope for a US-Indian agreement on food stockpiling and the Trade Facilitation Agreement, and urged progress on key areas of US concern, such as intellectual property rights. The talks will focus on building on mutual interests and delivering on the promise of the "defining partnership of the 21st century" between the two countries.

site_title: Derby Court up for en bloc sale by tender
summary: Derby Court, a 35-year-old freehold condominium in Singapore's Novena area, has launched a collective sale with an indicative price of S$68.28 million (S$1,286 psf ppr). The 18,500 sq ft site can accommodate up to 70 apartments and has a prime city-fringe location near popular schools and MRT stations. The sale will close on January 20, 2015, with a breakeven cost of over S$1,700 psf, according to Savills Singapore. This sale follows the recent en bloc attempt by Fragrance Court, and the collective sale agreement expires next year.

site_title: UK proposes terror law on Internet user data
summary: The UK government proposes legislation requiring internet companies to provide user data to authorities to help identify potential terrorists and criminals. The plan, announced by Home Secretary Theresa May, would require internet-service providers to retain information on internet protocol addresses and supply it to security services on request. This comes as the UK raises its terror threat to "severe" and officials express concern about the internet's role in spreading terrorism. The proposed law aims to enhance security powers to deal with the increased threat.

site_title: Sanctions against Russia depress Moscow rental income
summary: Sanctions against Russia have led to a decline in Moscow rental income, with European and US companies pulling workers out of the country. The rouble has dropped 11% against the euro. As a result, many Russians, like TIMUR Pankov, who relied on income from a Moscow property to cover their expenses in Paris, are now facing significant rent costs. The situation highlights the economic impact of the sanctions on Russia.

site_title: Increase in AsiaPhos' phosphate resources
summary: AsiaPhos Ltd reported an increase in its total measured and indicated phosphate resources to 30.3 million tonnes as of Sept 30, 2014, a 31% increase from the previous year. The increase was driven by the granting of an exploration permit for a larger area, allowing the company to expand its exploration rights. AsiaPhos CEO Ong Hian Eng stated that the expansion would provide better value for shareholders upon successful conversion to a mining license.

site_title: Russian economy minister estimates Jan-Oct GDP growth at 0.8% y/y
summary: Russian Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev estimated the country's January-October GDP growth at 0.8% year-on-year, exceeding the formal prediction of 0.5% for 2014. This may be an underestimate, according to ministry officials.

site_title: US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel resigns
summary: US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has resigned, ending nearly two years in the Pentagon's top job. He submitted his resignation letter after lengthy discussions with President Barack Obama, who accepted his resignation and will remain as Defense Secretary until his replacement is confirmed by the US Senate. Hagel's departure is seen as a recognition that the threat from the Islamic State requires different skills than his, and he had struggled to fit in with Obama's close circle of loyalists.

site_title: Samsung mobile execs likely to pay for fall in earnings
summary: Samsung Group's management restructuring, set to announce next month, aims to focus on the executives leading the smartphone business amid a slump in earnings and shrinking market share. This move comes after the family patriarch's heart attack in May. The changes will be overseen by Lee Jae Yong, the heir apparent, as part of the company's efforts to address its declining performance. The restructuring is expected to have a significant impact on the company's leadership and operations.

site_title: Hagel resigns as US defense secretary, official says
summary: US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has resigned, according to a defense official. President Barack Obama accepted his resignation, and Hagel will remain in the Pentagon's top post until a successor is named.

images.alt_text: US Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has resigned, a US defense official said on Monday, adding that President Barack Obama had accepted his resignation.

site_title: Key findings in the report
summary: A joint study by ACCA and KPMG in Singapore examines governance requirements across global markets. The 14-month report, "Balancing Rules and Flexibility," focuses on similarities and differences in CG requirements. It does not review compliance or outcomes. The study aims to provide insights for companies and regulators to balance rules with flexibility in governance.

site_title: Numoni awarded for infocomm innovation
summary: Numoni, a Singapore-based payments company, won the "Most Innovative Infocomm Product/Solution" award at the National Infocomm Awards for its Nugen, a cash-based self-service terminal that allows people without bank accounts to access basic financial services. The Nugen enables users to top-up prepaid airtime, pay bills, and make small remittances. The award recognizes Numoni's innovative solution to bring the digital economy to the masses, with a goal of reaching 80% of the world's population.

site_title: Use open conference calls for listed firms' updates
summary: Singapore listed companies have been criticized for selectively disclosing post-result information to analysts, institutional investors, and the media, leaving retail investors in the dark. This practice, common in advanced markets like the US, denies retail investors an equal opportunity to access important information. Market regulators are urged to make it mandatory for companies to hold open conference calls to address this issue, giving retail investors a fairer chance to make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Euro gets respite from German index rebound
summary: The euro gained 0.2% against the US dollar on Monday after a stronger-than-expected German business survey, but remained close to a two-year low due to bets of further easing in the eurozone. European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi's comments on the need for faster inflation reduction also weighed on the euro. The dollar rose 0.4% against the yen, while most emerging Asian currencies rose as investors sought stimulus in China and Europe.

site_title: Mexico's assembly plants turning out top-of-the-line German cars
summary: Mexico is set to become a major hub for German luxury car production, with BMW, Audi, and Mercedes-Benz announcing plans to build billion-dollar factories in the country. By the end of the decade, Mexico is expected to claim fourth place globally in terms of German luxury car output, surpassing Belgium, Spain, and Brazil. The country's emergence as an auto-assembly powerhouse is attributed to its skilled workforce, expanding domestic parts industry, and favorable business environment, which has won over the trust and investment of top car manufacturers.

site_title: Iras gets tougher on fraudulent PIC claims
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has strengthened its efforts to curb abuse of the Productivity and Innovation (PIC) scheme by introducing new laws and measures. As of October 31, Iras has recovered or denied cash payouts and bonuses for 150 cases, totaling S$7.6 million. Businesses must now show IT and automation equipment is on premises for cash payouts, and those promoting abusive arrangements can be punished. Iras has flagged 4,500 high-risk applications, with 1,485 rejected due to compliance issues.

site_title: Schlumberger-Anton venture to reduce headcount
summary: A joint venture between Schlumberger Ltd and Anton Oilfield Services Group, Tongzhou IPM Services Co, will reduce headcount to cut operating costs after failing to win enough contracts. The Sichuan-based venture, which has participated in some oilfield-services projects in China, may earn $20 million this year. The partnership's slower-than-expected development and high operational costs have led to the decision. Schlumberger will continue to own its 20% stake in Anton, and the venture's eventual fate will be decided by both partners at an appropriate time.

site_title: Tech helps boost SME productivity
summary: Old Street Bak Kut Teh, a Singaporean restaurant chain, has seen a 30% increase in business since implementing an e-menu system that allows customers to place orders on iPads. The system, provided by Aptsys, streamlines operations and reduces wait times from 25 minutes to 10 minutes. The restaurant chain has also seen improved efficiency in serving customers and increased staff productivity, enabling them to focus on customer service. The deployment of technology has also helped the company make smarter procurement and planning decisions, reducing food wastage.

site_title: Nanshan Group's Song family buys GCB in Holland Park
summary: The Nanshan Group, a China-based conglomerate, has purchased a brand-new Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Holland Park, Singapore, for S$30 million through its director Sui Yongqing. The property has a land area of 15,070.54 sq ft and features a pool, lift, five bedrooms, and a helper's room. This is part of the group's increasing presence in the Singapore property market, following recent purchases, including a S$270 million site in Middle Road and a S$173.57 million plot in Lorong Puntong.

site_title: Obama's immigration changes fall short, say US tech, medical sectors
