The trend, driven by interest in professional sporting watches and celebrity endorsements, has led to a surge in sales. TW Steel, a Dutch watch brand, was one of the first to capitalize on the trend, introducing its Canteen Collection in 2005. The company's watches, which feature large dials and durable steel cases, have become a staple in the market, with distributors now available in 100 countries. Experts predict the trend will continue, with larger watches becoming a fashion statement and a way to differentiate from smart watches.

site_title: Airbus wins order for 50 planes from Delta
summary: Delta Air Lines has ordered 50 new planes from Airbus, including 25 A350-900s and 25 A330-900neos, beating Boeing in the bid. The order, valued at around $6 billion, was won by Airbus due to its ability to deliver planes sooner. The deal marks a significant victory for Airbus in the US wide-body market and validates the company's decision to produce a new version of its A330 plane with more energy-efficient engines.

images.alt_text: OFFERING FUEL EFFICIENCY: Industry analysts estimate that Delta could get as much as 60 per cent off the list price, putting the total value of the Airbus order at roughly US$6 billion.

site_title: Genting's Q3 net profit down by almost 24%
summary: Genting Malaysia reported a 23.6% drop in third-quarter profit to RM352.7 million, primarily due to declining revenue from its Singapore casino unit. The group's net profit was lower than the same period last year. This decline was attributed to the impact of falling revenue from big money gamblers.

images.alt_text: FALLING REVENUE: China's corruption crackdown and economic slowdown have reduced the number of VIPs at casino tables.

site_title: Market players welcome LTA regulation of third-party taxi apps (Amended)
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has introduced a regulatory framework for third-party taxi-booking apps, aiming to safeguard commuter safety and interests. The new rules, set to come into effect in the second quarter of 2015, require third-party apps to disclose fare rates, surcharges, and fees upfront, and to ensure equal accessibility to all commuters. Major players such as GrabTaxi, Easy Taxi, Uber, and Hailo have welcomed the move, praising its balance between flexibility and consumer protection. The regulations also require drivers to hold a taxi driver's vocational licence and prohibit bidding and pre-trip tipping.

site_title: YouTube goes online for second Music Awards
summary: YouTube is revamping its Music Awards for the second edition, ditching a star-studded gala for a day-long online celebration in March 2015. The site will use existing metrics to determine video popularity, focusing on content expected to generate buzz in the coming year. This change aims to provide a more forward-looking and unique experience, showcasing collaborations between top directors and creators. The overhaul comes after the inaugural awards received criticism for lacking a distinct YouTube flavor and poor reception among social media users.

site_title: Interim Sanofi head gives assurance on leadership
summary: Sanofi's interim head has sought to reassure investors about the company's leadership and stability after the sudden firing of its CEO three weeks ago. The change was due to a row over management style, causing stock prices to plummet. Despite this, the interim head confirmed that there was still a "pilot in charge" and expressed confidence in the company's viability.

site_title: Greek port unit of Cosco Pacific lands 4th cargo-train MNC customer
summary: Greece's Piraeus port unit, Piraeus Container Terminal SA (PCT), has secured its fourth multinational cargo-train customer, bolstering its goal of becoming a main trade gateway into Europe. The new client, an Asian electronics manufacturer, uses rail-freight services to transport high-value goods to central Europe. This addition, along with existing clients Huawei Technologies Co, ZTE Corp, and Hewlett-Packard Co, is expected to increase demand for sea and rail transport in the region. PCT aims to expand operations and become a distribution centre for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa.

site_title: Thai government to boost growth through infrastructure spending
summary: The Thai government plans to boost economic growth through infrastructure spending, accelerating projects on mass transit, railways, and roads. The ministry aims to invest $91.5 billion in transport infrastructure from 2015 to 2022. The move comes as the country's economy faces a slowdown, with forecasted growth of one percent in 2014 and exports expected to remain flat. The government has also introduced a stimulus package of $11 billion and plans to increase budget spending to boost domestic consumption.

site_title: Goldman fires two bankers over secret Fed documents
summary: Goldman Sachs has fired two employees after a junior banker brought secret documents from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York into the firm. The incident prompted an internal memo stating the firm has "zero tolerance" for improper handling of confidential information. The move follows a series of allegations of regulatory capture and conflicts of interest, including a former examiner's secretly recorded conversations with New York Fed co-workers. Goldman Sachs is reviewing its hiring policies from governmental institutions to ensure effectiveness and robustness.

site_title: Tech-savvy customers find their FairPrice online
summary: FairPrice, a Singaporean supermarket chain, has revamped its online portal to make shopping for groceries on-the-go easier. The portal is now mobile-optimized, allowing customers to access and purchase over 5,100 SKUs online. The company has also introduced a Click&Collect service, allowing customers to pick up orders at selected stores or Esso Service stations. With a 15% year-on-year growth in online sales and 45,000 active online subscribers, FairPrice is poised to capitalize on Singapore's growing e-commerce market, predicted to reach $4.4 billion by next year.

site_title: Golden Ocean Group posts Q3 loss of S$11.4m
summary: Golden Ocean Group Limited posted a net loss of S$11.4 million for Q3 2014, down from a net profit of S$15.4 million in the same period last year. Total operating revenue decreased to S$53.4 million. The company will merge with Knightsbridge Shipping in 2015, creating a leading dry bulk company with 72 vessels. A dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents was declared for Q3. The merger is expected to close in the first quarter of 2015 and is subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: China's hopes for shale boom may be fading
summary: China has cut its shale gas output target for the end of the decade to a third of its earlier estimate, citing difficult geology, lack of infrastructure, and limited exploration rights. The nation had awarded exploration rights to 18 companies in 2011 and 2012, but only one, state-owned China Petroleum & Chemical Corp, has started to produce commercially. Lower crude prices and China's commitment to clean energy also weigh on shale's promise, with the country instead focusing on renewable sources. China's shale boom may be fizzling out before it even gets going.

site_title: The end is nigh? Just turn down the noise
summary: Australian shares have risen despite ongoing global economic concerns, such as the Ukraine conflict, China's property market, and the US rate hike speculation. This volatility is reminiscent of the 2014 Australian recession and the 2013 US fiscal cliff. Despite these worries, markets continue to climb, with the S&P 500 reaching a record high. Experts attribute the resilience to dollar asset diversification, productivity gains, and the growth of retail investors in Asia and Europe, driving massive ETF growth.

site_title: A tale of 5 million immigrants
summary: President Barack Obama pledged a "more fair and more just" immigration system, offering protection from deportation to nearly 5 million undocumented migrants who have lived in the US for over five years and have a US citizen or legal permanent resident child. They can apply for three-year work authorizations, allowing families to emerge from the shadows and seek work permits. The move infuriated Republican critics, but Obama aimed to fix the "broken" immigration system.

site_title: Modi nearly out of time to meet deficit goals
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is running out of time to meet the country's 2014/15 fiscal deficit target of 4.1% of GDP, with a tough budget due in February that may require spending cuts. Despite implementing pro-growth measures, the economy remains sluggish, with factories operating at 30% below capacity. Opposition parties are opposing key bills, including a constitutional amendment for a goods and services tax, raising concerns of a parliamentary log jam. Experts predict the economy may miss its growth target, citing a need for looser fiscal policy to revive economic growth.

site_title: The 'folklore' of finance
summary: A nearly two-year study by State Street found that investors' mistaken beliefs, or "folklore of finance," contribute to their failure to achieve high returns and long-term objectives. The study identified two disconnects: the difficulty in achieving alpha (beating a benchmark) due to overconfidence and a lack of understanding of long-term goals. Investors prioritize short-term gains over long-term objectives and are often misled by performance ratings and external validation. The study advocates for a more nuanced approach, focusing on goal-setting and regular check-ins with advisers to address behavioral biases and improve investment decisions.

site_title: Draghi widens QE as recovery wanes
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi widened the scope for quantitative easing, warning that a stronger economic recovery is unlikely in the coming months. Draghi emphasized the need to raise "very low" inflation quickly, stating that the ECB will step up its efforts if current measures fail to lift inflation. The ECB's price stability mandate requires the bank to take action to raise inflation and inflation expectations, and Draghi vowed to do so by expanding and broadening the channels of intervention if necessary.

site_title: Keppel unit buys data centre in the Netherlands
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) has acquired a 5,000 square meter data centre in Almere, Netherlands, to meet growing demand for high-quality data centres in Europe. The data centre, Almere Data Centre 2, will be fitted to Tier III power and cooling standards and is located near Amsterdam. It will be included in Keppel's data centre real estate investment trust (Keppel DC Reit), which is targeted for a December listing, alongside an adjacent fully occupied property, Almere Data Centre 1.

site_title: Sino Construction morphing from building to resource player
summary: Sino Construction, a Singapore-listed company, has announced the successful completion of trial batches of coal from its Mongolian mine Baruun Noyon Uul (BNU). The company's first trial batches of coal will recommence operations, marking a significant step in its transformation into a resource player. Sino Construction has been aggressively acquiring coal assets, with a focus on high-grade thermal coal and coking coal for steel-making, in response to China's policy changes that have led to higher import taxes and quality restrictions on coal.

site_title: Indonesia firm sells first SGD bond with S$180m issue
summary: Indonesian firm Protelindo Finance has sold its first SGD bond in Singapore, worth S$180 million, with a 10-year 3.25% interest rate. The bond is guaranteed by the Asian Development Bank's Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF), promoting financial stability and long-term investment in the region. The deal was oversubscribed, with 91% of the issue going to Singapore investors, and is the largest CGIF-guaranteed transaction to date.

site_title: Blackstone to buy GE Japan's residential property arm
summary: Blackstone Group LP agreed to buy GE Japan Corp's residential property business for over $2.1 billion, expanding its apartment holdings in Japan. The business owns and operates over 200 properties with 10,000 units, mainly in Tokyo, Osaka, and Fukuoka. The acquisition, valued at 45% of Advance Residence Investment Corp's portfolio, is part of Blackstone's expansion in the Japanese market, driven by the weak yen and low interest rates. The deal is expected to boost demand for rental housing in Japan's major cities.

site_title: Fresh face of retail
summary: Department stores in Singapore, such as Metro and Tangs, are revamping their spaces and introducing new outlets ahead of the Christmas shopping season. Metro has transformed its store at The Centrepoint with a barber shop, bespoke furniture, and monogramming services, while Tangs has added two floors dedicated to fashion brands. These moves aim to appeal to younger shoppers and provide a more immersive experience, as online shopping continues to grow. The stores are also incorporating digital initiatives, such as mobile POS and a mobile shopping app, to cater to changing consumer trends.

site_title: Thailand, Indonesia, M'sia plan rubber exchange
summary: Asian rubber producers Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia are planning a regional exchange to facilitate physical trading of rubber, allowing producers and consumers to hedge and ease transactions among the three countries. The exchange, expected to launch within 18 months, will initially offer 30-day delivery contracts denominated in US dollars. The move aims to reduce excess supply and shore up global prices, which plummeted to five-year lows in October. The exchange could eventually be expanded to include other rubber-producing countries, potentially competing with established futures contracts traded on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange and Singapore Commodity Exchange.

site_title: Karting fun for BMW owners
summary: BMW owners participated in a high-speed karting event at the KF1 Karting Circuit in Mandai, organized by Performance Motors. Up to 40 owners, mostly from the Performance Motorsports Circle club, engaged in a three-evening competition, with each participant paying S$250 for dinner, trophies, and prizes. This event is part of the company's customer engagement activities, which also include a dedicated driving simulator at the BMW showroom.

site_title: KL scraps decades-old fuel subsidy policy
summary: Malaysia will abolish its decades-old fuel subsidy policy starting December 1, with the cost of petrol and diesel based on a managed float system. The move is seen as an opportunity to scale back subsidies amid falling global fuel prices. The decision is part of Prime Minister Najib Razak's plan to trim the fiscal deficit to 3.5% of GDP by 2015 and achieve a balanced budget by 2020. The Malaysian ringgit rose 0.3% against the US dollar following the announcement.

images.alt_text: PM NAJIB: Wants to trim M'sia's fiscal deficit from 3.9% of GDP in 2013 to 3.5% this year and 3% in 2015

site_title: Honda admits it failed to comply fully with US law
summary: Honda admitted to failing to fully comply with US law regarding reporting of Takata air bag-related deaths and injuries. The company will provide an internal review of its reporting practices to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration by November 24. Honda could face a $35 million fine if found in violation of the Transportation Recall Enhancement, Accountability and Documentation Act. The company has linked two US deaths to the air bags and is investigating two more.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Lian Beng Group has entered a joint venture deal to redevelop a Mandai plot, with The Legacy Industrial and Wealth Property holding 65% and 35% equity interest respectively. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a warehouse in South Korea for S$25.2 million. Viva Industrial Trust raised S$15.6 million through a private placement. Marco Polo Marine posted a net profit of S$2.5 million for Q4, down 40% from the previous year.

site_title: Human capital development still top priority for Singapore
summary: Singapore remains committed to human capital development, citing its success as a top priority. Despite ranking 16th globally in the World Talent Report, the government emphasizes its focus on skills and talent development, as seen in the establishment of the SkillsFuture Council. This effort aims to address the need for more local talent, while also attracting foreign high-skilled labor. The government's dedication to human capital development underscores its recognition of the importance of a skilled workforce in driving the country's continued success.

site_title: Analysts evenly split on Opec decision
summary: OPEC analysts are evenly split on whether to cut supply at the upcoming meeting, with half forecasting a reduction to stem plunging prices and the other half expecting no change. The decision poses a difficult choice, as cutting output could lose market share to US shale drillers, while doing nothing could deter US growth and squeeze finances of poorer members. Prices are expected to be volatile, with some predicting a potential price increase of $10 if OPEC does nothing.

site_title: China cuts benchmark interest rates, first since July 2012
summary: China cut benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012, lowering the one-year deposit rate to 2.75% and the one-year lending rate to 5.6%. The move aims to support the world's second-largest economy, which is experiencing its slowest full-year growth since 1990. The decision contrasts with the Federal Reserve's halt to quantitative easing and follows a series of liquidity injections and targeted cuts to reserve requirements. The PBOC ruled out aggressive measures to stimulate growth, citing a still-growing economy.

site_title: JBS to pay A$1.45b to buy Primo Group
summary: JBS SA, the world's largest meat producer, has agreed to pay A$1.45 billion (S$1.6 billion) to acquire Primo Group, the largest producer of ham and bacon in Australia and New Zealand. The acquisition aims to increase exports to Asia, particularly China, where pork demand has increased by four-fold since 2009. Primo's five processing plants, employing 3,000 people, will be integrated into JBS, enabling the company to capitalize on the growing demand for processed meats in Asia.

site_title: Alibaba sells US$8b of bonds at reduced yields
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd raised $8 billion in bonds at yields lower than initially offered, with investors submitting orders of at least $57 billion. The bonds, priced at 95 basis points above similar-maturity Treasuries for the 5-year notes and 128 basis points for the 10-year notes, were sold to refinance credit agreements. This sale adds to the banner year for corporate bonds, with worldwide issuance reaching $3.8 trillion and on pace to exceed $4 trillion. Alibaba's notes are rated A+, or the fifth-highest investment-grade ranking.

site_title: iFast Corp plans 32.8m share IPO
summary: iFAST Corp plans to issue 32.8 million new shares in an initial public offering, with 2.8 million for the public and 30 million for cornerstone investors. The company intends to use the proceeds for expansion, acquisitions, and working capital. Existing major shareholders will hold 50.89% of the post-offering share capital, while the cornerstone investors will hold 7.4%. The IPO aims to raise funds for the company's growth in China, product enhancement, and other working capital purposes.

site_title: HSBC says Swiss unit charged in Paris with money-laundering
summary: HSBC's Swiss unit, HSBC Private Bank, has been charged in Paris with money-laundering, with a 50 million euro guarantee demanded. The bank stated it will cooperate with French authorities. This development follows HSBC's 2012 settlement with US regulators over money-laundering issues.

site_title: Roar for our Lions in their den
summary: The Asean Football Federation Suzuki Cup, co-hosted by Singapore and Vietnam, kicks off this weekend at the National Stadium in Kallang. Singapore, the defending champions, faces Thailand in the opening match, while their second opponent is Myanmar, coached by Radojko Avramovic, who previously led the Lions to three Suzuki Cup wins. The group stage is considered the "Group of Death" due to the unpredictable matches, with Singapore also facing Malaysia in the final match. The grand final will take place on December 20, with the winner retaining the trophy on home soil.

site_title: Toll rises to 10 in killer US snowstorm
summary: A rare pre-winter snowstorm in the northeastern US has paralysed communities for days, killing 10 people and dumping over six feet of snow near Buffalo. The National Weather Service warns of "lake effect snow" and hazardous travel conditions, with a state of emergency in place. The storm has caused widespread damage, cancelled flights, and stranded motorists, with over 5,000 people assisting with snow removal and recovery efforts. Temperatures are expected to rise above freezing on Saturday, prompting severe flood warnings.

site_title: Design Coup
summary: Mercedes-AMG unveiled its new GT coupe, marking a new design language for the brand. The car features a 4.0-litre V8 biturbo engine with 462 hp in the GT and 510 hp in the GT S. Its styling, dubbed "sensual purity," is characterized by a more compact design, reduced front overhang, and a strong rear end. The car's exterior designer, Mark Fetherston, aimed to create a cohesive design that resembles the original concept model. The AMG GT is a foray into a new segment, competing with the Porsche 911 Carrera S and Jaguar F-Type, and represents a clear identity for Mercedes' high-performance division.

site_title: Britain drops bid to overturn EU cap on bankers' bonuses
summary: Britain has abandoned its bid to overturn the EU cap on bankers' bonuses after a senior EU official rejected its arguments at the EU Court of Justice. Chancellor George Osborne stated he won't pursue the challenge further, redirecting efforts to counter the effects of the EU remuneration rules. The UK Treasury may develop standards to ensure non-bonus pay is at risk, echoing remarks from Bank of England governor Mark Carney. The EU rules, which limit bonuses to twice basic salary, are seen as valid, according to the EU Court of Justice's non-binding opinion.

site_title: Jeff Bezos makes his mark on Washington Post with new app
summary: Jeff Bezos has launched a new app for Amazon Kindle tablet owners, delivering The Washington Post content for free for six months. The app, designed in collaboration with Bezos, aims to reduce "cognitive overhead" by streamlining news content, a principle Bezos introduced to Amazon. The Post's culture is reportedly merging with Bezos' ideas, with a focus on expanding its national and international audience. The app will feature two editions daily and cost $1 after the initial six-month free period.

site_title: China commits US$45.6b for projects in Pakistan
summary: China has committed $45.6 billion to various energy and infrastructure projects in Pakistan over the next six years, as part of the China-Pak Economic Corridor (CPEC). The projects, valued at $33.8 billion for energy and $11.8 billion for infrastructure, aim to solve Pakistan's crippling power shortages and include investments from major Chinese companies. The deal is expected to add 16,000 megawatts of electricity to Pakistan's grid by 2021, reducing power shortages by 4,000 to 7,000 megawatts.

site_title: Over US$2b of 1MDB's Cayman funds managed by Aussie firm
summary: Australian firm Avestra Asset Management is managing over $2 billion of 1Malaysia Development Bhd's funds invested in Cayman Islands funds, including Bridge Global Absolute Return Fund. Avestra shares executives with Bridge Global, whose fund 1MDB has invested in. The funds, which generated $267 million in dividends, were invested via segregated portfolio companies in the Cayman Islands. 1MDB has not provided details on the funds or the names of the fund manager, despite criticism for its opaque investment decisions and high debt.

site_title: Play on banks overshadows Shanghai-HK connect, news of Japan recession
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 3,345.32 on Friday, driven by big price gains in the banking sector, which accounted for around three-quarters of the index's weekly gain of 30 points. The sector's upward trend is attributed to upgrades by brokers in the past two to three weeks. However, dealers predict that the play could be short-lived due to lacking liquidity and diverse investor participation. Meanwhile, corporate news included a proposed merger between Keppel Infrastructure Trust and CitySpring Infrastructure Trust, and Yoma Strategic's involvement in a joint venture to operate Mandalay airport.

site_title: ECB's Draghi throws door to QE wide open as recovery wanes
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi announced the potential for more drastic measures to revive the eurozone economy, citing "excessively low" inflation. Draghi stated that the ECB would expand its quantitative easing program if current measures are ineffective in raising inflation, and could consider purchasing sovereign bonds. This move is seen as a significant escalation of the ECB's efforts to combat low growth and weak inflation, which has persisted for months.

site_title: Urban farmers
summary: Urban farming is gaining popularity in Singapore, with many city dwellers growing their own edible greens on balconies, in offices, and neighborhood plots. Celebrities like Spa Esprit's CEO Cynthia Chua and urban farmer Gina Ong are investing in urban farming initiatives, with Chua investing in Edible Gardens, an urban farming consultancy firm, and Ong managing community gardens in Marine Crescent and Laguna Park. These urban farmers are growing a variety of vegetables, herbs, and fruits, including kale, basil, and papaya, and are sharing their experiences and tips on sustainable living. Companies like Singapore Technologies Kinetics and hotels like Fairmont Singapore and Swissotel The Stamford are also embracing urban farming, with their own private gardens providing fresh produce for their restaurants and bars.

site_title: Removing the corrupt culture in banking
summary: A new study published in Nature found that bankers are more likely to cheat and lie when they think of themselves as bankers, rather than as everyday people. In a simple coin-flipping game, bankers who were primed to think of themselves as bankers cheated significantly more often than those who were primed to think of themselves as everyday people. The study suggests that this "banker" identity is a key factor in the corrupt culture of banking, and that changing this identity could help address the issue. The study's findings have profound implications for how banks are run and regulated, and may require a fundamental shift in the way bankers think of themselves and their role in society.

site_title: SGX to launch 5 petrochemical derivatives
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to launch five petrochemical derivatives by the end of January 2015 to provide market players with better hedge options. These contracts will be the first in the market to be cleared on an exchange, offering more effective risk management solutions.

site_title: Audi scores with sports models
summary: Audi has set ambitious sales targets for Asia, with a projected 1.7 million cars for 2015, up from 1.5 million previously. The company expects its sports models, such as S, RS, and R8, to drive growth, with year-to-date sales increasing by 50%. Audi aims to reach 2 million cars by 2020 and is developing its premium high-performance wing, with enhanced S, RS, and R8 models being established in dealerships. The brand is well-positioned to surpass its competitors, Mercedes-Benz and BMW, globally under the leadership of Luca de Meo.

site_title: Chinese insurer buys Sydney's Hyde Park Sheraton for A$463m
summary: Chinese insurer Sunshine Insurance Group has purchased the Sydney's Hyde Park Sheraton hotel for A$463 million from Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide. The sale allows Sunshine to diversify its holdings with a "trophy asset" in Sydney. This transaction follows other recent sales of high-end hotels in Sydney, including the Four Seasons and Sofitel Wentworth, as foreign buyers continue to show interest in the city's luxury hotels.

site_title: US: Wall St climbs at open on China rate cut
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, setting major indexes up for a fifth week of gains, after China's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for the first time in over two years to boost its cooling economy. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 131.46 points, or 0.74%, to 17,850.46, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained 12.43 and 48.57 points, respectively.

site_title: One-stop foodie haven
summary: A new online platform, Batch, has launched to connect food lovers with artisanal products from independent makers, chefs, and kitchen artisans. Founder Debbie Yong aims to elevate domesticity to an art by offering a one-stop shop for quality and taste. The site features exclusive collaboration items, specialty products created by chefs, and resources for home cooks and foodies. Batch also includes behind-the-scenes interviews and videos with food makers and chefs, and plans to launch retail pop-ups for Christmas.

site_title: Raising the bar
summary: The local cocktail bar scene in Singapore has evolved, with many establishments now offering handcrafted drinks and unique ambiances. To stand out, bar owners are creating new concepts, such as The Library, a password-required speakeasy, and Long Play, a vinyl record bar. Experts like Loh Lik Peng, owner of The Library, believe that the sophisticated clientele demands more from bars, leading to increased competition and innovation in the industry.

site_title: Swiss vote to abolish tax breaks for rich losing impetus
summary: The Swiss electorate is set to vote on November 30 on a proposal to abolish a 152-year-old tax break for rich foreigners, known as the forfait. Despite a recent poll showing 46% of voters are against abolishing the system, the move has been met with opposition from bankers and the government, who warn it could crimp revenues, cut jobs, and reduce Switzerland's appeal as a destination for wealthy individuals. The forfait allows foreigners to negotiate lump-sum payments with Swiss cantons, exempting them from income tax.

site_title: Immigration: Doing the right thing
summary: The article discusses President Barack Obama's new immigration initiative, focusing on offering decent treatment to undocumented children who have grown up in the US and are already Americans in every sense. The author, who has a personal connection to immigration, supports the initiative as a matter of human decency, citing the positive experience of their own grandparents who came to the US as immigrants. The author argues that treating undocumented children with dignity and offering them citizenship is not only humane but also beneficial for the economy and society, as they will become taxpayers, workers, and neighbours.

site_title: EDBI invests in e-signature firm DocuSign
summary: EDBI, the investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board, has joined Samsung Ventures and BBVA Ventures in investing in DocuSign, a US-based e-signature firm, in a series E round of funding. The trio's investments total US$115 million, with EDBI leveraging its network to boost growth in Singapore's cloud and online services. DocuSign's technology enables secure digital transactions, and the company expects to help Singapore push into cloud services and online financial services.

site_title: Married children to get better chance of getting HDB flat near parents
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has announced that up to 30% of new flat supply will be reserved for first-timer families and up to 15% for second-timer families. Married children who want to live near their parents will have a greater chance of success when applying for flats under this new scheme.

site_title: Indonesian leader plans powerful "kitchen cabinet" to bolster reforms
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo plans to introduce a "kitchen cabinet" of four trusted aides to help push through reforms in the country. The team will have extensive powers, including designing policies and setting targets for ministries. This move comes after Widodo's unpopular decision to impose fuel price hikes and is a sign he wants to assert control over a potentially unruly cabinet. The reforms aim to address corruption, which is seen as deeply entrenched in Indonesia's economy.

site_title: Credit Suisse's US$2.6b tax evasion plea deal faces last hurdle
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to a US$2.6 billion plea deal to resolve allegations of helping wealthy Americans avoid paying taxes. The deal, which includes penalties for the US Treasury, Federal Reserve, and New York State Department of Financial Services, faces a final hurdle from a federal judge who will decide whether to accept or reject the agreement. A conviction could disqualify the bank from handling pension assets valued at billions of dollars, and its ability to serve as a qualified professional asset manager is under review by the Labor Department.

site_title: Survey prompts rethink on heavy drinkers
summary: A US government study of 138,100 adults found that 9 out of 10 heavy drinkers are not alcoholics and can change their behavior with prompting. The survey counters conventional wisdom that every "falling-down drunk" must be addicted to alcohol. Excessive drinking, defined as 5+ drinks for men or 4+ drinks for women, affects 29% of the population, but only 10% meet the criteria for alcoholism. Strategies to curb excessive drinking include increasing taxes, zoning laws, and physician interventions, which have shown promise in reducing consumption.

site_title: EU's search for new anti-dumping powers is dead, Italy says
summary: The EU's proposed plan to grant Brussels new anti-dumping powers to fight unfair Chinese exports has been deemed "dead" by Italy, citing ideological divisions among member states. The plan, which aimed to make it easier to penalize exporters selling goods below production costs, faced opposition from countries like France, which sees it as protectionism, and Sweden, which advocates for free trade. The proposal needs approval from EU governments, with the European Commission and Parliament supporting it, but the divisions have stalled its progress.

site_title: Malaysia's Genting net profit drops 23.6 pct as Singapore gaming unit drags
summary: Malaysia's Genting reported a 23.6% decline in third-quarter net profit to 352.7 million ringgit (US$105.21 million) due to a weaker performance by its Singapore gaming unit. This drop is attributed to a decrease in revenue from its Singapore gaming business. The company's net profit was lower compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Owner of luxury retailer Net-a-Porter eyes 2015 IPO: Bloomberg
summary: Luxury goods group Richemont is considering a market listing for online retailer Net-a-Porter as early as 2015, according to Bloomberg. Richemont acquired two-thirds of Net-a-Porter in 2010 and bolstered its luxury internet shopping position. The company has held talks with advisers over options, including an initial public offering and a sale of the business. This move comes after Richemont denied sale plans last year after talks with Italian rival Yoox.

site_title: VW announces multi-billion investment plan on expansion, models
summary: Volkswagen announced a 5-year, 85.6 billion euro ($106 billion) investment plan to expand its operations globally, focusing on sports utility vehicles and modernizing its light commercial vehicle portfolio. The majority of spending will be on new models and technology based on the modular toolkit, with investments also planned in China's joint ventures, totaling 22 billion euros. This move aims to support the company's quest for global leadership despite an austerity drive.

site_title: Barbie under siege from book gaffe and rival doll
summary: Mattel's Barbie is facing criticism for a 2010 book titled "I Can Be a Computer Engineer" that depicted the doll as less technically savvy than male peers, leading to accusations of sexism. The book was removed from Amazon and other outlets after a backlash on social media. Meanwhile, a new rival doll, marketed as having more realistic features such as acne and stretch marks, has been gaining attention. Mattel has apologized for the book's portrayal of women, highlighting the ongoing challenges of promoting positive and inclusive representations of women in toys and media.

site_title: UK October public finances show improvement
summary: Britain's public finances improved slightly in October, with public sector net borrowing totaling £7.706 billion (S$15.73 billion), down 2.4% from a year earlier. This beats economists' forecasts of £7.9 billion. The improvement gives finance minister George Osborne hope that the budget might recover at a faster pace ahead of next year's general election.

site_title: China rate cut boosts miners
summary: China cut benchmark interest rates for the first time in over two years, boosting shares in mining companies, including Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, and Anglo American. The move is seen as an effort to tackle slower growth. European markets, including the FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40, also rose, with miners being among the biggest gainers. The People's Bank of China slashed its one-year deposit rate to 2.75% and its lending rate to 5.6%.

site_title: China central bank cuts interest rates to lift sagging economy
summary: China's central bank cut benchmark interest rates for the first time in over two years to lower borrowing costs and boost the cooling economy. The People's Bank of China lowered one-year benchmark lending rates by 40 basis points to 5.6%, while deposit rates were lowered by 25 basis points. The moves aim to lift the economy, which is on track for its slowest annual growth in 24 years. The interest rate cuts will take effect on November 22.

site_title: Without QE, ECB balance sheet ambitions crimped by bank squeeze
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) efforts to prime the eurozone economy with a trillion euros are hindered by commercial banks' lack of appetite for its cheap money. The ECB's balance sheet has shrunk by a third since 2012, and its current balance sheet is 1 trillion euros short of its target. A Reuters poll suggests the ECB's balance sheet will be 60 billion euros smaller when it hands out the second round of cheap loans in mid-December. Many strategists predict the ECB will launch a quantitative easing program by its March 5 meeting to meet its balance sheet ambitions.

site_title: Malaysia to abolish fuel subsidies from December: ministry
summary: Malaysia will abolish fuel subsidies for petrol and diesel starting December 1, according to the government. Retail prices for RON95 petrol and diesel will be fixed according to a managed float system. This move aims to save the government more than US$8 billion next year, similar to Indonesia's recent increase in subsidized fuel prices.

site_title: MLT buys warehouse in South Korea for 21.4 billion won
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has agreed to acquire Smart Logistics Centre in South Korea for 21.4 billion won (S$25.2 million). The three-storey warehouse is fully leased to two established Korean logistics operators and will strengthen MLT's market position in Gyeonggi-do, South Korea's prime logistics hub. The acquisition is part of MLT's investment strategy to rebalance its portfolio towards higher growth markets and expand its presence in South Korea. The deal is expected to be completed by December 2014 and will increase MLT's total portfolio to 117 properties.

site_title: China's central bank says Chinese markets have ample liquidity
summary: China's central bank stated that its financial markets have ample liquidity, with the ability to provide support when needed. This comes after a recent rise in initial public offerings, which led to volatile short-term interest rates. The central bank cited the need for liquidity support amid a surge in money market rates as investors demanded more cash to buy new stock offerings.

site_title: Eurozone yields hit record low as Draghi shows more easing zeal
summary: Eurozone yields hit record lows as European Central Bank President Mario Draghi signaled that government debt purchases may be imminent. Ten-year bond yields in Ireland, Italy, and Austria fell to record lows, with Italian yields reaching 2.246%, and Irish and Austrian yields hitting 1.52% and 0.953%, respectively. Draghi's comments, which emphasized the need to raise inflation, lifted market expectations and boosted inflation-linked financial products, while sparking concerns in Germany over the potential for quantitative easing.

site_title: China central bank rules out strong economic stimulus after rate cut
summary: China's central bank ruled out strong economic stimulus after cutting interest rates for the first time in over two years. The People's Bank of China stated that the economy is growing at a reasonable speed, and no aggressive measures are needed. The rate cut aimed to further free up interest rates by allowing companies and individuals to sell negotiable certificates of deposits. The move is seen as a response to China's slowing GDP growth, but the bank emphasized that the economy is still on a stable path.

images.alt_text: China's economy is still growing at a reasonable speed and there is no need to use any aggressive measures to stimulate growth, the Chinese central bank said on Friday after cutting interest rates for the first time in more than two years.

site_title: Indonesia's Protelindo debuts in Singapore bond market with S$180 million issue
summary: Indonesian telco infrastructure company Protelindo has debuted in the Singapore bond market with a S$180 million 10-year, 3.25% bond guaranteed by the Asian Development Bank's Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF). The issuance was oversubscribed, with 91% of the issue allocated to investors in Singapore, and 97% to asset managers, insurance companies, and sovereign wealth funds. This marks the first CGIF-guaranteed transaction and aims to promote financial stability and boost long-term investment in the region.

site_title: China commits US$45.6b for economic corridor with Pakistan
summary: China has committed $45.6 billion to build energy and infrastructure projects in Pakistan over the next six years as part of the China-Pak Economic Corridor (CPEC) deal. The projects, valued at $33.8 billion for energy and $11.8 billion for infrastructure, will be financed by Chinese companies and banks, with Pakistan not taking on any additional debt. The deal aims to address Pakistan's power shortages, which have crippled its economy, and is seen as a key factor in strengthening ties between the two nations, with the potential to upset rival India.

site_title: China could overtake world's top two LNG buyers: Qatargas
summary: China may surpass Japan and South Korea as the world's top LNG buyer, according to Qatargas executive Iain Scott. Japan's LNG demand is forecast to fall to 60-70 million tonnes by 2020, while South Korea's demand may also decline. China's LNG imports have grown at 25% per year for the past four years, totaling around 18 million tonnes in 2013. Qatargas, the world's largest LNG producer, sees opportunities for growth in China and other markets, potentially replacing Japan and South Korea as top LNG buyers.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 29.72 points to 3,345.32. The 1.16 billion shares traded valued at S$1.09 billion, with 268 gainers and 151 losers. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Alarm for Singapore bonds as private bank bid falters
summary: Singapore's high-yield bond market is experiencing a slump as private banks reduce their appetite for local bonds, causing several bonds to fall in value. The decline in demand is attributed to the volatile global credit market and concerns over the oil and gas sector, which has been impacted by low crude oil prices. Companies such as Swiber Holdings and Loyz Energy have seen their bonds fall in value, while others like Ezion Holdings have managed to maintain their value. The market's reliance on private bank demand highlights the risks attached to illiquid placements.

site_title: ECB's negative rates to hit bank profits: Deutsche CFO
summary: Deutsche Bank's CFO, Stefan Krause, stated that European bank profits will suffer due to the European Central Bank's negative interest rate policy, as banks struggle to pass charges on to clients. The ECB's policy, which began in September, charges banks 0.20% interest to park funds at the central bank. Krause said banks will have to absorb the negative margin, potentially forcing them to reduce profits. Some banks, like Commerzbank AG, are considering passing deposit charges to major clients, but few have committed to doing so.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rebound as casinos gain, but shed over 2% on week
summary: Hong Kong shares rebounded on Friday, closing 0.4% higher as profit-taking pressure eased, but ended the week 2.7% lower. The Hang Seng Index and Hong Kong China Enterprises Index dropped 2.9% and 2.7% respectively, despite the launch of the "stock connect" between Hong Kong and Shanghai exchanges. Casino and oil companies were among the top gainers, while mainland Chinese investors took up less than 2% of daily trading quota.

site_title: EDBI invests in e-signature technology company DocuSign
summary: The investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDBI) has joined Samsung Ventures and BBVA Ventures in a series E round of funding for US-based e-signature technology company DocuSign, raising around US$115 million this year. The three new investors, along with existing ones, will help facilitate DocuSign's growth in Singapore and Asia. The investment is expected to support Singapore's push into cloud services and online financial services.

site_title: iFAST Corporation holding briefings for IPO
summary: iFAST Corporation, a regional financial services firm, is holding briefings for accredited investors to learn about its initial public offering (IPO) plans. The company, which operates in Malaysia, Hong Kong, and has key shareholder SPH AsiaOne, has kicked off its book building roadshows in the region and London.

site_title: UK retailers look to US Black Friday for Christmas lift-off
summary: UK retailers are expected to see a significant boost in Christmas sales from Black Friday promotions, with 65% of multi-channel retailers planning discounts on November 28. The event is expected to see 518 million pounds spent online, the largest day for e-commerce in the UK. Major retailers such as John Lewis, Dixons, and Asda are joining in, while Sainsbury's is taking part for the first time. However, some analysts question the commercial sense of the event, citing potential delays in autumn sales and blunted sales in subsequent weeks.

site_title: Indonesia introduces debt market benchmark indexes
summary: Indonesia's debt market regulator launched three benchmark indexes for local government and corporate bonds, providing investors with a reference for pricing and performance. The INDOBEX Composite index includes 54 government bonds and 256 corporate bonds, offering total return, clean price, and yield data. The move aims to increase liquidity and credibility in the bond market, encouraging more investors to participate in the Indonesian bond market, which sees significant daily transactions.

site_title: Alibaba prints jumbo deal without China premium
summary: Alibaba Group Holding successfully sold a $8 billion bond offering in the US market, priced tightly against US credit peers. The deal, which included six tranches, was oversubscribed with orders totaling $57 billion. Asian investors, who were allocated just 15-20% of the notes, found Alibaba bonds expensive due to the "China Discount" premium. The deal repriced the Asian tech space, with curves for Tencent and Baidu tightening. Alibaba's bonds were priced 30-50 basis points tighter than Chinese peers, with some investors opting for state-owned enterprises instead.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.33%

site_title: SGX launching five petrochemical derivatives products
summary: SGX is launching five new petrochemical derivatives products in response to increasing demand for effective risk management solutions. The products will be launched over the next two months, starting with the SGX Platts PX CFR China Swaps and Futures on December 2, 2014. Four other contracts will follow on January 19, 2015.

site_title: Eurozone yields near record lows as inflation expectations drop
summary: Eurozone bond yields remain near record lows as inflation expectations drop to one-month lows. The euro five-year, five-year breakeven forward fell to 1.80%, its lowest since Oct 24, amid speculation of further European Central Bank easing. Business activity data missed forecasts, and ECB policymakers' stronger hints of monetary policy easing measures contributed to the drop. This has supported bond bulls, with German 10-year Bund yields at 0.795% and Spanish yields at 2.07%. ECB President Mario Draghi and Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann are set to speak later.

site_title: LTA to set new rules for third-party taxi booking apps by Q2 next year
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore plans to introduce a basic regulatory framework for third-party taxi booking services by Q2 2015. These services must register with LTA, dispatch licensed taxis, and disclose upfront information on fare rates and fees. Bidding and pre-trip tipping are prohibited, and booking fees cannot exceed those charged by taxi companies. The regulations aim to safeguard commuter safety and interests, ensuring equal accessibility to all members of the public.

site_title: ST Engineering makes role changes to key management appointments
summary: Singapore Technologies Engineering (ST Engineering) has announced key management role changes, effective December 1, 2014. Lee Fook Sun will become deputy CEO, overseeing synergies across the group's four business sectors. Vincent Chong Sy Feng will be deputy CEO (corporate development), while Lim Serh Ghee will be president of ST Aerospace, replacing Tan Pheng Hock. The appointments aim to explore additional synergies and drive growth across the group's businesses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open flat
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on Friday, despite a record close on Wall Street, amid a lacklustre week following the disappointing launch of a link-up with the Shanghai exchange. The Hang Seng Index edged up 4.08 points to 23,353.72.

site_title: Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia plan regional rubber exchange
summary: Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia are planning a regional rubber exchange, expected to be set up within 18 months, to facilitate hedging and ease physical transactions among the three countries, which produce 70% of the world's natural rubber. The exchange will initially offer 30-day delivery physical rubber contracts denominated in US dollars, with plans to introduce futures contracts later. This move may stoke competition with existing rubber futures contracts traded on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange and Singapore Exchange, which are primarily used by consuming countries.

site_title: Yen recovers from multi-year lows
summary: The Japanese yen recovered from multi-year lows against the dollar and euro after a steep decline, but analysts predict further losses. The yen slipped to 117.85 yen against the dollar, a six-year high, while the euro reached 147.23 yen, also a six-year high. The yen's decline is attributed to Japan's economic slowdown and the Bank of Japan's expansion of its monetary easing program. The dollar, however, received support from upbeat US data, including a manufacturing index and existing-home sales, which suggests a strong US recovery despite weakness in other economies.

site_title: Obama's immigration tweaks leave Big Tech wanting more
summary: President Barack Obama announced plans to ease immigration rules for foreign tech workers, including letting spouses of H-1B visa holders work and streamlining visa applications. The changes aim to make it easier for high-skilled immigrants to stay and contribute to the US economy. However, Silicon Valley representatives expressed disappointment that the changes do not address longstanding demands for more visas and faster green cards. The tweaks are part of Obama's efforts to help undocumented people and address long-standing immigration issues.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 5-wk low as iron ore worries outweigh US promise
summary: Australian shares fell to a five-week low on Thursday, closing down 9.44 points or 0.2% to 5306.8, as concerns about a slump in iron ore prices outweighed positive US economic data. The S&P/ASX 200 index has now fallen for five straight sessions, trading at a 0.8% discount to 2013 levels. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also declined 0.6%.

site_title: Japan lower house dissolved ahead of election
summary: Japan's lower house parliament was dissolved ahead of a general election, expected on December 14, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seeks to consolidate power and reinvigorate his economic drive. Abe wants voters to endorse his decision to postpone a sales tax rise, which had negatively impacted the economy. The election comes after two of the "three arrows" of Abenomics have been fired, but a third remains stalled due to resistance from vested interests. Opinion polls show Abe's approval rate has fallen to 39%, with a disapproval rate of 40%.

site_title: Pressured Fed reviews of 'cosy' relations with banks
summary: The Federal Reserve announced it's reviewing its bank examination operations amid accusations of "regulatory capture" due to perceived cozy relations with banks. The reviews will examine whether inspectors and regulators receive necessary information and if divergent opinions are being considered. This comes after a former bank examiner, Carmen Segarra, alleged the New York Fed was soft on mega-banks like Goldman Sachs, citing questionable conflicts of interest and wrongful termination. The move follows a ProPublica article revealing recordings of Fed officials discussing Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.33%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed up 0.33% on Friday, driven by bargain-hunting ahead of Japan's upcoming election. The Nikkei 225 index rose 56.65 points to 17,357.51, while the Topix index gained 0.18%. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's dissolution of the lower house of parliament is seen as a positive factor by investors, who expect him to win and push for policies against deflation. The yen, which had fallen sharply in the past week, steadied against the dollar.

site_title: Long 'to do' list for India's Modi as clock ticks on reform
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces a tight deadline to implement pro-growth measures to meet the country's fiscal deficit target of 4.1% of GDP. Despite a surge in foreign investment, the economy remains sluggish, with factory utilisation and capital spending low. The government is pushing for legislation to allow foreign investment in the insurance industry and plans to auction coalfields and sell stakes in state-owned companies. However, critics warn that missing the fiscal target could be beneficial, as looser fiscal policy could aid the economic revival, with growth expected to be at the lower end of the 5.4-5.9% forecast.

site_title: Australia's RBA upbeat on outlook for China resource demand
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's head of economic research, Alexandra Heath, expressed optimism about China's resource demand, citing the country's urbanization and maturation into a consumer-led economy. Despite slower growth and increased supply of coal and iron ore, Heath believes China's demand for resources will remain strong in the medium to long term due to its large economy and ongoing urbanization. This supports prices for steel, food, and energy, according to Heath.

site_title: Seoul: Won recovers from 15-month low on yen rebound; shares edge higher
summary: The South Korean won recovered from a 15-month low against the Japanese yen, closing 1.2% lower for the fourth consecutive week. Despite the decline, the won edged higher against the dollar, closing at 1,113.8 to the dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.35% to 1,964.84, driven by risk appetites supported by US economic data and a rebound in the yen.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Friday, up 20.62 points to 3,336.22, with gains outnumbering losses 89 to 33. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Blackstone to buy GE's real estate in Japan for US$1.6b
summary: US private equity firm Blackstone has agreed to buy General Electric's residential real estate arm in Japan for approximately $2.08 billion, marking a significant investment in the country's recovering real estate market. The deal, valued at 190 billion yen, includes more than 10,000 units in 200 properties in major cities such as Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya. Blackstone believes in the fundamentals of the residential sector, particularly in Japan's major cities, and sees this acquisition as an opportunity to invest in a high-quality business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.14 points to 1817.15, amid a lack of significant market-moving news. The market saw 46.09 million lots traded worth RM13.76 million, with 91 gainers and 59 losers.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed at end of a downbeat week
summary: Asian markets ended the week on a mixed note, with Tokyo falling 0.85%, Sydney losing 0.16%, and Hong Kong shedding 0.17%, despite a record close on Wall Street. Japan slipped into recession, while a Hong Kong-Shanghai exchange link-up failed to impress investors. Shanghai edged up 0.12%, and Seoul gained 0.20%. US shares rose, with the Dow and S&P 500 hitting new peaks, driven by positive economic indicators, including a manufacturing index and existing-home sales.

site_title: Google tests replacing web ads with contributions
summary: Google has launched an experiment allowing users to support websites they frequent by making monthly donations in exchange for ad-free pages. The Google Contributor program, initially partnered with tech news sites Mashable and The Onion, allows users to set a donation amount between $1 and $3 per month. Donated funds are distributed based on visited websites, with Google keeping an unspecified portion. In return, users see a thank-you message with a pixel pattern where ads would normally appear.

site_title: GM shuffles top managers, including high-ranking women
summary: General Motors Co has reassigned four senior executives, including two high-ranking women, Mary Chan and Alicia Boler-Davis. Chan resigned as vice-president, global connected consumer, while Boler-Davis took over her duties. Boler-Davis also headed GM's quality organization, now assigned to Grace Lieblein. Steve Kiefer and Dan Nicholson have been reassigned to new roles, with Kiefer leaving and Nicholson taking over as vice-president, global powertrain. The changes aim to strengthen GM's customer-centric organization.

site_title: Airbus set to sign deal with Delta for 50 planes
summary: Airbus is set to sign a contract with Delta Airlines for 50 long-haul planes worth $14 billion, with 25 A350-900s and 25 A330-neos. The deal is expected to be finalized in the coming days, with the announcement potentially made next week. The order is a significant win for Airbus, which is competing with Boeing in the lucrative long-haul segment, and comes as Delta seeks to modernize its fleet and reap fuel savings.

site_title: Da Vinci: A man ahead of his time
summary: A large exhibition of Leonardo da Vinci's ideas is being shown at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore, featuring his mastery in five areas: mathematics, natural sciences, architecture, music, and technology. The exhibition includes video projections, models of his creations, and artworks inspired by da Vinci by five contemporary artists. The show celebrates both the old and new, with a focus on da Vinci's broad-based genius, as seen in his famous notebook, the Codex Atlanticus. The exhibition runs until May 2015, with tickets starting from S$10.50.

site_title: Singaporeans lead online shoppers in South-east Asia: survey
summary: Singaporeans lead online shopping in South-east Asia, with 26% of residents shopping online at least once a week and 58% doing so once a month, according to the Visa Consumer Payment Attitudes Study 2014. The study found 19% year-on-year growth in e-commerce transactions among Singaporean Visa cardholders, with the majority citing convenience, lower prices, and direct delivery as key drivers. The survey also revealed that Singaporeans prefer to shop online for travel, concert, and sporting tickets, with 51% buying flights online.

site_title: Nicaragua US$50b canal construction to start in December
summary: Nicaragua's US$50 billion canal construction project, aimed at rivaling the Panama Canal, is set to begin in December. Despite opposition from farmers and environmentalists, the Hong Kong-based company Hong Kong Nicaragua Development will start building the waterway, which will link the Caribbean and Pacific, with initial groundwork beginning on December 22. Environmental impact reports are to be completed before construction starts, and the project is expected to include ports, an airport, and an economic zone. Nicaragua's President Daniel Ortega hopes the project will create jobs and alleviate poverty, but concerns remain about its environmental impact.

site_title: Indonesia clears path for geothermal energy as power needs rise
summary: Indonesia aims to triple its geothermal power output by 2019, targeting 10% of the nation's power demand by 2020. The country plans to introduce reforms to streamline land acquisition, reduce regulatory hurdles, and increase investment in geothermal projects. With its unique geology and abundant heat resources, Indonesia has the potential to become the world's largest producer of geothermal energy, surpassing the Philippines and the US.

site_title: Bittersweet farewell from early-retiring Jason Mraz
summary: Jason Mraz is wrapping up his early retirement tour, a 3-hour acoustic show with his band Raining Jane, after a near-sold-out audience at The Star. The 37-year-old singer-songwriter has chosen to bow out to focus on charity work, showcasing his continued talent and positivity. The tour featured a mix of stripped-down versions of his hits, new songs, and covers, with Mraz's banter and humor saving the show from dragging. His farewell tour is a bittersweet end to a career marked by his "all-round nice guy" persona.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.26%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.26% lower on Friday, following a brief respite in the yen's fall, ahead of a snap election in Japan next month. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 17,256.58, as investors eyed the political developments. The yen's decline, which had fueled stock rises and falls in the currency, took a breather on Thursday. The US dollar rose to 118.15 yen, while the euro strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: World's ultra-rich getting much richer: UBS study
summary: A new study by UBS and Wealth-X reveals that 0.004% of the world's adult population controls nearly $30 trillion in assets, 13% of the world's total wealth, making them ultra-high net worth individuals. The number of UHNW individuals grew 6% over the past year, while their wealth increased 7%, driven by strong equity markets. The concentration of wealth among the ultra-rich is growing, with 2,325 having over $1 billion in assets.

site_title: Dollar eases off after 7-year peak against the yen
summary: The US dollar eased off a seven-year peak against the yen, falling to 117.88 yen, ahead of data showing moderating US consumer prices. The euro also hit a six-year high, but gave up gains after weak eurozone business growth. The Federal Reserve's minutes suggested interest rate hikes next year, contrasting with Japan's loose policy outlook.

site_title: Twitter boss launches global cash register service
summary: Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey launched Square Register, a global cash register service, allowing small businesses to track sales and provide digital receipts. The software, available for free in over 130 currencies, was previously available in Canada, Japan, and the US. Dorsey stated that Square Register is a "great replacement to any cash register" and aims to help businesses grow. The service supports digital payments, although not actual payments at this time.

site_title: EU rejects Britain bonus cap challenge
summary: The European Union's top court has rejected Britain's challenge to a cap on banking bonuses, dealing a blow to Prime Minister David Cameron's government. The cap, set by the EU to curb excessive risk-taking, limits bonuses to twice a banker's fixed salary, or the fixed salary itself. The court's Advocate General Niilo Jaaskinen advised that the limits are valid, although the decision is not binding. This ruling comes as a setback to ties between London and Brussels, with Cameron pledging a referendum on leaving the EU in 2017.

site_title: A helping hand for charitable giving
summary: Credit Suisse's SymAsia Foundation, launched in 2011, has seen growing interest from clients, with nearly 30 sub-foundations disbursing over S$60 million in funding to 250 charities worldwide. The foundation supports a wide range of causes and donor involvement levels. Managing director Benjamin Cavalli attributes the growth to the platform's ease of use, allowing wealthy individuals to engage in charitable activities without administrative hassle.

site_title: Keppel unit buys Dutch data centre
summary: Keppel T&T, a joint venture between Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation and Keppel Land, has acquired the Almere Data Centre 2 in the Netherlands, adding over 5,000 square meters of data centre space. The data centre is located 40 minutes from Amsterdam and will cater to growing demand for high-quality data centres in Europe. The acquisition is part of Keppel T&T's expansion plans in the region.

site_title: Britain's anti-EU UKIP takes second seat in parliament
summary: Britain's anti-EU UK Independence Party (UKIP) won its second seat in parliament in a by-election, with Mark Reckless re-elected with 42% of the vote. The Conservative Party's attempt to hold on to the seat failed, with their candidate lagging behind on 35%. The result is seen as a significant blow to Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party, which has vowed to hold a referendum on Britain's EU membership if it wins the next general election. UKIP leader Nigel Farage hailed the result as a key moment in British politics, predicting that "all bets are off" for the general election in May 2015.

images.alt_text: Britain's anti-European Union UK Independence Party (UKIP) won its second seat in parliament on Friday, in a by-election that could signal upheaval in a general election in six months' time.

site_title: South Korea Q3 household income growth rises 1.6% y-o-y
summary: South Korea's household disposable income grew 1.6% in the third quarter of 2024, marking the 14th consecutive quarter of year-on-year growth. This marginally exceeded the 1.1% growth seen in the second quarter. Real household spending also increased 2.0% in the July-September period, up from 1.3% in the second quarter. These figures indicate a slight improvement in the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: South Korean household disposable income in July-September grew for the 14th consecutive quarter on a year-on-year basis, government data showed on Friday, with the pace picking up slightly from the second quarter.

site_title: Britain urges Russia to shut down webcam spying site
summary: Britain's Information Commissioner's Office urges Russia to shut down a webcam spying site offering live feeds of thousands of devices worldwide, including CCTV cameras and baby monitors, due to their poor security. The site, accessed via default login credentials, reveals device locations and manufacturers. Britain plans "very prompt action" with the US Federal Trade Commission to get the site closed down, while data watchdogs worldwide have drawn attention to the issue, highlighting the need for strong passwords to protect device owners' privacy.

site_title: JetBlue introduces new fees for checked luggage
summary: JetBlue Airways Corp introduced new checked baggage fees, prompting praise from Wall Street but criticism from consumers. The airline plans to shrink seat pitch to 33 inches and add 15 seats to its Airbus 320 aircraft over two years, saving on fuel costs. The changes are expected to earn JetBlue approximately $65 million in 2015 and $200 million in total. The move is seen as a necessary step to boost revenue and close the financial gap with peers, with analysts noting the industry's increasing reliance on fees.

site_title: HDB's married child priority scheme goes from chance-based to quota-based
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has introduced a quota-based system for its married child priority scheme. Up to 30% of new flat supplies will be reserved for first-timer families and 15% for second-timer families. This change replaces the previous system, which granted extra ballot chances for families who wished to live with or near each other. The quota-based system aims to provide greater assurance of success for married children applying for new flats.

images.alt_text: Married children who want to live close to their parents will now have greater assurance of success when they apply, the housing board announced on Friday.

site_title: Making a meaningful impact
summary: Former investment banker Ian Learmonth, now executive director of Social Ventures Australia, is playing a key role in impact investing. He joined the organization in 2011 to create better social outcomes for disadvantaged Australians. Learmonth aims to use his skills to achieve both financial and social returns, shifting from profit-driven work to a more positive social impact. With over two decades of experience in investment banking, Learmonth seeks to make a meaningful impact through his work in impact investing.

site_title: Sotheby's CEO to step down, shares rise after hours
summary: Sotheby's CEO William Ruprecht is stepping down, roughly a year after activist investors called for big changes, including the sale of its Manhattan headquarters and improving its balance sheet. The news led to a 7% increase in Sotheby's shares in after-hours trading.

site_title: US pigs too fat for holiday hams as prices surge
summary: US pork prices have surged to a record high due to a shortage of suitable hogs for holiday ham production. Heavier pigs, resulting from a virus that killed millions of piglets, have led to a 24% increase in retail prices to $3.389 per pound. The shortage has reduced the number of hogs available for slaughter, with pork output down 1.2% through September, and is expected to drive up meat costs more than any other food group this year.

site_title: Searing expose of Tinseltown
summary: David Cronenberg's film "Maps to the Stars" offers a scathing satire of Hollywood's excesses, exploring the dark side of the industry through the eyes of a director. The movie follows a group of self-absorbed stars and their entourage, exposing the cruel humor and depraved behavior that lurks beneath the surface. While Cronenberg's film doesn't always succeed, it earns credit for its bold attempt to tackle the industry's darker aspects, veering into uncharted territory with a vicious edge.
