The SiMSCI Index generated a 4.2% total return in 2014, while the MSCI Singapore Small Cap Index generated a 4.6% return.

site_title: Facebook launches tech news page
summary: Facebook has launched FB Techwire, a tech news page featuring original content from influential sources, including breaking news, analysis, and photos and videos. The page aims to aid journalists in discovering and sharing high-value tech content in real-time. The launch follows the announcement of Facebook at Work, a business-focused social network in development. Posts on the page will also be shared on Twitter from the @fbtechwire account. This move aims to provide a centralized platform for tech news and updates.

site_title: China's Greenland in talks to buy Australia's agricultural firms
summary: China's Greenland Holding Group Co is in talks to acquire Australian agricultural firms as part of its expansion plans. The company, which has already invested A$1.6 billion in Australian real estate, aims to import more Australian products into China. Greenland's growth is concerning ratings company Standard & Poor's, citing unfavourable market conditions and capital needs. Despite this, the company's chairman, Zhang Yuliang, dismissed concerns, stating the growth will continue "in a very healthy way".

site_title: Nigeria facing 'serious challenges' amid oil price collapse
summary: Nigeria faces significant challenges due to the collapse of global oil prices, with the country's main crude product selling at US$79 per barrel. Finance Minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has announced belt-tightening measures, including a cutback in foreign travel and new taxes on luxury items, to offset the revenue shortfall. Analysts praise the moves as "pragmatic" but criticize the government for failing to address corruption and waste, which has hindered the country's ability to save for future economic shocks.

images.alt_text: Nigeria has made pragmatic moves to curb spending to offset falling global oil prices, analysts said, but blamed corruption for the failure to prevent a budget crisis that many saw coming.

site_title: Netflix heading for Australia and New Zealand
summary: Netflix will launch its streaming service in Australia and New Zealand in March, offering a library of TV shows, films, documentaries, and original content. The service will be available on various devices, including tablets, smartphones, and smart TVs, at a "low monthly price" yet to be disclosed. This expansion comes after Netflix reported disappointing subscriber growth, gaining just 3 million members in the past quarter, and amid increased competition from HBO's standalone streaming service.

site_title: Uber hits brakes on talk of finding dirt on reporters
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick condemned an executive's suggestion to dig up dirt on reporters who write critically of the company. Emil Michael, Uber's executive vice president of business, had proposed creating a team of researchers to investigate reporters' lives as payback for negative coverage. Kalanick called Michael's comments "terrible" and "unrepresentative" of the company's values, and stated that such tactics are not part of Uber's approach. The incident sparked a public backlash, with Uber attempting to repair its image and relationships with the media.

site_title: Safety watchdog urges full Takata air bag recall in US
summary: US safety regulators urged a nationwide recall of cars with defective Takata air bags, citing millions of vehicles that need to be recalled to address the deadly problem. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) wants Takata and automakers to issue the recall, with the agency warning that it will use its powers to force one if they do not comply. The recall affects 7.8 million cars in the US and is part of a global recall of 16 million cars worldwide, blamed for several deaths and numerous injuries.

site_title: Five more assets no longer tied to bank loans: AA Reit
summary: AA Reit announced that five of its assets valued at S$283.6 million are no longer tied to bank loans, bringing the total value of assets not tied to bank loans to S$527.2 million (42.9% of its S$1.23 billion portfolio). The move reflects the trust's solid financial position, with a healthy interest coverage ratio of 4.2 times and a leverage ratio of 32%. CEO Koh Wee Lih stated that releasing these assets provides further financial flexibility and strengthens the balance sheet.

site_title: Brazil tycoon on trial for insider trading
summary: Brazilian tycoon Eike Batista, once the country's richest man, went on trial for insider trading. He faces up to five years in jail for allegedly selling off company stock using privileged information. Batista's oil company OGX filed for bankruptcy after production targets proved overly optimistic, and he is accused of manipulating the market by selling shares just before the firm announced it was suspending development of its only producing wells. Batista claims he sold stock to meet debt payments, and his assets have been frozen at an estimated $635 million.

site_title: Jetstar HK still to take off after 18-month wait
summary: Jetstar Hong Kong, a budget airline backed by Qantas and China Eastern, remains without approval nearly 18 months after applying for a licence to operate in Hong Kong. The airline has sold six of its nine new Airbus A320s and many of its pilots have quit or been redeployed. Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flag carrier, is believed to be the main reason behind the delay, with sources suggesting the airline is opposing the budget carrier due to concerns over foreign control.

site_title: WhatsApp messages get end-to-end encryption
summary: WhatsApp has partnered with Open Whisper Systems to implement end-to-end encryption, protecting messages from snooping. The TextSecure protocol scrambles messages in transit, hiding content from prying eyes. The feature, already available in recent WhatsApp mobile versions, represents the largest deployment of end-to-end encrypted communication in history, with billions of messages exchanged daily. WhatsApp co-founder Brian Acton and the WhatsApp engineering team were praised for their dedication to the project, which is supported by donations and grants.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters break into govt building as tensions flare again
summary: A small group of Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters broke into the city's legislature via a side door, defying expectations of a peaceful resolution. The incident occurred as tensions escalated following a period of calm, with protesters demanding free elections for the city's next leader in 2017. Riot police used pepper spray and batons to disperse the crowd, while protesters held up umbrellas to defend themselves. The incident marks a rare escalation in the 2-month-old protest movement, which has been largely peaceful.

site_title: Abe delays tax hike and calls snap election in bold but risky strategy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has postponed a further rise in the national sales tax to April 2017 and called a snap general election in a bold but risky strategy. The move comes after the economy stalled due to the April consumption tax hike, with Abe acknowledging recovery had stalled. He vows to continue fiscal stimulus and defy critics who say "Abenomics" is a failure, promising to resign if his government fails to secure a fresh mandate. The election is expected to take place on December 14.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.23%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.23% higher on Wednesday, supported by the yen's drop against the dollar and record closes on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 40.25 points to 17,384.31, boosted by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's call for early elections to delay next year's sales tax increase. A weak yen is positive for Japanese exporters, making them more competitive abroad. Shares in Takata rose despite US safety regulators pushing for a nationwide recall of cars with defective air bags.

site_title: China's property downturn continues into second month
summary: China's home prices fell 2.6% in October from a year earlier, marking the biggest drop since 2011 and the second consecutive month of decline. This intensifies concerns that a softening housing sector will hinder growth, with property investment growing at its slowest pace in over five years. Despite government efforts to boost the market, the bad loan ratio at Chinese banks rose to 1.16%, adding to financial risks. Foreign investment into China also slowed in October, with a 1.3% year-on-year increase.

site_title: Producer prices make unexpected gains in Oct
summary: US producer prices unexpectedly rose 0.2% in October, driven by a jump in services sector prices, but the underlying trend suggests a benign inflation environment. This could delay the Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates. Despite global growth slowdown and falling oil prices, inflation remains tame, with a broader measure increasing 1.6% in the past 12 months. The Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates until mid-2015, and US homebuilder sentiment rose in November, indicating a steady housing recovery.

site_title: Airbus to deliver first A350 jetliner to Qatar Airways around Dec 12
summary: Airbus plans to deliver the first A350 jetliner to Qatar Airways by mid-December, with delivery expected between December 12 and 15. The long-range, twin-aisle plane received certification from the US Federal Aviation Administration and European regulators, and is designed to seat 314 passengers. With 750 orders booked, Airbus aims to increase production to three A350s per month by year-end, with plans to reach 10 a month by mid-2018. The successful test flight program and regulatory certification have boosted Airbus investors, with shares rising over 7% in the past month.

site_title: US services exports to S'pore dip to US$11.4b
summary: US services exports to Singapore fell to $11.4 billion in 2013, a decline from 2012's $13.16 billion and 2011's $11.61 billion. Despite this drop, US services exports to Singapore remained above $10 billion, as they have since 2010. The trade gap between Singapore and the US narrowed, but US services exports to Singapore continued to outpace imports. Exports of intellectual property, management consultancy, and other services declined, but the overall trend of steady growth in US services exports to Singapore remained.

site_title: Weaker finance flows could deepen UK current account woes: BoE's Forbes
summary: Bank of England official Kristin Forbes warns that weaker finance flows could deepen UK's current account woes, making it harder to fund the country's large deficit. Global financial flows have declined sharply since the 2008 crisis and are unlikely to return to pre-crisis levels. This could lead to a more expensive and difficult process for the UK to fund its deficit, which stood at 5.2% of GDP in the second quarter. Forbes also notes that the UK's economy may become more dependent on domestic financing and less resilient to external shocks.

site_title: Sub-prime car loans riskier than ratings: Moody's and Fitch
summary: Moody's and Fitch analysts claim that sub-prime car loans are riskier than their current ratings imply, as many issuers lack a track record in the bond market and may not be able to handle soured debt. Despite this, major rating firms such as Standard & Poor's have assigned high grades to many of these issuers, sparking concerns that the market is vulnerable to a downturn. The sub-prime auto business has grown rapidly, with private-equity firms and Wall Street banks arranging $20.6 billion in deals this year, but the rising default rate and lack of underwriting standards pose a risk to the entire auto industry.

site_title: Modi seeks to accelerate trade pact talks with Australia
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed his desire to accelerate trade pact talks with Australia, seeking better access for Indian businesses to the nation's markets. This comes after China and Australia completed negotiations on a free-trade agreement. Modi stated that India is an "emerging, democratic superpower of Asia" and emphasized the need for greater cooperation on regional security, particularly in the South China Sea. The Indian leader also pledged to work with Australia to counter China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: France plans to beef up labour reforms
summary: The French government plans to advance with labour reforms, despite controversy, to make the job market more flexible and fight unemployment. The reforms aim to reduce the time it takes to fire staff and set a tariff for compensation, but officials will take a cautious approach to avoid jeopardizing talks with unions and employers. The goal is to create 140,000 jobs by easing bureaucratic obligations for companies hiring more staff, as suggested by a recent study by Ifrap.

images.alt_text: The French government will press ahead cautiously with controversial labour reforms making it easier to fire staff, as it seeks to fight unemployment by making the job market more flexible, officials said on Tuesday.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow end at record highs, boosted by healthcare
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 closed at record highs on Tuesday, driven by gains in healthcare shares and hopes for a stronger global economy. The S&P 500 scored its fourth consecutive day of gains, with biotechs such as Actavis Plc and Gilead Sciences contributing to the rally. The Nasdaq biotech index rose 2.1% and the Dow and S&P 500 broke through new highs, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: US dollar assets set to be winners again
summary: US dollar assets are expected to be winners in a disinflationary trend, according to Schroders' Remi Ajewole, who believes central banks' policies will diverge and favor the dollar. In contrast, emerging market equities are likely to suffer. Ajewole cited the UK, Switzerland, Australia, and New Zealand as G-10 markets grappling with disinflation. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to drive dollar asset diversification, while retail investors are expected to drive massive ETF growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Under Modi, Israel and India forge deeper business ties
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has strengthened ties with Israel through a series of defence and technology deals. In May, Modi's cabinet cleared a purchase of Israeli missiles for India's navy, followed by a US$520 million deal for anti-tank missiles in October. A jointly developed aerial defence system recently passed a major trial, with both countries hailing the cooperation as a "milestone". The deals have underscored a growing commercial and political relationship between the two nations under Modi's leadership.

images.alt_text: Since Modi came to power in May, ties between Israel and India have been in overdrive, with the two signing a series of defence and technology deals that have underscored their burgeoning commercial and political relationship.

site_title: German investor sentiment back in positive territory in November
summary: German investor sentiment rebounded in November, jumping to 11.5 points from -3.6 points in October, according to the ZEW economic institute. This marks the first increase in 2014 and suggests the economy is stabilizing, with data showing Germany escaped recession in the third quarter. However, analysts caution that the economic environment remains fragile due to ongoing geopolitical tensions. A higher ZEW index supports the notion of stabilizing growth, but its volatility makes it difficult to read into the data, with some predicting modest growth of 0.2% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Study finds alternative to anti-cholesterol drug, clarifies role of LDL
summary: A six-year study found that combining a statin with ezetimibe (Zetia) significantly reduces the risk of heart attacks and strokes, with 6.4% fewer cardiac events among those taking the combination. The study, involving 18,000 people, showed that ezetimibe can effectively lower LDL cholesterol levels, with no reported side effects. Genetic studies also supported the findings, suggesting that lowering cholesterol with ezetimibe or statins should lower heart disease risk by a similar amount.

site_title: Twitter indexes every public tweet ever sent
summary: Twitter has launched a searchable index of all public tweets since 2006, allowing users to search through hundreds of billions of tweets. The index, built over the past eight years, will be rolled out in the next few days and will be accessible through Twitter's "All" tab on web browsers and mobile applications. The move is seen as a major infrastructure investment by the company, which has been investing heavily in growth and recently went public with a $1.8 billion debt issue.

site_title: Travel-size projectors and virtual keyboards for those on the move
summary: Tiny gadgets are flooding the business travel market, offering executives a range of portable devices to enhance their work experience. Products like the Pocket Projector Pro, a US$450 projector that fits in a pocket, and the Mophie Space Pack, a backup-battery-cum-phone-case, are popular among jet-setting executives. Other devices, such as the LaCie Fuel, a 4.5-inch square storage device, and the Sharper Image 4-USB-Port Charging Tower, are also gaining traction. These devices aim to make work more efficient, convenient, and enjoyable for business travelers.

site_title: New S Korea agency to replace coast guard in search and rescue
summary: South Korea launches a new National Safety Agency to handle search and rescue operations, replacing the coast guard seven months after a ferry disaster killed 304 people. The agency will have over 10,000 staff and incorporate fire and emergency response teams. The move comes after President Park Geun-hye vowed sweeping reforms to improve emergency response and safety oversight following the Sewol capsizing. The new agency starts operation on Wednesday, addressing criticism that regulatory controls and safety standards have not kept pace with South Korea's technological advancements.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Centurion Corp won a tender for a 12,000-bed dormitory land plot in Penang, Malaysia, for S$8.06 million, strengthening its foothold in the market. Despite a potential surge of beds, the company remains positive due to its cost structure, margins, and experience in the dormitory business. The company's expansion plans are on track, and its target price is set at S$0.89, with a buy recommendation. The company's revenue fell 51% year-on-year due to completed key projects and lower revenue recognition.

site_title: S'pore among first 10 cities to enjoy Uber-Spotify service
summary: Singapore has become one of the first 10 cities worldwide, and the first in Asia, to offer the Uber-Spotify service, allowing users to personalize their taxi rides with their preferred music. The service, which integrates Spotify's music streaming platform with Uber's ride-hailing app, will be available across all three Uber products in Singapore. The partnership aims to create a unique user experience, but some Uber drivers have expressed concerns over the potential distraction and impact on their ratings.

site_title: Can racial diversity influence financial bubbles?
summary: A study by Columbia University researchers found that racial diversity among traders can reduce the likelihood of financial bubbles. In simulations, diverse groups of traders made more accurate price assessments, while homogeneous groups became more prone to irrational pricing. The study suggests that traders in homogeneous markets place undue trust in each other's decisions, leading to inflated prices. This phenomenon may contribute to the development of financial bubbles, which can have devastating consequences. The findings offer a fascinating insight into the role of diversity in preventing speculative booms and busts.

site_title: How a late booking jammed the brakes on Trans-Cab's IPO
summary: Trans-Cab's initial public offering (IPO) was scrapped at the last minute due to a late notification from its insurer, First Capital Insurance, of an additional premium of S$1.83 million. The insurer had only informed the taxi operator last Friday, and the firm's chairman and CEO, Teo Kiang Ang, felt pressured to withdraw the IPO to avoid disclosing inaccurate information in the prospectus. The move came just days before the planned listing and drew criticism from investors and market watchers, who questioned the firm's transparency and ability to predict its future.

site_title: Building relations from the ground up
summary: Architect Liu Thai Ker, 76, has received the Business China Excellence Award for his decades-long career advising China's city planners. Liu's professional relationship with China began in 1978, where he briefed Chinese Premier Deng Xiao Peng on Singapore's urbanization efforts. He has since advised over 30 cities, including Fuzhou and Xiamen Island, and was chairman of the jury for the 2008 Beijing Olympics Park. Liu's work has helped shape China's urban landscape and has earned him a reputation among Chinese leaders.

site_title: Wall Street deal-makers enjoy biggest merger boom since 2000
summary: Wall Street is experiencing a major merger boom, with a record $1.5 trillion in deals targeting American companies announced this year, surpassing the 2000 level. The surge in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) is driven by low borrowing costs, rising share prices, and a sense of relative stability, with many CEOs feeling optimistic about the future. However, economists are divided on the impact of M&A on the economy, with some arguing that it can lead to job cuts and redundancies, while others see it as a sign of growth and consolidation.

site_title: Air Asia X shares take a beating on news of wage-bill woes
summary: Air Asia X shares plummet 6% to RM0.70 apiece due to concerns over wage-bill woes, with analysts expecting further losses and a potential capital-raising exercise. The carrier's operating expenditure jumped 50% in the second quarter, and its net gearing ratio is expected to rise as it takes delivery of new planes next year. Maybank Investment Bank warns of "record forex translation losses" and a depleted capital base, prompting concerns over the airline's financial stability.

images.alt_text: The largest shareholder in AirAsia X is Tune Ventures, a private firm comprising Tony Fernandes, the founder of AAX's sister budget airline AirAsia, and his business partners.

site_title: Process of using platinum for fuel cells being tested
summary: Anglo American Platinum Ltd, the world's largest platinum producer, is testing a process to boost demand for the metal by using it in fuel cells to power remote areas. The test in South Africa's Naledi Trust village, which lacked electricity for five years, has been successful and will run for at least a year. The system uses methanol and platinum as a catalyst to produce electricity, offering a potential solution for the 1.3 billion people worldwide without electricity, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. This could lead to wider use of fuel cells as a source of power in developing regions.

site_title: Draghi slightly more optimistic about eurozone economy
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi expressed a slightly more optimistic view of the eurozone economy, citing a reversal of the decline in bank lending and growing economies in most countries. Draghi acknowledged that economic performance remains "dismal" and unemployment is high, but noted that only two countries in the eurozone are in recession. He reiterated that the ECB will be prepared to buy government bonds to stimulate the economy if necessary, and stated that previous measures are beginning to show results.

site_title: Orchard Rd retail rents 7th most expensive in Asia-Pacific: report
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road retail rents are the 7th most expensive in the Asia-Pacific, at US$348 per sq ft per year, according to Colliers International's Global Retail Highlights 2014 report. This is despite a tight labor market, higher costs, and dwindling profits in the industry. The top spot is held by Hong Kong's Queen's Road Central at US$2,073 per sq ft per year.

site_title: Aviation to form a big part of Dubai GDP
summary: Dubai's aviation sector is expected to contribute 37.5% to the emirate's economy by 2020, valued at US$53.1 billion, according to a study by Oxford Economics. This growth is driven by an increase in passenger numbers and expansion of Dubai International Airport, which will handle over 100 million passengers annually. The sector currently accounts for 27% of Dubai's GDP, valued at US$26.7 billion in 2013. Aviation's contribution to Dubai's economy is expected to grow at a faster rate than the economy as a whole between 2014 and 2020.

site_title: Facebook testing workplace-collaboration tools: source
summary: Facebook is testing a workplace-collaboration tool, Facebook at Work, which allows employees to communicate and collaborate using the social network's traditional tools without mixing personal and professional posts. The product, in trials at Facebook and several other companies, will likely debut publicly in a few months and poses a threat to corporate social-media tools like Microsoft's Yammer and Salesforce.com's Chatter. Facebook at Work's familiar user experience could blur the lines between employees and customers, and its debut may impact companies like LinkedIn and Jive Software.

site_title: Opec output cut not in its own interests: Goldman
summary: Opec, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is unlikely to implement a large production cut to prop up crude prices due to its potential impact on the expansion of US shale oil. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. stated that such a cut would be difficult to implement due to financing needs of some Opec members, and would ultimately lead to further cuts starting from 2016. Opec's production has already exceeded its 30 million barrel a day target for five consecutive months, and the group is set to meet on Nov 27 in Vienna.

site_title: Sino Construction turning itself into a global coal resource player (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based Sino Construction, a mainboard-listed construction company, is transforming into a global coal resource player. The company has acquired three coal assets in Australia, Mongolia, and South Africa, with plans to grow into a 10 billion-tonne resource company within two years. Sino Construction aims to supply China and India, and its acquisitions are guided by four requirements: high-grade coal, mine life, accessible infrastructure, and cost efficiency. The company's chairman, Andy Chee, and investor Edward Lee believe that coal remains a key source of power and will continue to expand demand due to population growth and urbanization.

site_title: MAS delays Q3 results
summary: Malaysian Airline System (MAS) has delayed the release of its Q3 results to Nov 28, citing the need to include more details. The airline, which has been hit by two jet disasters this year, was initially scheduled to report its earnings for the July-September period on Tuesday. The delay was due to missing some key details, according to an investor relations official. This is the last set of earnings before MAS goes private.

site_title: Second OW unit in Singapore files for liquidation
summary: Singapore's Dynamic Oil Trading, a subsidiary of insolvent marine fuel supplier OW Bunker, has filed for liquidation with KPMG as provisional liquidator. This follows OW's own insolvency filing in Denmark less than two weeks prior. The move marks the second OW unit to seek liquidation in Singapore, highlighting the company's ongoing financial struggles.

images.alt_text: The fallout from the collapse of beleaguered Danish marine fuel supplier OW Bunker continues.

site_title: Fewer babies herald African 'economic miracle': UN
summary: The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) reports that declining fertility rates in 59 nations, mostly in sub-Saharan Africa, could lead to a "demographic dividend" worth $500 billion per year over three decades, equivalent to a third of the region's current GDP. This demographic shift could propel developing economies forward, potentially tripling per capita income in Nigeria and making democratic transitions more likely. However, the report warns that governments must have a solid economic framework to realize this opportunity.

site_title: China's clean energy drive will create investment opportunities
summary: China has pledged to step up investment in clean energy, aiming to cut CO2 emissions and shift away from coal. The country plans to triple natural gas consumption by 2020 and increase solar installations ten-fold by 2017. To meet growing demand, China will invest billions in natural gas infrastructure and energy efficiency. This shift is expected to create investment opportunities in industries such as photovoltaic panels and energy-efficient transport. China's "war on pollution" aims to reduce coal consumption to 63% by 2017 and push for cleaner energy sources.

site_title: PAP advocacy body calls for law to raise rehiring age
summary: The PAP Seniors Group, an advocacy body of the ruling People's Action Party in Singapore, has submitted a paper to the Ministry of Manpower urging the government to introduce a law to raise the rehiring age for older workers to 67. This is in response to the current age range of 62-65, which the group believes is not effective in ensuring the rehiring of older workers. The group argues that legislation is a more effective method and calls for better use of existing grants to support older workers, as well as review of training efforts and policy improvements.

images.alt_text: THE PAP Seniors Group, an advocacy body of the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), wants the government to take a tougher stand in pushing the rehiring age for older workers to 67.

site_title: Starbucks criticised for ties to group fighting GMO law
summary: Starbucks has faced criticism for its membership in the Grocery Manufacturers Association (GMA), a trade association fighting Vermont's GMO food labelling law. Activists, including musician Neil Young, have called for Starbucks to sever ties with the GMA, which has sued to block the law. Starbucks denies involvement in the lawsuit and claims it's not aligned with Monsanto to block food labelling. The law, which requires labelling of foods containing genetically modified organisms, was passed in Vermont earlier this year and is the first state in the US to mandate such labelling.

site_title: India's coal firms face rising debt as auctions loom
summary: Indian coal firms face rising debt as auctions for 74 coal mines are set to take place by March 31, including 40 operational ones. The country's top court canceled 218 coal mining permits in 2014, citing arbitrary and illegal allocations. Companies such as Hindalco and Jindal Steel are concerned about increased acquisition costs and delayed debt reduction. The auctions may provide policy certainty, but could also cap prices and reduce competition. The move is expected to impact the nation's $1.9 trillion economy, which is already dealing with coal shortages and supply bottlenecks.

site_title: Shrinking shipping's environmental footprint
summary: Maersk Group, a leading shipping company, has set a new target to reduce CO2 emissions from its container shipping arm, Maersk Line, by 60% by 2020. This targets a reduction of 200 million tonnes of CO2 from 2007 levels. The company aims to achieve this through energy efficiency improvements and pioneering fleet and network innovations, which will cost around $15 billion. This move reflects the industry's growing responsibility to mitigate negative impacts on the climate and environment.

site_title: Business China honours Liu Thai Ker
summary: Singaporean urban planner Liu Thai Ker has been awarded the top honour at the 2014 Business China Awards for his contributions to Singapore-China relations. Liu, known as Singapore's Father of Urban Planning, was recognized for his work in transforming the country's housing scene and his involvement in designing the Chinese Embassy in Singapore. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry and singer JJ Lin also received awards for their roles in promoting bilateral trade and cultural exchange between the two countries.

site_title: Equity markets could face a difficult year in 2015
summary: Equity markets are expected to face a challenging 2015 due to the end of the US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing program and concerns over global economic growth. Japan's economy has contracted, and the International Monetary Fund warns of high debt, low growth, and unemployment in Europe. The Bank of England's Mark Carney has also expressed fears of stagnation in Europe. Markets are transitioning from liquidity to growth-based allocation, leading to increased volatility, and geopolitical risks are expected to rise. A significant correction in the second half of the year is predicted by Credit Suisse.

site_title: Bankers weigh air bag fallout for Takada family
summary: Bankers are weighing the potential fallout for the Takada family and third-generation CEO Shigehisa Takada as the Japanese company, Takata Corp, faces air bag defect scrutiny. The company, which supplies over a fifth of the world's air bags, has set aside $774 million for recall-related costs, but a 60% drop in its share price this year could dilute the family's 59% stake. Bankers are brainstorming financing proposals, including raising new capital or recapitalizing the company under new management, which could threaten the family's control.

site_title: Russia steps up gold purchases to counter US, European sanctions
summary: Russia has increased its gold purchases to counter US and European sanctions, buying 55 tonnes of gold in the third quarter, while emerging economies such as China and Kazakhstan have also been stocking up. The move is driven by fears of the negative impact of quantitative easing policies on global financial stability. Central banks around the world bought a total of 93 tonnes of gold in the third quarter, with the overall aim of building up a currency bloc to counter the US dollar and other global currencies.

site_title: Nine China state-owned firms listed on SGX
summary: Nine China state-owned firms are listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with a total market value of S$8 billion. The firms, spanning sectors such as pharmaceuticals, water purification, and shipping, have an average trading multiple of 1.2 times book value. The market update comes as a landmark stock-trading link between Shanghai and Hong Kong markets has been launched, making Chinese stocks more accessible to global investors. The largest SOE-linked stock is Tianjin Zhongxin Pharmaceutical, with China Merchants Holdings (Pacific) being the only stock to make a positive return year-to-date.

site_title: American casual-dining players breaking into slump-hit Brazil
summary: US casual-dining chains, such as Red Lobster and PF Chang's, are expanding in Brazil due to stagnant growth and a weaker currency, which has led to a decline in foreign goods sales. Middle-class Brazilians are seeking mid-range dining options, priced out of higher-end eateries, and are opting for a more affordable "classier" night out. This trend is driving growth for US casual-dining operators in the country.

site_title: EU fails to reach agreement on budget for 2015
summary: The European Union failed to reach an agreement on its 2015 budget, forcing officials to draw up a new proposal. EU governments and the European Parliament had been locked in talks over a budget of about 140 billion euros, with the Parliament pushing for a 8.1% increase. A deal was not reached by the Monday deadline, and the EU's executive arm will now present a new draft budget. This comes after a heated row over unpaid bills and member state contributions, with Britain refusing to pay an extra 2.1 billion euros.

site_title: The art of contrarian investing (Amended)
summary: Edward Lee, a 35-year-old Singaporean, retired at 28 after becoming a millionaire through savvy investments, mostly in property. A value-driven, contrarian investor, Lee seeks unloved assets with potential for intrinsic value growth. He adopts a barbell strategy, investing in large-cap blue chips and small stocks, and real estate, with a focus on multi-bagger returns within two to three years. Lee has pocketed significant profits, including a S$13 million gain from his investment in Singapore-listed mobile-phone retailer mDR, and takes a risk-averse approach, aiming to lose sleep over losses rather than seeking to win all the time.

site_title: Spanish artists sell porn in protest over taxes on theatre
summary: A group of Spanish actresses from theatre company Primas de Riesgo are selling pornography to protest the government's 21% tax on theatre admission, citing a lower tax rate for magazines. The move is part of a larger protest against the government's increased taxes and reduced funding for the arts. The company's director, Karina Garantiva, stated that the protest aims to highlight the tax gap and force Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy to recant. The move echoes previous demonstrations by the Spanish arts world, with some experts arguing that the government's tax increase on theatre is unfair and could erode Spain's drama heritage.

site_title: US new vehicle sales seen close to 17m in 2015
summary: The National Automobile Dealers Association (NADA) has revised its forecast for US new vehicle sales in 2015, predicting 16.94 million units, up from an earlier estimate of 16.8 million. The improvement in the economy, rising employment, and low interest rates are cited as key factors contributing to the increase. To reach the 17 million mark, automaker incentives and younger consumers buying cars at a faster pace will be necessary, according to NADA chief economist Steven Szakaly.

site_title: Singapore govt's IT spending expected to hit US$3.2b in 2014: Gartner
summary: Singapore's government is expected to spend US$3.2 billion on Information and Communications Technology (ICT) in 2014, with growth projected at 3% annually over the next four years. This spending is driven by various e-Government and Smart Nation initiatives. By 2018, ICT spending is forecast to reach US$3.7 billion, driven by the government's focus on digitalization and innovation.

site_title: Beefing up its brand in China
summary: OCBC Bank has acquired Wing Hang Bank, expanding its presence in China and Hong Kong. The acquisition gives OCBC a stronger platform to grow its business in North Asia, particularly in the consumer segment, SME market, and offshore yuan market. OCBC now has 31 branches in China, 43 in Hong Kong, and 13 in Macau, with plans to open a new branch in Suzhou by the end of the year. The acquisition is expected to boost OCBC's wealth management services and SME business, as well as its ability to tap into the growing offshore yuan market.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of Wing Hang has added a significant larger presence for OCBC and has given it added capabilities.

"We can learn from them and they can learn from us. We want to cross-transfer each other's best practices so that one plus one equals three." - George Lee, OCBC's head, global corporate banking (above)

site_title: HK students can go home with their heads held high
summary: China is increasingly emphasizing "one country" over "two systems" in Hong Kong, sparking concerns about the city's autonomy. Pro-democracy protests, led by students, have brought international attention to the issue, with the US Congress and UK Parliament holding hearings on Hong Kong. The Hong Kong government has agreed to submit a report on public sentiment, providing an opportunity for a potential reassessment by the central government. Despite this, Beijing may curtail existing rights and freedoms, and the students' efforts have been deemed a success, with their quest for democracy and human rights making Hong Kong a global issue.

site_title: Nokia announces new brand-licensed tablet computer
summary: Nokia has announced a brand-licensed tablet computer, the N1, running on Google's Android platform. The tablet's manufacturing, distribution, and sales will be handled by Taiwan's Foxconn. This comes six months after Nokia sold its phone business to Microsoft for over $7 billion. The company plans to release more devices in the future, with Sebastian Nystrom, head of products, stating this is a step in that direction.

images.alt_text: Finland's Nokia announced a brand-licensed tablet computer which runs on Google's Android platform, just six month after the company sold its ailing phones and devices business to Microsoft for over US$7 billion.

site_title: Hyundai Heavy workers to stage overtime walkout
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries workers in South Korea will stage a symbolic overtime walkout on Thursday, marking the world's largest shipbuilder's first full-fledged strike in 18 years. The strike is in response to a long-running wage dispute, with workers demanding a 6.5% pay rise and a one-off bonus equal to 10 weeks' wages. The company, facing a 1.9 trillion won operating loss, has refused to meet the demands, and wider industrial action could take place as early as next week.

site_title: Docklands provide room in Mumbai
summary: Mumbai's docklands redevelopment project aims to create a waterfront area with public space, a hospital, affordable housing, and luxury amenities. The government values the land at $12 billion and plans to open 30% of the land to the public. The project includes a floating hotel, convention center, and luxury marina, and is seen as a model for urban regeneration in India. However, concerns remain about the project's feasibility and potential for unregulated development, given Mumbai's history of poor urban planning and rapid population growth.

images.alt_text: Owned by Mumbai Port Trust, much of the seven square kilometres up for redevelopment is occupied today by crumbling warehouses and informal housing.

site_title: US port slowdown may delay export of Xmas trees to Asia
summary: A labour dispute at the Port of Tacoma in Washington state has caused a slowdown, potentially delaying the export of 8-10 million Christmas trees to Asia, where they are in high demand. The trees, grown in Washington state and Oregon, are usually shipped to cities like Hong Kong and Tokyo in 23 days, but have been stuck in shipping containers for two weeks. This has resulted in the cancellation of over 12,000 pre-cut trees and an estimated 50,000 more trees being backlogged at the terminal.

site_title: Two govt sites up for tender to yield 700 residential units
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has released two government land sale (GLS) sites, one in Yishun and the other in Sengkang, for tender, which are estimated to yield a total of 700 residential units. The sites, which are 99-year leasehold, will be developed into mixed-use projects, with consultants expecting a high number of bids due to their attractive features. However, the sites' proximity to unsold units in the vicinity may deter developers. Bidders are expected to submit offers between S$650-S$750 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) for the Yishun site and S$320-S$360 psf ppr for the Sengkang site.

site_title: Global mutual funds picking up S'pore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds increased their holdings of Singapore stocks in the three months to Nov 14, with net buys of S$1.9 billion and net sells of S$769.4 million. The top five stocks with market capitalization of S$1-2 billion saw more sells than buys, while smaller-cap stocks saw net buys. Top buys included The Straits Trading Company and top sells were dominated by Super Group Ltd. This data provides insight into where fund managers are focusing their attention, although alternative investors and institutional money managers may also be trading.

images.alt_text: The top five stocks saw net buys of S$1.9 billion in aggregate, compared to net sells of S$769.4 million.

site_title: Flash boys of new era of volatility
summary: The US Treasury market experienced a significant jump in volatility on October 15, with the bond market experiencing its largest quarter-century jump. High-frequency traders are increasingly influencing the market, leading to concerns about potential turbulence ahead. This trend reflects a broader shift in the market, with investors seeking safe havens and considering dollar diversification, particularly in Asia.

site_title: Addressing digital fraud in Asia
summary: Asia's growing digital economy is increasingly vulnerable to payment fraud, with the region taking the lead in mobile payments. The number of online banking customers is expected to reach 1.7 billion by 2020. To combat this, financial institutions are adopting EMV chip and pin payment technology, which has already reduced card fraud rates in some markets. Customer education and sophisticated fraud detection systems are also being implemented to prevent and detect fraudulent transactions.

site_title: Turning climate change into a political football
summary: The US Republican Congress is determined to fight the China-US agreement on carbon emissions, citing concerns that the deal is "non-binding" and would harm the economy. Despite China's commitment to cut greenhouse gas pollution, Republicans argue that the US concessions are too concrete and immediate. The disagreement reflects the ideological radicalization of the Republican Party, which has shifted to the right and become more anti-science, questioning the theory of evolution and global warming. The outcome will be determined by politics rather than scientific evidence, with Democrats hoping to mobilize support for the deal among their constituencies.

site_title: Prudential's nine-month new business profit up 17% at £1.51b
summary: British life insurer Prudential reported a 17% increase in nine-month new business profit to £1.51 billion, driven by higher sales in its three life insurance businesses. In Asia, new business profit rose 15% to £775 million, mainly due to annual premium equivalent sales. The increase was largely attributed to higher sales in its three life insurance businesses.

site_title: Pressure on coal prices unlikely to ease for now
summary: Coal prices are unlikely to ease due to overcapacity and weakened demand, with India and China driving long-term demand. Analysts predict that thermal coal prices will remain under pressure until end-2015 and beyond, while coking coal prices may not see an improvement until supply is reduced and demand from Chinese steel mills picks up. Short-term price recovery will depend on incremental exports from the US and emerging markets, with India expected to drive significant demand in the longer term.

site_title: German data boosts euro; yen hits 7-year low
summary: The euro regained ground against the dollar after a better-than-expected survey of German economic sentiment, while the yen touched a seven-year low after Japan's snap election, with the yen passing 117 per dollar. The Bank of Japan is expected to print more yen to revive its economy, which has struggled for over a decade. The dollar has made steady progress since July, based on diverging fortunes between the US, Europe, and Japan.

site_title: A century of building bridges
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI) has been a key link for businesses in China and Singapore for over a century, since its founding in 1906. The chamber has promoted business and trade cooperation between the two countries through various activities, including seminars, business missions, and management training. Its efforts have been widely acknowledged by both governments, and it has been honoured with several awards, including the Business China Enterprise Award. The SCCCI currently has over 4,000 corporate members and represents over 40,000 companies, and it plans to continue organizing events and activities to promote economic cooperation between Singapore and China.

site_title: Joko must now make case for fuel price hike to voters
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced the country's second fuel price hike in as many years, sparking a challenge to sell the reform to voters and his own party. The Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle previously opposed fuel price hikes during its decade-long opposition, with its chairwoman, Megawati Sukarnoputri, resisting the move during her 2004 re-election campaign. Widodo's party will now face the task of convincing its members to support the price increase.

site_title: ECB stress tests not accurate gauge of bank stability: poll
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) stress tests of eurozone banks were deemed inaccurate by 51% of investors, traders, and analysts polled. Despite 25 institutions failing the test, regulators felt it wasn't enough to prevent another financial crisis in Europe. Only 46% of respondents believed US stress tests provided an accurate gauge of banks' financial stability, with 48% saying US regulators had done enough to prevent another crisis. Regulators are under pressure to strengthen the financial system after previous failed tests.

site_title: Rates will stay low due to macroeconomic factors: RBA governor
summary: Australia's economy has spare capacity and contained inflation, justifying low interest rates, according to Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens. The central bank has opted to maintain record-low rates of 2.5% for 15 months to encourage non-mining investment and stabilize the economy. Housing construction is expected to continue growing, with recent data showing increased labor productivity and a revival in housing construction. However, the RBA is concerned about a jump in credit to investors and is probing whether people are getting "overexcited" about home lending.

site_title: StanChart closing accounts of some financial institutions
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore is closing accounts with selected financial institutions as part of its business review, citing a need to improve profits. The bank, which makes about three-quarters of its earnings in Asia, has been under pressure since a 2012 deferred prosecution agreement for violating US sanctions on Iran. As part of its efforts to cut costs, the bank plans to close 80-100 retail branches and implement job cuts in 2015, aiming to save US$400 million annually. The bank stated that financial institutions remain an important client base, but the closure is part of its business strategy.

site_title: EU budget talks break down on how to use fines money
summary: EU budget talks have stalled due to a disagreement over how to use fines money, with the European Parliament and member states at odds over allocating the 5 billion euros in windfall income. The European Commission will present a new budget draft, but if no agreement is reached by December 31, monthly spending will be capped at this year's levels. The delay raises concerns about the impact on EU recipients, including small businesses and researchers, and highlights tensions between EU spending and opposition from wealthier member states.

site_title: India's central bank chief wants focus on sustainable growth
summary: India's central bank Governor Raghuram Rajan emphasized the need for sustainable economic growth, urging developed economies to follow suit. India's economy has grown less than 5% for two years, and Rajan aims to achieve 6% inflation by January 2016. Despite pressure to cut interest rates, Rajan is focused on inflation control, and analysts do not expect a rate cut when he announces his next policy on December 2. The government has implemented reforms, and Rajan is committed to taking necessary actions to boost growth.

site_title: Singapore's CitySpring to merge with Keppel Infrastructure Trust
summary: Singapore's CitySpring Infrastructure Trust has agreed to merge with Keppel Infrastructure Trust, creating a trust with assets over S$4 billion. CIT will issue 1.3 billion new units and each KIT unitholder will receive 2.106 new CIT units. As part of the deal, KIT will buy a 51% stake in a power plant for S$510 million. The transaction is expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2015, with Keppel and Temasek Holdings retaining their largest unitholder positions.

site_title: Celebrating a milestone
summary: China's 25th Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit, hosted by Beijing, has showcased the country's growing confidence and poise on the international stage. China aims to be an influential power through collaboration rather than confrontation. Recent announcements, such as the Asia Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Infrastructure Fund, are expected to benefit Singapore, which will co-invest in these initiatives. Strong bilateral ties between Singapore and China will promote trade and investments between China and the region, with Singapore playing a pivotal role in the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road network.

site_title: Merging different roles
summary: Singer JJ Lin, a Singaporean Mando-pop star, has been awarded the Business China Young Achiever Award for his contributions to Singapore-China relations. Lin, who has successfully navigated the Chinese market with his music, credits his bilingualism and willingness to learn about Chinese culture for his success. He has performed at various events, including the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games and the Shanghai World Expo, and has also donated to charity efforts. Lin aims to expand his business ventures into China, including the food industry, and advises young Singaporeans to be open to learning about and adapting to Chinese culture to succeed in the market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after latest S&P record
summary: US stocks opened flat on Tuesday, holding near its record close, as benign inflation trends continued despite a rise in producer prices. The Dow Jones fell 0.57 points to 17,647.18, while the S&P 500 gained 1.02 points to 2,042.34 and the Nasdaq Composite added 5.45 points to 4,676.45, reaching fresh records.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 25.06 points to 3,313.73. The 1.28 billion shares traded valued S$1.01 billion, with 235 gainers and 181 losers.

site_title: CitySpring and Keppel trusts merging to form S$2b entity
summary: CitySpring Infrastructure Trust (CIT) and Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) are merging to form a S$2 billion entity, with CIT acquiring KIT's assets and units in exchange for new CIT units. The combined trust will acquire a 51% stake in Keppel Merlimau Cogen for S$510 million, with an equity fund raising of up to S$525 million planned. The deal, expected to be completed in the second quarter of 2015, will create the largest Singapore infrastructure-focused business trust, with a market capitalization exceeding S$1.9 billion and total assets exceeding S$4 billion.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) and CitySpring Infrastructure Trust are poised to create the largest Singapore infrastructure-focused business trust listed on the Singapore Exchange, following the combination of the two trusts, and the acquisition of a stake in Keppel Merlimau Cogen.

site_title: IBM launches business e-mail that integrates social media
summary: IBM launched IBM Verse, a business e-mail application that integrates social media, file sharing, and analytics, aiming to shift its focus to cloud computing and data analytics. The service includes a personal assistant that learns user behavior and drafts responses, and allows users to transform e-mail content into social media threads. The free initial model has limited mailbox sizes and file sharing, with a paid version available in January 2015. IBM hopes to eventually replace Microsoft Outlook, while maintaining user data privacy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.9 points to close at 1,818.38, driven by gains in the stock market. The index saw 1.76 billion lots traded, with 437 gainers and 345 losers. The rally follows a strong performance in Singapore and other Asian markets, where investors are brushing off US President Trump's threats to extend a stock rally.

site_title: WWII celebration plans to score points
summary: China and Russia plan to jointly observe the 70th anniversary of World War II in 2015, aiming to warn Japan against historical revision and create difficulties for the US-Japan alliance. The joint celebration, agreed upon by Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin, will highlight the Soviet contribution to defeating Nazi Germany and Japan, while downplaying China's role. The move is part of Xi's agenda to promote China as an equal player in global politics, and may lead to tensions with Japan, which is opposed to the joint commemoration.

site_title: 17 project signings after meeting of Singapore-Guangdong council
summary: Singapore and Guangdong, China's southern province, signed 17 projects in urban solutions, healthcare, transportation, and environmental services, including a healthcare hub and smart city solutions. The Guangdong Enterprise Association (Singapore) was established to help Guangdong companies expand into Singapore and forge partnerships. The agreements aim to boost trade and economic collaboration between the two regions, with Singapore's cumulative investments in Guangdong reaching $9 billion.

site_title: US home builder sentiment rises in November: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment rose in November, reaching 58, the highest since February, according to the National Association of Home Builders. This marks the fifth consecutive month above the 50-point benchmark, driven by low interest rates, affordable home prices, and solid job creation. The single-family home sales component increased to 62, and prospective buyer traffic rose to 45. NAHB Chief Economist David Crowe attributed the improvement to a steady housing recovery, expecting momentum to continue into 2015.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB Q3 net profit slides 16%
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd reported a 16% decline in third-quarter net profit to 890 million ringgit (US$265.35 million) due to higher loan impairments at its Indonesia operations. This drop is compared to the same quarter last year, when the bank reported a net profit of 1.06 billion ringgit.

site_title: Toyota rolls out world's first mass market fuel-cell car
summary: Toyota has unveiled the world's first mass-market fuel-cell car, the Mirai sedan, with a price tag of $57,500 in Japan and plans to expand sales to the US and Europe in 2015. The Mirai can travel 650km without refuelling, producing only water vapour from its tailpipe, and aims to sell over 3,000 units in the US by 2017. Toyota hopes to produce "tens of thousands" of the vehicle over the next decade, aiming to create a hydrogen-based society and address global environmental and energy problems.

images.alt_text: Toyota said on Tuesday it would start selling the world's first mass market fuel-cell car in Japan next month and elsewhere in 2015, in what its top executive called an industry milestone.

site_title: Australia rates to stay low for some time given spare capacity: RBA
summary: Australia's central bank Governor Glenn Stevens said interest rates are likely to remain low for some time due to spare capacity in the economy. The RBA is monitoring housing market over-exuberance and is working with regulators to ensure banks maintain lending standards. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority plans to announce tighter lending standards before the end of the year, aiming to prolong a recovery in home building. Stevens emphasized that a high level of construction is preferable to a sharp boom and bust cycle.

site_title: Singapore 2nd top Asia destination for China real estate investors
summary: China's real estate market has cooled, prompting mainland Chinese investors to seek overseas investments, with Singapore emerging as the second most-preferred destination in Asia after Hong Kong. Between 2008 and June 2014, China invested $3.23 billion in Singapore's real estate market, with $5.1 billion spent in the first half of 2014. Chinese investors favor mature markets like the US, UK, and Europe, and prefer greenfield investments and mergers and acquisitions. Despite the trend, challenges such as lengthy approval procedures and unfamiliarity with foreign regulatory environments are expected to hinder Chinese outbound investment.

site_title: British annual inflation rises to 1.3%: official data
summary: British inflation rose unexpectedly to 1.3% in October, reversing a five-year low from the previous month, driven by higher costs for computer games and smaller falls in transport costs. Analysts had expected a 1.2% rate. The Office for National Statistics attributed the increase to these factors.

site_title: Banks, Jardine propel STI 25 pts higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged 25.06 points to 3,313.73, driven by gains in the banking sector and Jardine group. The STI's biggest gainer was DBS, which rose 3.5 points to S$19.47. Analysts attributed the gains to a firm opening in Europe markets, suggesting another Wall Street rally. Maybank Kim Eng upgraded DBS to "overweight" and predicted a sector re-rating, while Credit Suisse expects a year of two halves for equity markets in 2015.

site_title: Seven big US companies paid more to CEOs than in federal taxes: study
summary: Seven of the US's largest corporations, including Boeing, Ford, and Chevron, paid more to their CEOs than in federal income taxes in 2013. The companies, which reported over $74 billion in combined pre-tax profits, paid an average of $17.3 million to their CEOs. The study, compiled by the Institute for Policy Studies and the Center for Effective Government, found that these companies gained $1.9 billion more than they owed in taxes. The findings highlight "deep flaws" in the corporate tax system, according to the study's authors.

site_title: Indonesia maintains 2014 GDP outlook despite fuel price hike
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry maintained its 2014 GDP growth forecast at 5.1% despite a fuel price hike, indicating minimal impact on the country's economy. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro also forecast 5.8% growth for next year. The move suggests Indonesia's economy is resilient to external shocks.

site_title: European car sales recovery vulnerable to slowing economy
summary: European new car sales rose 6.2% in October, driven by buying incentives in southern countries. The recovery is fragile, however, and vulnerable to a slowing economy. Despite a 14-month growth streak, the market remains weak and susceptible to economic setbacks. Sales in Spain, Portugal, and Greece jumped over 20%, while Germany and Britain saw gains, but France slipped 3.8%. Analysts predict European car sales growth to slow to 3.5% in 2015, citing a gloomy economic outlook and high unemployment.

site_title: Malaysian Airline says delays Q3 results to include more details
summary: Malaysia Airlines has delayed the release of its third-quarter results to November 28, citing the need to include more details. The airline, which has been hit by two jet disasters this year, was scheduled to report results on November 18. The delay comes after passenger numbers fell and yields dropped in the quarter, which would have been one of its worst ever quarters. The airline missed some details that needed to be included in the earnings results, according to an investor relations official.

site_title: Services lift US producer prices in October
summary: US producer prices rose 0.2% in October, driven by a 0.5% increase in services sector prices, the largest rise since July 2013. Despite this, the underlying trend points to a benign inflation environment, supporting the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates low. Producer prices increased 1.5% in the 12 months through October, the smallest advance since February. Energy prices fell 3.0% in October, marking four consecutive months of decline. Fed officials view the current low inflation environment as transitory, diminishing the likelihood of persistently low inflation.

site_title: China's home-price fall deepens despite policy support, FDI slips
summary: China's home prices fell 2.6% in October, the largest drop since 2011, despite government support measures. Prices in Beijing dropped 1.3% year-over-year, and foreign direct investment (FDI) slipped 1.2% in the first 10 months of the year. Analysts predict a prolonged housing market correction, with some expecting it to last 5-7 years. The government has cut mortgage rates and reduced minimum downpayment levels to boost the economy, which is threatened by a sagging housing market.

site_title: Prudential posts 17% rise in new business profit for first nine months of 2014
summary: British life insurer Prudential reported a 17% increase in new business profit for the first nine months of 2014, reaching £1.51 billion. The growth was driven by higher sales in Asia, the US, and the UK, with 15% increase in Asia and 16% in the US. Total annual premium equivalent (APE) sales rose 14% to £3.43 billion, mainly driven by growth in Asia. The insurer attributed its success to its focus on health and protection offerings in Asia and plans to build on its regional distribution platform and chosen market segments.

site_title: Seoul: Shares up more than 1% on ECB stimulus prospect; won lower
summary: South Korean shares rose more than 1% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day losing streak, due to anticipation of European Central Bank stimulus. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,967.01 points. The South Korean won fell against the dollar, reaching a four-year high against a basket of currencies, as expectations of more easing from Europe and Japan pushed the greenback higher.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-wk lows, iron ore miners slump
summary: Australian shares fell to their lowest in over three weeks, with the S&P/ASX 200 index declining 0.2% due to a 10.3% drop in junior iron ore miner BC Iron and a 6.6% decline in Fortescue Metal Group. Benchmark iron ore spot prices reached their lowest since 2009, extending a supply glut's pressure on the commodity.

site_title: Japan Aso's signals tax hike delay, says must not happen again
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso has signaled a delay in the planned second sales tax hike, citing Japan's recession and massive public debt. Aso stated that raising the sales tax is unavoidable to pay for social welfare costs, but said Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may delay the hike to next year. The government plans to pass a supplementary budget to fund a stimulus package, and Aso removed a clause allowing for a delay if economic conditions are too severe. A snap election is expected to be held in December, two years before Abe's term ends.

site_title: SGX market update: We have nine China SOE stocks
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has identified nine China state-owned enterprise (SOE) stocks listed on its platform, totaling S$8 billion in market value. These stocks span sectors including pharmaceuticals, water purification, and shipping, trading at 1.2 times their book value on average.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 1.13% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.13% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 267.91 points to 23,529.17, amid weak Chinese economic data and a decline in mainland investments. China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.71%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.18%. The decline was attributed to mainlanders pulling back from investing in Hong Kong via the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock link.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 2.18%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.18% on Tuesday, rebounding from a 3% drop the previous day due to weaker yen and bargain-hunting. The Nikkei 225 index gained 370.26 points to 17,344.06, while the Topix index rose 2.10% to 1,394.88. The economic data showing Japan's recession led to the market's decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares skid to 3-week lows, miners pinned down by growth woes
summary: Australian shares fell to a three-week low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index edging down 0.1% due to concerns over global growth and declining iron ore prices. Iron ore producer Fortescue Metal dropped 5% and Rio Tinto shed 0.4% after iron ore futures hit a record low. The decline follows data showing Japan's unexpected recession and China's falling average new home prices, which raised uncertainty about the Asian giant's economy.

site_title: Jack Ma, social media firm Tencent raise stakes in Huayi Bros
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma's investment firm and social media firm Tencent are investing 2.8 billion yuan (US$588 million) in Huayi Brothers Media Corp, increasing their stakes in the entertainment company. Huayi Brothers plans to use the funds for new projects and debt repayment. The investment firm controlled by Jack Ma will subscribe to 61.76 million shares, while Tencent will purchase 51.55 million shares, marking the tech giants' push into the entertainment industry.

site_title: Shanghai-Hong Kong trade link disappoints on day two
summary: Hong Kong's Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect launched on November 18, 2014, but investors largely ignored the link-up on the second day of trading, with China-based investors buying only 7.6% of their daily allowance of Hong Kong shares. Mainland traders used up less than 20% of their quota, while Hong Kong dealers picked up less than a third of their Shanghai quota. The weak uptake was attributed to the limited familiarity of mainland traders with the Hong Kong market.

site_title: Abe calls snap Japan poll, delays tax hike
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called a snap election, delaying a planned sales tax rise, citing the country's recession. The move comes after two years of "Abenomics" policies, which aimed to boost prices and stimulate growth, but have instead led to deflation and stagnant wages. Abe, with approval ratings around 50%, is expected to win the election and use it as an opportunity to reset his premiership, potentially paving the way for further reforms and nuclear reactor restarts.

site_title: OW Bunker Far East to meet liquidator over debt on Dec 4
summary: Singapore-based arm of bankrupt shipping fuel trader OW Bunker will meet with liquidator KPMG on Dec 4 to discuss outstanding debt totaling almost $1.5 billion globally. OW Bunker filed for bankruptcy after revealing losses of at least $125 million at a Singapore-based subsidiary, sending the bunker fuel market into turmoil. The firm owes $750 million to financers and $730 million to 150 trading counterparties globally. A meeting with creditors and estimated claims will be discussed, with major energy companies such as Statoil and BP among the debtors.

images.alt_text: The Singapore arm of bankrupt Danish shipping fuel trader OW Bunker will meet with its liquidator KPMG in early December to discuss the firm's outstanding debt, which totals almost US$1.5 billion globally.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 16.63 points to 3,305.3. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 41, and volume reached 59.9 million shares worth S$45.4 million. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up 0.30% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.30% at open, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 71.82 points to 23,868.90. The move follows a disappointing start to a cross-border trade link-up with Shanghai.

site_title: Neil Young vows Starbucks boycott over GMO suit
summary: Rock icon Neil Young has vowed to boycott Starbucks due to the coffee giant's alleged support for an industry group challenging a Vermont law requiring labels on genetically modified products. Young, an environmental activist, is urging his fans to pressure Starbucks over the lawsuit. Starbucks denies the charges, calling them "false." The company is a major supporter of Young's environmental activism, and this move may lead to a significant loss in business for the coffee chain.

site_title: India, Australia vow closer security and trade ties
summary: India and Australia have strengthened their defense and security ties, with a focus on combating terrorism and transnational crimes. The two nations signed agreements on drug control, social security, and tourism, as well as a new framework on security cooperation. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi described the partnership as "natural" and emphasized the importance of economic cooperation. The two countries also aim to finalize a free trade deal by the end of next year, with Australia's Prime Minister Tony Abbott calling for easier access to Indian markets and quicker investment approvals.

site_title: China Jan-Oct inbound FDI down 1.2% y-o-y
summary: China drew $95.9 billion in foreign direct investment (FDI) in the first 10 months of 2014, a 1.2% decrease from the previous year. Non-financial direct outbound investment rose 17.8% to $81.9 billion. In contrast, October FDI was $8.5 billion, a 1.3% increase.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds extraordinary meeting after fuel price rise
summary: Indonesia's central bank held an extraordinary meeting after President Joko Widodo raised fuel prices by 30% to fund his reform agenda, aiming to tackle budget and current account deficits. The move is expected to add 2 percentage points to inflation, but with inflation forecast at 8%, some economists believe the central bank will hold policy rates steady. A rate rise could support the rupiah, which has fallen 6% against the dollar. The government plans to use the saved funds for infrastructure and social programs, with no major protests reported.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed after Wall St record, Tokyo recovers
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, with Tokyo leading gains after a record close on Wall Street and data showing Japan's economy was in recession. Tokyo rose 1.83%, while Seoul added 1.04%. Hong Kong and Shanghai extended losses, while Sydney dipped 0.19%. Investors expect Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to delay another sales tax rise and call a snap election. The dollar recovered from Monday's losses, and the euro edged up against the dollar. Oil prices fell, and gold remained steady.

site_title: Australian, Indian leaders target free trade pact, economic boost
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced plans to pursue a free trade pact between their countries, aiming to boost economic ties. The deal would follow Australia's recent landmark free trade agreement with China, which significantly expanded ties between the two nations. Trade between Australia and India stands at around $15 billion annually, and the agreement would aim to secure greater access for Indian investors and simplify investment approvals. The pact would also facilitate cooperation on civil nuclear energy, with Australia set to increase uranium supplies to India.

site_title: What is Abenomics?
summary: Japan slipped into recession, contradicting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics plan, which aimed to combat deflation through big government spending, monetary easing, and an inflation target of 2.0%. Initially, Abenomics led to a weak yen, stock price gains, and modest wage hikes, but a second tax rise and increased government spending failed to stimulate the economy. The recession, coupled with a national debt over twice the economy's size, has raised concerns about the plan's success, and Abe is expected to call an early election and consider further stimulus measures.

site_title: G20: ambitious economic goals or hollow promises?
summary: G20 leaders set ambitious economic goals to boost global growth by 2.1% by 2018, with measures to lift investment, trade, and competition expected to add over $2 trillion to the global economy. However, economists consider these goals as hollow promises due to countries' preoccupation with their own issues, hindering global recovery efforts.

site_title: For Fed, low inflation still a likely foe: study
summary: A study by the San Francisco Fed found that, two years from now, the Federal Reserve is twice as likely to face low inflation as high inflation. By late 2016, the probability of inflation above 3% is 16% or less, while the likelihood of inflation below 1% is about 30%. This reverses historical trends, where high inflation was more likely. The study suggests the Fed can remain patient on raising interest rates as unemployment falls, bolstering arguments from Fed officials.

site_title: Hot stock: Yuuzoo Corp up 6.6% to S$0.405 on improved revenue figures
summary: Yuuzoo Corp, a newly listed internet company, saw its stock rise 6.6% to S$0.405 after reporting improved revenue figures for the three months ended Sept 30. The company reported US$10.2 million in revenue, a 38% increase from the previous year, despite a net loss of US$16 million due to reverse takeover expenses. Yuuzoo's executive chairman, Thomas Zilliacus, attributed the company's strategy to reaching users through television networks in emerging countries. The company's stock made its debut in September after a reverse takeover of components trader W Corp.

site_title: China central bank approves offshore yuan investment programme: state newspaper
summary: China's central bank has approved the Renminbi Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (RQDII) programme, allowing domestic institutional investors to buy offshore yuan products. This move aims to internationalize the yuan, promoting its use as a global currency. The RQDII programme will not be restricted by quotas, unlike the current Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (QDII) scheme. The approval is part of Beijing's efforts to increase the yuan's global presence, including the establishment of offshore yuan centres and the relaxation of currency restrictions.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on ECB stimulus expectation; won retreats
summary: South Korean shares rose over 1% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day decline, due to anticipation of European Central Bank stimulus. ECB President Mario Draghi hinted at further easing measures, including sovereign bond purchases. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) was up 1.14% at 1,965.72 points, driven by offshore buyers and traditional defensive plays such as consumer staples. The South Korean won retreated against the dollar, reaching 1,098.6 to the dollar.

site_title: China Oct home prices fall y-o-y in 67 of 70 cities polled
summary: China's average new home prices in 70 major cities fell 2.6% from a year earlier in October, marking the second consecutive month of annual decline. Home prices dropped in 67 cities, with Beijing and Shanghai experiencing a 1.3% and 2.0% year-on-year decrease, respectively. Economists believe the cooling housing market poses a significant risk to China's economy, despite Beijing's efforts to stimulate overall growth.

site_title: Rowsley sets up S$500m multicurrency medium term note programme
