CitizenM, a design-driven brand, is also expanding into Asia, with plans to open hotels in Taipei, Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Macau, Jakarta, and Bangkok. Meanwhile, Premier Inn and Element/Avani are also entering the Asian market, targeting budget and mid-range travelers.

site_title: Silicon Valley still a draw for Singapore startups
summary: Singapore remains a draw for startups, despite government support, with many entrepreneurs choosing to launch in Silicon Valley or other US hotspots. The US offers better access to financing, co-founders, technical workers, and market opportunities, driving Singaporeans to seek opportunities abroad. However, some entrepreneurs are now starting businesses from Singapore, particularly those with location-specific or US-based business models. The Singapore government is exploring ways to improve its innovation ecosystem, including easing ownership requirements and funding conditions for US startups expanding into Singapore.

site_title: Thio Shen Yi elected Lawsoc president
summary: Thio Shen Yi, a Senior Counsel and joint managing director of TSMP Law Corporation, has been elected president of the Law Society of Singapore, replacing Lok Vi Ming. Thio aims to focus on pro bono work and integrating foreign law firms into the Singapore legal fraternity during his term. He also seeks to provide thought leadership in initiatives that benefit the community, business, and legal sectors.

site_title: September retail sales up 5.5%, buoyed only by vehicle sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 5.5% year-on-year in September, driven by a 30% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales were flat. The growth was attributed to lower tourist spending and potential negative wealth effects from a cooling property market. Categories such as medical goods, telecommunications apparatus, and department stores also saw strong growth, while recreational goods and furniture contracts were significant.

site_title: 701Search, Myriad tie up on Indonesia, Thailand online classifieds
summary: 701Search, a Singaporean company affiliated with Singapore Press Holdings, has partnered with Myriad International Holdings to develop online classifieds businesses in Indonesia and Thailand. Myriad, a subsidiary of Naspers, will handle the development, while 701Search will provide the necessary infrastructure. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for online classifieds in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Olam Q1 profit dips 2.9% to S$44.3m
summary: Olam International's first-quarter net profit fell 2.9% to S$44.3 million, impacted by price movements in hazelnuts and dairy, and challenges in its upstream dairy business. Revenue dipped 0.5% to S$4.3 billion. Despite concerns, CEO Sunny Verghese remains "cautiously optimistic" about the full-year outlook. The company is exploring opportunities for acquisitions and divestments, but has not signed any agreements. Net gearing stood at 1.85 times, higher than a quarter earlier.

site_title: Malaysia's economy grows 5.6% in Q3
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 5.6% in Q3, driven by private consumption and investment, putting it on track for a 5.5-6% full-year growth. Household debt rose 10.4%, but loan delinquency risk remained low. The central bank tightened lending criteria, moderating personal financing loans to 4.2% per year. Domestic borrowing by businesses rose 7.6% and home loans accounted for 40% of total loans, with 3 in 10 applications rejected. The government's contingent liabilities, estimated at 12-15% of GDP, were deemed manageable, but public anxiety over off-balance sheet amounts remains.

site_title: Warner Music ties up with China's Tencent
summary: Warner Music Group has announced a partnership with China's Tencent, marking the first deal for a major global record label in the Chinese market. The partnership will include streaming services across China, including QQ Music. Warner Music will distribute its content through Tencent's platforms, allowing artists such as Prince and Coldplay to reach a new audience in China. The deal is seen as a significant move for the global music industry, expanding its presence in the growing Chinese market.

site_title: Tech app-etisers
summary: Two local startups, Asteroid and Beacon-In, are exploring the potential of beacon technology in the F&B industry. Asteroid allows users to access exclusive deals and promotions at participating merchants, while Beacon-In provides location-based information and recommendations. Frunk, another startup, aims to speed up the food ordering process by allowing customers to browse menus and place orders directly through the app, using beacon technology to secure orders. These apps aim to improve the customer experience and increase efficiency in the F&B industry.

site_title: Test of stock link rests with investors on both sides
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets are set to link up, allowing investors to buy and sell shares across the border. The initial test will see investors in Hong Kong able to buy 568 Shanghai-listed companies, while mainland investors can buy 266 Hong Kong-listed stocks. Trading will be restricted, with daily quotas and caps on ownership. The link is seen as a potential step towards China opening up its capital account, with broader implications for investors and the country's integration with global financial markets.

site_title: Week when UOB, DBS swings dictate STI moves
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 30 points or 0.9% to 3,315.67, driven by large swings in UOB and DBS, with DBS up S$0.21 to S$19.71 and UOB up S$0.09 to S$23.29. Genting Singapore reported disappointing results, while a takeover offer for UEL was announced. Trading conditions in the local market have been criticized, but the Singapore Exchange defended its position, citing strong fund-raising efforts and investor education. A new listing, Resources Prima Group, was also reported.

site_title: The beginning of luxury
summary: Hyundai's Genesis luxury sedan, a full-size model, has been revamped with sleek styling, a classic front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout, and a 3.8-litre V6 petrol engine. The car boasts a near-perfect weight distribution and impressive torque, making it surprisingly nimble despite its 1.9-tonne weight. It features multiple driving modes and precise steering, setting it apart from its mass-market stablemates. The Genesis is a significant departure from Hyundai's affordable models, positioning the brand as a luxury carmaker.

images.alt_text: GOING UPSCALE: The cabin has the requisite 'towkay' features, such as the electrically operated rear seats, and a rear centre console
GOING UPSCALE: The cabin has the requisite 'towkay' features, such as the electrically operated rear seats, and a rear centre console

site_title: Otto Q3 profit halved on lower one-time gains
summary: Otto Marine's third-quarter profit halved to US$2.02 million due to a sharp drop in one-time gains, despite a 16.8% increase in revenue to US$96.82 million. Revenue from shipyard and offshore chartering rose, but other income slumped 86.4% due to a decrease in foreign exchange differences and reduced gains on disposal. The company's earnings per share decreased to 0.05 US cents.

site_title: Moreish mashups
summary: Singaporean chefs are experimenting with cross-cultural culinary fusions, incorporating local flavors into modern dishes. Restaurants like Wild Rocket, Pidgin Kitchen and Bar, and The Prawn Star are serving unique adaptations of traditional Singaporean street food. Willin Low's Mod-Sin creations, such as 48-hour sous vide beef short ribs, and Adrian Ling's unexpected combinations, like bak kwa mac-and-cheese, showcase the East-meets-West trend. Other eateries, like Hyde & Co and Sinpopo Brand, are offering gula melaka crumpets and revamping their menus to include local flavors and ingredients, reflecting the growing interest in locavore dining.

site_title: Norway oil fund to enter Asian real estate market
summary: Norway's US$860 billion sovereign fund plans to enter the Asian real estate market next year, targeting an investment horizon of 'forever'. The fund aims to invest around US$8-10 billion annually and will focus on big cities, including two yet-to-be-identified Asian cities. Its real estate portfolio has yielded unexpectedly high returns, with a 8.95% return in the first nine months of the year, but Mr. Kallevig believes these returns are unsustainable. The fund seeks long-term growth and will not aim to beat market cycles.

site_title: SSA, MPA confirm no bunker disruption in wake of fraud at OW
summary: The Singapore Shipping Association (SSA) and Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) have confirmed that bunker supply and bunkering operations in Singapore have not been disrupted following a reported US$125 million fraud at OW Bunker's Singapore-based subsidiary Dynamic Oil Trading (DOT). OW Bunker reported a US$150 million risk-management loss, prompting its banks to hesitate on credit extensions. Despite the incident, SSA and MPA stated that there is no impact on bunker supply and operations in Singapore.

images.alt_text: OW Bunker sign in front of OW Bunker headquaters in Aalborg on Nov 6, 2014.

site_title: Car manufacturers agree on measures to secure data generated by vehicles
summary: US-based car manufacturers have agreed on measures to secure data generated by vehicles, including providing notices of privacy practices and describing when data will be shared with government authorities. The Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers and the Association of Global Automakers released a 13-page document outlining steps to preserve customer privacy. Carmakers including BMW, Ford, General Motors, and Toyota will take these measures, but cybersecurity experts are calling for more scrutiny of potential hacking risks and urging implementation of basic guidelines to defend cars from cyber attacks.

site_title: SGX Bull Charge raises S$2.6m for four charities this year
summary: The SGX Bull Charge 2014 charity run raised S$2.6 million for four charities: AWWA, Autism Association of Singapore, Fei Yue Community Services, and Shared Services for Charities. The 11th edition of the annual run, attended by 6,000 runners, including SGX CEO Magnus Bocker, has contributed almost S$24 million to over 50 charities since its inception in 2004.

site_title: Manulife's Q3 profit up 6.4% at C$1.1b
summary: Manulife Financial Corp reported a 6.4% increase in Q3 profit to C$1.1 billion, despite lower-than-expected earnings in Canada and the US. Insurance sales fell 19% in the US and 23% in Canada, but rose 46% in Asia, while wealth management sales surged 74% in the region. Total revenue rose 75% to C$11.04 billion, and core earnings increased 7.2% to C$755 million. CFO Steve Roder cited favourable economic and market trends in Asia, expecting healthy growth in the region.

site_title: Berkshire to buy P&G's Duracell in stock swap
summary: Berkshire Hathaway Inc, led by chairman Warren Buffett, has agreed to buy Procter & Gamble Co's Duracell battery business in a stock swap. Berkshire will exchange US$4.7 billion of P&G shares for the business, valued at about US$1.7 billion in cash. The deal is expected to be completed in the second half of next year, allowing Berkshire to reduce its stake in P&G without incurring tax costs. P&G has been streamlining its operations, cutting expenses and selling non-core businesses, including its pet-food business and slower-selling brands.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to defer more bonus pay for brokers
summary: Morgan Stanley, the world's largest brokerage firm, plans to defer 1.5-15.5% of its brokers' cash and stock bonuses in 2015, a significant increase from past years. Brokers with average revenue will see 10% of their bonus deferred, with varying vesting periods for cash and stock payouts. The change aims to give a clearer view of what brokers will give up in deferred pay if they leave for a rival firm, potentially prompting other firms to adopt similar plans.

site_title: Deep vein distress
summary: A woman, Madam A, developed deep vein thrombosis (DVT) while on a cruise ship, causing chest pain and shortness of breath. Clots in her leg veins traveled to the lungs, obstructing blood flow. She was treated with blood-thinning medication and an umbrella-like device inserted into her leg veins to prevent further clots. The condition can be caused by immobility, genetic factors, or oral contraceptives. Prevention measures include regular leg movement, hydration, and compression stockings. Early detection is crucial, and ultrasound scans can confirm the presence of clots. In severe cases, IVC filters may be inserted to prevent recurrent clots.

site_title: Charmed by Sri Lanka's majestic course
summary: The Victoria Golf and Country Resort in Sri Lanka hosted the SriLankan Airlines Golf Classic, attracting 90 foreign and 100 local golfers from 18 countries. The 18-hole par 73 course, designed by Donald Steel and Martin Ebert, features stunning views of the Knuckles mountain range and Victoria Reservoir. Sri Lankan Amrith de Soysa won the men's section with a gross score of 74, while Qin Ami of Pakistan took the ladies title. The tournament was organized by the resort and sponsored by SriLankan Airlines, offering a unique blend of golf and scenic beauty.

site_title: Dormitory demand drives Centurion's Q3 net profit up 47%
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$7.92 million in Q3 2014, driven by its accommodation business. Revenue rose 46% to S$20.90 million, with its optical disc business experiencing a decline. The company's gearing ratio increased to 57% due to higher borrowings, but its interest cover remains adequate. Centurion plans to explore strategic acquisitions and partnerships to expand its accommodation business.

site_title: Tech innovators enticed by Silicon Valley
summary: Lawrence Suen, co-founder of startup Appsverse, explains why he broke his Singapore government bond to pursue a career in Silicon Valley. Suen met his business partner Fai Leong at Cornell University in the 1990s and both later relocated to the US. Appsverse, launched in 2011, is a photon flash-browsing software that generates millions in revenue. Suen attributes the company's success to its ability to squeeze every bit out of its servers. He sees expansion opportunities in Singapore and plans to develop a more general-purpose browser.

site_title: G20 'needs to get global economy growing again'
summary: Singapore Business Federation chief executive Ho Meng Kit urges G20 leaders to implement structural reforms to boost global economic growth. The private sector drives growth, and confidence in business communities is key. Ho supports the G20's aim to boost collective economic growth by 2% over the next five years and hopes Singapore can play a role in a new global infrastructure hub in Sydney. The B-20 Summit has made recommendations to free up trade, boosting global growth by $3.4 billion and creating 50 million jobs.

site_title: Scottish independence party names new leader
summary: Scotland's ruling Scottish National Party (SNP) has named Nicola Sturgeon as its new leader, vowing to continue the fight for independence despite the September referendum's defeat. Sturgeon, the party's deputy, was elected unanimously and will become Scotland's first female first minister next week. She expressed confidence that Scotland will become an independent country, but emphasized that the decision will be made by the Scottish people. The SNP is now seen as a potential "kingmaker" in the upcoming British general election.

site_title: Sales tax hike, snap poll put Abe in a bind
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's return from the G-20 summit in Australia has raised uncertainty in Tokyo's financial markets, with speculation over whether he will call a snap general election or delay implementing a planned consumption tax hike. The uncertainty has led to a surge in the Nikkei 225 average and a seven-year low for the yen. Analysts warn that either decision could have significant political and economic risks, with a snap election potentially harming the Liberal Democratic Party and delaying the tax hike undermining Abenomics.

site_title: Straco Q3 net profit up 28% to S$19.5m
summary: Straco Corporation reported a 28% increase in net profit to S$19.5 million for Q3 2014, driven by higher visitor numbers at its Shanghai and Xiamen aquariums, which reached 1.65 million. Revenue rose 26% to S$38.6 million. The company expects domestic travel in China to continue rising in line with government initiatives for the tourism industry. The results did not include the Singapore Flyer's partial results, which will be reported in the fourth quarter.

site_title: US consumer sentiment at more than 7-year high
summary: US consumer sentiment reached a 7-year high in November, exceeding forecasts at 89.4, driven by falling unemployment and lower gasoline prices. The current conditions index rose to 103.0, while expectations increased to 80.6. However, income gain expectations remained low, and inflation expectations fell to 2.6%. The low expectations for income gains and inflation outlook highlight concerns about a declining standard of living.

site_title: Falling oil prices = merrier X'mas
summary: US consumers will enjoy a multibillion-dollar boost during the holiday season and into next year due to falling oil prices, largely influenced by Saudi Arabia's discounts for crude oil. The steepening drop in gasoline prices will provide a significant economic boost, benefiting the US economy.

images.alt_text: PUMP SAVINGS: Barclays says the extra cash in US shoppers' wallets could help generate nearly half a percentage point in added economic growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Mizuno launches concept store
summary: Mizuno Singapore has launched the country's first Mizuno Concept Store, located at KALLANG Wave Mall in Singapore Sports Hub. Inspired by traditional Japanese elements, the store features a kimono house design and showcases the brand's strong Japanese nuances. The launch coincided with the release of the Wave Rider 18 Limited Edition running shoe. Mizuno aims to grow its business in Southeast Asia, with plans to upgrade all concept stores and "shops within shops" from 2015, and provide affordable and quality products to sports enthusiasts in the region.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says sticking to interest rate and inflation forecasts
summary: St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President James Bullard reaffirmed his forecast of raising interest rates in the first quarter of 2025, citing a strengthening US economy and lower oil prices. Bullard expects inflation to reach the central bank's 2% target by mid-2025. However, he expressed concern about potential "outsized declines in inflation" beyond oil price factors.

site_title: Higher revenue and gross margin boost United Engineers' Q3 bottom line
summary: United Engineers reported a 7% increase in Q3 revenue to S$786.3 million, driven by the progressive recognition of the sale of its Eight Riversuites condominium development. This led to a 47% increase in net profit to S$18.5 million. The company's 9-month revenue rose 134% to S$2.74 billion, with net profit up 89% to S$66.9 million. Despite ongoing property cooling measures, the group's property development projects are on track, and its US subsidiary expects to maintain a solid relationship with customers while continuing cost management.

site_title: US mortgage delinquencies fall to lowest since 2007: MBA
summary: US mortgage delinquencies have fallen to the lowest level since 2007, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association's National Delinquency Survey. The delinquency rate decreased to 5.85% in the third quarter, down from 6.0% in the second quarter. The foreclosure inventory rate also dropped to 2.39%, the lowest since 2007. This marks six consecutive quarters of decline in delinquencies, indicating improved housing market conditions.

site_title: Bank crisis reforms largely done: FSB chairman
summary: The Financial Stability Board (FSB) chairman, Mark Carney, says reforms to address the 2007-09 financial crisis are largely complete, with a focus on spotting new risks and rebuilding trust among regulators. The FSB has enforced rules requiring banks to hold more capital and implemented tougher standards for financial derivatives. However, further work remains to build a fully resilient system and address concerns about "too big to fail" banks. The FSB will now focus on new and evolving risks from "shadow banking" and refining its implementation of rules.

site_title: HK warns of slower growth due to democracy protests
summary: Hong Kong's government warned of slower growth due to pro-democracy protests, which have paralyzed parts of the city for over a month. Despite a 2.7% growth in the third quarter, the government forecast annual growth at 2.2%, at the lower end of its 2-3% range. The protests have dampened economic activity, affecting the city's encouraging growth in the third quarter.

site_title: G-20 Brisbane Summit to mark a year of action
summary: The G-20 Brisbane Summit marks a year of action, with leaders set to finalize commitments to strengthen the global economy, create jobs, and deliver prosperity to billions. The summit aims to boost global GDP by at least 2% over five years, adding over $2 trillion to the global economy and creating millions of new jobs. Since setting the goal, G-20 nations have developed over 1,000 measures to drive economic growth, achieving 90% of the way to meeting the target. The summit will focus on addressing global problems, including jobs, infrastructure, tax, trade, and corruption, with the goal of restoring confidence in the global economy.

site_title: Better studies on prejudice needed
summary: Research on under-represented groups in top echelons of organizations has been criticized for its methodological flaws. Studies often rely on percentage representation of minorities, which fails to account for omitted variables such as family background and education. Anomalous findings in countries like India and Indonesia suggest that women's rise to leadership positions may be due to factors like family ties and business ownership rather than positive attitudes towards women. To address the issue, researchers need to conduct robust statistical analyses that control for these variables. Meaningful solutions can be devised only when the root causes of the problem are understood, and governments can play a role by providing incentives for companies to upgrade the skills and career prospects of minority employees.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after retail sales, UMich data on tap
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday, tracking a fourth consecutive weekly advance, after retail sales data and a consumer sentiment report. Retail sales rose 0.3% in October, beating expectations, while import prices fell 0.3% in September. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record high, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also set new records, despite modest gains.

site_title: Yongnam Q3 loss deepens to S$8.4m
summary: Yongnam Holdings has reported a net loss of S$8.4 million in its third quarter, down from S$3.4 million a year ago, with revenue halving to S$47.3 million. The decline is attributed to the completion of several contracts, resulting in lower fabrication and erection activities. The company's stock price remained unchanged at S$0.205.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, was a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are strengthening cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Oil 'price rout' not over: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts oil prices will continue to slide into 2015 due to weak demand and increased shale production, contradicting speculation of a new equilibrium at US$80-90 per barrel. The agency's supply and demand forecasts indicate downward price pressures could build further in the first half of 2015, unless new supply disruptions occur. This suggests the "price rout" has not yet run its course, with prices expected to remain low.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge up on Shanghai-connector expectations
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by expectations for the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connector launch on Monday, which is expected to boost trading activity. Oil shares declined due to a drop in US crude futures. The Hang Seng index rose 2.3% for the week, while the HSCE advanced 2.1%. Mengniu Dairy was a top winner, while oil companies including Kunlun Energy, Sinopec, and PetroChina were among the biggest losers.

site_title: Room for more
summary: Crate and Barrel has opened its second store at Orchard Gateway in Singapore, expanding to 25,000 square feet, nearly 40% larger than its first store at Ion Orchard. The new store features a wider range of kitchen gadgets, botanicals, furnishings, and designer curtains. Executive director Yung Ong believes the second store will attract a different customer base and offer a more relaxed, American, and contemporary shopping experience. The store is spread across five floors, with a basement entrance connected to the MRT.

site_title: Retail sales point to more spending zeal by US consumers
summary: US retailers reported a 0.5% increase in sales in October, exceeding analyst expectations. This surge in sales, which accounts for about one-third of consumer spending, indicates American consumers are spending more. Despite a 1.5% drop in gasoline sales, driven by falling oil prices, overall retail sales rose 0.3%. Sales at clothing and sporting goods retailers increased, while auto dealers and parts stores also saw gains. The strong sales data suggests the US economy may continue to grow at a brisk pace.

site_title: HK student leaders plan Beijing visit
summary: Hong Kong student leaders plan a trip to Beijing to push for democratic reforms, amid six-week protests demanding free elections in 2017. The trip, led by Alex Chow, Eason Chung, and Nathan Law, aims to meet with Premier Li Keqiang. Beijing has deemed the protests illegal, and a police crackdown is expected, with some businesspeople calling for the protests to end to maintain stability. The protests, which have dwindled from 100,000 to around 1,000, are part of China's "one country, two systems" formula, which grants Hong Kong autonomy and universal suffrage.

site_title: US business inventories rise in September
summary: US business inventories rose 0.3% in September, slightly above economists' expectations, but the August estimate was revised downward. Retail inventories excluding autos rose 0.2% and business sales remained flat. At September's sales pace, it would take 1.3 months for businesses to clear shelves. This suggests little impact on economic growth in the third quarter.

site_title: China gives tax breaks on Hong Kong-Shanghai stock link
summary: China has temporarily exempted taxes on profits from a landmark scheme linking the Shanghai and Hong Kong stock exchanges, removing a potential stumbling block for global investors. The Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect will allow international investors to trade Shanghai-listed shares via Hong Kong and mainland investors to trade in Hong Kong shares via Shanghai. Individuals and companies in Hong Kong buying shares in Shanghai will be exempt from income tax for an unspecified period, while mainland investors will be liable for tax on dividends.

site_title: Airbus profits rise but A400M problems resurface
summary: Airbus reported a 12% increase in nine-month operating earnings to 2.6 billion euros, driven by strong civil aerospace demand and deposits for new jets. However, the company faces challenges with its A400M troop carrier project, which has experienced delays and potential cost overruns, prompting Airbus to introduce a caveat about the impact on its forecasts. The company reaffirmed its full-year forecasts but warned that incremental charges for A400M delays are possible.

site_title: Wheelock Properties Q3 revenue, earnings fall
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a 7.2% drop in net profit to S$11 million for its Q3 2014, with revenue falling 17.4% to S$22.8 million. Lower dividend income and higher other operating expenses contributed to the decline. The company's revenue was also impacted by the disposal of its investment in Hotel Properties Ltd. The counter closed at S$1.795, 2 cents lower.

site_title: WTO sees global trade pact within two weeks
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has reached a deal on streamlining global customs rules, with a high probability of implementation within two weeks, according to Director-General Roberto Azevedo. The agreement, known as the Bali package, was reached after an impasse between India and the US was resolved, which had threatened to derail global trade reforms valued at around $1 trillion. The WTO had been paralyzed by the dispute, but the breakthrough is seen as a major step forward for global trade.

site_title: Putin berates US over sanctions before G20 meeting
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized the US over sanctions imposed on Russia, calling them a "mistake" that harm both Russia and the global economy. He argued that the US is violating international law and trade agreements by imposing asset freezes, visa bans, and restrictions on Russian companies accessing Western financial markets. Putin stated that Russia's economy is resilient due to its large reserves and plans to strengthen ties with China, including providing financial support to state-controlled energy producer Rosneft.

site_title: Samsung Electronics sees squeeze in African growth as economy slows
summary: Samsung Electronics expects high single-digit revenue growth in 2014 due to a slowdown in Africa's economy, similar to the rest of the world. The slowdown is attributed to investment and access to funding and credit decreasing in the continent. According to Samsung Vice President George Ferreira, Africa's growth has been affected by the global economic malaise, with a slowdown in growth but still experiencing growth.

site_title: India's inflation hits 5-year low, fans rate cut hopes
summary: India's wholesale inflation fell to a 5-year low of 1.77% in October, down from a year earlier, as fuel and food prices decreased. The drop in inflation has sparked hopes for the Reserve Bank of India to cut interest rates, boosting economic growth. The decline in global oil prices has contributed to the decrease in fuel costs, benefiting the fuel-import-reliant nation. This move could lead to lower interest rates and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Tat Hong Q2 net profit up 39% at S$11.5m, boosted by subsidiary sale, forex gain
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a 39% increase in Q2 net profit to S$11.5m, driven by the sale of subsidiary Hup Hin Transport and foreign exchange gains. However, excluding these factors, revenue fell 18% to S$152.8m. CEO Roland Ng expressed optimism about the group's key Australian business, but noted a slow recovery.

site_title: China lending drops sharply, fuels calls for bolder stimulus moves
summary: China's bank lending dropped 36% to 548.3 billion yuan (US$89.5 billion) in October, the lowest level in 6 months, amid growing economic weakness. The decline in credit growth and money supply raises fears of a sharper slowdown in the economy. Economists are urging the government to implement bolder stimulus measures, including cutting interest rates, to counter the slowdown. The drop in credit comes after bad loans rose at their fastest clip in two years and deposits shrank, highlighting growing strains on the financial system.

site_title: Top 10 investment bank revenues rise in Q3: survey
summary: Top 10 global investment banks' trading revenue rose 11% in Q3 to $36.5 billion, driven by a 16% increase in fixed income, currencies, and commodities (FICC) due to market volatility. Equities revenue was $9.9 billion, 3% up on last year, while investment banking divisions (IBDs) saw a 12% increase to $9.4 billion. However, annual trading revenue is expected to be little changed from last year at $152.7 billion. Bank restructuring continued, with headcount down 4% year-on-year across all divisions.

site_title: OW Bunker collapse to shake up world's largest ship fuel market Singapore
summary: Singapore's largest marine fuel market, valued at over $25 billion, is expected to be shaken up by the collapse of OW Bunker, a leading supplier of marine fuel oil, after it filed for bankruptcy in Denmark. The incident has led to a credit squeeze, causing small companies in the supply chain to shrink, while major oil companies like BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Vitol may expand their market share. The market's reliance on open credit has raised concerns of a domino effect, with fuel oil sellers demanding payment guarantees and credit costs increasing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,813.79 after 1.65 billion lots valued at RM1.60 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 235-548. This is not related to the provided articles about Singapore and US stocks.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index rising 10.74 points to 3,315.67. The 1.52 billion shares traded valued at S$1.05 billion, with 191 gainers and 239 losers. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines claims long-awaited IPO 'a success'
summary: Vietnam Airlines successfully completed its long-awaited IPO, raising over $52 million by selling 49 million shares at an average price of 22,307 dong ($1.05) per share. The airline sold shares to over 1,500 investors, with the company maintaining control. This marks a significant milestone for the national carrier, ending decades of speculation and failed attempts. The IPO's success will likely have a positive impact on the airline's operations and future growth.

site_title: China inquiries on US property jump after visa rules eased
summary: Chinese inquiries about US real estate surged 35% after the US and China extended short-term visas to 10 years, up from one year. Student visas were also extended to 5 years, potentially leading to more inquiries. Many Chinese parents buy US property for their children to study abroad, with 85% of wealthy Chinese wanting to educate them overseas. The US remains the top destination for Chinese property inquiries, followed by Australia, Canada, and Britain.

site_title: Oxley's Q1 net profit down 96% on revenue plunge
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 96% decline in net profit to S$10.1 million in Q1 2014, largely due to an 82% drop in revenue to S$120.3 million. This resulted in a significant decrease in earnings per share, from 8.51 Singapore cents to 0.34 Singapore cents. The company's poor performance is attributed to the decline in revenue.

site_title: Eurozone grows faster than expected in third quarter
summary: Eurozone economic growth surpassed expectations in the third quarter, expanding 0.2% quarter-on-quarter and 0.8% year-on-year. Germany grew 0.1% and France 0.3%, defying recession fears. The eurozone's growth rate is still slow, but not as weak as predicted, according to ABN AMRO's Nick Kounis, who believes a slow recovery rather than a third recession is likely. This outcome is a relief for policymakers, who had been concerned about the economy's trajectory.

site_title: Property sales boost United Engineers Q3 performance
summary: United Engineers reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$18.5 million for the Q3 period, driven by progressive revenue recognition from the sale of its Eight Riversuites development and a positive contribution from its US subsidiary. Revenue rose 7% to S$786.3 million. Earnings per share decreased to 2.9 Singapore cents, compared to 3 cents the previous year. The company's stock closed 2 cents higher at S$2.88.

site_title: India's Tata Motors says profit falls after domestic sales drop
summary: Tata Motors, India's largest automaker, reported a 7.1% drop in second-quarter profit to 32.91 billion rupees (US$533 million), missing analyst estimates. Sales of commercial and passenger vehicles fell 15.7% domestically, while revenue rose 6.5% to 601.64 billion rupees. The company relies heavily on Jaguar Land Rover's sales, which helped prop up profits in previous years. Analysts had expected a profit of 46.2 billion rupees and revenue of 634.28 billion rupees. The decline in domestic sales has raised concerns about Tata Motors' financial stability.

site_title: Thai Beverage Q3 profit falls 9% on flat revenue
summary: Thai Beverage reported a 9% drop in net profit to 3.7 billion baht in Q3 2014, driven by a 1% rise in revenue to 35.3 billion baht. The company attributed the increase in revenue to higher sales of beer, spirits, non-alcoholic beverages, and food. However, the weaker bottom line was due to lower profits from spirits and food businesses, greater losses from non-alcoholic business, and lower contributions from subsidiaries. The company's revenue growth was not enough to offset the decline in profits.

site_title: Germany skirts recession with 0.1% growth in Q3
summary: Germany narrowly avoided a recession with a 0.1% growth in the third quarter, narrowly escaping two consecutive quarters of falling GDP. This is good news for the eurozone, particularly France, which reported a 0.3% growth. Positive factors included increased spending by private households and a rise in exports, while investment declined in equipment and construction. A detailed breakdown of GDP components will be published on November 25.

site_title: Hong Kong student protesters plan Beijing visit, but may not be allowed in
summary: Hong Kong student protesters plan to visit Beijing to meet Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, seeking greater democracy and free elections in 2017. The protests, which have occupied key districts for six weeks, have been labeled illegal by Beijing and the Hong Kong government. Police may clear protest sites as early as Monday, but a lawyer says the move could be delayed due to a vague legal document. The protests, sparked by Beijing's refusal to allow universal suffrage, have dwindled from 100,000 to a smaller core group, but remain a pressing issue in Hong Kong.

site_title: China considering cutting coal export tax to 3%: traders
summary: China is considering reducing its coal export tax to 3% from 10% to support local miners, which have been struggling due to a year-long price drop. The proposal, first made by the China National Coal Association, is being reviewed by the National Development and Reform Commission and could be introduced as early as 2015. Analysts believe the cut would have limited impact on Asian seaborne supplies, but could make Chinese coal exports more attractive further down the line if administrative fees are abolished. The move aims to help prop up prices, which have fallen to a five-year low.

site_title: Bedok's new integrated transport hub will open on Nov 30
summary: The Bedok Integrated Transport Hub (ITH) in Singapore will open on November 30, replacing the temporary Bedok bus interchange. The new hub will serve 40,000 daily commuters with 29 bus services and 10 boarding and 5 alighting berths. The interchange also features 400 square meters of commercial space linked to Bedok Mall. This is the seventh ITH to be developed in Singapore, with three more under construction at Joo Koon, Bukit Panjang, and Yishun, set to open between 2015 and 2018.

site_title: China auto sales up 2.8% in October: industry group
summary: China's auto sales grew 2.8% year-on-year in October, reaching 1.99 million vehicles, according to the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers. This marks a slight acceleration from the previous month's weak result. Passenger car sales increased 6.4% to 1.71 million units, while overall vehicle sales rose 6.6% to 18.99 million in the first 10 months of the year. Despite a challenging operating environment, General Motors reported a 3.2% year-on-year increase in sales to 291,371 vehicles in October, a new record for the month.

site_title: Fitch: Singapore casinos to be resilient to drop in visitors
summary: Fitch Ratings has stated that Singapore's casinos, including Genting Singapore Plc and Marina Bay Sands, are likely to remain resilient despite a decline in international visitor arrivals, which led to a 6% drop in visitor arrivals in 2Q14. The casinos' mature gaming properties and strong credit profiles will allow them to withstand narrower EBITDA margins for 12-18 months. However, longer-term competition from new casinos in the Philippines, Macau, and potentially Japan may pose a threat to their growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong shares opened flat on Friday, edging down 12.72 points to 24,007.22, as profit-taking offset a record high close for the Dow on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares opened a touch lower Friday as profit-taking offset a record high close for the Dow on Wall Street.

site_title: Indonesia sharpens centralised Islamic finance oversight
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator has signed an agreement with the national sharia board to strengthen oversight of the Islamic finance industry, supporting a centralised approach. The move aims to standardise industry practices and improve consumer perceptions, as Indonesia's Islamic banks lag behind Malaysia and the Middle East. A five-year roadmap is being finalised to reshape the industry, with a focus on consolidation and building a new regulatory system, in an effort to increase sharia-compliant products and grab a bigger share of the market.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's offer for PCRT now unconditional
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' (PREHL) offer for Perennial China Retail Trust (PCRT) has become unconditional. As of Thursday, PREHL and its affiliates own 55.16% of PCRT units. The offer is 0.52423 PREHL shares per PCRT unit.

site_title: Australia: Shares end losing streak, but down 1.7% for the week
summary: Australian shares ended a four-day losing streak, rising 0.2% on Friday to 5,454.3, but still down 1.7% for the week. Gains in banks and miners offset losses in energy stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% to 5,483.99 points. The rally was not enough to halt the decline in the market, which had four weeks of gains prior to the recent losses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 1.14 points to 1812.65. Volume reached 44.13 million lots worth RM11.68 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 116 to 50.

site_title: Nokia lifts long-term network targets
summary: Nokia has lifted its long-term network targets, increasing its expected operating margin to 8-11% compared to a previous range of 5-10%. The Finnish mobile network equipment maker now anticipates growth in 2025, marking a shift from previous caution. This upward revision suggests increased confidence in the company's business prospects.

site_title: Thailand's October tourist arrivals up 6% on year
summary: Thailand's October tourist arrivals rose 6.14% year-over-year to 2.18 million, the first increase since January. The recovery is attributed to efforts to restore order and confidence following months of political unrest. However, overall tourist numbers for the first 10 months of 2014 fell 8.7% to 19.7 million. The country still faces travel warnings from several countries and the unresolved murders of two British tourists, which may impact visitor numbers. The military junta expects around 25 million tourist arrivals for 2014, down from 26.5 million in 2013.

site_title: Cordlife in the red in Q1 due to fair value loss on investment
summary: CORDLIFE Group reported a Q1 loss of S$3.6 million, down from a net profit of S$8.7 million a year ago, due to a S$4.9 million fair value loss on its China Cord Blood Corporation investment. Revenue rose 17% to S$13.3 million, driven by increased client deliveries and marketing efforts. The company's losses per share were 1.36 Singapore cents, compared to earnings per share of 3.73 Singapore cents a year ago.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group on Friday posted a S$3.6 million loss for its first quarter ended Sept 30, 2014, compared to a net profit of S$8.7 million a year ago.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall as profit-taking hits Samsung SDS, won retreats
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.78% on Friday, with Samsung SDS shares plummeting 13.8% on profit-taking after its trading debut. The won also weakened, falling to a 7-year low against the dollar. The decline follows new signs of slowing economic growth in China, which affected the broader market. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,945.14 points.

site_title: China's fiscal spending falls in October from year earlier
summary: China's fiscal expenditure declined 5.7% in October from a year earlier, marking a slowdown in government spending after a surge in previous months. Total spending for the first 10 months reached 11.4 trillion yuan, higher than the same period last year. Money spent on grain and oil reserves grew the most, up 21.6%, while transportation sector spending rose 15.8%. The decline in fiscal expenditure may continue to weigh on China's economic growth, which is expected to slow.

site_title: OECD sees G20 measures topping 2% global growth target
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) predicts that the G20 nations' plans to boost the global economy could exceed their 2% growth target by 2018. Over 1,000 measures proposed since February aim to achieve this, according to OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria. However, geopolitical risks, including the Ukraine crisis and Ebola, pose significant threats to global economic stability. The OECD and G20 are pushing for structural reforms, including tax evasion crackdowns, to address the risks.

site_title: CitySpring, Keppel Infrastructure Trust said to be in possible merger talks: report
summary: CitySpring Infrastructure Trust and Keppel Infrastructure Trust are reportedly in merger talks, according to Bloomberg. The two trusts, which generate power and provide utilities, are negotiating terms and have halted trading of their units pending an announcement. Temasek, a major shareholder of CitySpring, owns 37% of the trust. The potential deal would combine CitySpring's residential gas business with Keppel Infrastructure Trust's power generation and reclaimed water supply. No final decision has been made, and spokesmen for the companies have declined to comment.

site_title: Shipping Association confirms no disruption to bunker supply in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Shipping Association (SSA) and Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) have confirmed that there has been no disruption to bunker supply and bunkering operations in Singapore. Following the $125 million fraud at OW Bunker's Singapore unit, firms were advised to inspect their contractual obligations and work closely with stakeholders to minimize any disruption. SSA president Patrick Phoon emphasized the well-regulated nature of the Singapore bunkering industry, urging affected parties to remain calm and avoid knee-jerk reactions.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly lower, Japan GDP eyed
summary: Asian markets mostly slipped Friday, with Tokyo down 0.36%, Hong Kong flat, Shanghai down 0.21%, and Seoul down 0.77%. Despite a strong US economy and record closes on Wall Street, losses were driven by profit-taking after a healthy month. The dollar reached a seven-year high above 116 yen, with the Bank of Japan's stimulus program contributing to the rise. The G20 summit and Japanese GDP data this weekend and Monday will be key events.

site_title: Update: Oil prices rebound in Asia
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 7 cents to $74.28 and Brent crude gaining 38 cents to $77.87. Despite the slight increase, bearish sentiment about OPEC's potential production cut remains, driven by concerns about a global supply glut. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' next meeting is set for November 27. Oil prices had fallen to fresh lows earlier in the week, with Singapore's United Overseas Bank reporting the lowest settlement prices since September 2010.

site_title: Japan PM wants more defence ties with US, Australia
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wants to deepen defence ties with the US and Australia to ensure peace in the Asia-Pacific region. Abe outlined his vision for expanded military cooperation ahead of the G20 summit, which could irk Beijing. A stronger tripartite alliance could limit China's expansion in the region. Abe's comments come amid China's increasing assertiveness over territorial disputes, particularly with Japan. The prospect of closer ties between Japan, the US, and Australia is likely to raise tensions with China.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 8.04 points to 3,312.97. This marks a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Volume was 42.7 million shares worth S$73.7 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 59 to 58.

site_title: Malaysian economy grows 5.6% in Q3, current account surplus 7.6b ringgit
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 5.6% in Q3, the slowest pace this year, with exports struggling against a fragile global economy. The current account surplus narrowed to 7.6 billion ringgit (US$2.28 billion) in the third quarter. Central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz expects the economy to remain on a steady growth path, with investment activity supported by ongoing and new projects. The central bank kept its forecast for full year growth between 5.5-6.0% in 2014 and between 5.0-6.0% in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong bunker suppliers expect more demand as shipowners divert from Singapore
summary: Hong Kong bunker suppliers anticipate a 20% increase in inquiries from shipowners seeking alternative fuel sources after OW Bunker's bankruptcy. Shipowners who had fuel contracts with OW are diverting to Hong Kong, where marine fuel prices are 10% lower. This shift has led to a surge in demand, causing Singapore's marine fuel prices to spike to their highest in over two years. The increased demand is attributed to tightening credit and a supply crunch, with Singapore's delivered marine fuel oil prices reaching a record high.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.56%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.56% to a 7-year high, driven by a weaker yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,490.83, its best close since July 2007, while the Topix index gained 0.78%. The gains followed earlier losses, as investors sought to capitalize on the yen's decline. The recovery marked a more positive tone in Asian markets, which were also boosted by the US stock market's edge to fresh records.

site_title: OW Bunker's US units file for bankruptcy protection, Korea refiners mull legal action: reports
summary: US units of OW Bunker A/S, a Danish shipping-fuel supplier, filed for bankruptcy protection in Connecticut, listing assets of up to $50 million against debt of up to $100 million. The company's Singapore unit reported a $125 million fraud, and two employees were reported to police. South Korean refiners are considering legal action against OW Bunker, estimated to have lost $150 million on bad risk management, trading and selling around 100,000-150,000 tonnes of bunker fuel oil a month.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.48% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.48% higher on Friday, driven by the robust performance of Wall Street shares and a weak yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 84.03 points to 17,476.82.

site_title: SPH associated firm 701Search and Myriad International to set up JVs in Thailand, Indonesia
summary: SPH's associated firm 701Search and Myriad International Holdings are partnering to develop online classifieds businesses in Thailand and Indonesia through joint ventures. Myriad will sell its assets in Malaysia and Vietnam to 701Search, while 701Search will sell its Philippine assets to Myriad. The companies will hold 36% and 64% stakes in the Indonesian JV and 55.9% and 44.1% stakes in the Thai JV, respectively. The transactions are subject to EU approval and expected to close early next year, enhancing regional presence and expertise for both companies.

site_title: Retail sales for September up 5.5% y-o-y, lifted by sales of motor vehicles
summary: Retail sales in Singapore grew 5.5% year-on-year in September, driven by a 30% increase in motor vehicle sales. The total retail sales value reached S$3.1 billion. Other categories posting year-on-year growth included medical goods, telecommunications, and watches. Retail sales of recreational goods and furniture fell 7.1% and 6.9%, respectively. Month-on-month sales growth was seen in categories like motor vehicles, supermarkets, and medical goods.

images.alt_text: BOOSTED by sales of motor vehicles, retail sales grew 5.5 per cent year on year in September, without which they would have been up a more muted 0.6 per cent.

site_title: Hot stock: Resources Prima hits 19.6 Singapore cents
summary: Resources Prima Group, a Catalist-listed company, reached a high of 19.6 Singapore cents on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after acquiring Energy Prima for S$265 million in a reverse takeover. The company plans to grow organically and through mergers and acquisitions, with an estimated market capitalization of S$366.6 million. This marks the first Indonesian coal mining company on SGX, with 25 mining companies totaling S$5.3 billion in market capitalization.

site_title: Australian billionaire Rinehart to invest in dairy exports to China
summary: Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart is investing A$500 million in a dairy joint venture, Hope Dairies Ltd, to export infant formula to China, starting in 2016. The venture aims to produce 30,000 metric tonnes of formula annually. Rinehart's partner is believed to be China National Machinery Industry Corp.

images.alt_text: Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart is expanding outside mining with a A$500 million (US$435 million) investment in a dairy joint venture that aims to export infant formula to China, a spokesman said on Friday.

site_title: Gold down on drop in oil prices, bright US outlook
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,159.59 an ounce due to a sharp decline in oil prices and improving US jobs data, reducing the metal's appeal as a hedge against economic uncertainty. Spot gold fell below the $1,180 technical level, triggering demand from physical buyers, but outflows from gold-backed ETFs suggest further losses. US job market data and potential monetary policy tightening also weighed on gold prices.

site_title: South Korea household debt burden eases slightly: survey
summary: South Korea's household debt burden eased slightly in March, with debt reaching 156.4% of average annual disposable income, down from 160.4% a year earlier. The debt-to-income ratio excluding non-financial liabilities fell to 106.8% from 108.9%. This indicates households spent more of their income to pay off debts, which had reached high levels. The improvement suggests a slight easing of the financial strain on South Korean households.

site_title: Obama to shield 5m immigrants from deportation: report
summary: US President Barack Obama is reportedly planning to announce measures to prevent the deportation of 5 million undocumented immigrants, potentially redirecting 12,000 immigration agents to focus on non-deportation efforts. The plan would allow parents of US citizens or legal residents to obtain work permits, protecting families from separation. Obama's executive orders would not require congressional approval, following a midterm election defeat for Democrats and a Republican takeover of Congress in January. Deportations would still occur for convicted criminals, national security risks, and those who crossed the border illegally.

site_title: BlackBerry in new business solutions push, inks partnerships
summary: BlackBerry unveiled its new mobile device management platform, BES 12, allowing clients to manage and secure devices on rival operating systems like Android and iOS. The company partnered with Samsung to provide a secure mobility solution for Android and Salesforce.com to securely access data via the BlackBerry platform. BES 12 is part of CEO John Chen's plan to turn around the company, shifting focus from smartphones to services and enterprise clients. Since a migration push in March, 5 million BES licenses have been registered, with 30% of clients moving from rival platforms.

site_title: Changtian Plastic & Chemical swings back into the black for Q3
summary: Changtian Plastic & Chemical Limited reported a net profit of 4.08 million yuan (S$861,000) for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2014, swinging back into the black after a net loss in the same period last year. Revenue increased 14.8% to 30.84 million yuan, with more than half coming from its adhesive tape business. The company has cash and bank balances of 963.8 million yuan and plans to maintain profitability through stringent cost controls.

site_title: Britain's Major warns 'real possibility' of EU exit
summary: Former British Prime Minister John Major has warned that there is a "real possibility" of Britain leaving the European Union in a referendum, citing the need for more immigration controls. In a speech in Berlin, Major stated that Britain "may be poised to leave the European Union." However, he himself is in favor of Britain staying in the EU. Major's comments come as the UK's economic woes continue to mount, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

site_title: Hankore gets major shareholder's support on planned China Everbright Water buy
summary: Hankore Environment Tech Group announced that its major shareholder, Wang Yu Huei, has pledged to vote in favor of the planned purchase of China Everbright Water Investments Ltd. As part of the deal, Hankore will acquire the subsidiary and allot new shares at 7.03 Singapore cents per share. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of 2014, subject to certain conditions and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Centurion's Q3 net profit up 47% on healthy dormitory demand
summary: Centurion Corporation Limited reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$7.92 million for Q3 2014, driven by a 46% rise in revenue to S$20.90 million. The accommodation business saw a 61% revenue growth, while the optical business declined due to weaker demand. The company benefited from increased bed capacity and rental rates, as well as new revenue streams from student accommodations. Centurion plans to explore strategic acquisition and partnership opportunities to expand its accommodation business.

site_title: Royal Bank of Scotland to exit US mortgage business
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland plans to exit its US mortgage trading business, a move to reposition its US operations ahead of new US Federal Reserve rules. The company will eliminate hundreds of US jobs over two years to reduce assets. RBS will retain its non-mortgage asset backed securities team. The decision follows significant progress in reducing US assets, which now exceed the $50 billion threshold for foreign banks to set up intermediate holding companies.

site_title: Fed's Kocherlakota: If inflation rises, 2015 rate hike possible
summary: US Federal Reserve President Narayana Kocherlakota suggests he could support a 2015 interest rate hike if inflation rises faster than expected. Kocherlakota, who has historically pushed for easier monetary policy, now believes inflation won't reach the Fed's 2% goal until 2018, making a rate hike next year "inappropriate." However, he leaves the door open for a rate hike if inflation expectations rise, potentially moving the "lift-off" forward to next year.

site_title: Olam's Q1 FY2015 net profit dips 2.9%
summary: Olam International reported a 2.9% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$44.29 million for Q1 FY2015, driven by lower volumes and increased commodity prices. Sales remained nearly flat at S$4.3 billion, with a 14.6% decline in overall sales volume. The company's earnings per share decreased to 1.64 Singapore cents. Despite this, Olam's CEO expressed confidence in its future growth, citing investments in platforms prioritized for growth.

site_title: Takata says it is subject of US criminal probe on air bags
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese auto parts maker, is under investigation by US authorities over defective car air bags linked to five deaths. A federal grand jury in New York has subpoenaed Takata's US unit to produce documents, and the US Senate commerce committee is set to hold a hearing on air bag defects. Takata has disclosed the probe in a closed-door meeting with financial analysts, despite previously saying it was not considering adding production lines to make replacement air bag inflators. The company is preparing to build new production lines in Mexico.

site_title: Otto Marine's Q3 net profit halved in absence of gain from disposal of assets
summary: Otto Marine's Q3 net profit halved to US$2.02 million, down from US$4.12 million in the same quarter last year, due to a lack of asset disposal gains. Revenue rose 16.8% to US$96.82 million, driven by stronger contributions from all segments. The company's order book for the offshore chartering segment strengthened, and it plans to divest smaller vessels to focus on larger ones. The recent decrease in oil prices has created uncertainty for new exploration and development activities, affecting the OSV market.

site_title: Warner Music in first big label music deal in China
summary: Warner Music Group has announced a partnership with Chinese Internet company Tencent, marking the first major label music deal in China. The deal allows Warner to distribute its music to Tencent's platforms, including QQ Music, and aims to provide consumers with greater choice and value for artists. The agreement excludes mobile applications and is part of Warner's expansion into Asia, following the acquisition of Hong Kong-based Gold Typhoon earlier this year. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to expand Tencent's music offerings and tap into the world's largest population.

site_title: Top officials among 11 held in Portugal's 'golden visa' probe
summary: Portuguese police arrested 11 top officials, including the head of the border service and a senior justice ministry official, in a probe into corruption related to the "golden visa" program. The program, launched in 2012, granted residency rights and visa-free travel to foreign investors who bought property worth €500,000 or more. The investigation found evidence of corruption, influence peddling, and money laundering, with 60 raids ongoing nationwide. The "golden visa" scheme has generated over €1 billion since its launch and granted 1,649 residency rights, mostly to Chinese nationals.

site_title: SGX constantly enhancing quality of stock market here
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) has been enhancing the quality of its market, with a 10% annual return on the Straits Times Index (STI) and dividends over the past 12 quarters. Despite concerns over thin market volumes, SGX has introduced measures to boost liquidity, such as lowering clearing fees and market maker programs. The exchange has also seen positive results, with a 10% narrowing of bid-ask spreads for top stocks. Upcoming initiatives include smaller board lot sizes, minimum trading price, and collateral trading requirements. SGX aims to improve the market's quality through various enhancements and stakeholder engagement.

site_title: Bank Indonesia holds key rates before Jokowi's fuel-price move
summary: Bank Indonesia kept benchmark borrowing costs unchanged at 7.5% in its first meeting since President Joko Widodo took office, ahead of fuel price hikes. The decision was seen as a precautionary measure to avoid tightening policy before the government raises fuel prices. The country's economy has been growing at its slowest pace in five years, and inflation has cooled to 4.83%. The government plans to cut energy subsidies, which are expected to be raised by the end of the month, but the magnitude of the change remains unclear.

site_title: STI steady, up 0.7% in mixed backdrop
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,304.93, driven by gains in banking stocks and mergers and acquisitions news, despite soft Chinese data and a Wall Street retreat. Japan's Nikkei 225 led the gains, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose 0.3%. China's Shanghai Composite fell 0.4%. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, advanced, while United Envirotech jumped 6% after announcing a merger with Citic.

site_title: Australia spares no expense on security moves
summary: Australia is spending over A$100 million on security for the G-20 Summit in Brisbane, with 6,000 police officers and 900 Australian Defence Force soldiers deployed. The event, attended by world leaders such as US President Barack Obama, Chinese President Xi Jinping, and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will see 27 protest groups authorized to protest near the convention center. The summit's security operation is the largest in Australia's history, with a fleet of 16 bomb-proof limousines and a public holiday declared on Friday to reduce crowds.

images.alt_text: South Africa's President Jacob Zuma and his wife at Brisbane Airport on Wednesday. He was the first leader to arrive for the Summit.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: City Developments (CDL) is trading at a 25% discount to its revised net asset value, with analysts expecting overseas residential projects to contribute to earnings in time. Biosensors Int'l's Q2 earnings were dismal, leading to a downgrade from "add" to "hold" due to concerns over product sales and licensing revenue. United Envirotech is accepting an offer from Citic, valued at 27 times 2015 forecast earnings, but liquidity and valuations are vulnerable to market volatility.

site_title: Stable outlook for emerging Asian economies: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has stated that emerging Asian economies, including China and India, are expected to experience "healthy" growth over the next three to four years, surpassing subdued growth in advanced economies. However, the OECD notes that these economies have struggled to establish strong institutions, such as the rule of law and contract enforcement, which are crucial for market stability. Despite this, the OECD remains optimistic about Asia's prospects, citing its growing economic potential.

site_title: China's Xi steers Apec into neglected directions
summary: China's President Xi Jinping successfully steered the APEC Summit in Beijing, showcasing China's ability to influence Asia's development agenda. He emphasized the need for Asian integration not to be hijacked by Western-imposed blueprints, instead pursuing a bold vision for the future "geography" of Asia. This includes the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP), a less well-known entity aimed at promoting economic cooperation and integration in the region. Xi's determination demonstrated China's growing influence in regional power dynamics.

site_title: YouTube turns on subscription music service
summary: YouTube has launched Music Key, a subscription service offering ad-free access to music and the ability to listen offline. The service is being tested in several countries and will be available worldwide with introductory monthly fees of $7.99. YouTube has partnered with major and independent record labels, with 95% of the music industry's labels already signed up. The move aims to challenge competitors such as Spotify and Pandora, and is expected to generate significant revenue for the platform.

site_title: Amazon to keep investing in cloud despite margin squeeze
summary: Amazon plans to continue investing in its cloud computing arm, Amazon Web Services (AWS), despite concerns about sacrificing margins. AWS chief Andy Jassy stated the company aims to build data centers in every large country, making the cloud a larger part of its business. Despite missing quarterly results expectations, Amazon will invest as much as needed to grow the business, citing high barriers to entry as a factor limiting competitors. The investment push is expected to be costly, with estimates suggesting at least $1.1 billion for a single data center in the US.

site_title: KrisEnergy ready for oil volatility
summary: KrisEnergy, an oil and gas firm, is preparing for oil volatility by diversifying its portfolio with a mix of oil and gas production, tied to long-term contracts. The company has a flexible financing approach, with most capital expenditures not committed to work programs, allowing for adjustments in developing oil and gas fields and acquisitions. This strategy is expected to help the firm navigate price fluctuations, according to its chief financial officer, Kiran Raj.

site_title: High-end 'fire sales': misleading headline
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) responds to an article stating that their third-quarter results announcement mentioned "fire sales" in the high-end market, but the headline was misleading. CDL explains that "fire sales" could apply to mortgage borrowers across all market segments due to factors like unsteady residential prices, government cooling measures, declining rents, and a weak secondary market. The company clarifies that the factors were mentioned in their results statement but were not fully captured in the article's headline.

site_title: US: Energy weighs on Wall Street as crude tumbles
summary: US stocks closed with little change on Thursday, despite a decline in energy shares as crude prices slid. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average ended flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose. Consumer stocks, led by Wal-Mart and Apple, gained, with Wal-Mart hitting a record high and Apple surpassing Exxon Mobil as the second-largest publicly traded US company. Energy prices fell 3.8% to their lowest in more than four years, weighing on the S&P 500 energy sector.

site_title: McDonald's to open store in Kazakhstan next year
summary: McDonald's to open its first store in Kazakhstan next year, marking the company's 120th global market. The store will be a partnership between McDonald's and Kazakh businessman Kairat Boranbayev, featuring free Wi-Fi and a menu including Big Macs and French fries. This move follows the company's recent closures in Russia due to consumer-safety inspections. McDonald's aims to expand abroad as US sales struggle, with competitors already having locations in Kazakhstan.

site_title: Shell Refining Malaya plunges to RM200m Q3 loss
summary: Shell Refining Company (Federation of Malaya) Bhd reported a loss after tax of RM200 million for the third quarter to end-September, driven by slumping oil prices. The company's stockholding losses of RM154 million and RM179 million in the third and year-to-date periods, respectively, contributed to the loss. Revenue decreased by 12% to RM3.4 billion due to declining product prices. Shell anticipates weak refinery margins for the rest of the year, focusing on operational and product quality to maximize margin opportunities.

site_title: Hour Glass emerges stronger in Q2
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 24% increase in net profit to S$11.75 million for the second quarter, driven by a 3% rise in revenue to S$164.83 million. The company also posted a 10% increase in net profit to S$20.12 million for the six months to end-September, despite a sluggish macroeconomic backdrop. Executive director Michael Tay attributed the company's resilience to its ability to adapt to economic cycles and emerge stronger.

site_title: Watch the watchmen on insider trading
summary: A study published in the Journal of Law and Economics found that supervised industries in the US showed increased signs of insider trading when regulators possessed undisclosed information. The study analyzed price movements of financial services, pharmaceuticals, and utilities between 1996 and 2009 and found that insider trading spiked after detailed financial data was submitted to regulators, then decreased over time. The study suggests that regulators' possession of private information can contribute to insider trading, highlighting the need for revised rules to account for regulators' potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: US discharged bankrupts still haunted by zombie debts
summary: US discharged bankrupts are still being haunted by zombie debts, with some banks ignoring court discharges and keeping debts alive on credit reports. The banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Citigroup, are suspected of violating federal bankruptcy law by not updating credit reports to reflect discharged debts. This practice forces borrowers to make payments on bills they no longer owe, potentially benefiting debt buyers. Federal judges have raised alarms, and lawyers are investigating the banks, with some borrowers paying for "clean" credit reports to secure loans.

site_title: South Korea refiners consider legal action over OW losses
summary: South Korea's major refiners, SK Innovation and GS Caltex, are considering legal action against OW Bunker's Singapore unit due to losses from the bankruptcy of the world's largest marine fuel supplier. OW Bunker's collapse has disrupted the global ship fuel market, causing sellers to tighten credit policies and forcing buyers to provide letters of credit or pay cash upfront. The credit squeeze has led to a sharp decline in trade activity, with prices of obtaining a letter of credit ranging from 0.04% of the transacted value.

site_title: Religare Health Q2 distribution income up
summary: Religare Health Trust posted a 22% increase in Q2 distribution income to S$14.35 million, driven by a 38% rise in total revenue to S$31.98 million. The trust's net service fee and hospital income grew 44% year-on-year to S$22.06 million, largely due to higher operating margins. The company's distributable income per unit increased to 1.81 Singapore cents from 1.48 cents a year ago, despite entering one-year forward foreign exchange contracts to protect against currency volatility.

site_title: After huge settlements, banks face higher-stake phase of forex probes
summary: US banks face a higher-stake phase of forex probes after agreeing to a $4.3 billion civil settlement with US and UK authorities. The Justice Department may bring its first criminal charges against banks early next year, with sources indicating that a level of penalties could be more severe than those levied in a separate Libor investigation. The settlement does not resolve ongoing probes led by New York's Benjamin Lawsky, who could take action against banks before his expected departure in early 2015.

site_title: Pac Radiance Q3 buoyed by higher vessel gain
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine services firm, posted a 24% boost in net profit to US$13.07 million in Q3, driven by increased gains from vessel sales. Revenue fell 9% to US$44.36 million, mainly due to lower subsea business contributions. The company attributed the boost to its strategy of expanding in emerging markets, keeping its fleet relevant, and strengthening operational capabilities. Despite a challenging business environment due to declining oil prices, Pacific Radiance remains optimistic about delivering steady growth over the medium and long term.

site_title: Slide in China property sales eases to -1.6% in October
summary: China's property sales showed a slight improvement in October, easing to a -1.6% decline in floor space, after Beijing implemented measures to boost the sector. However, property investment growth slowed to a 5-year low of 12.4% in the first 10 months of 2014, and home prices dropped for a sixth consecutive month. Analysts doubt the government's efforts to stimulate the market, citing a glut of unsold homes and a persistent property downturn, which poses a significant risk to China's economy.

site_title: SGX stoppage inquiry takes step forward
summary: The inquest into the SGX trading breakdown has taken a step forward with the establishment of a board committee of inquiry (BCOI). The BCOI will investigate the facts and circumstances surrounding the breakdown on November 5, review findings, and recommend improvements to prevent recurrence. The committee will also review SGX's decision-making process, incident management, and communications with market participants and the public. This development aims to enhance crisis management and processes at the exchange.

site_title: Petronas, 2 other firms begin extracting gas from field off Sabah
summary: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas, in partnership with ConocoPhillips and Shell, has begun extracting gas from a Sabah offshore field. Production is expected to ramp up to 500 million standard cubic feet of natural gas per day by April 2015. The Kebabangan field is one of the largest offshore structures in Malaysia, with the capacity to process up to 825 million standard cubic feet of natural gas daily. The move is seen as a testament to the company's confidence in the global oil market, despite declining prices.

site_title: JC Penney, Macy's post lacklustre Q3 sales
summary: US retailers JC Penney and Macy's reported lacklustre Q3 sales, with JC Penney posting a loss of 62 US cents a share on sales of US$2.76 billion, while Macy's saw total sales fall 1.3% to US$6.2 billion. Warmer fall weather and consumers delaying purchases until the year-end sales were cited as reasons. Despite improving job numbers and low petrol prices, analysts found it puzzling that shoppers weren't spending more, with some attributing it to a shift in spending habits and lack of wage gains for lower-income consumers.

images.alt_text: By offering in-store pick-up, more customers are expected to flock to Macy's and Bloomingdale's during the holiday season.

site_title: Oil slide to give global growth a push
summary: Oil prices have fallen below $80 a barrel for the first time since 2010, potentially boosting the global economy's fragile growth. Asia's energy importers are expected to benefit most from the decline, as lower oil costs can increase purchasing power and stimulate economic activity. The drop in oil prices may also lead to increased consumer spending and investment, which could have a positive impact on the world economy. However, the impact on oil producers is expected to be negative.

site_title: Opportunities remain, but market has to go beyond vanilla equity
