summary: US stocks reached record highs for the fifth consecutive session, with the Dow and S&P 500 closing at new highs. The S&P 500 rose 1.42 points to 2,039.68, and the Nasdaq Composite added 8.94 points to 4,660.56. Consumer discretionary shares, including homebuilders and Zoetis, drove the gains. The market's rally has been fueled by supportive economic data and solid corporate earnings reports, with the S&P 500 up 10.4% for the year so far.

site_title: Australia wages stuck in the slow lane, but wealth on the rise
summary: Australian wage growth remained stagnant, increasing by 0.6% in the third quarter, matching the previous quarter's growth. Annual wage growth remained at 2.6%, the slowest pace in at least two decades. Real wages showed little growth, with consumer prices rising 2.3% over the same period. This suggests that despite a restraint on inflation, Australian households' incomes and spending power remain under pressure.

site_title: India waits for Modi to dig economy out of investment hole
summary: India's economy remains sluggish despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's election six months ago, with construction equipment sales showing little improvement. The country's stock market has performed well, but firms are hesitant to invest due to high interest rates and low factory utilization rates. Capital investment has barely grown since 2012/13, and economists predict a further decline in industrial production. Modi's reform agenda has been modest, and experts say he needs to overhaul laws on land acquisition, labor, and tax to stimulate investment.

site_title: Japan's Abe to postpone tax hike, call December election: media
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to postpone a planned 1.5-year delay of the national sales tax increase to April 2017, citing weak third-quarter GDP. This move will also trigger a general election in December, as the delay will exceed the current term of the Lower House of Parliament. The tax hike was previously set to increase to 10% in October 2015. Abe's decision comes after Japan's biggest economic contraction since the global financial crisis in the second quarter. The election will be Abe's second in three years.

site_title: SpaceX chief Musk confirms Internet satellite plan
summary: SpaceX chief Elon Musk confirmed a plan to launch a network of small, low-cost satellites for wireless Internet access worldwide. Working with satellite industry veteran Greg Wyler, Musk aims to deploy 700 satellites, each weighing less than 250 pounds, to provide global coverage. The project, in its early stages, promises a feasible and affordable solution to the current satellite industry. An announcement is expected in two to three months, following a report in the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: G-20 nations spend US$88b a year on fossil-fuel exploration
summary: The G-20 nations spend around $88 billion annually on fossil-fuel exploration, despite agreeing to phase out inefficient subsidies in 2009. This expenditure contributes to carbon emissions, contradicting efforts to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius. The US, Australia, and Russia are among the top contributors, with the US leading in direct state subsidies and tax breaks. Experts call for a shift from fossil fuel exploration to renewable energy, citing the potential for the same instruments to support clean energy.

images.alt_text: The G-20 group of major economies spend US$88 billion a year on fossil-fuel exploration, five years after pledging to phase out industry subsidies, a study showed.

site_title: Luxury driving force
summary: Eurokars Group, Singapore's largest privately held car distributorship, has achieved impressive growth over the past three decades under the leadership of Executive Chairman Mr Karsono Kwee. The company represents luxury brands such as Porsche, Rolls-Royce, MINI, and Mazda in Singapore, and Porsche, Rolls-Royce, Maserati, BMW, Mazda, and 3M in Indonesia. Eurokars has expanded its operations, including acquiring a stake in a Rolls-Royce dealership in China, and has been recognized with the prestigious Enterprise 50 award in 2004, solidifying its reputation as a leading luxury car distributor.

site_title: Remisiers should stop complaining
summary: A Singaporean writer, Vincent Khoo, argues that remisiers should stop complaining about the declining trading volume and reduced take-home pay on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). He questions the accuracy of figures such as $6,000 to $8,000 a decade ago and $1,000 average net commission, citing a local broking house's gross commission of $5,000. Khoo emphasizes that surviving on $1,000 a month is impossible, leading many remisiers to leave the industry. He advocates for a shift from speculation to informed investing, and praises SGX for taking steps to create a better-quality market.

site_title: Alpine investing US$20m in Myanmar dealerships
summary: Alpine Global has invested US$20 million in Myanmar, expanding its Chevrolet dealership in Yangon and planning to open more showrooms in the next two years. The company, authorized distributor for Chevy and Opel, taps into Pacific-AA Group's nationwide distribution network and market knowledge. Sales are encouraging, with the Trailblazer SUV, Colorado mid-sized pick-up truck, Spin sub-compact MPV, and Cruze compact sedan being popular models. With the government encouraging new vehicle sales and investing in infrastructure, investors like Alpine are optimistic about the market's growth potential.

site_title: Alibaba Singles' Day online sales hit new record
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd reported a record-breaking US$6 billion in online sales on its Singles' Day event, surpassing the previous year's record. Over 39 billion yuan (S$8.24 billion) worth of goods were sold in the first 15 hours of the event, with 9 hours remaining. This marks a significant increase in sales, driven by heavily discounted goods and customer demand.

site_title: Italian businessman trumps Chinese bid for Club Med
summary: Italian businessman Andrea Bonomi has made an improved offer of 23 euros a share, valuing Club Med at 874 million euros (US$1.1 billion), surpassing a Chinese bid worth 839 million euros. The offer is also larger than a previous Bonomi bid. The French stock market authority has announced the new offer, which is recommended by Club Med's board of directors. US private equity giant KKR is in talks to be a small co-investor alongside Bonomi, who is competing with Fosun for control of the French holiday firm.

images.alt_text: A long battle to control French holiday firm Club Med took another turn Tuesday after the French stock market authority announced Italian businessman Andrea Bonomi had made an improved offer.

site_title: US tech, software industry cheers China IT trade deal progress
summary: US tech and software groups welcomed a breakthrough in talks to eliminate duties on information technology products, paving the way for a global IT trade deal. China and the US agreed to cut global tariffs on medical equipment, GPS devices, and other products, expected to create jobs, boost US exports, and benefit consumers. The deal is seen as a win-win for the digital economy, with US makers of semiconductors, medical products, and software developers among the likely beneficiaries. The agreement could raise global GDP by up to $190 billion annually.

site_title: Sydney house sellers' asking price tops A$1m
summary: Sydney's median asking price for detached houses reached A$1 million for the first time, a record high, due to low interest rates fueling investor demand. The price increased A$10,600 over the past week, with the median price across Australian state and territory capitals rising A$6,400 to A$755,100.

site_title: Indonesia rolls out red carpet to investors, promises reforms
summary: Indonesia's new government, led by President Joko Widodo, is launching efforts to attract foreign investors to improve the country's infrastructure, promising to reduce corruption and bureaucracy. Widodo aims to resolve land acquisition problems, which have hindered infrastructure development, and has proposed a five-year infrastructure plan that includes building ports, dams, airports, and roads. Companies are calling for major reforms before investing, and if Indonesia fails to attract sufficient private investment, it may consider joining the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's new government is launching a bid to convince sceptical foreign investors to pour billions of dollars into improving the country's dilapidated infrastructure, promising to reduce corruption and bureaucracy.

site_title: Region set for significant growth, despite the bumps
summary: Asean, a 10-member economic grouping, is set for significant growth despite challenges. Established in 1967, the region aims to become a single market through the Asean Economic Community, with a target completion by 2015. Despite a wide economic gap, Asean has been a consistent growth outperformer, with an average annual growth rate of 5% from 1980-2013. The region's population is expected to rise by 10% to 690 million by 2020, driven by urbanization and increasing female participation in the labor force, making it a significant consumer market and source of demand for goods and services.

site_title: McKinsey identifies 3 catalysts for further growth of Asean
summary: McKinsey identifies three catalysts for Asean's growth: globalization, urbanization, and digital technology. The 10-member economic grouping must double its productivity growth to capitalize on these trends. Economic development has been driven by an expanding labor force, particularly the shift from agriculture to industry. To achieve sustained growth, Asean must adapt to changing global and domestic conditions, leveraging its workforce and technological advancements.

site_title: US sends biggest trade delegation to Egypt
summary: The US has sent its largest-ever trade delegation to Egypt, consisting of around 70 executives from major companies including Apache Corp and Coca-Cola Co, to explore business opportunities in the country. The delegation met with President Abdel-Fattah El-Sisi and discussed ways to enhance investment and stability in Egypt, which has been recovering from three years of unrest. The visit comes after the US cut some military aid to Egypt following the army's ouster of President Mohamed Mursi, but Secretary of State John Kerry has since indicated that full aid will resume soon.

site_title: OW Bunker case may reverberate through Singapore's bunkering industry
summary: The OW Bunker case, a major bunkering industry scandal in Singapore, may have a limited impact on fuel supply in the country, with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) stating that OW Bunker Far East accounted for under 3% of bunker supplies in 2013. Despite this, at least two oil traders are filing legal claims, and the financial fallout may still unsettle the industry. The MPA has downplayed the potential disruptions, but the case's impact on the industry's credit and financial stability remains to be seen.

site_title: UOB's S-E Asia strategy pays off
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is seeing its South-east Asia strategy pay off with strong economic fundamentals attracting more investments and increasing intra-regional trade flows. The bank has the largest presence in the region, with 484 branches and 86% of its customer loans coming from key markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia. UOB has doubled its cross-border corporate loans since 2011 and won the Most Admired Asean Enterprise award for its Asean-centricity. The bank's focus on the region is also expected to drive investments in countries like Myanmar, which is becoming a key destination for foreign direct investment.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, Kia to spend 670b won to buy back shares
summary: Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp plan to buy back 6.87 million shares worth 670 billion won (S$791 million) to improve shareholder value after a recent property purchase sparked a sell-off. The buybacks, completed by Feb 11, aim to stabilize share prices. Hyundai shares rose 5.7% after the announcement, while Kia rose 2%, easing concerns about dividend cuts. The move is seen as a step to improve investor sentiment and increase market expectations for a potential dividend increase.

site_title: Productivity boosts Rotary Q3 earnings
summary: Rotary Engineering reported a 37% increase in net profit to S$10.9 million for its third quarter, driven by productivity improvements and a 7% dip in revenue to S$172 million. Despite this, the company's nine-month net profit more than doubled to S$38.3 million. Rotary expects to end the fiscal year on a "significantly improved" financial performance, citing stable long-term fundamentals in the petroleum and petrochemical industry.

site_title: Oil magnate ordered to pay US$996m in divorce settlement
summary: Harold Hamm, CEO of Continental Resources, has been ordered to pay his ex-wife, Sue Ann Hamm, nearly $1 billion in a divorce settlement. The ruling, made by Oklahoma Special Judge Howard Haralson, is significantly lower than the $17 billion Ms. Hamm's lawyers had sought. The decision does not require Mr. Hamm to sell his 68% stake in Continental, a leading oil driller. The settlement includes $322.7 million in cash and $650 million in monthly installments, allowing Mr. Hamm to remain the company's controlling shareholder.

site_title: EuroSports Global posts S$3.13m H1 loss
summary: EuroSports Global Ltd reported a net loss of S$3.13 million for the first half of its fiscal year, down from a net profit of S$1.89 million a year ago. Revenue declined 41.2% to S$15.80 million due to lower new car sales, mainly affected by tighter government regulations and the end of the Lamborghini Gallardo model's life cycle. The company's gross profit fell 64.4% to S$2.27 million. Despite this, the group expects sales to pick up in the second half of 2015 with the launch of a new Lamborghini model.

site_title: US Postal Service announces theft of data from its computer systems
summary: The US Postal Service announced a data breach, stating that hackers potentially compromised databases containing employee and customer information, including names, birth dates, addresses, and Social Security numbers. The breach, which occurred between the beginning of the year and mid-August, may have affected around 800,000 employees and customers. The FBI is investigating the incident, but it's unclear who or what country is responsible. The breach raises questions about the value of obtained personal information and the motivations of the hackers.

site_title: Achieving social impact and financial returns with impact investing
summary: Impact investing, a form of investing that seeks both financial returns and positive social impact, has gained significant attention since its emergence in 2008. Unlike ethical investing and ESG investing, impact investing is focused on addressing social problems and needs. To be considered successful, impact investments must meet both financial and social impact goals. Investors can use various asset classes, including venture capital and private equity, and should prioritize commercially viable businesses with clear social metrics reporting. As the Asian economies mature, impact investing is becoming increasingly attractive for philanthropically inclined investors seeking to address social challenges.

site_title: Competition to shave M'sia telcos' margins: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Malaysia's telecommunications sector will experience intense competition in 2015, leading to a possible 1-1.5 percentage point drop in average operating earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation, and amortisation (EBitda) margin. The industry is dominated by three major players: Maxis, Axiata, and Digi, with niche players and new technologies also entering the market. Fitch expects average industry revenues to increase by 3-5% in 2015, driven by strong growth in broadband and mobile data services, with Telekom Malaysia expected to dominate the fixed-line and broadband sector.

images.alt_text: An international rating agency has predicted that competition in Malaysia's crowded telecommunications sector will prove so intense next year that margins could be shaved by between one and 1.5 percentage points.

site_title: Genting Singapore runs out of luck with Q3 profit halved
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 50% decline in quarterly net profit to S$97.39 million, driven by a 17% drop in revenue and a 7% decrease in cost of sales. The company attributed the weak results to low win rates in its VIP business, which is heavily reliant on luck. The decline in Chinese tourist arrivals, a major source of gaming revenue, has also contributed to the challenges. The company's shares have lost over 30% of their value year-to-date, and analysts predict a steep decline in Genting's VIP gaming revenue for the year.

site_title: Roadmap to set up Asia-Pac free trade zone to be launched
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced an agreement to launch a roadmap for the setting up of a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP), a personal success for Mr Xi. The establishment of the zone is seen as a blow to the US administration's push for its own trade zone, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The FTAAP is expected to add more to the global economy than the TPP, with estimates suggesting $2.4 trillion in potential economic growth by 2025. The announcement comes as China and Japan rekindle ties and China announces a free-trade agreement with South Korea.

site_title: Fortune Reit's Q3 DPU up 24.4%
summary: Fortune Reit reported a 24.4% increase in distributable income to HK$193.1 million for its Q3 2014, driven by strong rental growth and additional income from acquired properties. Net property income rose 33% to HK$286.7 million, and revenue increased 33% to HK$416.6 million. The Reit expects revenue growth from a HK$80 million renovation project at Belvedere Square. Despite economic uncertainty, Fortune Reit's non-discretionary retail properties are expected to benefit from resilient demand.

site_title: Absence of fair-value gains drags Blumont into the red for Q3
summary: Blumont Group reported a net loss of S$13.48 million for the third quarter, down from a profit of S$33.73 million a year ago due to the absence of S$40.91 million net unrealised fair value gains. Revenue fell 38% to S$779,000 and total expenses rose to S$12.24 million. The group's board warned of a full-year loss due to unrealised losses from fair value readjustments and impairment losses on financial assets.

site_title: Korea ferry captain jailed for 36 years, acquitted of murder in disaster
summary: Captain Lee Jun-Seok of the South Korean ferry Sewol was jailed for 36 years for gross negligence and dereliction of duty, but acquitted of murder charges due to prosecutors failing to prove intent to kill. Three senior crew members were sentenced to 15-30 years in jail. The court found that Lee was paralyzed by panic and failed to take measures to save lives, but he denied knowingly intending to sacrifice passengers. The acquittal was met with outrage from victims' relatives, who felt justice was not served.

site_title: It's not a 'quality market' for retail investors
summary: Retail investors in Singapore's stock market are largely disenchanted due to the dominance of algorithmic traders and reduced bid sizes. The removal of the lunch break has further hindered their ability to profit from minor market fluctuations. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has misfocused its marketing efforts on introducing complex products, rather than reviving basic, "plain vanilla" market offerings. As a result, retail investors have chosen to stay away from the market. The SGX needs to address these issues to attract and retain retail investors.

site_title: Virgin Australia to raise US$300m in US
summary: Virgin Australia Holdings Limited, a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines, is planning to raise US$300 million in the US through a bond issue. The airline, which has a 22.8% stake in VAH, aims to diversify its funding and strengthen its financial position. Credit rating agencies Moody's and Standard & Poor's have assigned a "stable" outlook to VAH, with a "B+" and "B2" credit rating, respectively, ahead of the bond issue. This move is seen as an attempt to improve the airline's credit metrics and increase its liquidity profile.

site_title: UOL sharpening recurring income play
summary: UOL Group reported a 10% rise in Q3 net earnings to S$102.57 million, driven by higher profits from associated and joint-venture companies. The group plans to launch a 800-unit condo project in Upper Paya Lebar-Bartley in Q1 next year. UOL will focus on commercial and hospitality assets with recurring income, while being selective in residential land acquisitions. The group's gearing increased to 0.35 due to higher borrowings, and its cash and cash equivalents decreased to S$270.71 million.

site_title: Washington and Beijing hold the key to Asia-Pacific trade integration
summary: The Apec Summit in Beijing highlighted divergences between Asia-Pacific nations, particularly between the US and China, over trade integration. China proposed the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP), while the US-backed Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) excludes China. The US and China have differing views on the economic architecture of the region, with China seeking to limit the US pivot towards Asia. To foster closer ties, a comprehensive trade deal that includes China is needed, with both sides viewing the proposal from an economic and strategic lens. Internal reforms in China are also necessary to align with the vision of other Apec members.

images.alt_text: This week's Apec Summit in Beijing has revealed some deep-seated divergences between members of the 21-nation grouping.

site_title: Vicom posts 5.6% rise in Q3 net profit to S$7.16m
summary: Vicom Ltd, a vehicle inspection and testing services provider, reported a 5.6% year-on-year rise in Q3 net profit to S$7.16m. Revenue rose 3.5% to S$27.01m, while operating expenses increased 2.9%. The group's operating profit rose 4.9% to S$8.55m. Vicom expects moderate demand for vehicle testing services and growth in its non-vehicle testing business, despite competition.

site_title: Fast-paced video games may be good for the brain
summary: Researchers have found that playing fast-paced action video games, such as Call of Duty, can improve cognitive abilities including multitasking, learning, and vision. A study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that gamers performed better on cognitive tasks and retained information longer than non-players. The benefits were seen even in non-regular players who played for just two hours a day for two months. The study suggests that the fast-paced games can adapt the brain's connectivity, leading to improved learning abilities.

site_title: Petra Foods' Q3 profit down 29.1%
summary: Petra Foods reported a 29.1% decline in Q3 net profit to US$10.5 million, down from US$14.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 6.5% to US$118.2 million due to lower sales during the Muslim Lebaran festivities and discontinued distribution of agency brands. The company's nine-month net profit was US$36.4 million, a significant increase from US$4.7 million in the previous year.

site_title: Modi's 'Make in India' drive skids on red tape
summary: India's "Make in India" initiative to boost manufacturing is hindered by bureaucratic obstacles, with recent mine closures by Tata Steel and Steel Authority of India Ltd due to permit delays. The country's World Bank ranking has slipped to 142nd out of 189 economies due to its ease of doing business, and iron ore production has dropped in four of the past five years. The government aims to increase manufacturing's share of GDP to 25%, but regulatory hurdles and judicial bans over environmental and regulatory lapses continue to constrain production.

site_title: Temasek, RRJ Capital revisit US LNG play with US$1b deal
summary: Temasek Holdings and RRJ Capital have agreed to invest US$1 billion in Cheniere Energy through convertible notes to support a liquefied natural gas project in Corpus Christi, Texas. The six-and-a-half-year notes will pay 4.875% interest and be convertible into Cheniere common stock at US$93.64 per share. This is the second joint investment by Temasek and RRJ, following a US$468 million stake in 2012. Construction on the Corpus Christi project is expected to start in early 2015 and will have an annual production capacity of about 13.5 million tonnes.

site_title: E50's jubilant 20 years
summary: The Enterprise 50 Awards, established in 1995, celebrated the 20th anniversary of the top 50 privately held companies in Singapore. The awards, jointly organized by The Business Times and KPMG, recognized companies that have achieved significant growth and success. The list of award winners was not provided in the article, but the awards ceremony acknowledged the achievements of these successful companies.

site_title: Springboard to the world
summary: Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing Pte Ltd, a Singaporean frozen-foods maker, has a global reach with over 90% of its "Spring Home" brand products exported to Europe, North America, and Asia-Pacific regions. The company, which topped the Enterprise 50 list in 2000, has expanded its brand portfolio to include Happy Belly and Master Chef, targeting specific niche markets. Its products range from spring-roll pastry to dim sum delicacies, catering to diverse tastes and preferences. Tee Yih Jia's success showcases Singapore's capabilities in the food manufacturing industry.

site_title: Asean back on investors' radar; draws US$122b FDI in 2013
summary: Foreign direct investments (FDI) in Asean reached $122 billion in 2013, equivalent to 8% of global FDI flows, surpassing China's FDI for the first time since 1993. The influx was led by multinational corporations expanding operations in the region. Asean's FDI stock per capita increased five-fold to nearly $2,500, and intra-Asean investments accounted for 17% of total inflows. The Asean Economic Community (AEC) is expected to attract more investors, with many companies establishing operations ahead of its implementation next year.

site_title: Australia business index hits new high in October
summary: Australia's business index reached a record high of +13 in October, driven by stronger sales, profits, and employment, according to National Australia Bank's survey. The index, which measures business conditions, surged 12 points from September's +1, while business confidence dipped to +4. Sales, profitability, and employment all rose, with forward orders increasing due to a sharp rise in construction. The Reserve Bank of Australia may welcome the signs of growth, which could offset a cooling in the resources sector.

site_title: OW collapse shocks industry; damage limitation top priority
summary: OW Bunker, a major global bunker player, has filed for bankruptcy after a US$250 million fraud loss and significant "risk management" losses. The company's collapse is attributed to an alleged fraud in its Singapore operation and was not anticipated despite falling oil prices. OW Bunker's large market share and global operations make its bankruptcy a significant concern for the industry. The company's chairman stated that a sale as a going concern was not a realistic option, and damage limitation will be the top priority.

site_title: Stock purchases outshine sales
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore stocks in the three months to Nov 5, with the top five stocks seeing a net purchase value of S$1.88 billion. Finance sector stocks excluding Reits were the top picks, with DBS being the most valued at S$291.9 million in net buys. In contrast, Mapletree Industrial Trust was the top stock among sales, with a sell value of S$51.2 million.

site_title: Metro Q2 profit doubles with one-off boost
summary: Metro Holdings' second-quarter net profit doubled to S$61.2 million, driven by a one-off gain of S$59.3 million from associate Top Spring. The company's operating loss narrowed from S$14.6 million to S$10.3 million, and its pre-tax operating profit remained largely from the property business. Metro's retail business lost S$388,000 in operations before tax, mainly due to higher operating expenses. The company expects refurbishment costs to hit profitability, but rental income for its property division is expected to remain steady.

site_title: Invesco fund treads untested path as major investor in distressed debt
summary: Invesco's senior loan fund, a US$6 billion exchange-traded fund, has become a major investor in distressed debt, taking a significant position in leveraged loans from a Texas utility company. This investment has raised concerns among regulators, who worry about the liquidity and credit risk of these assets. The fund's rapid growth has made it an outlier in the ETF market, which has attracted attention from top investment management firms. Despite its success, analysts warn that leveraged-loan ETFs are too risky and may not be able to pay back investors in time.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Singaporean stocks saw mixed reviews from analysts. Super Group's share price fell to 18 times its current earnings, prompting a "hold" rating with a target price of S$1.15. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's share price rose to S$1.19, earning a "buy" rating with a fair value estimate of S$1.31. Sarine Tech's share price remained steady at S$3.10, with a "hold" rating and a target price of S$3.11. Analysts expect softer commodity prices to boost gross margins for Super Group, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding benefits from the shipping industry's lower fuel costs.

site_title: Providing concrete solutions
summary: Excel Precast Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based precast concrete manufacturer, has seen steady growth over the past 15 years due to increasing demand for its products. The company, which operates three plants in Singapore and Malaysia, has won several Enterprise 50 awards and is committed to providing value-added buildable construction solutions. With state-of-the-art technology and production processes, Excel Precast produces a range of customized pre-stressed and precast products for various customers, including the Housing and Development Board and private residential projects. The company aims to supply precast concrete components for the construction industry.

site_title: Wilmar's Q3 profit up 1.5% at US$422.4m
summary: Wilmar International reported a 1.5% increase in Q3 net profit to US$422.4 million, driven by foreign exchange gains and higher results from associates, particularly China. Revenue declined 2.7% to US$11.5 billion. The company's oilseeds and grains unit saw a 87.5% increase in pre-tax profit due to improved crush margins in China. Despite a 49% drop in palm and laurics business profits, Wilmar expects a "satisfactory performance" in plantation and palm oil mills, and stable contributions from consumer products.

site_title: Vard suffers Q3 net loss of 37m kroner despite 18.5% rise in revenue
summary: VARD Holdings reported a net loss of 37 million Norwegian kroner (S$7.01 million) in Q3, despite a 18.5% revenue increase to 2.81 billion kroner. The loss was primarily due to higher operating costs and a negative operating margin of 3.8%. The company attributed cost overruns in its European set-up and a high workload at its Romanian yards. However, it expects to see a return to positive Ebitda margins in Q4 and further improvements in 2015, driven by continued demand for subsea support and construction vessels.

site_title: Value-added edge in M&E
summary: Wah Loon Engineering, a Singapore-based company, has experienced significant growth since its founding in 1988 as a sole proprietorship. The company has expanded its services from electrical engineering to mechanical and engineering (M&E) services across various industries, with a staff strength of around 300 employees and a turnover of approximately S$152 million in 2010. Key milestones include moving to main contractor status in 2003, doubling turnover to S$100 million in 2008, and establishing a presence in the Malaysian construction market.

site_title: Australia gives A$6m boost to illegal logging fight
summary: Australia has pledged A$6 million to combat illegal logging in the Asia-Pacific region, part of a broader effort to reduce rainforest loss and cut greenhouse gas emissions. The funds support the Responsible Asia Forestry and Trade program, which aims to promote accountable forest management. The program, in partnership with organizations like WWF and the Nature Conservancy, will help nations develop national forestry monitoring systems. The move comes as deforestation and forest degradation pose significant threats to biodiversity, government revenues, and local communities.

site_title: Looking back on E50
summary: Accenture's Enterprise 50 (E50) awards, established 20 years ago, recognizes top privately held companies in Singapore. Founded by Willie Cheng and Patrick Daniel, the first E50 rankings and event exceeded expectations, with a soft launch that later gained traction. Since then, the awards have grown, including TV series, books, and golf tournaments. The E50 process balances quantitative and qualitative factors, ensuring deserving companies are recognized. The awards have become a valuable endorsement for Singaporean companies, with many going on to become publicly listed. The event's success can be attributed to its credibility, methodology, and setting, with over 1,000 attendees annually.

site_title: HK banks vie for stock-link cash with prizes, fee cuts
summary: Hong Kong banks are offering incentives to attract customers to the new Shanghai-Hong Kong stock link, a $5 billion daily cross-border purchase program. Hang Seng Bank and Bank of China (Hong Kong) are waiving fees, while Bank of China is offering gold medals and discounts on interest rates. Other banks, such as China Citic Bank International, are offering commission-free trading and discounts on foreign exchange. The move is seen as a bid to secure market share before the program begins on November 17.

site_title: Greenback climbs to 7-year high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-year high against the yen, trading at 116.02 yen, after a Japanese government official suggested Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may delay a planned sales tax increase. This move boosted the Nikkei index and fueled a renewed appetite for risk across markets. The US dollar's gains were also driven by the Japanese central bank's expansion of its stimulus program and the government pension fund's asset reallocation to foreign holdings. The greenback is expected to continue its upward trend ahead of key US data releases later this week.

site_title: Abe may opt for snap poll ahead of key decision
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering dissolving the Lower House of Parliament and calling a snap election by the end of the year, amid speculation about delaying a second hike in Japan's national sales tax. The prospect of a surprise move comes as Abe weighs the likelihood of delaying the tax hike, which could be seen as a "failure of Abenomics." A snap election would be a public referendum on the issue, and Abe could use his success in restoring relations with China as a campaigning ploy.

site_title: Beware environmental damage from projects funded by regional lenders, ADB warns
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has warned that environmental damage and social harm may result from major infrastructure projects in Asia, funded by new regional lenders such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) and the New Development Bank. The ADB urges these new lenders to adopt "international best practices" on environmental and social safeguards, as the region's over-reliance on natural resources threatens environmental damage and future prosperity. The OECD also calls for a greener growth model, citing the need to shift away from fossil fuels and towards a more sustainable path.

site_title: European Court of Justice rules against 'welfare tourism'
summary: The European Court of Justice has ruled that EU member states do not have to provide social welfare payments to EU citizens moving to their country solely to claim benefits. The court's decision aims to prevent "welfare tourism" and address concerns about the abuse of the EU's core freedom of movement principle. The ruling is a setback for anti-EU parties and Prime Minister David Cameron's efforts to limit immigration, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel having previously warned that the UK's immigration proposals were approaching a "point of no return".

site_title: S&P lowers rating on Bumi's US$700m notes
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) lowered its long-term issue rating on PT Bumi Resources' US$700 million senior secured notes to 'D' due to a missed interest payment. The notes, guaranteed by the Indonesian coal mining firm, were issued in 2014 and were due in 2017. S&P removed the rating from CreditWatch, citing the 30-day grace period under the bond indenture. The move is attributed to Bumi Resources' failure to make the interest payment.

site_title: Asia borrowers win as banks compete
summary: Banks are redirecting funds from Western markets to Asia, where borrowers rated below investment grade are securing large loans. In 2014, Asia borrowers received $27.7 billion in loans, nearly double the amount in 2013. European leveraged lending declined 6.8% compared to the same period last year. This shift is driven by banks seeking better returns in the face of stagnant growth in the West. As a result, Asian companies, from resort operators to pig farmers, are benefiting from increased funding.

site_title: It's high time Japan mended fences with neighbours
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's historic meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping may lead to eased tensions between the two countries. A four-point agreement was announced, reaffirming the principles of four basic documents between Japan and China, but neither side has changed its position in public. The agreement acknowledges the need to "squarely face history" and advance towards the future, but the two sides are far from full agreement on what is needed to improve relations. Japan's historical revisionism, including praise for Japanese war criminals, has raised doubts about its interpretation of history, and Abe must keep his views to himself to mend fences with China and South Korea.

site_title: BOJ stimulus not aimed at yen slide: Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe defended his country's ultra-loose monetary policy, stating it aims to end deflation and boost growth, not weaken the yen. Abe emphasized that exchange rates should be determined by markets, contradicting criticism from countries like South Korea. The yen has dropped to a seven-year low, sparking concerns over trade advantages. Abe acknowledged the pain caused by the yen's fall on small firms but vowed to take steps to ease the impact. The Bank of Japan's stimulus program is aimed at achieving 2% inflation next year.

site_title: Celebrating 20 years of visionary leadership and entrepreneurial success
summary: Singapore's Enterprise 50 Awards, established in 1995, recognizes local privately-held companies contributing to economic development. Over 500 companies have been honored, with over 100 listed on the local bourse and making a global impact. The 20th edition, held on Nov 27, will focus on "Creating Value to Stay Ahead" and emphasizes innovation and value creation as competitive advantages. The awards aim to identify elite SMEs contributing to half of Singapore's GDP, with winners using the Enterprise 50 logo on their corporate materials.

site_title: Business of post-midterms Washington is . . . business
summary: The US Republican Party's electoral ascendancy has shifted the balance of power in Washington to favor business interests, mirroring the views of former President Calvin Coolidge. The GOP now controls both the Senate and the House of Representatives, with key committees to be chaired by Republican leaders. This shift is expected to push for pro-business policies, including trade promotion authority, corporate tax reform, and the approval of the Keystone XL oil pipeline. However, some populist Republicans may resist these efforts, potentially leading to legislative standoffs and government shutdowns.

site_title: Clinic that treated Joan Rivers cited for multiple failings
summary: A government agency report cited a New York outpatient clinic for multiple failings after the death of comedian Joan Rivers, who suffered cardiac arrest during a throat procedure at the Yorkville Endoscopy centre. The report found that staff did not follow standard protocols, including weighing Rivers before administering sedative Propofol and failing to detect her deteriorating vital signs. The clinic will undergo an unannounced survey to ensure compliance, and if it meets requirements, it will not face termination of federal Medicare and Medicaid funding.

site_title: Condo resale prices flattish in October: SRX
summary: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore stabilized at 0.4% in October, with prices rising in the city fringe and suburbs but falling in city apartments. Despite this, analysts believe prices won't recover in the short term due to the TDSR framework and cooling measures remaining in place. Year-on-year prices have dropped 4.5% since October 2013, and 5.2% since January 2014, with a median "transaction over X-value" remaining negative, indicating poor market sentiment.

site_title: Prices in 'hot' areas holding up even in soft market
summary: Prices in popular areas of Malaysia's real estate market remain stable despite a soft market, with owners unwilling to sell even with generous premiums. In prime locations such as Bangsar and Damansara Utama, buyers are being turned away despite offers of up to 40% above the asking price. The Malaysian Institute of Estate Agents (MIEA) expects prices to grow 5-10% annually in prime areas, while remaining flat in less popular spots. Limited supply and high land prices are driving the demand for prime locations.

site_title: Koh Brothers' Q3 profit up 3% at S$7.1m
summary: Koh Brothers' net profit for the third quarter rose 3% to S$7.1 million, driven by improved margins in its real estate and construction divisions. The company's revenue fell 7% to S$82.2 million. In contrast, BBR Holdings' net profit plummeted 82.9% to S$1.4 million, despite a 42.7% revenue increase. Koh Brothers' managing director Francis Koh attributed the growth to diversified revenue streams and increased collaboration among business lines.

site_title: Connected generation to gain from open Internet
summary: US President Barack Obama proposes an open Internet, urging the FCC to regulate broadband under "strongest possible rules" to prevent Internet-service providers from demanding extra payments for speedy delivery of content and data. This could stifle innovation in the budding industry for Web-connected devices, with research firm IDC expecting it to reach $3 trillion by 2020. The proposal would ensure equal transmission speeds for all users, benefiting start-ups and consumers, but cable and wireless companies have responded with concerns it would be bad for business.

site_title: Planemakers flock to China's fast-growing aviation market
summary: Foreign planemakers are flocking to China's rapidly growing aviation market, where air travel grew 11% last year to 350 million passengers. Airbus and Boeing see opportunities in the market, with Airbus announcing a $10 billion deal for 100 planes and forecasting China will need 6,020 new planes over the next 20 years. However, the market faces challenges, including economic slowdown, airspace controls, and corruption crackdowns, which may impact the growth of Chinese-made planes.

site_title: Boustead Q2 earnings up 94% at S$17.5m
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a net profit of S$17.5 million for its second quarter, up 94% from last year, driven by a higher gross profit margin and lower other losses. Revenue increased 14% to S$129.7 million. The company declared an interim dividend of two Singapore cents a share. Chairman and CEO Wong Fong Fui expects a reasonable level of profit for the current financial year, citing a strong order book and business development initiatives.

site_title: Rouble continues slide after currency floated
summary: The Russian ruble continued its dramatic slide, losing 1.4% against the dollar and 1.8% against the euro, after the central bank floated the currency on Monday. The currency has lost nearly 30% of its value against the dollar this year, driven by falling oil prices and economic sanctions imposed over Russia's policy in Ukraine. The central bank aims to target inflation rather than the exchange rate, and has halted regular interventions, but will still keep the market in check. Western countries say sanctions could be lifted soon, but a new threat to the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine has raised hopes that sanctions will remain in place.

site_title: Oxfam tells G-20 to tackle rising inequality
summary: Oxfam warns the world's top economies to address rising inequality, citing the richest 1% holding $6.2 trillion of the $17 trillion wealth gain since 2014. The agency calls for the issue to be acknowledged at the G-20 summit, arguing that ignoring it would trap millions in poverty and hinder economic growth. Oxfam supports global tax reform and efforts to combat tax evasion, which cost poor countries $100 billion annually. The organization emphasizes that tackling inequality is crucial for achieving inclusive growth and economic growth.

site_title: Germany's economic advisers see 1% growth in 2015: Sueddeutsche
summary: Germany's economic advisers forecast 1% growth in 2015 due to geopolitical risks and unfavorable eurozone developments. They cut their forecasts for 2014 to 1.2% from 1.9%. Other economists and the government have also reduced their forecasts.

site_title: Merkel says EU not planning new sanctions against Russia
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that the European Union is not planning new economic sanctions against Russia over the ongoing violence in Ukraine. Merkel stated that existing sanctions lists against pro-Russian separatists are being considered, but no further economic sanctions are planned due to the winter season approaching. The EU's goal is to achieve a "real truce" in Ukraine, and Merkel reiterated her stance that the EU will continue to support Ukraine during this time.

site_title: US small business confidence gains in October: NFIB
summary: US small business confidence increased in October, rising to 96.1 on the National Federation of Independent Business's Small Business Optimism Index. 26% of business owners planned capital outlays, the second-highest reading since 2008, while 24% reported unfilled job openings, a 3-point increase from September. However, profits for many owners remained low, limiting overall gains.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop slightly on weak resources, energy
summary: Australian shares dropped slightly on Tuesday, falling 6.9 points to 5,517.1, as weakness in metals, mining, and energy stocks offset a positive catalyst from Wall Street's record close. This is the second straight drop for the S&P/ASX 200 index, which lost 0.5% on Monday.

site_title: Petra Foods' Q3 profit falls 29.1% to US$10.5m
summary: Petra Foods reported a 29.1% decline in Q3 net profit to US$10.5 million, due to a 6.5% drop in revenue to US$118.2 million. The company's nine-month net profit increased to US$36.4 million, but declined 14% year-over-year. Its stock price fell 6 cents to S$3.74. Petra Foods sold its cocoa ingredients division in June last year.

site_title: HK protesters told to clear streets or risk arrest
summary: Hong Kong's government has ruled out talks with pro-democracy protesters, Chief Secretary Carrie Lam stated. Student leaders made "unrealistic" demands in the first round of talks last month. The government is preparing to enforce a court ruling to clear the streets. Lam said there's no need for protest leaders to seek direct talks with Chinese officials in Beijing. The government's stance indicates a firm stance against the protesters' demands.

site_title: United Envirotech Q2 profit soars to S$18m, revenue doubles to S$105.4m
summary: United Envirotech, a Singapore-based company, reported a 144.9% increase in Q2 net profit to S$18 million, driven by a 102.8% increase in revenue to S$105.4 million. The company's earnings per share rose to 1.83 Singapore cents, higher than the previous year's 1.20 cents. Revenue growth was mainly attributed to its treatment business, engineering business, and membrane sales, which jumped 104.7% to S$74.7 million. The company remains confident in China's water treatment industry and is seeking strategic partners to boost membrane sales.

site_title: Credit Suisse private banking APAC posts record performance
summary: Credit Suisse's Asia Pacific private banking business posted record performances, driven by a focus on ultra-high net worth individuals, increased hiring of relationship managers, and higher productivity. Net new assets from APAC rose 82% to 16 billion Swiss francs, assets under management increased 27% to 143 billion Swiss francs, and ultra-high net worth lending surged 600% to 1.4 billion Swiss francs. The bank's Singapore business is leading the surge, with its asset base tripling in three years. Despite higher costs, Credit Suisse is profitable in Asia, with a falling cost-to-income ratio.

site_title: BBB recovery keeps central banks in play
summary: The global economy is in its sixth year of a bumpy, below-par and brittle (BBB) recovery from the Great Recession, with inflation running below target in most major economies. Central banks are likely to continue providing ample accommodation, supporting a potential record-long expansion. The uneven and unsynchronised nature of global growth may actually be beneficial, as it reduces the risk of joint overheating. With inflation subdued, monetary policy is likely to remain supportive, and central banks may keep interest rates low for an extended period, potentially leading to a prolonged economic expansion.

site_title: Bank fines to aid British charities linked to poppy tribute
summary: British banks' fines for rigging interest rates will be used to finance a tax break for six military charities raising funds from a First World War memorial at the Tower of London. The government will donate £1.1 million in VAT revenue to the charities, on top of the proceeds from poppy sales already set to be shared among them. The fines total £460 million, paid by seven banks and brokers, including Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays.

site_title: CNMC Q3 net profit doubles to US$3.38m
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, reported a double-digit growth in revenue for the third quarter, reaching US$10.05 million, up 59.2% from the previous year. Net profit doubled to US$3.38 million, driven by increased fine gold production and sales volume. The company expects lower gold prices to affect profitability but remains optimistic due to its low all-in costs. Net profit for the nine months ended September 30 surged to US$9.08 million, with revenue up 153.3% to US$23.43 million.

site_title: German retailers confident ahead of Christmas season
summary: German retailers are optimistic ahead of the Christmas season, with the retail industry federation HDE raising its growth forecast for 2014 to 1.8% from 1.5%. The stable labour market is expected to boost consumer spending, with Christmas sales projected to grow 1.2% and reach 85 billion euros (US$106 billion). Consumers are also expected to spend an average of 447 euros on Christmas presents, up 50 euros from last year.

site_title: China wins Apec support for free trade 'roadmap'
summary: China secured support from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit for a free trade area, with host Xi Jinping calling it a "historic" step. The endorsement comes amid diplomatic efforts, including meetings between Xi and US President Barack Obama, as well as Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The Apec meeting also saw Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott and Russian President Vladimir Putin meet separately. The endorsement is seen as a boost for China's free trade ambitions, but the region's economic landscape is facing challenges, including slowing GDP growth and US tariffs on Asian goods.

site_title: US: Stocks open flat after four-day record streak
summary: US stocks opened flat on Tuesday, marking a four-day record streak, after setting record closing highs for four straight sessions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.35 points, the S&P 500 rose 0.11, and the Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.77. Despite the slight decline, stocks remained close to their previous record highs, indicating a continued market rally.

site_title: China, US make breakthrough on IT free trade deal: US trade rep
summary: China and the US have reached a breakthrough in talks on eliminating duties on information technology products, paving the way for the first major tariff-cutting agreement at the World Trade Organisation in 17 years. The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) would reduce global tariffs on products like medical equipment, GPS devices, and semiconductors, with over 200 tariff lines to be eliminated. The deal could lead to the expansion of the ITA, which covers more than $4 trillion in annual trade, and is seen as a positive step for the US-China relationship and the multilateral trading system.

site_title: UOL Q3 profit up 10 per cent to S$103m
summary: UOL Group's third-quarter net earnings rose 10% to S$102.57 million, driven by a 66% revenue jump to S$433.54 million. The increase was largely due to the recognition of S$212.2 million in property development revenue from a project in Tianjin. Earnings per share rose to 13.23 cents and net asset value per share increased to S$9.29. The counter eased seven cents to close at S$6.37 after the market closed.

site_title: Fortune Reit's Q3 distributable income up 25.9%
summary: Fortune Reit reported a 25.9% increase in distributable income to HK$193.1 million for its Q3 2014, driven by a 33% rise in net property income and 32% increase in total revenue. This translates to a 10.30 Hong Kong cents DPU, 24.4% higher than the previous year. Strong rental growth and additional income from acquired properties contributed to the results.

site_title: Zico performs strongly on its SGX-Catalist debut
summary: Zico Holdings, an integrated provider of multidisciplinary professional services, made its debut on the SGX-Catalist board at S$0.46 and closed at S$0.515, a 71.7% increase from the placement price. The company raised approximately S$12.5 million through its placement, which will be used for business expansion, potential acquisitions, and working capital purposes. The strong debut was attributed to the overwhelming response from institutional investors and the investing community, recognizing Zico's competitive edge and growth prospects.

site_title: How To Catch a Murderer
summary: A podcast called Serial re-examines the 1999 murder of American high school student Hae Min Lee, whose ex-boyfriend Adnan Syed was convicted of her murder. The case turned on a 21-minute time frame where police say Lee was killed, with Adnan's memory proving patchy. The podcast's exploration of botched trials and complex motivations raises questions about Adnan's guilt. The case's reliance on this 21-minute window has become a pressing issue, as the internet's ability to track and record daily life has made it easier to account for such time frames, potentially changing the outcome of similar cases.

site_title: Thailand sees budget deficit for next two fiscal years
summary: Thailand is expected to face budget deficits for the next two fiscal years due to increased spending on public health and education. The estimated budget deficit for 2015/16 and 2016/17 is around 350 billion baht (US$10.66 billion), equivalent to 15% of the government's revenue collection. Finance Minister Sommai Phasee stated that the government does not expect to balance the budget over the next two years. This is larger than the 2014/15 budget deficit of 250 billion baht.

site_title: Proposed FTAAP among key outcomes of meeting: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that a Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP) is a key outcome of this year's Apec Summit, with China proposing the framework. Lee stated that the FTAAP is a long-term goal, not achievable within two to five years, with a possible timeline of 10 years. He emphasized that the FTAAP is not a Chinese idea, but rather the original intention of Apec in 1989. The summit also discussed the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and the potential for China to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) in the future.

site_title: Indonesian sugar refineries shut as govt chokes raw imports
summary: Indonesia's sugar refineries face a temporary shutdown as the country's top sugar buyer, a major import quota cutter, reduces its imports. Two plants have already closed, with two more expected to shut down by the end of November unless new permits are granted. The industry has forecast import demand to exceed 3 million tonnes this year, but the government has already exhausted its quota of 2.8 million tonnes. The country aims to restore self-sufficiency in sugar production within four years by reducing imports.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.27% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 8.85 points to 3,292.15. A total of 1.15 billion shares were traded, with 150 gainers and 242 losers. This comes after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q3 earnings tumble 43% to S$127m
summary: Genting Singapore's Q3 earnings plummet 43% to S$127.10 million due to weak high-roller business. Revenue fell 17% to S$644.77 million, while earnings per share dropped to 0.80 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to low win rates, but attributed growth in attractions and hotel businesses. Genting plans to spend on marketing to improve visitation from traditional markets. Shares closed 1.5 Singapore cents lower at S$1.04.

site_title: Bank selloff drags STI below 3,300
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 8.85 points to 3,292.15 on Tuesday, its largest decline since November 2013. The decline was largely due to a weak trading session with low volumes, averaging 1.15 billion units worth S$989 million. This follows the end of the US Federal Reserve's quantitative-easing programme in October, which led to a decrease in market activity. The index has been experiencing a subdued trading session, with dealers describing it as "quiet" and "average" by recent standards.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC Ltd ratings placed on CreditWatch negative on possible takeover
summary: Standard & Poor's has placed STATS ChipPAC Ltd's 'BB+' long-term corporate credit rating and 'axBBB+' long-term ASEAN regional scale ratings on CreditWatch with negative implications due to a possible takeover by China-based Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology (JCET). The acquisition's impact on the company's credit profile and government support is uncertain, and the rating may be lowered if the acquisition occurs.

site_title: Alibaba says Singles Day shoppers spend US$2b in first hour
summary: Alibaba sold US$2 billion in goods in the first hour of its Singles Day shopping event, surpassing last year's full-day sales of US$5.8 billion. The ecommerce giant maintained its dominance as the world's biggest retail event, going global for the first time. Over 12.23 billion yuan (US$2 billion) of deals were settled within the first hour and 12 seconds, with 45.7% of transactions made via mobile devices. Alibaba's third-quarter net profit jumped 15% year-on-year to $1.1 billion, with revenue soaring 53.7% to US$2.7 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump 2.05% to new seven-year high
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 2.05% to a seven-year high, driven by a weak yen and record closes on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index reached 17,124.11, its highest since October 2007, while the Topix index gained 1.11%. This follows a strong showing on US markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Nam Cheong's Q3 profit doubles to RM126.29m
summary: Nam Cheong's net profit for the third quarter ended Sept 30 more than doubled to RM126.29 million, driven by a 81% surge in revenue to RM618.62 million. The company's shipbuilding segment recorded an 86% leap in revenue to RM595.1 million, while its vessel chartering business saw a 9% rise in revenue to RM23.5 million. The company's order book for offshore support vessels stands at RM1.9 billion, with a record order of 25 vessels worth US$505 million year-to-date.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to revive Maybach brand for top end S-Class
summary: Daimler has announced plans to revive the Maybach brand for its top-end S-Class models, including a sports utility vehicle and a high-end luxury limousine. The new Mercedes-Maybach S 600 will be unveiled at the Guangzhou Motor Show and Los Angeles Auto Show. The brand was previously discontinued in 2012 due to low sales, but is expected to sell well in China, the US, Russia, and Japan. Mercedes-Benz will also launch a new labeling system to help customers understand its expanding range of vehicles.

site_title: Boustead's Q2 profit nearly doubles to S$17.5m
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a net profit of S$17.5 million for its second quarter, nearly doubling from S$9 million a year ago. Revenue increased 14% to S$129.7 million. The company declared an interim dividend of two cents per share and has a strong order book of S$441 million. Recent business development initiatives in the real estate solutions division contributed to the growth. The company expects to deliver a reasonable level of profit for the current financial year.

site_title: Metro's Q2 earnings double on one-off gain
summary: Metro Holdings' Q2 earnings doubled to S$61.2 million, or 7.4 Singapore cents per share, due to a one-off gain of S$59.3 million from the recognition of a transitional negative goodwill from Hong Kong-listed developer Top Spring. This lifted the company from an operating loss of S$14.6 million to a profit. Despite a cautious Singapore residential property market, Metro's retail business faces challenges, while refurbishment costs for Metro City are expected to hit profitability. The company's shares closed at 87 Singapore cents, 0.6% lower.

site_title: Wilmar's Q3 profit rises 1.5% to US$422.4m
summary: Wilmar International reported a 1.5% increase in third-quarter net profit to US$422.4 million, driven by other operating income and associate results. Revenue declined 2.7% to US$11.5 billion. Key contributors to the growth included a recovery in the oilseeds and grains unit, as well as higher profits from consumer products and plantations. However, the palm and laurics business saw a 49% decline in pre-tax profit due to excess capacity in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore oil supplier Vanguard Energy files for bankruptcy: court document
summary: Singapore oil supplier Vanguard Energy filed for bankruptcy in late October, according to court documents. This comes just a week after the world's largest marine fuel supplier, OW Bunker, also filed for bankruptcy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.82 points to 1,825.11. Over 2.25 billion lots worth RM1.86 billion were traded, with 241 gains and 625 losses recorded.

site_title: Maersk's third-quarter profit beats forecasts
summary: Maersk's third-quarter net profit rose 25% to $1.5 billion, beating analyst forecasts of $1.38 billion. The company maintained its full-year profit forecast of $4.5 billion but raised its net profit forecast for Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipping company, to above $2 billion.

site_title: StanChart to axe 80-100 branches under revival plan
summary: Standard Chartered plans to cut 80-100 retail branches, or 8% of its network, in 2015 to save $400 million annually. The move aims to improve profitability after three profit warnings this year and a 30% plunge in shares. The bank also aims to increase assets under management in wealth management and private banking businesses by 10% or more, and boost corporate finance revenues. Finance Director Andy Halford acknowledged investor concerns over high costs, bad debts, and non-performing loans, but vowed to tackle these issues and deliver sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Asia-focused bank Standard Chartered plans to cut up to 100 retail branches in 2015, or 8 per cent of its network, to help save US$400 million a year to improve profitability.

site_title: Hong Kong official tells democracy protesters to clear sites
summary: Hong Kong's acting chief executive Carrie Lam called on pro-democracy protesters to clear occupied sites, warning those who remained could face arrest. Authorities may start removing protesters as early as Wednesday. A court ruled that police can arrest protesters who defy authorities. The student-led protesters demand fully democratic elections for the city's next chief executive in 2017. Demonstrators have defied riot police and intense government pressure, with nearly 90% ready to stay on the streets for over a year.

site_title: Singapore oil trader prepares lawsuit against ship fuel supplier OW Bunker
summary: Singapore oil trader Hin Leong Trading is preparing a lawsuit against ship fuel supplier OW Bunker, seeking $1.67 million in damages over the sale of goods. The move comes after OW Bunker filed for bankruptcy in Denmark, citing suspected fraud at its Singapore trading unit. The company's collapse has sent shockwaves through the shipping fuel market, with rising prices and fears of counterparty risk. OW Bunker has blamed internal fraud for losses of at least $125 million at another Singapore subsidiary. The move is expected to have minimal disruption to Singapore's bunkering supplies.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q3 net profit slumps to 4-year low
summary: Genting Singapore PLC reported a 43% decline in Q3 net profit to S$127.1 million (US$98 million), the lowest since 2010. Gaming revenue dropped 21% due to lower VIP player revenue and a low win percentage for premium players. The company attributed the decline to economic slowdown in major visitor markets and environmental factors. Genting's shares have hit a four-year low and are down 30% this year, making them the worst performer in Singapore's benchmark index.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.27% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.27% to 23,808.28 on Tuesday, driven by a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index gained 63.58 points on turnover of HK$95.95 billion. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.16% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.92%.

site_title: Indonesia's 2015 palm output growth to slow after drought: industry
summary: Indonesia's palm oil output is expected to grow by 3% in 2015, slower than the 7% growth rate in 2014, due to prolonged drought in the main growing region of Sumatra. Output is forecast to reach 31.5 million tonnes, with exports remaining flat at around 19 million tonnes. Higher domestic biodiesel usage and rising demand from Pakistan are expected to offset the negative impact of potential import taxes from India. The industry association recommends that President Joko Widodo scrap the forest-clearing moratorium and cap the country's CPO export tax to support the sector.

site_title: Japan consumer mood worsens to 6-mth low in October: govt survey
summary: Japan's consumer confidence index fell to a 6-month low in October, reaching 38.9, down from 39.9 in September. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, reflecting a weakening economy after the April sales tax hike. A reading below 50 suggests consumer pessimism, further downgrading the Cabinet Office's view on consumer confidence. The survey's sentiment index has not been this low since April.

images.alt_text: Japanese consumer confidence deteriorated for a third straight month in October, reflecting a stumbling economy after the April sales tax hike.

site_title: New Zealand parliament, newspaper sent bottle labelled Ebola
summary: New Zealand's parliament in Wellington was placed on lockdown after receiving a package containing a plastic bottle labeled as a sample of the Ebola virus. Similar packages were sent to a newsroom in Auckland earlier in the day. The bottle was secured by police with the help of the army's explosive ordnance disposal team and sent for forensic testing. The incident led to a lockdown of the parliament mailroom, with police working to determine the origin and intent behind the packages. The situation remains under investigation.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's parliament mailroom was in lockdown Tuesday after it was sent a bottle claiming to contain a sample of the Ebola virus just hours after a newsroom in Auckland received a similar package, police said.

site_title: US regulator pushes for more disclosure on prepaid debit cards: WSJ
summary: US regulators plan to unveil comprehensive consumer protections for prepaid debit cards, including fee disclosure and limits on overdrafts. The proposed rules, set by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, will require fee disclosure and prevent users from spending more than they have loaded onto the card. The regulator will also ensure protection from fraudulent transactions and set limits on overdrafts, which currently allow customers to spend more money than they have loaded onto the card for a fee. The standards aim to protect users who mostly use prepaid cards without bank accounts.

site_title: Heat on over climate as US, China leaders meet
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping are meeting in Beijing to discuss climate change, a topic where they have few common ground but are willing to make commitments to fight the threat. China, the world's top emitter, has pledged to "strive" for its emissions to peak in the near future, while the US aims to cut emissions by 20-30% by 2025. The two countries' leaders are seeking to find a middle ground ahead of a global agreement in Paris next year, with the goal of limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Families furious over report MH370 to be declared 'lost'
summary: Malaysia Airlines' commercial director Hugh Dunleavy reportedly stated that authorities would set a date to announce MH370 as "lost", potentially ending the search. Relatives of victims criticized the airline, saying the declaration would bring "intense agony and confusions" to families. However, Malaysia Airlines and Australian officials denied the comments, with the Joint Agency Coordination Centre in Australia reiterating its commitment to the search. The search for the missing Boeing 777, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people aboard, remains ongoing.

site_title: Singapore port authority says little disruption to bunker supply after OW Bunker bankruptcy
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) expects minimal disruption to bunker fuel supplies in the country's port following the bankruptcy of Denmark's OW Bunker. OW Bunker's Singapore-based subsidiary accounted for less than 3% of the port's 42.6 million metric tonnes supplied in 2013. The MPA is working with industry associations to mitigate the impact on operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.77 points to 1831.03. The market saw 51.5 million lots traded worth RM14.18 million, with 99 gainers outnumbering 49 losers.

site_title: China and Japan 'need each other': Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said China and Japan "need each other" as they strive to improve relations between the two historically frosty nations. The statement came after an Asia-Pacific summit in Beijing, where Abe emphasized the importance of both countries' roles in maintaining regional and global peace and prosperity. Beijing and Tokyo have been at odds over competing claims to the Senkaku/Diaoyu islets in the East China Sea, with tensions at their lowest in decades. Abe's comments mark a push for cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Japan's current account surplus up 61.9% in September
summary: Japan's current account surplus rose 61.9% in September to 963.0 billion yen (US$8.4 billion), surpassing market forecasts. The surplus was driven by higher repatriated returns on foreign investment, despite a widening merchandise trade deficit. A weaker yen, influenced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pro-spending policy and the Bank of Japan's monetary easing, contributed to the increase.

site_title: Singapore tourists to Japan up 15.9% in January-September
summary: Singapore tourists to Japan increased by 18,319, or 15.9%, between January and September this year, compared to the same period last year. The growth is attributed to cheaper domestic fares and discounts offered by All Nippon Airways (ANA). ANA's "Is Japan Cool?" website promotes Japan's culture, history, and nature, contributing to the surge in tourism. ANA boasts Japan's largest route network, connecting 36 international destinations and 115 domestic locations.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday with the Straits Times Index up 7.38 points to 3,308.38. Gainers outnumbered losers 59 to 50. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Hyflux opens largest desalination plant in Algeria
summary: Hyflux has opened the Magtaa Desalination Plant in Algeria, the largest seawater reverse osmosis desalination plant in the country. The plant can desalinate 500,000 cubic meters of seawater daily, supplying water to Oran and neighboring provinces under a 25-year contract. Hyflux will operate and maintain the plant, which is its second in Algeria after the Souk Tleta Desalination Plant. The project aims to strengthen Hyflux's presence in the region and demonstrate its technology and capabilities for sustainable and cost-effective water solutions.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine doubles Q3 profit, revenue rises nearly 60%
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 100% increase in net profit to US$3.38 million for Q3 2014, driven by a 59.2% rise in revenue to US$10.05 million. Production of fine gold increased 61% to 7667.17 ounces, with operating profit rising 57.2% to US$4.38 million. Despite lower gold prices, the company expects its low all-in costs to mitigate the impact, and does not anticipate significant profitability changes due to a goods and service tax in Malaysia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nam Cheong, Vard, Blumont, ARA, Sim Lian
summary: Nam Cheong's net profit more than doubled to RM126.29 million for the third quarter, driven by higher revenue. Vard Holdings reported a net loss of 37 million kroner due to higher costs. Blumont incurred a net loss of S$13.48 million, contrasting with a net profit of S$33.73 million last year. The results suggest resilience in the shallow water segment of the offshore and marine industry.

site_title: Australian bank regulator happy to be seen as tougher than the rest
summary: Australia's financial regulator, APRA, says it aims to be perceived as tougher than the rest of the world, with stricter lending standards and securitization requirements. APRA's executive general manager Charles Littrell stated that Australian banks are "conservatively regulated and supervised" and that securitization deals should be perceived as safe, simple, and reliable. This stance contrasts with local lenders, who are urging APRA to be more flexible to compete with international peers. APRA's standards are considered among the strictest globally, with securitization deals required to withstand a 20% loss, compared to 5% in Europe.

site_title: US judge says Citigroup can process Argentina's next bond payment
summary: US District Judge Thomas Griesa ruled that Citigroup Inc can process an $85 million interest payment by Argentina on US dollar-denominated bonds issued under its local laws following its 2002 default. The judge also canceled a hearing on whether Citigroup can regularly process payments on the bonds, deferring the briefing until 2015. This decision allows Argentina to make its interest payment on December 31 as scheduled.

site_title: New York doctor infected with Ebola to be released from hospital
summary: A New York doctor, Dr. Craig Spencer, 33, who contracted Ebola after working in West Africa, is to be released from Bellevue Hospital Center on Tuesday. Spencer was diagnosed on October 23 and had been held in isolation. His release comes after public alarm about the possible spread of the virus in the city, despite medical experts stating Ebola can only be transmitted through bodily fluids of those showing symptoms.

site_title: Virgin Australia now SIA's associate, may be looking to raise funds
summary: Singapore Airlines announced that Virgin Australia Holdings Limited (VAH) is now an associated company, with SIA holding a 22.8% stake. The airline group is reportedly planning to raise $300 million in the US, according to ratings agencies Moody's and Standard & Poor's. This move comes after SIA, Air New Zealand, and Etihad collectively hold a 70% stake in VAH. The airline's credit metrics are expected to improve, but it will remain highly leveraged for the next two years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares climb 0.27% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.27% at the opening on Tuesday, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,809.41, adding 64.71 points. This comes as global markets continue their rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia business conditions jump most on record-survey
summary: Australia's business conditions index surged to +13 in October, the largest monthly gain on record, driven by stronger sales, profits, and employment. The index of sales rose to +20, profitability to +15, and employment to +2. While business confidence dipped to +4, the improvement was broad-based across industries. This positive sign may boost the Reserve Bank of Australia's hopes for a revival in non-mining investment. Inflationary pressures remained restrained, with subdued wages growth and modest purchase costs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.53% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.53% higher on Tuesday, driven by the dollar's rebound against the yen and US stock markets' record-breaking advances. The Nikkei 225 index rose 88.96 points to 16,869.49. Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund plans to double its domestic stock exposure, citing a rapidly ageing population.
