Analysts expect the Nikkei to reach the 18,000 mark, driven by latent demand and low interest rate scenarios.

site_title: Vard turns in Q3 loss of 37 million kroner
summary: Vard Holdings, a Norwegian shipbuilder, reported a net loss of 37 million kroner (S$7.01 million) for the third quarter, compared to a profit of 76 million kroner in the same period last year. Revenue increased 18.5% to 2.81 billion kroner, driven by deliveries of five vessels and new contracts. The company's operating loss was 108 million kroner, attributed to rising costs and expenses. Despite this, Vard remains well-positioned with an order book valued at 20.1 billion kroner and expects negotiations on several contracts to continue.

site_title: Canada boosts restrictions for travelers from Ebola-hit nations
summary: Canada has increased travel restrictions for individuals returning from Ebola-stricken countries, particularly Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone. Those who have come into contact with the virus are required to self-monitor for 21 days and report to local health officials. "High risk" travelers may be quarantined at a special facility during this period. If symptoms of Ebola appear, individuals will be isolated and sent to a hospital for medical examination. Canada has not reported any cases of Ebola and is taking precautionary measures to protect Canadians from the threat of the deadly virus.

site_title: All companies will be able to e-file income tax returns from next year
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will begin allowing all companies to e-file income tax returns from next year, regardless of annual revenue. Larger companies will be able to file the Corporate Income Tax Form (Form C) online, reducing compliance costs and increasing productivity. Smaller companies with annual revenue of up to S$1 million will have until Dec 15 to e-file Form C-S, a shortened three-page tax return. This change aims to improve efficiency and cut costs for companies.

images.alt_text: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) will be extending e-filing to all companies, regardless of annual revenue, from next year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up after Wall St records
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, following US shares that hit fresh records for a fourth straight session. Japan's Nikkei extended its recent rally, while Hong Kong and Shanghai also gained. The weaker yen contributed to Japan's rally. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Blumont plunges into the red for Q3 in the absence of equity investment gains
summary: Blumont Group reported a net loss of S$13.48 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2014, due to the absence of S$40.91 million in unrealized fair value gains from financial assets. Revenue fell 38% to S$779,000. The group's board warned of a potential loss for the full financial year ending Dec 31, 2014, citing unrealized losses and impairment losses on financial assets.

site_title: The Ayala formula for success
summary: Chairman and CEO of Ayala Corporation Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala shares the key principles behind the family business's success over seven generations. These include a pioneering and entrepreneurial spirit, constantly seeking new sources of growth through redefining existing businesses or entering new industries. This approach has guided the company's growth and enabled it to stay competitive.

site_title: Nam Cheong's Q3 profit more than doubles, revenue rises 81%
summary: Nam Cheong, an offshore marine group, reported a net profit more than double to RM126.29 million (S$48.68 million) in Q3, driven by a 81% surge in revenue to RM618.62 million. The company secured a record order of 25 vessels worth US$505 million. Group chief Leong Seng Keat attributed the growth to the resilient shallow water segment and the increasing demand for modern vessels with fuel-efficient features, particularly in low oil price periods.

site_title: Germany and Britain agree on closing "patent box" loophole: officials
summary: Germany and Britain have agreed to close the "patent box" loophole, a tax break that allows firms to minimize tax bills on patented research. Britain will wind down its patent box rebates and join other OECD countries in granting tax breaks only for patents tied to research and innovation at home. The deal could serve as a blueprint for a broader G20 agreement, with Germany and Britain presenting a joint proposal to the OECD forum in January. This move addresses British concerns and paves the way for a potential G20 agreement.

site_title: Obama pressures FCC for strong net neutrality rules
summary: US President Barack Obama has pressured the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to adopt strong net neutrality rules, calling for ISPs to be reclassified as public utilities and banned from striking paid "fast lane" deals. The move came after nearly 4 million comments flooded the FCC in response to Chairman Tom Wheeler's proposal, which would have allowed ISPs to make "commercially reasonable" deals with content providers. Obama's statement sided with consumer advocates, but the FCC's decision is expected to face legal challenges from large ISPs, with some analysts predicting a White House veto if attempts to overturn new net neutrality rules are made.

site_title: Winning potential customers through content marketing
summary: Businesses can generate sales leads through content marketing by creating and distributing useful knowledge and information to potential customers for free. This approach helps establish credibility, builds an interested audience, and generates leads. Effective content marketing involves repurposing existing content, curating external content, and creating original content that addresses the audience's needs and interests. By doing so, businesses can position themselves as thought leaders and trusted advisers, increasing the likelihood of conversion into loyal customers.

site_title: Firms flock to China's fast-growing aviation market
summary: Global aviation firms are flocking to China's fast-growing market, where air travel grew 11% last year to 350 million passengers. Companies like Airbus and Boeing are seeking to tap into the market, with Airbus announcing a $10 billion deal for 100 planes. China is developing its own passenger planes, including the C919 and ARJ21, to rival Boeing and Airbus. However, the market faces challenges, including an economic slowdown, strict airspace controls, and a corruption crackdown, which could impact air traffic management and the market's growth.

images.alt_text: Global aviation firms flocked to China on Tuesday to show off their wares as economic development and an expanding middle class promise a bonanza in one of the world's fastest-growing aircraft markets.

site_title: Fitch: SingTel ratings may face pressure; M1, StarHub stable in 2015
summary: Fitch Ratings warns that SingTel's ratings may face pressure due to deteriorating leverage, which could reach 1.9x-2.0x in 2015, threatening negative rating action. In contrast, M1 and StarHub's ratings remain stable due to improving profitability and manageable dividend payouts. SingTel's debt-funded acquisitions to expand its Digital Life segment are credit negative, and the company expects EBITDA losses in the segment for 2015-16.

site_title: ECB's Mersch says state-bond buys 'theoretically possible'
summary: European Central Bank Executive Board member Yves Mersch stated that the ECB could theoretically buy state bonds to stimulate the euro zone's sluggish recovery. Mersch expressed concerns about the critical state of the euro zone's recovery, citing weak growth, low inflation, and a loss of momentum. He noted that the situation would need to deteriorate further before considering such a move, and that governments must act to halt the decline through economic reforms, including structural reforms.

site_title: Singhaiyi Q2 profit falls 75% to S$1.86m
summary: Singhaiyi Group reported a 75% drop in Q2 net profit to S$1.86m, mainly due to exceptional one-off items from the acquisition of Tri-Country Mall in 2014. The lower bottom line was largely offset by a S$12.8m provisional gain from the mall's acquisition.

site_title: Google to boost Ebola donations
summary: Google has launched a campaign to raise money to fight Ebola, donating $10 million and matching donations two-to-one until $7.5 million more are collected. The company's CEO Larry Page's family foundation is also contributing $15 million. This comes after Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg and his wife donated $25 million to the US efforts to contain the epidemic. The funds will be distributed to groups such as InSTEDD, Medecins Sans Frontieres, and Save the Children to support frontline responders and underfunded health systems in West Africa.

site_title: Hackers target CEOs in 'Darkhotel' scheme
summary: Hackers have been targeting CEOs and high-ranking executives through a scheme called "Darkhotel," which involves compromising hotel Wi-Fi networks to steal sensitive information. The scheme, which has been active for at least four years, has infected thousands of systems in Japan, Taiwan, China, Russia, and South Korea, with executives from the US and Asia also targeted. The hackers use malicious software to trick victims into downloading tools that collect data, keystrokes, and login credentials. The risk can be mitigated by using a virtual private network, and travelers should be cautious about software updates and use protection against a range of threats.

site_title: G-20 global infrastructure hub set to be based in Sydney
summary: A Global Infrastructure Initiative, proposed by G-20 nations, will be based in Sydney and funded by Australia. The initiative aims to match investors with projects and cut red tape, aiming to spur economic growth by shifting from government-led to private sector-led growth. Australia will be the main contributor to funding, with other countries expected to make modest contributions. The hub will operate for four years, with a focus on raising commercial funds for new public works, and will not be a permanent institution.

site_title: Joseph Gordon-Levitt to play Edward Snowden in Oliver Stone film
summary: Actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt will play Edward Snowden in a film directed by Oliver Stone. The movie, based on two books, will go into production in Munich in January. Snowden leaked classified documents in 2013, sparking a firestorm over the NSA's mass surveillance programs. He currently lives in Moscow, where he was granted asylum. Gordon-Levitt, known for films like "Lincoln" and "Inception," will portray the former NSA contractor. The untitled film aims to remain independent, avoiding political pressures.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at record highs; transports jump
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Monday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 extending their winning streak for the fourth session. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.81 points, while the S&P 500 gained 6.34 points. Transportation and healthcare shares led the gains, with railroads and airlines experiencing significant increases. Oil prices fell, contributing to the rally. Analysts attribute the gains to low interest rates, low oil prices, and investor complacency. The Dow and S&P 500 have risen over 7% in the past three weeks, their best performance since October 2011.

site_title: China strikes 2nd major gas deal with Russia
summary: China has secured a second major gas deal with Russia, with the two countries agreeing to supply 30 billion cubic meters of gas annually from West Siberia to China over 30 years. The deal is smaller than a previous $400 billion accord reached earlier this year and is expected to give China almost 17% of its gas consumption by 2020. The agreement is seen as a way for Russia to diversify its market and spur its economy, and for China to secure its energy needs.

site_title: Greenback weaker after Friday's job numbers
summary: The US dollar weakened against a basket of currencies, 0.4% lower, following weaker-than-expected US jobs numbers on Friday. The Swiss franc strengthened to its strongest in two years, edging up to 1.20 francs per euro. Analysts predict the US dollar will continue to rise due to diverging economies and monetary policy differences. The eurozone's economic struggles and potential recession also support a stronger dollar.

site_title: Property development boosts Sim Lian's Q1 net earnings
summary: Sim Lian Group's Q1 2014 net earnings more than doubled to S$77m, driven by strong revenue bookings from property development projects. Revenue from property development more than doubled to S$297.23m, with the construction division's revenue rising 87%. The company expects a set of profitable operating results for FY2015, but faces a challenging private residential property market.

site_title: SGX glitch not a negative commentary on its technology
summary: A power outage at the Singapore Exchange (SGX) caused a three-hour trading suspension, but the incident is not a negative commentary on the exchange's technology. A lightning strike was the cause, highlighting the importance of maintaining and monitoring technology systems. The outage is not unique, with several major stock exchanges and banks experiencing similar disruptions in recent years. The incident serves as an opportunity for SGX to review its processes and develop new SOPs to prevent a recurrence, with the benefits of technology use outweighing the pitfalls.

images.alt_text: The board of inquiry set up by SGX will eventually unearth why the bourse's uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system malfunctioned.

site_title: China's rich raises bar for extravagance
summary: China's luxury market continues to thrive, with bespoke vehicles like the Prombron Black Shark offering extravagant features such as Swarovski-crusted bonnets, armour-plating, and anti-paparazzi door handles. The market's growth is driven by China's swelling millionaire population, with the number of millionaires increasing by almost a million last year. Luxury brands are shifting towards high-end, unique products, and Chinese consumers are willing to pay premium prices, with some vehicles costing over six figures. This trend is expected to continue, with McLaren Automotive Ltd. and Koenigsegg Automotive AB expecting strong sales in China.

site_title: Demystifying the Fed's bond buying enigma
summary: The Federal Reserve has ended its $3.7 trillion bond buying program, leaving questions about its success in strengthening the economic recovery. While some studies suggest the program created 2 million jobs and raised output by 3%, others argue the results are overstated. Critics warn of potential inflation, while supporters note the program's impact on long-term interest rates and stock prices. More rigorous research is needed to evaluate the program's effectiveness, as it may be proposed again in the future.

site_title: ECB must pursue quantitative easing to reverse deflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should adopt quantitative easing to reverse deflation in the eurozone, as conventional monetary policy has had limited impact. The ECB must develop a strategy tailored to the eurozone's unique system, considering factors such as low bond yields and adverse distributional implications. One feasible option is to distribute funds directly to citizens through social-security numbers or electoral registers, potentially boosting spending and reducing government deficits. This approach would have massive political benefits, including reducing resentment towards European institutions and helping to stem the rise of nationalist parties.

site_title: Global Yellow's bottom line hit by one-off disposal adjustment
summary: Global Yellow Pages reported a widened net loss of S$2.35 million for its fiscal second quarter, up from S$794,000 a year ago, due to a one-off disposal adjustment. Revenue rose 16.2% to S$4.74 million, while total expenses increased 37.1% to S$7.96 million. The loss per share was 0.14 Singapore cents, down from 0.12 cents in the previous period. The company attributed the loss to the disposal of a foreign associated company and a reclassification of currency translation loss.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng F&B business flat in Q3
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a Singapore-based food and beverage counter, reported a net profit of S$3.15 million for the three months ended Sept 30, 86% lower than the previous year. Revenue decreased 11% to S$114.7 million, mainly due to depreciation and increased advertising expenses. The company attributed the decline to increased raw material prices, energy costs, and competition. For the nine months, food and beverage revenue rose 0.5% to S$332 million, but net profit fell to S$7 million. The company's available-for-sale financial assets continued to slide in value, valued at S$166 million at end-September.

site_title: India's slowing profits growth offers wake-up call for record-high shares
summary: India's corporate earnings are experiencing the weakest growth in nearly six years, with a 4.3% increase in the fourth quarter, according to recent data. This slowdown contrasts with the country's record-high shares, which have risen by a third this year under Prime Minister Narendra Modi's pro-business administration. Despite the economic concerns, Modi's government is seen as a positive factor for investors, with many expecting continued growth. The data has raised questions about the government's ability to revive the economy, which has been stuck in below-5% growth for nearly a quarter of a century.

images.alt_text: Indian corporate earnings are growing at the weakest pace in nearly six years, in a more sober reflection of the economy than a stock market hovering near record highs since the May election of pro-business Prime Minister, Narendra Modi.

site_title: No bulging stockings for Wall St bankers this Christmas
summary: Wall Street bonuses are expected to drop by as much as 10% for trading desks and hedge funds, but investment bankers and private equity employees may see a 10-15% increase in bonuses. Asset managers are also likely to receive bigger paychecks. The decline in bonuses reflects the fading away of riskier financial activities and the rise of more stable businesses such as wealth management and deal-making. The shift is consistent with regulations that discourage banks from doing risky trading and encourage them to focus on client-facing businesses.

site_title: Malaysia's support for wealth fund debt questioned
summary: Malaysia's support for its sovereign wealth fund's dollar-denominated debt is being questioned by investors. Deputy Finance Minister Ahmad Maslan stated that the government only guaranteed sukuk bonds, not the conventional dollar notes, issued by 1Malaysia Development Bhd. This comes after Goldman Sachs made significant commissions for managing the sale of the notes, which have seen a drop in price to 98.5 cents on the dollar. Investors are advised to avoid the notes due to a lack of clarity and financial details, citing a letter of support from Prime Minister Najib Razak without an express guarantee.

site_title: Staying the course across generations
summary: The Ayala Corporation, one of Asia's most respected family businesses, has been successfully sustained across generations. Chairman and CEO Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala attributes the company's longevity to its long-term strategic focus, stewardship, and resilience. The 180-year-old business empire has navigated challenges such as the liberalization of the telecommunications industry and the privatization of public utilities, emerging as a leading player in the Philippines. Zobel emphasizes the importance of a strong family culture, governance standards, and a commitment to national development, citing the company's recognition for corporate governance and philanthropic efforts.

site_title: Apple iOS bug makes devices vulnerable to attack: experts
summary: Researchers at FireEye Inc have warned that a bug in Apple's iOS operating system makes most iPhones and iPads vulnerable to cyber attacks by hackers. The bug, known as the "Masque Attack," allows hackers to replace trusted apps with malicious software via tainted text messages, emails, and web links. This can result in the theft of sensitive data, such as banking and email login credentials. Experts consider the vulnerability "very powerful" and "easy to exploit." Apple has not commented on the issue, leaving devices exposed to potential attacks.

images.alt_text: Researchers have warned that a bug in Apple Inc's iOS operating system makes most iPhones and iPads vulnerable to cyber attacks by hackers seeking access to sensitive data and control of their devices.

site_title: S'pore consumer confidence climbs to highest levels in 3 years
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence reached its highest levels in three years, surpassing 100 points in Q3 with a score of 103. The rise is driven by optimism in job prospects and personal finances, with 59% of Singaporeans expecting good or excellent financial conditions in the coming year. Consumers are also focusing on saving and spending on holidays, clothes, and debt repayment, with 51% planning a holiday and 30% planning to pay off debts. The region's consumer confidence also improved, with Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam showing notable increases.

site_title: Malaysia's top auditor wants tax collection system beefed up
summary: Malaysia's Auditor-General has called for stronger enforcement of the real property gains tax (RPGT) collection system, citing long delays in processing tax forms and a backlog of thousands of cases. The tax on RPGT has risen by 29% between 2012 and 2013, reaching RM787 million. The AG recommends increasing the number of employees in tax units and issuing notices of assessment sooner to improve revenue collection. He also suggests barring tax dodgers from leaving the country and taking civil action against offenders.

site_title: Loyz Energy swings into the black in Q1
summary: Loyz Energy, an exploration and production energy firm, reported a net profit of US$541,000 in Q1 FY2015, more than tripling revenue to US$6.87 million. The company attributed the growth to its share of crude oil from its Thailand concessions. Gross profit rose to US$5.05 million, with earnings before interest and taxation (EBITDA) reaching US$4.54 million. The company plans to explore fund-raising options to enhance shareholder value and acquire producing oil and gas properties.

site_title: Australia lags on renewables as US, China race ahead
summary: Australia is falling behind China and the US in tackling climate change, with a 70% drop in renewable energy investment in 2014. The Climate Council report attributes this decline to the lack of clear federal government renewable energy policy under conservative Prime Minister Tony Abbott. In contrast, China and the US are leading the way in developing and investing in renewable energy, with other nations adopting carbon pricing schemes. Australia's climate action is under scrutiny ahead of the G-20 summit, with the need for increased ambition to reduce emissions.

site_title: Detergent pods dangerous for kids
summary: US researchers warn that laundry detergent pods are a danger to young children, with over 17,000 reported incidents of children under 6 being exposed to the chemicals in 2012-2013. The study comes as reports of kids swallowing the capsules continue to grow. Detergent pods, introduced in the US in 2010, are small enough to be a choking hazard and can cause serious harm if ingested. The study's findings highlight the need for improved safety measures and warnings to prevent further incidents.

site_title: UK lawmakers to consider shale gas sovereign wealth fund
summary: UK lawmakers will consider a plan to establish a sovereign wealth fund using revenues from shale gas, a potential energy source to offset North Sea production decline. The fund, announced by the government, aims to benefit future generations and support local economies, particularly in the north of England. The proposal includes £100,000 in compensation for communities near shale gas sites and a community fund based on developer revenue. The House of Lords will debate the plan as part of discussions on infrastructure legislation.

site_title: Spike in foreign currency bonds expected from S'pore banks
summary: Singapore banks are expected to increase foreign currency bond sales to fund their intra-regional expansion, driven by loan growth outpacing deposit inflows. Moody's Investors Service notes that Asean banks will increasingly turn to capital markets, particularly bonds, to fund lending operations. Singapore banks, such as OCBC Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank, have been active in tapping the foreign currency debt market to fund their growing trade finance business. Loan growth is expected to remain robust in the mid-teens in percentage terms, driven by infrastructure spending and regional expansion.

site_title: Xi meets Abe for first summit in over two years
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping met Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe for the first summit in over two years, aiming to repair ties between the two nations strained by territorial and historical disputes. The 25-minute meeting took place during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Beijing, marking Abe's first trip to China since taking office in 2012.

site_title: Business leaders force British PM to defend EU referendum plan
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron defended his plan to hold a referendum on European Union membership, despite opposition from business leaders, at the Confederation of British Industry's annual conference. Eight out of 10 CBI members support staying in the EU, and Cameron argued that a referendum is necessary for reform. Labour Party leader Ed Miliband criticized the idea, saying it would be destabilizing, while business leaders emphasized the importance of immigration for growth.

site_title: Obama's electoral loss may impact Asia trip
summary: US President Barack Obama's upcoming Asia trip, starting with a visit to Beijing, may be seen as a symbolic gesture following his electoral loss in the midterm elections. Other world leaders will view him as a lame duck president with limited clout, while domestic challenges in China, such as consolidating power and economic reforms, may lead President Xi Jinping to seek increased cooperation with the US. The trip will focus on key issues like the Trans-Pacific Partnership and regional security, but disagreements over trade and territorial disputes may hinder progress.

site_title: S Korea awaits verdict on Sewol ferry disaster
summary: South Korean officials await the verdict in the Sewol ferry disaster trial, where 15 defendants, including Captain Lee Jun-seok, face charges of mass murder and other crimes. Prosecutors seek life sentences for the chief engineer and first and second mates, while the remaining crew members face lesser charges. The trial has centered on the crew's alleged "wilful negligence" in failing to evacuate passengers, despite receiving emergency dispatchers' instructions. The outcome is expected to determine the fate of Lee and his senior officers, with families of victims calling for the death penalty.

site_title: HK High Court upholds street protest injunctions
summary: The Hong Kong High Court upheld injunctions against pro-democracy protesters, allowing court-appointed bailiffs to remove barricades in Mong Kok and Admiralty districts. The ruling may lead to violent clashes between police and protesters, who are in their seventh week of demonstrations. A poll showed 70% of respondents want the occupation to end, with the government stating it won't tolerate the protests for long. The decision follows stalled government talks and China's refusal to grant free elections in Hong Kong in 2017.

site_title: Patek Philippe marks 175 years
summary: Patek Philippe celebrated its 175th anniversary with a record-breaking auction in Geneva, selling 100 wrist and pocket watches for a total of $19.731,099. The rare pink gold item sold for $2.67 million, setting nine world records. The three-hour bidding battle saw the auction surpass its original estimate, showcasing the luxury watch brand's enduring success and commitment to excellence in timepieces.

site_title: Singapore can leverage a revived Silk Road
summary: Singapore is seen as a potential beneficiary of China's proposal to revive the Silk Road, given its role as a major transportation, logistics, and maritime hub. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed optimism about deeper cooperation with neighboring countries, particularly China, through the Silk Road initiative. Singapore hopes to provide services through its sea port and airport network, and encourage Chinese companies to set up operations in the country. The proposal is part of China's efforts to boost trade and maritime cooperation, and is seen as a counter to the influence of the US in the region.

site_title: Making the right suit to help save lives of Ebola fighters
summary: Biomedical engineers at Johns Hopkins University launched a design challenge to create a better protective suit for Ebola fighters, with the goal of saving lives. The challenge, which received over 60 applications, aimed to improve upon the existing suits that are often too hot, too big, and difficult to remove. A team of experts, including a wedding dress maker, Jill Andrews, combined their skills to create a one-size-fits-all suit with elastic and a simplified removal process, which is expected to be submitted to the US Agency for International Development for a potential $1 million award.

site_title: NZ home loan limits set to go gradually
summary: New Zealand's central bank is set to gradually phase out its year-old limits on high loan-to-value ratio lending, which restricts retail banks to 10% of new home loans for borrowers with less than 20% deposits. The move comes as tame inflation and a slower housing market reduce the need for the limits, which have helped ease inflation and housing market pressures. Annual house price inflation has fallen to 6% from 10% a year ago, and the limits were worth 25-50 basis points of interest rate rises.

site_title: Scientists share US$36m worth of prizes
summary: Scientists Simon White and Michael Turner, who discovered dark energy, have won the $36 million Breakthrough Prizes, the richest science prize. They previously shared a Nobel Prize and the $1 million Shaw Prize for their work. The Breakthrough Prizes recognize outstanding achievements in life sciences, physics, and mathematics.

images.alt_text: Mr Riess (above), Mr Schmidt and Mr Perlmutter are on one of the two teams of astronomers handed the US$3 million Fundamental Physics Prize for their work on dark energy.
Mr Riess, Mr Schmidt (above) and Mr Perlmutter are on one of the two teams of astronomers handed the US$3 million Fundamental Physics Prize for their work on dark energy.
Mr Riess, Mr Schmidt and Mr Perlmutter (above) are on one of the two teams of astronomers handed the US$3 million Fundamental Physics Prize for their work on dark energy.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Several Singaporean companies received upgrades from brokers, indicating potential long-term growth. Japfa Comfeed's "buy" rating was maintained due to strong demand for animal protein in Indonesia, with a target price of S$1.00. Innovalues was also upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$0.65, citing attractive yields and a turnaround thesis. CapitaLand's "add" rating was maintained with a target price of S$3.84, driven by expected growth in China and Singapore. The upgrades suggest potential upside for these companies.

site_title: Vallianz in US$36.09m asset deals with parent firm
summary: Vallianz Holdings has entered into two deals to acquire assets from its controlling shareholder Swiber Holdings for US$36.09 million. The deals include buying Newcruz International Pte Ltd for US$18.59 million and a 49% stake in PT Swiber Berjaya for US$17.5 million. The acquisitions aim to expand Vallianz's presence in the offshore marine industry, particularly in Indonesia's OSV market, with the potential to increase its earnings base.

site_title: Secret agent of the dark Web
summary: Lawrence Baldwin, a 49-year-old computer science graduate, has been secretly helping US financial institutions combat sophisticated hacking attacks. Despite his low profile, he has gained a reputation as a valuable consultant, providing actionable intelligence to banks such as JPMorgan Chase. Baldwin's methods involve immersing himself in the dark Web, gathering intelligence on online financial crime, and developing a network of contacts across industries. His work has been praised by security specialists, who describe him as a "secret agent" who provides original and effective intelligence. However, his methods raise concerns about personal safety and the use of information as evidence in criminal proceedings.

site_title: KL plans investment platform to expand role of Islamic banks
summary: The Malaysian government plans to launch a syaria-compliant investment platform, the Investment Account Platform (IAP), in 2025. Backed by an initial RM150 million start-up fund, the IAP will serve as a central marketplace to finance small and medium-sized businesses. The platform aims to broaden the role of Islamic banks from credit providers to investment intermediaries.

site_title: Hong Kong-Shanghai trading link to start on Nov 17
summary: A trading link between Hong Kong and Shanghai's stock exchanges will start on November 17, marking a key step towards China's financial liberalization. The "Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect" will allow international investors to trade selected stocks on Shanghai's exchange and let mainland investors buy shares in Hong Kong, with expected daily transactions of up to $3.8 billion. Analysts predict the move will boost market confidence and is a significant step towards opening China's yuan-denominated domestic market, known as the A-share market.

site_title: Trade agreement showdown at Beijing summit
summary: The US and China are engaged in a trade agreement showdown at the Beijing summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum. China hopes to propose a feasibility study on a Free Trade Agreement for the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP), while the US aims to conclude the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) to steal the thunder. If the TPP is concluded, the US will announce plans for a free trade area in the Pacific Rim, potentially undermining China's proposal. Alternatively, China may announce a "Beijing Road Map" for an FTA, building on Apec rather than the TPP.

site_title: Ascott bags five new management contracts in China
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence business, The Ascott, has secured five new management contracts in China, increasing its portfolio to 12,000 apartment units. The contracts cover properties in Yinchuan, Changsha, Shenyang, and Xi'an, with openings planned for 2018. The Ascott aims to reach 20,000 units in China by 2020, driven by China's growing economy.

site_title: Uber in early talks to raise a further US$1b
summary: Uber is in talks to raise a further US$1 billion to finance its international expansion, following a US$1.2 billion fundraising in June. The company, co-founded by Travis Kalanick, is seeking a higher valuation than the US$17 billion previously achieved. Uber operates in 220 cities worldwide and is expanding into logistics and other markets. The new funding would deepen resources for expansion and competition with rival Lyft Inc. Uber faces protests from established taxi and limousine industries and has hired David Plouffe, former Obama campaign manager, for policy and strategy.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat, energy shares jump
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, with energy shares outperforming the market as crude futures prices rose. The Dow Jones fell 6.42 points, the S&P 500 gained 1.15 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.13 points.

site_title: Long-term govt bonds see big returns
summary: US long-term government bonds have seen significant returns, with those due in 30 years increasing 20% this year, compared to 2.9% for five-year Treasuries. This has reduced the yield premium for 30-year securities to 1.46 percentage points, the lowest since 2009. Despite potential interest rate hikes, investors remain confident in these bonds, indicating reduced concerns about inflation and economic growth.

site_title: ASME lays groundwork with key MOUs
summary: ASME, the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises in Singapore, has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with American Express, allowing ASME to access 15,000 Amex merchants and expanding its reach among SMEs. The partnership will fund activities for SMEs in retail, online, and food and beverage businesses, enabling ASME to create a more targeted approach. This is the third MOU signed by ASME, following agreements with the Singapore Human Resources Institute and Singapore Ship Suppliers Association. The partnership aims to help SMEs strengthen and grow their businesses in Singapore.

site_title: Germany wants buffer for world's biggest banks nearer to 20%
summary: Germany is pushing for a 20% buffer for the world's largest banks to mitigate potential collapse, higher than the proposed 16-20% buffer by the Financial Stability Board. The buffer would apply to 30 systemically important global banks starting January 2019. This move aims to increase financial stability and prevent systemic risks.

site_title: Major economies should coordinate policy measures
summary: Major economies' disparate policy decisions suggest a "currency war" with disastrous consequences. The US dollar is likely to strengthen against the Japanese yen and euro, while emerging market currencies fall against the dollar. A lower oil price exacerbates global economic imbalances, including the US, China, and eurozone. The Japanese surplus is dwindling, and the global economy is out of sync with current account imbalances. Discrepant decisions by the Fed, ECB, and BOJ could lead to economic losses for all parties involved.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Giken Sakata plans to restructure under a new holding company, GSS Energy, through a one-for-one share swap, allowing for easier investment opportunities and capital raising. The move comes after the company's acquisition of Cepu Sakti Energy. The proposed scheme requires shareholder approval.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Reits cautious as rate hike looms
summary: Asia-Pacific Reits are growing cautious ahead of higher interest rates in 2015, following the US Federal Reserve's end of quantitative easing. The Standard & Poor's report notes that tighter monetary policies could impact Reits due to high interest expenses and reduced investor interest. However, S&P expects rated Reits to be better equipped, with superior portfolios and strong credit profiles. Reit managers are cutting interest burden by refinancing debt and extending loan tenors. Despite this, a cautious atmosphere remains, with some managers holding back on borrowing.

site_title: Keppel T&T pushes ahead with IPO of data centre Reit
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) is pushing ahead with the planned initial public offering (IPO) of its data centre real estate investment trust (DC Reit). The IPO is expected to raise approximately S$540 million and will list on the Singapore Exchange in early- to mid-December. The Reit's initial portfolio will comprise eight data centre properties in the Asia-Pacific and Europe. The listing is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the surge in demand for data centres driven by e-commerce, cloud computing, and big data, with a proposed yield of 7% and a market capitalization of around S$840 million.

site_title: ARA expects boost from Straits Trading alliance; Q3 profit up
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 60% increase in 3Q total revenue to S$52.8 million and a 53% increase in net profit to S$30.7 million. The boost was driven by higher recurrent management fees from Reits and acquisitions. ARA's assets under management rose to S$26.1 billion, with a new co-investment vehicle, Straits Real Estate, set up with a S$950 million capital commitment. Group CEO John Lim expects the alliance with The Straits Trading Company to contribute to further growth.

images.alt_text: Group CEO John Lim expects the firming up of the strategic alliance with The Straits Trading Company (STC) to contribute another leg of growth for ARA, in particular for its private funds platform.

site_title: It's no longer business as usual in China
summary: China is changing its business rules, forcing foreign companies to adapt or risk losing access to the world's second-largest economy. The country is scrutinizing companies for corruption, monopolistic practices, and tax evasion, with dozens of multinational firms facing fines. A recent pause in investigations has raised questions about China's priorities, with township governments continuing to raid local offices of foreign companies under old, vaguely worded laws. The Chinese government's increasing economic nationalism is expected to be debated at a major economic summit, with the US and other trading partners weighing their response to China's assertive stance.

site_title: Higher audit standards extended to public bodies
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has extended audit standards to public bodies, including charities, to meet the same independence standards as listed firms. The new rules, effective February 1, 2015, strengthen professional conduct and ethics guidelines for public accountants and accounting firms. The changes aim to safeguard audit independence and ensure public accountants remain a trusted source of information and advice, serving the public interest with integrity and independence.

site_title: China inflation hovers near 5-year low
summary: China's annual consumer inflation remained near a five-year low in October at 1.6%, reinforcing expectations of further measures to support growth. The producer price index fell 2.2% from a year ago, its 32nd consecutive decline, as sluggish demand curbed pricing power. Analysts predict China's policymakers will continue rolling out stimulus measures, with potential interest rate cuts if conditions deteriorate. The government's official 2014 growth target of 7.5% is at risk due to signs of economic momentum loss despite earlier stimulus measures.

site_title: China Sky earns 9.3m yuan in Q3 after year-ago loss
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co posted a 9.3 million yuan (S$1.96 million) net profit for the fiscal third quarter ended Sept 30, 2014, as revenue dropped 19.9% but sales costs improved. This marks an improvement from a year-ago loss of 29.1 million yuan. The company's 9-month net profit stood at 73.8 million yuan, against an 82 million yuan net loss in 2013. Earnings per share also increased to 1.15 renminbi cents.

site_title: Boeing wins US$8.5b SMBC Aviation order on growing Asian jet demand
summary: Boeing has secured a US$8.5 billion order from Japanese lessor SMBC Aviation Capital Ltd for 80 737 Max 8 models, set for delivery between 2018 and 2022. This is the largest single order of 737 Maxs by a lessor, following a similar deal by SMBC to purchase US$11.8 billion of aircraft from Airbus in July. Asian aircraft-leasing companies are betting on growing demand for new planes as economic growth in China, India, and South-east Asia stokes the market, with Boeing predicting China will overtake the US as the world's largest plane market in two decades.

site_title: Share buybacks this year close to 2012/13's combined total
summary: Singapore-listed companies are nearing a combined share buyback total of S$526.6 million this year, surpassing the 2012-2013 combined total. As of November 10, 107 companies have bought back 422.8 million shares, a 0.3% increase from 2013. Major buyers include OCBC Bank and Singapore Airlines, which have acquired S$124.2 million and S$121.8 million of their own shares, respectively. Analysts say share buybacks can be positive for shareholders, but warn of potential limitations and timing issues.

site_title: Obama: Momentum building for 'historic' trans-Pacific trade deal
summary: US President Barack Obama said momentum is building for a historic trans-Pacific trade deal, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), during his visit to Beijing. The deal, involving 12 countries, aims to liberalize trade in the Asia-Pacific region. Obama welcomed China's prosperity and acknowledged the country's push for a separate trade framework, the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific. Despite initial speculation of a major announcement, officials ruled out a major TPP announcement in Beijing, instead focusing on the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: M'sia GDP forecast to grow amid debt concerns
summary: Malaysia's GDP is forecast to grow between 5.8% and 6% in 2014 and 2015, driven by domestic demand and a recovery in exports. However, concerns over the country's high government and household debt levels, particularly that of sovereign wealth fund 1MDB, have sparked alarm. 1MDB recorded a loss of RM665 million in 2014, raising questions about its RM38 billion in debt. Despite this, Malaysia's total debt is around 70% of GDP, and its international reserves are over US$138 billion, deemed healthy by rating agencies.

site_title: London property firm's restaurant strategy pays off
summary: London property firm Shaftesbury has seen success with its restaurant strategy, boosting demand at shops on its properties. The company's approach involves partnering with successful eateries, creating a buzz and attracting customers to neighboring stores. Shaftesbury's villages, such as Carnaby and Covent Garden, feature a mix of shops, restaurants, and offices, with the company granting leases of 10-15 years to independent operators. This strategy allows the company to avoid committing to chains and maintain a unique tenant mix, drawing customers in and keeping them engaged. The approach has been successful, with increasing customer traffic and a "one-way bet" for landlords.

site_title: Redbox to open 2 more outlets in Singapore
summary: Redbox, a low-cost courier by AirAsia, is set to open two more outlets in Singapore as part of its expansion across the region. The company, which already operates in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Nepal, and Vietnam, plans to open additional locations in Indonesia, India, Thailand, Taiwan, Brunei, Australia, Korea, and Japan. This expansion is part of phase two, with phase three expected to wrap up by June 2015.

site_title: Putin confident of stable ruble, bank sets intervention limit
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed confidence that the ruble will soon stabilize, despite losing nearly a quarter of its value this year. The Bank of Russia said it will intervene only if financial stability is threatened, following a surge in capital flight due to Western sanctions. The central bank removed its fixed exchange rate range, allowing the ruble to float freely, but remains prepared to intervene if necessary. Analysts caution that tensions in eastern Ukraine and market volatility may test the central bank's resolve.

site_title: Super Group Q3 profit dives 47%
summary: Super Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage producer, reported a 47% drop in net profit for the third quarter to S$9.98 million, due to rising raw material costs and stiffer competition. Revenue dipped 3% to S$129.5 million, and the gross profit margin fell to 32%. Despite a 6% decline in branded consumer products sales, food ingredients sales increased 3% driven by non-dairy creamer sales. The company expects market conditions to remain competitive in the fourth quarter and plans to focus on geographical market expansion and product innovation.

site_title: Drugmakers turn focus to fatty liver, hepatitis B treatments
summary: Drugmakers are shifting focus to treating fatty liver and hepatitis B, with potential annual sales of up to $10 billion. Several companies, including Gilead Sciences, Intercept Pharmaceuticals, and Genfit, are working on treatments for these conditions, which can be controlled but not yet cured. Fatty liver disease, also known as nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), affects up to 30% of US adults and can progress to cirrhosis and potentially cancer. Gilead's simtuzumab has shown promise in reversing cirrhosis, with Phase II data expected next year.

site_title: Obama, Putin have "brief encounter" on Beijing summit sidelines
summary: US President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin had a brief, informal conversation on the sidelines of the APEC summit in Beijing, but didn't discuss main issues due to time constraints. The White House has stated there are no plans for formal face-to-face talks between the two leaders at the summit or the upcoming G20 meeting in Brisbane.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng's overall profits decline due to lack of property contributions
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's food and beverage segment reported a net profit of S$3.15 million for the three months ended Sept 30, a 86% decline from the previous year due to lack of property contributions and low disposal gains. Revenue dropped 11% to S$114.7 million, with core F&B revenue increasing 3% to S$113.4 million. The company expects earnings pressure due to rising raw material and energy costs, as well as intense competition. Its available-for-sale financial assets slid in value to S$166.4 million.

site_title: Obama says new rules should keep 'open Internet'
summary: US President Barack Obama voiced support for "free and open Internet" rules, calling for the Federal Communications Commission to implement strongest possible rules to protect net neutrality. The rules should prevent broadband providers from blocking or throttling certain services, and prohibit "paid prioritization" and throttling. Obama wants the rules to apply to mobile broadband and reclassify consumer broadband service as a public utility, a move opposed by industry sectors. The FCC is redrafting its rules after a court decision struck down its regulations, and consumer activists hail Obama's statement as a step towards promoting an open Internet.

site_title: India plans new push at airport sell-off
summary: India's new government plans to privatise four airports and list the state-owned airport operator on the stock market as part of a draft set of reforms aimed at boosting growth in the aviation sector. The move is expected to aid India's position as one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets, with millions of Indians flying each year. The government hopes to expand airports and improve air connectivity in remote areas to speed up the growth process.

site_title: Asian growth rescues Carlsberg from slumping Russia earnings
summary: Carlsberg A/S reported steady earnings in the third quarter, with operating profit reaching 3.39 billion crowns, despite a 15% revenue decline in Russia due to currency effects. However, Asian growth, particularly in China, offset the decline, with revenue rising 61% and beer volume increasing 35%. The company maintained its full-year forecast of low- to mid-single-digit percentage growth in organic operating profit, citing efficiency savings in Russia and Europe.

images.alt_text: Danish brewer Carlsberg A/S said earnings had held steady in the third quarter, as Asian growth offset the Russian downturn which prompted it to lower profit forecasts twice earlier this year.

site_title: News of HK-China connect boosts STI
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 14.61 points to 3,301 on Monday, driven by a large push on three banks and Noble Group, with DBS's 1.6% surge contributing 6 points. The news of Hong Kong's cross-border link with Shanghai set to go live on Nov 17 boosted the Hang Seng Index, which jumped 2% in the morning. The link is expected to create the world's third-largest equity market with a US$5.6 trillion single market capitalization.

site_title: China interested in Singapore-Malaysia high-speed rail, Chile ports: Xinhua
summary: China expresses interest in building a Malaysia-Singapore high-speed rail link and participating in Chilean and Australian railway and port projects. Premier Li Keqiang stated China's willingness to "actively participate" in the Singapore-Malaysia rail project and support firms in investing in Australia's railway and airport projects. China also plans to contribute $40 billion to a Silk Road infrastructure fund and has unveiled a $50 billion China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: Silverlake Axis declares 0.8 Singapore cent dividend as Q1 profit rises 17%
summary: Silverlake Axis has declared a 0.8 Singapore cent interim dividend after its Q1 net profit rose 17% to RM59.7 million, driven by robust demand for software services. Revenue grew 15% to RM116.3 million, with software licensing increasing 84% to RM38 million. Maintenance and enhancement services remained the largest segment, with a 22% revenue growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.74 points to close at 1,827.93 on Monday, driven by gains of 348 stocks while 482 stocks declined. Total trading volume reached 2.66 billion lots, valued at RM1.98 billion.

site_title: Nearly third of Indian cabinet charged with crimes, despite Modi pledge
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cabinet expansion has included seven ministers with criminal charges, taking nearly one-third of the 66-member cabinet to face prosecution. At least five cabinet members are accused of serious offenses such as rape and rioting. Critics argue that Modi's pledge to clean up politics has been undermined by the appointment of tainted politicians, citing a higher proportion of lawmakers facing charges than in the past. The inclusion of such politicians has led to criticism that Modi is failing to change India's corrupt political culture.

images.alt_text: Attempted murder, waging war on the state, criminal intimidation and fraud are some of the charges on the rap sheets of ministers Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi appointed to the cabinet on Sunday, jarring with his pledge to clean up politics.

site_title: Japan PM Abe's approval rating sags amid talk of snap election
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's approval rating has dropped to 44% in a public opinion poll, the lowest since his government began two years ago, amid speculation of a snap election. The decline follows two cabinet members' resignations over scandals and Abe's consideration of delaying a planned sales tax increase. A majority of respondents (76%) believe no election is needed, and 74% want the tax increase to be delayed or scrapped. Abe must decide on the sales tax by the end of the year.

site_title: Bank of Russia sees sanctions remaining until end of 2017
summary: The Bank of Russia predicts zero economic growth in 2015 and 0.1% growth in 2016 due to Western sanctions and falling oil prices. The central bank expects capital investment to fall by 3.1% and inflation to reach 6.2-6.4%, exceeding its 4.5% goal. The bank forecasts net private sector capital outflows to reach $128 billion this year and $99 billion in 2015, with the ruble expected to remain volatile. Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed confidence in the ruble's stability, blaming speculation for its volatility.

site_title: ARA Asset Management's revenue, earnings sharply up in Q3
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 60% increase in Q3 revenue to S$52.8 million, driven by higher management fees from Reits with better performance and acquisitions. Net profit rose 53% to S$30.7 million. The company attributed the growth to acquisition, divestment, and performance fees, totaling S$16.3 million. ARA is managing eight Reits and seven private funds.

site_title: Japan's 'Butter refugees' cry over spilt milk
summary: Japan is experiencing a severe butter shortage, with some grocers limiting sales to one block per customer due to a shortage of raw milk. The problem is attributed to a hot summer that left cows exhausted, and dairy farmers are prioritizing liquid milk production over butter. To address the shortage, the government imported 10,000 tons of butter in May and September, but stockpiles are down 30% from last year, indicating a shortage trend. Farmers are reluctant to raise milk production due to soaring feed prices and concerns about the dairy industry's future.

site_title: Banks face extra US$8 bln of IT costs for risk control: study
summary: Banks are expected to spend over $8 billion in the next six years to improve technology platforms and manage risk, according to a Sungard research paper. The costs will peak at $2 billion in 2017, mainly incurred by smaller banks. The move comes after the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision set higher standards for risk management, which smaller banks must meet from 2016. The increased spending will also benefit major insurance companies.

site_title: Asean bank bond issuances set to grow; Singapore lenders have increasing foreign currency funding needs
summary: ASEAN banks are expected to increase bond issuances to fund lending operations, driven by loan growth outpacing deposit inflows. Singapore lenders, in particular, have increasing foreign-currency funding needs due to their intra-regional expansion. Outstanding bonds and borrowings by rated Asean banks rose 71% to $168 billion at end-2013, with loan-to-deposit ratios reaching 90% at most banks. Singapore banks' LDR ratio has been steadily rising, with some banks facing elevated foreign-currency funding needs.

site_title: UK lawmakers to consider shale gas sovereign wealth fund
summary: Britain's House of Lords will consider a plan to create a sovereign wealth fund using revenues from shale gas, which the government hopes will offset North Sea energy decline. The fund, expected to be focused on the north of England, aims to benefit communities and future generations. The government has already promised 100,000 pounds in compensation to communities near shale gas sites, as well as a community fund based on developer revenue. The move aims to boost energy production and offset environmental concerns surrounding the extraction method.

site_title: Singapore's Temasek buys 10.16% stake in India's Intas Pharma
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings has acquired a 10.16% stake in Indian pharmaceutical company Intas Pharmaceuticals through a secondary purchase of shares from ChrysCapital. The deal was not disclosed in terms of financials. This investment marks Temasek's latest move to expand its portfolio in the Indian market, following a previous agreement to invest over US$80 million in the Indian food and beverage industry.

site_title: US wants China 'to do well', Obama says in announcing visa deal
summary: US President Barack Obama announced a visa deal with China, allowing Chinese visitors to stay in the US for up to 10 years, and extended student visas to 5 years. The deal aims to boost tourism and economic ties between the two countries, with the US welcoming China's rise as a prosperous and stable nation. However, Obama also raised concerns over China's tightly controlled exchange rate, human rights, and media freedoms, emphasizing the need for China to create a more level playing field for foreign companies and respect these rights.

site_title: Execs in Asian luxury hotels fall prey to cyber-espionage: study
summary: A Kaspersky Lab report reveals a sophisticated industrial espionage campaign targeting Asian luxury hotel guests using in-room wireless connections, claiming thousands of victims since 2009. Executives from various industries, including auto, manufacturing, and military services, have been hit. The attackers track victims' movements, downloading malware through hotel Wi-Fi networks. Ninety percent of victims come from five countries: Japan, Taiwan, China, Russia, and South Korea. The attacks appear to be linked to a larger hotel network compromise, with Kaspersky continuing to investigate.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 14.61 points to 3,301.00. Traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally, while the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The STI had previously risen 0.4% on Thursday, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Indonesia retail sales growth rises to 17.9% y-o-y in Sept
summary: Indonesia's retail sales growth surged to 17.9% in September, driven by sales of information and communications equipment. The growth is expected to continue in October, supported by increased purchasing capacity. However, price pressures are anticipated to persist due to concerns about a state-set fuel price hike. Businesses forecast a decrease in annual sales growth over the next six months.

site_title: Sim Lian Q1 profit soars to S$71.66m from S$27.68m
summary: Sim Lian Group reported a net profit of S$71.66 million for Q1 2014, up from S$27.68 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased to S$379.02 million, with property development revenue nearly tripling to S$297.23 million. Earnings per share rose to 7.1 Singapore cents and net asset value per share stood at S$1.05. The company expects to achieve profitable operating results for FY2015.

site_title: US, China to extend visa validity to boost trade, tourism
summary: US President Barack Obama announced an agreement with China to extend the validity of short-term visas for 10 years, from one year, to boost trade and tourism between the two countries. This deal, effective November 12, will allow Chinese nationals to stay in the US for up to 10 years for tourism and business, and up to 5 years for study. The move aims to increase Chinese tourism to the US, creating jobs and injecting billions of dollars into the economy, with estimates suggesting 440,000 new jobs by 2021.

site_title: Vietnam sells US$1b in sovereign bonds, sees strong global demand
summary: Vietnam sold US$1 billion in sovereign bonds at an annual coupon of 4.8%, beating its initial target. Foreign investors bid US$10.6 billion, with most allocations going to US investors (55%) and European buyers (28%). The proceeds will be used to swap government debts issued in 2005 and 2010. The bonds were assigned a provisional rating of (P)B1 by Moody's, maintaining the country's stable outlook.

site_title: Strike-hit Lonmin sets investment hurdles in bid to return to profit
summary: Lonmin, a South African platinum miner, reported a pre-tax loss of $326 million for the year to September, citing the impact of a five-month strike. The company will invest only in projects providing a return above 15% and may shut down the Hossy shaft, citing unaffordable capital requirements. This move casts doubt on the future of the shaft and some other mines, as the company targets higher returns to return to profit.

site_title: Obama says momentum building on "historic" trans-Pacific trade deal
summary: US President Barack Obama expressed optimism about building momentum for the historic Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) during a visit to Beijing, where he met with Chinese President Xi Jinping and other TPP leaders. The agreement, which has been stalled due to disagreements with Japan, has the potential to spur greater economic growth and jobs, but faces challenges from China's push for a separate trade framework and skepticism from some Asian allies. Obama sees progress in resolving outstanding issues, but his visit comes amid a weakened political position at home following midterm congressional defeats.

site_title: Putin says China, Russia to settle more trade in yuan
summary: Russia and China plan to increase trade settlement in yuan, aiming to reduce the dollar's influence in international trade. President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia and China intend to use national currencies in mutual transactions, including rouble and yuan. This move is seen as part of China's efforts to boost the yuan's global influence and reduce investment risks in the US dollar. Putin also vowed to keep Russia's foreign debt below 15% of GDP, amid concerns over the rouble's decline due to plunging oil prices and sanctions.

site_title: Japan's SMBC eyes 80 Boeing planes in up to US$8.7b deal: report
summary: Japanese aircraft leasing giant SMBC Aviation Capital plans to buy 80 Boeing 737 MAX 8 jets worth up to $8.7 billion, according to a report. The deal is expected to be finalized by 2022 and would increase SMBC's fleet to over 450 planes. The move is attributed to the growing demand in the budget carrier sector. SMBC Aviation has already ordered 115 Airbus A320s worth $11.7 billion and this deal is expected to be announced in Tokyo on Monday.

site_title: Editor's Note
summary: Singapore has surpassed its original vision as a regional hub for wealth management, with a survey by PwC predicting it will eventually surpass London and Switzerland. The country's wealth management sector has grown significantly since 2002, with assets under management increasing from S$570 million to over S$1.8 trillion in 2013. Despite challenges posed by the 2008 financial crisis, experts, including Ng Kok Song, chair of global investments at the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, remain confident in the sector's growth prospects, driven by global economic growth and Asia's increasing wealth creation.

site_title: Asian stocks mixed, link date lifts Hong Kong and Shanghai
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday, with Japanese shares falling 0.59% due to profit-taking, while Hong Kong and Shanghai rallied after a delayed trading link between their stock exchanges was announced for November 17. The US dollar retreated from multi-year highs, and the Dow and S&P 500 ended with record closes despite weaker-than-expected job growth. Inflation in China remained unchanged at 1.6% in October, adding to concerns about the country's economy.

site_title: Netherlands marks MH17 victims with memorial ceremony
summary: The Netherlands holds a national memorial ceremony for the 298 victims of the downed Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which crashed over Ukraine in July 2014. The ceremony, attended by 1,600 bereaved families, King Willem Alexander, and Prime Minister Mark Rutte, honors the 193 Dutch victims. The names of all victims will be read out, and a minute's silence will be observed. The ceremony comes as international investigators continue to investigate the crash, with Ukraine and the West attributing the cause to a BUK surface-to-air missile supplied by Russia, while Moscow denies the charges.

site_title: China October trade data shows signs of manipulation, hot money inflows: state newspaper
summary: China's October trade data shows exports rose 11.6% and imports rose 4.6%, resulting in a near-record trade surplus of $45.4 billion. Economists suspect manipulation and hot money inflows, citing rapid growth in trade with ASEAN nations, South Korea, and Hong Kong. Firms may be over-invoicing trade deals to evade capital controls. The data raises concerns about the accuracy of previous reports, which showed similar discrepancies in September.

site_title: Japan-China summit 'first step' to better ties: Abe
summary: Japan and China have taken the "first step" towards improving relations after a half-hour summit between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and President Xi Jinping in Beijing. The two countries have been strained due to a territorial dispute over the Senkaku islands and Japan's 20th-century treatment of China. The summit marked the first face-to-face meeting since Abe came to power and the first in three years. Abe and Xi agreed to implement a maritime communication mechanism and prevent the situation from aggravating through dialogue and consultation.

site_title: Russian central bank expects Western sanctions to remain until end of 2017
summary: The Russian central bank expects Western sanctions to remain until the end of 2017, impacting its 2015 and 2016 growth forecasts. It anticipates zero economic growth in 2015 and 0.1% growth in 2016. The bank also forecasts a long-term downward trend in the Urals oil price, averaging $95 in 2015 and $90 by 2017, constraining economic growth. This downward trend will continue to affect the Russian economy due to the sanctions.

images.alt_text: The Russian central bank said on Monday that it expects zero economic growth in 2015 and only 0.1 per cent growth in 2016, in a three-year monetary policy strategy that anticipates Western sanctions against Russia will remain until the end of 2017.

site_title: China eyes corruption extradition treaty with Australia: report
summary: Australia is considering an extradition treaty with China to assist Beijing in repatriating corrupt officials, as part of a declaration against corruption at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting in Beijing. The treaty would be in response to China's "Fox Hunt" campaign, which aims to repatriate corrupt officials and their family members who have moved abroad. The move comes as China's President Xi Jinping has made anti-corruption a central theme of his administration. Transparency International has called on G20 leaders to address corruption and end financial secrecy.

site_title: Consumer confidence in Singapore climbs to three-year high: Nielsen survey
summary: Consumer confidence in Singapore has reached a three-year high, surpassing 100 points in Q3 2024, according to Nielsen's Consumer Confidence Index. The index rose due to a 8% increase in consumers feeling positive about job prospects and a 4% rise in outlook on personal finances. 59% of Singaporeans expect their finances to be good or excellent in the coming year. The boost in consumer confidence is attributed to strong underlying factors, including clarity on the political front and economic factors. This marks the first time Singapore's consumer confidence has exceeded 100 points since 2011.

site_title: New Zealand central bank home loan limits set to go, gradually
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) plans to gradually phase out its year-old limits on high loan-to-value ratio lending, which restricted retail banks to 10% of new home loans for borrowers with deposits of less than 20% of a property's value. The limits were implemented to cool a hot housing market and have been deemed effective in reducing inflation and housing market pressures. The RBNZ will outline its plan in a financial stability report on November 12, with some analysts suggesting the limits could be raised to 15-20% of lending to prevent a potential rebound.

site_title: India's Modi names yoga minister in major reshuffle
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has appointed a yoga minister in a major reshuffle of his government, aiming to promote the ancient practice. As part of the revamp, 21 new ministers were appointed, including one for the AAYUSH ministry, which will focus on promoting traditional medicines and practices like Ayurveda and yoga. The move is part of Modi's efforts to speed up reforms and revive the faltering economy.

site_title: South Korea says effective trade deal reached with China
summary: South Korea has reached an effective free trade agreement with China, removing tariffs on over 90% of goods. The deal, reached during a meeting between President Park Geun-Hye and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC summit, will remove tariffs on 92% of Chinese goods and 91% of South Korean goods within 20 years. The agreement, pending final details, aims to boost bilateral trade to $300 billion in 2015 and increase cooperation in services, investment, and culture.

site_title: 'Milestone' Hong Kong, Shanghai stock link to launch
summary: A trading link between Hong Kong and Shanghai's stock exchanges will launch on November 17, marking a key step in China's financial liberalization. The Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect will allow international investors to trade selected stocks on Shanghai's tightly restricted exchange and mainland investors to buy shares in Hong Kong, with daily transactions expected to reach $3.8 billion. The move is seen as a milestone in liberalizing China's capital account and will boost market confidence, with analysts predicting significant volumes and profits for companies involved.

site_title: Super Group's Q3 net profit nearly halved
summary: Super Group reported a 47% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$9.98 million for the third quarter ended Sept 30, due to lower branded consumer sales and declining revenue to S$129.5 million. Branded consumer sales fell 6% to S$82.03 million, while food ingredients sales increased 3% to S$47.48 million. The decline in sales led to a decrease in earnings per share to 0.89 Singapore cents, down from 1.68 cents previously.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to build US$3b smartphone plant in Vietnam
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest US$3 billion in building a second smartphone factory in northern Vietnam's Thai Nguyen province, following its existing US$2 billion plant. The move aims to reduce costs and compete with low-priced Chinese rivals. This investment brings Samsung's total pledges in Vietnam to around US$11 billion this year. The company's first factory generated US$1.9 billion in export revenue in its first four months of operation, with export revenue reaching US$19.2 billion in the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: New joust over sea dispute expected at ASEAN
summary: The South China Sea dispute is expected to escalate at the upcoming ASEAN summit in Myanmar, with rival claims between China, Vietnam, and the Philippines set to dominate discussions. China's naval patrols and oil rig positioning in disputed waters have sparked tensions, while US President Barack Obama is expected to highlight US leadership in addressing maritime territorial disputes. Analysts are skeptical of a tangible deal, citing China's preference for bilateral talks and its massive economic and political leverage in the region. The issue is seen as a complex game of diplomatic and military competition between Washington and Beijing.

site_title: Japan-China icebreaker summit begins in Beijing: media
summary: A summit between Japan and China began in Beijing on November 10, 2014, after years of animosity over a territorial dispute and Japan's 20th-century treatment of China. The dispute centers on the Senkaku Islands, which Japan controls but China claims as the Diaoyus. The two sides issued finely worded statements before the summit, which both emphasized their positions. This marks the first summit between the two nations in three years.

site_title: China, South Korea FTA to cover 17 areas: Xinhua
summary: China and South Korea signed a free trade agreement covering 17 areas, including e-commerce and government purchasing. The deal aims to boost bilateral trade, which reached $228.9 billion in 2013, accounting for 21% of South Korea's total trade. The agreement is expected to strengthen economic ties between the two countries, with China being South Korea's largest trading partner.

site_title: China criminal gang floods market with 100 tonnes of toxic tofu
summary: A Chinese criminal gang has sold over 100 tonnes of toxic tofu, containing the banned industrial bleaching agent rongalite, onto the local market in Shandong and nearby provinces. The gang, led by three cousins, added the chemical to make dried tofu sticks, which are a popular snack in China. Authorities detained four men and seized nearly 10 tonnes of toxic tofu, but a further 100 tonnes had already been sold. Fortunately, no one has reported illness from eating the affected products. This incident highlights the challenges in controlling supply chains in China's food industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.28 points to 1824.47. The index saw 251.2 million lots traded worth RM112.9 million, with 165 gainers outnumbering 104 losers.

site_title: GM ordered new switches months before recall: WSJ
summary: General Motors ordered half a million replacement ignition switches in December 2013, nearly two months before alerting federal safety regulators, according to an email exchange with supplier Delphi Automotive. The recall, announced in February 2014, affected 2.6 million vehicles linked to fatalities and injuries. The delay has sparked criticism, with plaintiffs claiming GM should have notified customers immediately to prevent harm. A federal judge has set a trial for January 11, 2016, to address consolidated litigation over GM's safety issues, including the faulty ignition switch.

site_title: Hong Kong court orders psychiatric reports on UK banker
summary: A Hong Kong court has adjourned the case of Rurik Jutting, a 29-year-old British banker accused of murdering two Indonesian women, Seneng Mujiasih and Sumarti Ningsih, whose bodies were found at his apartment. The court ordered two psychiatric reports to assess Jutting's fitness to plead. Jutting, a former Bank of America Merrill Lynch employee, will remain in custody and will next appear on November 24. Prosecutors and defence lawyers discussed the possibility of a crime reconstruction and video recordings of police interviews with Jutting.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 20.17 points to 3,306.56. Gainers outnumbered losers 139 to 64. The rally follows a 5-day winning streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China says inflation unchanged at 1.6% in October
summary: China's inflation remained unchanged at 1.6% in October, the lowest point since January 2010, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. The consumer price index rose 2.1% year-over-year in the first 10 months of the year, falling short of the government's 3.5% target. This data suggests China's economic growth is slowing, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: MeTech International posts S$1.4 million loss for Q1 FY2015
summary: MeTech International reported a Q1 FY2015 loss of S$1.4 million, a significant decline from a profit of S$46,000 in the same quarter a year prior. Revenue rose 15.6% to S$9.89 million, driven by increased contributions from its Singapore operations. The company attributed the loss to lower margins due to challenging business climates in Singapore and the US, with gross margin declining from 18.8% to 1.9%.

site_title: SIA and Tourism Australia ink three-year, A$12 million marketing agreement
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has signed a three-year, A$12 million marketing agreement with Tourism Australia to jointly promote tourism in seven major inbound markets, including Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, India, China, Germany, and the UK. The partnership will focus on SIA being the exclusive airline partner for Restaurant Australia campaigns in key markets and providing international flights for a Tourism Australia event in Adelaide.
