The deal aims to increase tourism to Australia from Singapore, which is expected to grow to A$2.3 billion by 2020.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Tourism Australia are strengthening their existing partnership with a new, three-year marketing deal worth A$12 million (S$13.4 million).

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.72%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.72% lower on Monday, following the dollar's weakness against the yen after a mixed US jobs report. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 122.11 points to 16,758.27. Profit-taking is attributed to the dollar's decline, which had previously supported market gains.

site_title: Australia lags on renewable energy as China races ahead
summary: Australia is falling behind China and the US in addressing climate change, with a 70% decline in renewable energy investment in 2014, according to the Climate Council report. The country's lack of clear renewable energy policy and resistance to carbon pricing schemes have led to investment shifting overseas. Despite plans to reduce emissions by 5% below 2000 levels by 2020, experts urge Australia to increase its ambitions, aiming for a 40% reduction in new emissions by 2025, citing a need to keep pace with global leaders in renewable energy development.

site_title: N Korea's release of Americans shows Kim feeling pressure: analysts
summary: North Korea's release of two detained American citizens, Kenneth Bae and Matthew Miller, has been seen as a response to international pressure, particularly from US President Barack Obama and international sanctions over its nuclear program. The move is believed to be a strategic move by Kim Jong Un's regime to ease sanctions and block a potential ICC trial for human rights abuses. The release is also seen as a way for North Korea to reinforce Obama's position and pave the way for future talks on the nuclear issue, with analysts suggesting that the timing is a result of concern over Republican-led sanctions in January.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rally on FTA agreement with China; won higher after US jobs data
summary: South Korean shares rose over 1% on Monday after China and South Korea reached a free trade agreement, boosting hopes for a windfall to the country's economy. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) climbed 1.27% to 1,964.50 points, with Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor leading the gains. The South Korean won also firmed against the dollar, snapping a 7-day losing streak. The agreement is expected to add 0.92-1.25% to South Korea's GDP in 5 years, primarily benefiting shipping and automobile-related firms.

site_title: Singapore's Code of Ethics for public accountants to be amended from Feb 1, 2015
summary: Singapore's Code of Ethics for public accountants is set to be amended starting February 1, 2015, with the aim of strengthening independence standards and guidelines. The proposed changes include extending independence requirements to all audits and reviews of public interest entities, large charities, and large institutions, as well as new requirements for auditors. The review was conducted by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) with the support of the Ethics Sub-Committee, and the changes are aligned with international benchmarks.

images.alt_text: The Code of Professional Conduct and Ethics for public accountants and accounting entities will be strengthened further from Feb 1 next year.

site_title: Vallianz plans to buy Swiber's 49% stake in Indonesian chartering firm for US$17.5m
summary: Vallianz Holdings Limited plans to acquire a 49% stake in Indonesian chartering firm PT Swiber Berjaya (PTSB) for US$17.5 million. The acquisition will give Vallianz entry into Indonesia's offshore support vessel market. PTSB operates 18 OSVs and has plans to add four more. The deal will be satisfied by a combination of perpetual securities and new Vallianz shares. After the acquisition, Swiber will retain a 23.36% stake in Vallianz through its existing holding.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble hits S$1.30 after Q3 results
summary: Noble Group's shares rose to S$1.30 after reporting strong Q3 results, with net profit surging to US$153.9 million from US$22.9 million a year ago. The firm attributed the growth to higher trading volumes and a turnaround profit on its supply chain assets. The stock was the second most heavily traded by volume, with 18.73 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Landmark Hong Kong-China stock trading scheme to start Nov 17: HKEX
summary: A landmark stock trading scheme connecting Hong Kong and China's stock exchanges is set to launch on November 17. The Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) announced the delay of the initial October start date. The scheme, part of China's capital market liberalization, will allow global investors to trade Chinese stocks from Hong Kong and mainland investors to access the Hong Kong stock market.

site_title: Deal makers, private equity employees may get biggest bonus hikes this year
summary: Deal makers and private equity employees on Wall Street are expected to receive a 10-15% rise in bonuses this year, according to a forecast by Johnson Associates. This would be the largest bonus hike for these professionals, despite a mostly flat year-end incentive payment compared to last year. The consulting firm attributed the mixed fortunes to a moderately positive year across the financial services industry.

site_title: Keppel T&T proposes listing of Keppel DC Reit
summary: Keppel T&T plans to list Keppel DC Reit on the Singapore Exchange, seeking shareholder approval for the listing and divestment of its interests in several data centres. The initial portfolio will comprise eight data centre properties in Asia-Pacific and Europe, managed by a wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel T&T. The listing is subject to regulatory approvals and conditions, with Keppel Land planning to divest its indirect 30% stakes in two leasehold interests to Keppel DC Reit, resulting in net proceeds of around S$96 million.

site_title: TPP possible by early next year: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Long says the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) may be concluded by early next year despite some technical issues still being ironed out. The 12-country agreement, which includes the US, Australia, and New Zealand, aims to promote trade liberalization and competition. Meanwhile, China is backing the study of a free trade area for the Asia-Pacific region, with Singapore supporting the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB).

site_title: Asian stocks mixed, link date lifts Hong Kong and Shanghai
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai rallying after a delayed trading link between their exchanges was announced. Tokyo slipped 0.51% and Sydney dipped 0.64%, while Seoul rose 1.20%. The US dollar retreated from multi-year highs despite a record close on Wall Street, driven by upbeat jobs data. Chinese inflation remained steady at 1.6%, adding to concerns about the country's economy. The US stock market ended with a third straight record close, with the Dow and S&P 500 edging up, while the Nasdaq eased.

site_title: Singapore casinos brace for battle as VIP volumes fall
summary: Singapore's two major casinos, Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, are facing a decline in high-rolling players due to China's economic slowdown and corruption crackdown. The number of VIP visitors from China, which accounts for around 50% of their combined gaming revenues, has fallen 30% to 871,000 in the first half of 2014. Las Vegas Sands and Genting Singapore have responded by offering credit and incentives, but the issue of credit collection remains a challenge for the casinos. Fitch Ratings has predicted that Singapore gaming revenue will contract slightly in 2014 due to these factors.

site_title: Dollar up 3rd week running, yen hits 7-year low
summary: The dollar rose for a third consecutive week, reaching a 7-year low against the yen at 114.60 and a 2% gain against the euro. The European Central Bank held rates steady and expanded its balance sheet, while the Bank of Japan pledged unlimited easing measures to combat deflation. Emerging markets currencies fell, with 23 of 24 developing nations sliding versus the dollar. Hedge funds increased bets on a decline in the euro against the dollar, with a net short of 179,021.

site_title: Keppel tour for Prince of Monaco
summary: Prince Albert II of Monaco took a tour onboard a FPSO being converted by Keppel Shipyard for SBM Offshore. The tour was led by Keppel's CEO Mr. Chow Yew Yuen, along with other executives from Keppel and SBM Offshore. The tour aimed to brief Prince Albert on the conversion process and its significance for the marine industry.

site_title: Loyz Energy swings into the black with Q1 FY2015 profit of US$541,000
summary: Loyz Energy reported a net profit of US$541,000 for Q1 FY2015, compared to a loss of US$1.63 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue more than tripled to US$6.87 million due to crude oil production from its Thailand concessions. The company expects production to climb to 7,000 barrels of oil per day in the medium term, despite lower oil prices. Earnings per share improved to 0.13 US cents, with a gross profit of US$5.05 million.

site_title: Samsonite going from strength to strength
summary: Samsonite, a luggage brand, is expanding its presence in Asia with a US$2 billion turnover target for the next five years. The company has acquired several brands, including High Sierra, Hartmann, Lipault, Speck, and Gregory, to cater to different target consumers. To rejuvenate the brand, Samsonite launched Project Unicorn, which aims to bring fashion, color, and youthfulness to the brand. The company also introduced the Samsonite RED brand, which has seen significant success, and plans to expand its product lines and store presence across Asia.

site_title: Rising China, geopolitical tensions take stage at APEC
summary: World leaders, including Barack Obama, Vladimir Putin, and Shinzo Abe, converge on Beijing for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, hosted by China's President Xi Jinping. The summit comes amidst rising tensions between China and its neighbors, particularly Japan over disputed islands, and amid US-Russia tensions. China and the US have differing visions for trade integration, and China's growing territorial assertiveness in the South China Sea has raised concerns. The summit is seen as a rare opportunity for leaders to meet and discuss issues, but tensions are expected to simmer beneath the surface.

site_title: Gold extends slump in turbulent week
summary: Gold prices hit a four-year low due to persistent dollar strength, while crude oil plummeted to multi-year troughs amid fears of Saudi price cuts and abundant supplies. A rebounding greenback makes dollar-priced commodities more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies, reducing demand and prices.

site_title: S'pore, China headed for next phase of cooperation
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed satisfaction with the progress of bilateral ties with Singapore, marking 25 years of cooperation. The two countries are set to launch a feasibility study on a third government-to-government project in western China, with the goal of concluding the study by next year. Singapore and China have already completed two successful bilateral projects, Suzhou Industrial Park and Tianjin Eco-city. The study will consider locations such as Chongqing, Chengdu, and Xi'an.

site_title: Where's the beef? Not at Burger King's new India restaurant
summary: Burger King opened its first beef-free restaurant in New Delhi, India, marking the 100th country with a franchise. The menu features chicken, lamb, and vegetarian options, including Whoppers made from mutton and a paneer melt sandwich. The decision was made to cater to India's large Hindu population, where many object to cattle slaughter for religious reasons. The restaurant, located at Select Citywalk shopping mall, was developed after research and testing with over 5,000 customers across eight cities.

site_title: Asia-Pac CEOs more bullish about growth in next 12 months: survey
summary: Asia-Pacific CEOs are more bullish about growth over the next 12 months, with 46% expressing "very confident" revenue growth, up from 42% last year and 36% in 2012. 67% plan to increase investment in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) region, with China, the US, Indonesia, Hong Kong, and Singapore being top destinations. CEOs expect a more connected and balanced Asia-Pacific region, with the US-China dynamic remaining dominant, and are seeking policy relief on trade barriers and greater regulatory harmony.

site_title: Kerry meets China's biggest investors in US
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry met with China's biggest investors in the US, including Lenovo's Yang Yuanqing, China Petrochemical Corp's Fu Chengyu, Dalian Wanda Group's Wang Jianlin, and Xiaomi Corp's Lei Jun. The meeting occurred after Kerry discussed Ukraine with Russia's foreign minister in Beijing. The executives' US$5 billion asset purchases from US companies were highlighted during the meeting. Kerry's visit aimed to strengthen US-China relations, particularly in economic and trade matters. The meeting took place on Saturday in Beijing.

site_title: Hermes scarf designs now grace new watch models
summary: Hermes is introducing limited-edition watches featuring designs inspired by the company's classic silk scarves and traditional crafts. The watches, including the Arceau Lift and Arceau Temari, feature intricate enameling and precious metals, with designs inspired by vintage scarves and ancient Japanese art forms. The collection includes 24 numbered pieces, with the latest model, Arceau Cheval d'Orient, featuring hand-painted images of horses and Persian saddle rugs, marking a first for Hermes in watchmaking.

site_title: OMV likely to miss 2016 oil output target
summary: Austrian oil and gas group OMV may miss its 2016 production target of 400,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day due to a review of its investment program. The company cited a challenging operating environment, including low oil prices and unpredictable Libyan production, which impacted cash flow. Despite this, underlying operating profit rose 6% to 656 million euros in the third quarter. Production increased by 13% in the same period, driven by contributions from Norway and the modernization of its Romanian refinery.

site_title: London okays 750 MW Dong Energy offshore wind project
summary: The UK's Planning Inspectorate has approved a 750 MW offshore wind project, the Walney Extension, off northwest England's Cumbria coast. The project, led by Denmark's Dong Energy A/S, aims to generate enough power to power half a million homes. The UK is chasing a European Union target to get 15% of all energy from renewables by 2020, with this project contributing to that goal.

site_title: Ascott wins 5 more management contracts in China, marks foray into 2 new cities
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business under CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage 1,000 additional apartment units in China's Yinchuan, Changsha, Shenyang, and Xi'an. This marks its entry into the high-growth cities of Yinchuan and Changsha, with properties set to open in 2018 and 2015-2016. Ascott aims to reach 20,000 units in China by 2020, aligning with its global target of 80,000 units by 2020.

images.alt_text: Capitaland's serviced residence business The Ascott has landed contracts to manage five additional properties in China, boosting its portfolio to 12,000 apartment units in the populous country.

site_title: Self-driving car a breakthrough for handicapped
summary: Self-driving cars have the potential to revolutionize transportation for people with disabilities, granting them independence and mobility. However, US state laws require manual backup systems in case of emergencies. Automakers like Nissan and Google are developing autonomous vehicles, but most require an able driver to take control. Google's driverless prototype, however, has the potential to accommodate people physically unable to operate a vehicle, but California law requires manual controls for now. Regulators and the marketplace will ultimately determine the type of autonomous car offered for sale and its capabilities.

site_title: Grisly HK murders spark Western banker backlash
summary: A British expatriate, Rurik Jutting, has been charged with the brutal murder of two young Indonesian women in Hong Kong, sparking a backlash against wealthy Western bankers in the city's finance industry. Critics accuse them of treating Hong Kong as their "personal playground" and engaging in immoral behavior, including prostitution and substance abuse. The case has fueled criticism of privileged foreign workers and their impact on the city's wealth gap, with some calling for greater social responsibility from bankers.

site_title: US, EU and Iran in last-minute push for N-deal
summary: US, EU, and Iran are in a last-minute push to reach a nuclear deal by November 24, with formal negotiations set to begin in Vienna on November 18. The agreement would require Iran to limit its nuclear future in exchange for lifting international sanctions. Key areas of contention include uranium enrichment and sanctions lifting, with the US and EU suspecting Iran's intentions are not entirely peaceful. A final deal would need to address these gaps to achieve a comprehensive agreement.

site_title: Japan Coast Guard grappling with poachers
summary: The Japan Coast Guard is struggling to respond to over 200 suspected Chinese fishing boats poaching ornamental corals in Japanese waters, from the Ogasawara Islands to the Izu Islands. Despite receiving numerous calls, the JCG has only caught five vessels, one of which was poaching in territorial waters. The JCG's limited patrol vessels and resources hinder its ability to effectively combat the issue, with officials stating they cannot increase vessel numbers further.

site_title: Supply glut, tightening expat demand depressing rents
summary: Singapore's private residential leasing market has weakened, with non-landed private home rentals sliding 1.1% from Q2 last year to Q2 this year. The core central region led the decline, while Yishun-Sembawang suffered the steepest rent drop of 10.6%. In contrast, Bishan-Ang Mo Kio saw a 15.9% increase in rental prices, bucking the trend. Experts attribute the decline to a supply glut and shrinking tenant pool, with over 30,000 new units expected to be completed between H2 2014 and 2015, further depressing rents.

site_title: OSIM, Hyflux, OCBC dominate buybacks
summary: Key buyback activity was seen in Hyflux, OCBC, and OSIM International, with significant purchases made after third-quarter results announcements. Buyback values were S$9.1 million, down from S$5.2 million the previous week. Insider buys also occurred, with Suntec Reit's CEO buying 100,000 units and Roxy-Pacific Holdings' CFO purchasing 50,000 shares. The Straits Trading Co saw a substantial increase in its stake following a purchase by Franklin Templeton Institutional. Aberdeen Asset Management also acquired more shares of Keppel Corp at a lower price.

site_title: Oil-rich Norway's low-cost carrier sets its sights high
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle, Europe's third-largest budget airline, continues to expand its operations across the Nordic region, pushing rival SAS to the brink. Founded in 2002, the airline has achieved success through its low-cost model, large modern fleet, and focus on large population areas. With a new fleet of Boeing 737s and Airbus A320neos, Norwegian expects to save up to 15% on fuel and has been profitable since 2006. The airline is now targeting long-haul routes, but faces challenges from state-backed Gulf rivals and US politicians over labor practices.

site_title: French Revolution Assassin's Creed out Tues
summary: Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed: Unity will debut on Tuesday, allowing players to experience the French Revolution through a new installment of the action franchise. The game promises to be the most "dense and immersive" version yet, with realistic details and a focus on the French Revolution's spirit. The annual franchise has sold over 78 million units worldwide, but its constant release schedule poses a challenge in maintaining an overarching storyline. Ubisoft's Yves Guillemot emphasized the importance of capturing the essence of the French Revolution in the game.

site_title: Desperate search for yield keeps global bond prices high
summary: Global bond prices remain high as investors seek yield in a low-interest-rate environment. Despite predictions of higher yields and lower bond prices at the start of 2014, US Treasuries and European and Asian long-term government bonds have outperformed equities, gold, and junk securities. Since 2013, bond prices have risen by 7-21% in various countries, with some, such as Italy and Swiss bonds, offering attractive real yields. Economists Lacy Hunt and Gary Shilling remain bullish on US Treasuries, citing low velocity of money and disinflation, while warning that a "risk off" investment climate could surprise the market.

site_title: PepsiCo refreshes leadership pool
summary: PepsiCo has promoted three executives, Oswald Barckhahn, Laxman Narasimhan, and Mike Spanos, into bigger roles, aiming to replenish its leadership pool after several high-profile departures. The promotions include Barckhahn taking charge of Quaker, Gatorade, and Tropicana brands, Narasimhan leading food brands in Latin America, and Spanos overseeing food, beverages, and dairy businesses in China. The move comes after PepsiCo's president Zein Abdalla's retirement and potential successors Indra Nooyi and Hugh Johnston.

site_title: Lehman to sell Nylo New York hotel
summary: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc is selling its 291-room Nylo New York City hotel in Manhattan for an undisclosed price, following a $20 million renovation investment. The sale is part of the investment bank's efforts to unwind its real estate holdings after filing for bankruptcy six years ago. The hotel will be sold separately from the Nylo brand, allowing a new owner to operate the property independently. The sale comes as the New York lodging market experiences strength, with occupancy at 85% and average nightly room rates rising 2.5% year-over-year.

site_title: HK farmers protest against tycoon land grab
summary: Hong Kong farmers are protesting against a proposed government project that will see valuable agricultural land developed, threatening the livelihoods of thousands of residents. The project, worth billions of dollars, has been criticized for enriching real estate giants and catering to wealthy Chinese mainlanders, exacerbating the city's vast wealth gap. The protests, now in their second month, are fueled by resentment towards the government's "pro-developer policies" and the perceived cosy relationship between the government and powerful business elites.

site_title: Renting beats buying a home? It depends
summary: Research suggests that renting may be cheaper than buying a home in Singapore due to the current downward trend in residential property prices. However, it's unclear if this shift is beneficial for homebuyers, as it may impact long-term investment and wealth creation. Experts caution that property remains a viable option for parking cash, despite the changing market. The article highlights the need for individuals to weigh the pros and cons of renting versus buying in Singapore's unique market context.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, home prices have fallen faster than rentals, since loan curbs (that is, the total debt servicing ratio, or TDSR) kicked in.

site_title: LinkedIn sued over lost job opportunities
summary: LinkedIn is being sued by four plaintiffs alleging that the company's "Reference Search" feature, available only to premium account holders, enables employers to "anonymously dig into the employment history of any LinkedIn member" without ensuring accuracy, violating the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The plaintiffs claim they were denied jobs due to inaccurate information from the feature. LinkedIn denies the claims, stating that the feature only reveals publicly available information and that users can opt-out. The case highlights the growing use of social media for pre-employment screening and the need for clarity on consumer reporting agency regulations in the digital age.

site_title: Obama's Asia tour aims to bolster ties with region
summary: US President Barack Obama embarks on an eight-day Asia tour, visiting China, Myanmar, and Australia, focusing on strengthening ties with China amidst tensions over the South China Sea and human rights issues. Obama will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Myanmar President Thein Sein, and opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, with discussions on democratic reform and human rights. The trip aims to demonstrate Obama's ability to lead foreign relations in his final two years in office, amid ongoing crises in Iraq, Syria, and Ukraine.

site_title: Sweden's dilemma: massive household debt amid zero interest rates
summary: Sweden's government faces a challenge in managing massive household debt amid zero interest rates, which could prevent a steep fall in property prices and consumer confidence. Despite the country's strong economy, with a AAA rating and low public debt, officials struggle to balance controlling borrowing and house price rises without hurting the real estate market. A meeting between the government and financial authorities is underway to address the issue, which is seen as a tough task.

site_title: Ireland pressured into bailout, letters show
summary: Newly released documents suggest Ireland was pressured into a 67.5 billion euro bailout after the 2008 financial crash, with the European Central Bank (ECB) threatening to cut off emergency support unless the country applied for international rescue. The ECB's governing council demanded a commitment from the Irish government to undertake fiscal consolidation and financial sector restructuring in exchange for the aid. The documents, released by the ECB, show the central bank's role in determining the scope of the aid program and have reignited a debate about the international aid that Dublin accepted.

site_title: Lake Life EC in Jurong nearly sold out
summary: Singapore's Lake Life EC project in Jurong has sold 534 out of 546 units on its opening weekend, with 98% of units sold as of Sunday. The project, which features a 99-year leasehold, boasts unit prices ranging from S$799 to S$930 per square foot. The average unit price is S$685,000. This marks the first EC project in Jurong in 17 years and sets a record for the most units sold on the first day of sales since June 2013. The next EC project in Jurong is expected to launch in the first quarter of 2015.

site_title: Racquet Club scores an ace with tennis fans
summary: The 2014 BNP Paribas Women's Tennis Association (WTA) Finals tournament in Singapore saw a successful Racquet Club VIP experience, with 95% of 7,700 tickets sold and 20% of clients pre-booking 2015 tickets. The event generated $6.5 million in revenue and attracted over 8,000 guests to the exclusive Aces Lounge. WSG secured 24 sponsors, including SC Global Developments and Marina Bay Sands, and plans to enhance the Racquet Club experience for 2015.

site_title: Indian PM expands Cabinet to speed up economic reforms
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi expanded his Cabinet, appointing 21 new ministers to speed up economic reforms. The new additions bring the total number of ministers to 27, including 4 sworn in during a ceremony. The government also increased the number of junior ministers to 39. The move aims to implement Modi's promised economic reforms, which were implemented after he stormed to power in May 2014.

site_title: Commerzbank's Q3 profit beats expectations
summary: Commerzbank's Q3 net profit tripled to 225 million euros, beating analysts' expectations of 192 million euros. Earnings rose in retail and corporate banking units, while costs for bad loans fell, indicating a turnaround in the bank's performance. This marks a positive sign for Commerzbank's turnaround plan, with the bank's second-quarter earnings having also seen a significant improvement.

site_title: Berkshire Q3 profit down 8.6% on Tesco fall
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's Q3 profit dropped 8.6% to $4.62 billion, or $2,811 per share, due to a $678 million impairment on its Tesco holding. This was a rare mistake for Warren Buffett, but his overall investing record remains high. The company's operating earnings beat estimates, driven by strong performances from subsidiaries such as BNSF and energy utilities.

site_title: Genetically engineered potato gets USDA approval
summary: The US Department of Agriculture has approved a genetically engineered potato developed by JR Simplot, which reduces the production of acrylamide, a potentially harmful chemical formed when potatoes are fried, and resists bruising. The potato, known as the Innate potato, is the latest genetically engineered crop to receive US approval, following others such as corn and soyabeans. The approval applies only to US growers, and its adoption by food companies and restaurant chains, including McDonald's, is uncertain due to consumer opposition to genetically engineered foods.

site_title: Customisation adds new dimension to 3D printing
summary: 3D printing technology has gained significant attention in recent years, with companies like Normal and General Electric embracing its potential. The technology allows for customization, with some companies using it to create complex parts, such as fuel nozzles for aircraft engines. Market research predicts a significant rise in spending on 3D printing, from $1.6 billion in 2015 to $13.4 billion in 2018. While some companies see it as a long-term prospect, others believe it has the potential to revolutionize manufacturing, making it "sexy again".

site_title: Rally poised to continue if retail sales hold up
summary: US stock indices near record highs as the economy shows signs of continued growth. Retail sales data from last week is expected to confirm this boom, with low unemployment, soaring consumer confidence, and falling oil prices. The conditions for spending are favorable, despite a mixed October jobs report. As long as retail sales meet expectations, the rally is expected to continue.

site_title: Difficulties in gaining an advantage over others
summary: Investors seeking to gain an advantage in the stock market face difficulties, particularly those without insider knowledge. Passive investment products like exchange-traded funds (ETFs) can help, but may not offer vastly different advice. Key economic releases in the US, such as retail sales and consumer sentiment, will be closely watched, while interest-rate hikes will be scrutinized for clues. A recent study found that CEOs manipulate news releases to boost their stock price during equity vesting months, potentially creating opportunities for traders to time the market.

site_title: Change in Brazil subsidy plan to hit Embraer sales
summary: Brazil's subsidy plan to support flights to small cities has been altered in a way that no longer benefits Embraer's models, potentially affecting sales. AZUL, the only Brazilian airline flying Embraer jets, has threatened to cancel a 30-aircraft order if lawmakers approve the plan. Embraer's models are considered ideal for regional cities, and the airline's president, Antonoaldo Neves, has criticized the altered plan, stating that it would harm the airline's ability to serve these cities.

site_title: Gold reserves plan a disaster: Swiss banking chief
summary: Switzerland's central bank chairman, Thomas Jordan, has warned that a proposed referendum to boost the country's gold reserves would be "disastrous" for the country, citing it would limit the bank's ability to react to economic disorder and maintain currency stability. The proposal, backed by the right-wing Swiss People's Party, aims to require the Swiss National Bank to hold at least 20% of its assets in gold, but Jordan argues it would hinder the bank's monetary policy and require it to buy $93 billion worth of gold.

site_title: A yen for rejuvenation
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) latest monetary easing has sparked a positive reaction in the global economy, with a weaker yen expected to boost Japan's exports and stimulate economic growth. The move is seen as a bold step to combat deflation and anaemic growth, with potential benefits for other Asian economies. While the impact on global sentiment and business decisions is likely to be positive, some experts caution that the effects may be limited, and a third round of quantitative easing may be needed to achieve sustained growth. The devaluation of the yen is also expected to benefit foreign direct investment and tourism, particularly in Japan.

site_title: Good governance can be a big sell for IPOs
summary: A company's long-term strategy, including its mission, vision, and value proposition, plays a crucial role in making an initial public offering (IPO) compelling. A clear articulation of these elements can influence the IPO's price-earnings ratio, attract specific investors, and impact post-listing stock behavior. Good governance, particularly through a diverse and high-quality board, is also essential in signaling the company's intent and protecting investor interests. Companies that successfully balance these factors can achieve a successful IPO and enhanced corporate reputation.

site_title: Reducing workplace risks with new safety framework
summary: Singapore's government will launch a public consultation on a new mandatory framework, Design for Safety (DfS), to incorporate construction worker safety in building plans. The framework, led by the Manpower Ministry, aims to address work-related risks and hazards upstream. Developers will be required to ensure their designs are safe, and the ministry has already started industry consultations. The goal is to eliminate hazards at the design and planning phase, reducing risks during construction and maintenance. The move is seen as a way to protect workers' lives and health, while also promoting productivity.

site_title: FAA approves small Georgia airport opposed by Delta
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has approved a small Georgia airport, Paulding Northwest Atlanta Airport, to begin commercial service despite opposition from Delta Air Lines and the city of Atlanta. The approval, which added the airport authority as a co-sponsor for airport improvement grants, clears the way for an environmental study. County officials argue the airport will spur economic growth and create jobs, while Delta claims it's unnecessary and wasteful. The county plans to develop the airport, with a private equity fund and Allegiant Travel Co. expressing interest in providing service.

site_title: Formula One's rich-poor divide
summary: Formula One is facing a crisis due to a rich-poor divide among teams, with the wealthy teams earning significantly more than the struggling ones. The series earns $1.7 billion annually, with individual contracts distributing most of the money unevenly. The minimum cost of running a team is estimated at $120 million per year, making it impossible for smaller teams to survive on sponsorship alone. Possible solutions include increasing the grid size, allowing richer teams to sell cars to poorer ones, or implementing a cost cap, but these ideas are met with concerns about competitiveness and sustainability.

site_title: Asia-Pacific CEOs more bullish on revenue growth over next 12 months: PwC survey
summary: Asia-Pacific CEOs are more confident of revenue growth over the next 12 months, with 46% saying they are "very confident" of growth, up from 36% in 2012. The majority (67%) plan to increase investment in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) region, with 37% building or expanding facilities in China. CEOs also expect to raise their global headcount by at least 5% annually and are looking for policy relief on trade barriers. The region is seen as moving closer to a Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific, with businesses seeking greater regulatory harmony and collaboration.

images.alt_text: The majority of CEOs (67 per cent) say they plan to increase investment in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) region over the next 12 months. Such plans span across all 21 Apec member economies, with China, the US, Indonesia, Hong Kong and Singapore being the hottest investment destinations.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: NTUC FairPrice's Share-A-Textbook Project aims to collect 400,000 school textbooks by Dec 7, increasing by 5% from last year. 20,000 priority students will get to pick from donated textbooks first. Meanwhile, Singapore is set to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first Asean country by 2025, and is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines. Additionally, Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reached S$46 billion in FY2025, and Singapore's sustainable bond issuances jumped 80% to S$13.3 billion in 2024.

site_title: Board of inquiry to investigate SGX power outage
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has set up a board of inquiry to investigate the cause of a power outage that disrupted trading for over three hours on Wednesday. The committee, led by Quah Wee Ghee, comprises four independent SGX board directors. The investigation aims to determine the root cause of the power outage and its impact on the market.

images.alt_text: It doesn't matter what happens overseas, we've got to get it right here, says Mr Tharman.

site_title: Venture's Q3 profit up 3.1%
summary: VENTURE Corporation reported a 3.1% increase in Q3 net profit, driven by a rise in sales and stronger margins. However, the electronics manufacturing firm warned of higher labor costs ahead. This comes as the company faces challenges in its H2 revenue projections, which may be below target, with operating losses similar to the first half of the year.

site_title: Indonesia beckons, but caution still reigns
summary: Singapore businesses are cautiously optimistic about Indonesia's new president, Jokowi, despite past regulatory hurdles and scuppered deals. Economists expect growth to strengthen next year on lower global oil prices and investment recovery. However, investors are still waiting for concrete measures, particularly on fuel subsidy reforms. Despite this, SMEs in Singapore are keen to expand into Indonesia, with 44% of SMEs already doing business there. The new administration's focus on opening up Indonesia's maritime economic potential and infrastructure development could create opportunities for Singapore businesses.

images.alt_text: The promise of new political leadership and a market too huge to ignore should make Indonesia a ready target for Singapore businesses and investors - but ghosts of the past may not fade so easily, especially for larger companies.

site_title: US earnings outlook might be less rosy than investors think
summary: US third-quarter earnings season is ending with most companies beating profit expectations, but some analysts warn that investors may be overly optimistic. Only 66% of S&P 500 companies exceeded expectations after stripping away those that barely beat estimates, and analysts' profit forecasts are trimming down. Fourth-quarter earnings growth is now estimated at 7.6%, down from an initial forecast of 11.1%. Negative company outlooks outnumber positive ones by a ratio of 3.9 to 1, indicating a worsening trend. The outlook could worsen if weak overseas demand translates into weak US results.

site_title: More to dividends than meets the eye
summary: SIA Engineering, a component stock of the Straits Times Index, has cut its interim dividend by one cent to six cents per share after reporting a 41% drop in net profit for its second quarter. The company's dividend payout ratio has risen to 105%, exceeding its earnings. This unsustainable payout ratio may lead to the company drawing down its cash reserves to pay dividends, potentially affecting its financial health. The article highlights the importance of assessing a company's dividend sustainability, citing McDonald's as an example of a company that has successfully increased its dividends for 37 years.

site_title: Hermes says Q3 sales rise 11% at constant forex
summary: French luxury goods company Hermes reported an 11% rise in like-for-like third-quarter sales driven by robust demand for leather goods and ready-to-wear. Revenue reached 990.6 million euros (US$1.24 billion) in the three months to September 30. This comes after arch-rival LVMH agreed to redistribute Hermes shares it owns to shareholders on December 17.

site_title: Lyft board members discussed replacing CEO, court documents reveal
summary: Lyft's former COO Travis VanderZanden disclosed in court filings that he discussed replacing CEO Logan Green with board members, including the possibility of VanderZanden taking Green's position. VanderZanden denied allegations of improperly keeping Lyft's proprietary information after leaving the company. He stated that the CEO discussions occurred "unbeknownst to Green." Lyft sued VanderZanden for allegedly misusing confidential information.

site_title: Japan's old-style coffee shops unfazed by Starbucks' success
summary: Japan's traditional coffee shops, such as Cafe de L'Ambre, are thriving despite Starbucks' success. The independently-owned cafes, like L'Ambre, focus on high-quality, hand-roasted coffee and offer a unique atmosphere, with some even boasting historical connections to famous patrons. In contrast, Starbucks' popularity in Japan is attributed to its customizable drinks and free WiFi, but some locals prefer the traditional coffee shops' distinct offerings and welcoming environments.

site_title: Chrysler intensifies effort to reach Jeep SUV owners over recall
summary: Chrysler is intensifying efforts to reach 1.56 million Jeep SUV owners affected by a recall, with a weak response to initial mailings. As of Friday, only 8% of owners had responded, and the company has set up new websites to cast a wider net. Chrysler is also delving into registration records to determine ownership of vehicles that may have been resold since new. The company has produced 447,000 trailer hitch assemblies to fix vehicles, with plans to produce more.

site_title: French cuisine that's a steal
summary: Saveur Art, a French restaurant in Singapore, debunks the notion that French food is expensive by offering a $52 set dinner menu that is both affordable and delicious. The restaurant, owned by chef-chef Joshua Khoo and Dylan Ong, serves dishes such as squid ink crackers, cod poached in olive oil, and a tender pink pigeon breast, all made with high-quality ingredients. Despite its upscale atmosphere, the food is reasonably priced, making it an accessible option for those looking to experience French cuisine without breaking the bank.

site_title: How private housing rents have moved
summary: Private housing rents have experienced significant fluctuations worldwide. In the US, mortgage rates rose after five consecutive weeks of declines, affecting the housing market. In Singapore, the Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases anticipated. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, according to a recent index. Additionally, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul for 262 billion won. These developments signal a shift in the global real estate market.

site_title: Asian shares slip as commodity rout trumps US optimism
summary: Asian shares declined as commodity prices fell due to concerns over slower global growth. European shares are expected to fall, with traders watching the European Central Bank's policy meeting. The Bank of Japan's rally-inspired gains were reversed in Tokyo, while US shares edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The Singapore Stock Index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Surprise rally catches Asian feed millers short
summary: Asian feed millers have missed a multi-year-low corn and soymeal prices surge in the US futures market, leaving them with hefty costs despite record-high global supplies. The US soymeal futures jumped over 30% and corn gained almost 18% in October, triggered by fund buying, logistical bottlenecks, and harvest delays. Asian importers, including Indonesia, Vietnam, and Thailand, have been ordering cargoes with premiums, but now face higher prices as global supplies rise and demand remains strong, making a drop in prices unlikely.

site_title: Siemens core profit hurt by wind power charges
summary: Siemens missed fourth-quarter core profit expectations due to charges for faulty wind turbines, which hurt its wind power division. The company posted a 28% increase in total sectors profit to 2.2 billion euros, missing estimates. Siemens forecasts flat sales for the current year and aims for an industrial profit margin of 10-11%. The company agreed to sell its hearing-aid unit for 2.15 billion euros, while retaining a 200 million-euro equity investment.

site_title: Uber looks to pick up another US$1b in equity: FT
summary: Uber is in talks with investors to raise an additional $1 billion in equity, seeking a higher valuation than its previous $17 billion. The company plans to tap into new investors, particularly in Asia, and still has $1 billion in its bank from its last funding round. This comes after a Las Vegas court ruling allowed Uber to operate in Clark County, despite opposition from taxi drivers. Uber's existing investors, including Blackrock and Google Ventures, will also contribute to the new funding round.

site_title: Grand Canyon national park proposes hiking visitor fees
summary: Grand Canyon National Park proposes hiking visitor fees, with a 20% increase to $30 per vehicle for a 7-day pass, up from $25. An annual pass would cost $60, up from $50. Motorcycle fees would rise to $25, and pedestrian fees to $15. The fee increases are part of a nationwide plan to prepare facilities for future generations of visitors. The park receives $18 million annually from entrance fees and is seeking public comment until January 7.

site_title: China softens push for vast trade area amid US resistance: report
summary: China has agreed to soften its push for a vast new Asia-Pacific free trade agreement, the Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP), amid US resistance. The US has been promoting its own regional trade pact, the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). China has downgraded FTAAP from a "feasibility" study to a "strategic study" and dropped its target date of 2025, according to a report. This compromise is seen as a result of US pressure, with Beijing reportedly seeking to avoid confrontation on the issue during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting, which includes leaders from China and the US.

site_title: Institutional shareholders in US firms push for boardroom say
summary: Institutional shareholders in the US are pushing 75 companies to allow investors to hire and fire directors directly, aiming for greater accountability and erasing "clubby" aspects in corporate boardrooms. The proposal, led by New York City Comptroller Scott Stringer, would give shareholders with 3% or more stake the power to nominate directors for election. The effort targets companies with poor board diversity, climate change practices, and excessive executive compensation. If successful, the proposal could bring systemic reform to US boardrooms, with advocates citing studies showing greater shareholder wealth and improved board performance from greater involvement.

site_title: Hitting the networking track hard
summary: A cycling-based business networking initiative, the Peloton Club, is launching in Singapore, offering C-suite executives a chance to meet and ride together once a month. The event aims to promote cycling as a time-efficient and healthy activity, with a competitive edge. Spectrum Worldwide, the organizer, has also seen a growth in cycling popularity in Singapore, citing environmental benefits, family participation, and group riding as contributing factors. The company has learned from a tragic accident at last year's Cycle Singapore event and plans to enhance safety measures for next year's event.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat after payrolls but uptrend seen intact
summary: US stocks remained near record highs on Friday despite a weaker-than-expected October payroll report, which showed 214,000 jobs added. The unemployment rate fell to 5.8% from 5.9%. Energy shares led the gains, while Disney fell 3.1% after meeting earnings expectations. The Dow and S&P 500 closed near record highs, with the Dow up 0.9% and the S&P up 0.7% for the week.

site_title: Small-cap companies showcase their worth
summary: More than 400 high-net-worth investors attended the Singapore Capital Expo and Small Cap Showcase 2014, where 28 private and small-cap Australian-listed companies showcased their investment merits. The event, held at Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre, introduced companies in the property, funds, life science, healthcare, and technology industries. Participating companies included SGX-listed firms Declout and YuuZoo.

site_title: Estee Lauder snaps up third luxury brand in a month
summary: Estee Lauder acquired French luxury perfume brand Editions de Parfums Frédéric Malle, its third acquisition in less than a month, as part of its strategy to boost its portfolio of high-end luxury perfumes and skin care brands. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, follows the acquisition of Le Labo and Rodin olio lusso in October and September, respectively. The move aims to counter brand fatigue and competition from niche brands, which have been eating into market share.

site_title: China oil producers face cuts after period of 'runaway' spending
summary: China's major oil producers face cuts in spending and production due to the slump in oil prices, which have fallen 26% this year to a four-year low. The decline threatens to reduce profits and earnings for companies such as PetroChina and CNOOC Ltd. If Brent averages $80 a barrel next year, earnings could drop 54% and domestic production would decline by 1.5%. Analysts warn that years will be needed to tap into unconventional resources, and a prolonged period of lower prices will impact the companies' ability to invest.

site_title: Adidas sees slower sales growth in 2015 as trims margin target
summary: Adidas reported third-quarter results in line with forecasts, with sales of 4.118 billion euros and operating profit of 405 million euros, a 13% decline. The company trimmed its gross margin target to 48-48.5% and expects slower sales growth in 2015, at a mid single-digit rate, compared to mid to high single-digit growth for 2014. The slowdown is attributed to the absence of the World Cup, which typically boosts Adidas sales. The company's long-serving CEO Herbert Hainer faces pressure after a series of profit warnings.

images.alt_text: German sportswear firm Adidas, struggling to keep pace with larger US rival Nike , said it expected sales growth to slow in 2015 as it reported third-quarter results in line with forecasts.

site_title: GT Advanced says fell victim to 'bait-and-switch' by Apple
summary: Apple allegedly used a "bait-and-switch" tactic to force GT Advanced Technologies into a money-losing deal to supply the company with sapphire, according to a senior executive's affidavit. In 2013, Apple offered GT Advanced a deal to supply sapphire, but later changed the terms to shift economic risk to the company, allowing Apple to buy the sapphire at a lower market value. GT Advanced was left unable to pursue other deals and was effectively forced to accept the unfair deal, according to the affidavit.

site_title: Global law enforcement strikes deep into 'Dark Web'
summary: A global law enforcement operation, "Operation Onymous," shut down dozens of online "dark markets" selling illegal goods and services, including those using the Tor encryption network. US and European authorities arrested 17 people, seized 414 websites and hosting servers, and seized virtual Bitcoins worth $1 million, as well as cash and drugs. The operation targeted sites like Silk Road 2.0, which enabled over 100,000 people to buy and sell contraband anonymously, and sites selling firearms, stolen credit card data, and counterfeit currency. The crackdown aims to disrupt international cybercrime and show that criminals are not beyond reach.

site_title: TRE Residences to be launched next weekend
summary: TRE Residences, a 250-unit condominium project in Geylang, Singapore, is set to launch next weekend with an average indicative pricing of S$1,560 psf. Early-bird discounts of up to 5% are available. Prices start from S$690,000 for a 420-sq-ft one-bedder to S$1.38 million for a 947-sq-ft four-bedroom unit. The project's breakeven price is around S$1,300 psf, and rental yields for selected 99-year condos in the area are around 3.8-3.9% per annum.

site_title: KL trade surplus widens as import growth slows
summary: Malaysia's trade surplus widened to RM9.3 billion in September, driven by a 2% year-on-year rise in export growth, led by palm oil, electronics, and chemicals. However, import growth slowed to 1.1% from 7.6% in August. The central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, maintained its accommodative monetary policy stance, keeping interest rates unchanged, amid moderating GDP growth and higher inflation. Economists expect another rate hike in the middle of next year due to inflation projections of 4-5% in 2015.

site_title: Branching out
summary: Two Singaporean businesses have ventured into new industries. The Adonis Hotel, a luxury hotel in Purvis Street, combines the hospitality spirit of the Adonis Beauty International brand with modern amenities. Suitsupply, a European menswear label, opened a 5,500 square foot store at Ion Orchard, offering classic tailoring with modern fashion. Meanwhile, The Refinery, a multi-disciplinary concept house, aims to bring together the local creative community of craftsmen and designers, featuring a casual dining restaurant, intimate bar, and artisan workspace. Additionally, Bureauware, a graphic design firm, has launched a line of furniture and home accessories, including the Kin Box modular cat habitat system.

site_title: Obama to meet Indonesia leader during Beijing summit
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott at the upcoming APEC summit in Beijing, where leaders aim to clinch a pan-Pacific trade deal. Obama will also discuss the Trans-Pacific Partnership with other nations, but progress is unlikely due to China's absence. The meeting with Xi Jinping will focus on advancing US-China bilateral relations and addressing global issues. Obama's visit will also include stops in Myanmar and Australia, where he will meet with opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and discuss regional security issues.

site_title: The hidden tax you pay for waiting
summary: A new study by Australian economics professor Robert Slonin found that long waiting times discourage people from donating blood, with a 38% increase in waiting time decreasing annual donations by 14%. The study, which analyzed data from the Australia Red Cross Blood Service, also found that longer waiting times discourage whole-blood donors from becoming plasma donors, potentially exacerbating severe plasma shortages in countries like Australia. The study suggests that "time taxes" can have serious adverse effects on people's well-being and should receive more attention than tax cuts.

site_title: Minted in Singapore, coined for the world
summary: The Singapore Mint, a subsidiary of Sembcorp Industries, has shifted its business from producing most of Singapore's circulation coins to a foreign mint, the Royal Canadian Mint. This change was made due to the need for a large quantity of coins and the ability of the foreign mint to ship them quickly. Although the Singapore Mint was disappointed by the loss of the national business, it views the move as an opportunity to expand its services to other countries, including Thailand and the Philippines. The mint now earns a higher margin from commemorative coin projects, which are more lucrative, and is exploring opportunities to sell gold bullion.

site_title: Japan drawing up national strategy to tackle dementia
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a national strategy to tackle dementia, which will involve a nationwide survey targeting 10,000 people to develop effective treatments. The government will also conduct a nationwide follow-up survey to promote research and support dementia patients and their families. The strategy aims to address the issue, which affects about one in four elderly people, and will cover non-dementia patients as well. The survey will run from 2016 to 2020 and may include genetic information analysis.

site_title: US consumer confidence nears August 2013 high
summary: US consumer confidence rose to its second-highest level since 2008, reaching 38.1 in the period ended Nov 2, just short of the five-year high of 38.3 in August 2013. The increase was attributed to cheaper petrol and more job opportunities lifting Americans' spirits.

site_title: SIA chief rules out offer for full control of Tiger Airways
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) CEO Goh Choon Phong has ruled out a full takeover of struggling carrier Tiger Airways, instead opting to focus on helping the airline restore its financial health. SIA plans to increase its 40% stake in Tiger to 55% and potentially 71% through a proposed rights issue. The airline aims to support Tiger's recovery through cooperation with its budget carrier Scoot and by leveraging SIA's scale and connectivity network.

site_title: Blackstone gets US$1.5b in commitments for property fund
summary: Blackstone Group LP has secured commitments of US$1.5 billion for its first property fund, focused on buying stable, well-leased US real estate. The fund, Blackstone Property Partners, plans to hold its first close on capital commitments. Blackstone has already made several core-plus investments, including the purchase of 1740 Broadway in Manhattan for US$605 million. The company aims to expand its investments in real estate, which is its largest segment by revenue and profit.

site_title: Payrolls exceed 200,000 in October as jobless rate hits 6-year low
summary: The US job market saw its ninth consecutive month of job gains in October, with 214,000 new workers added to payrolls, resulting in a 5.8% unemployment rate, the lowest in six years. This boost in employment suggests domestic demand is holding up despite global economic struggles. However, wages continued to lag behind, with average hourly earnings rising only 0.1% in October, less than projected.

site_title: Passport to the good ol' days
summary: BlackBerry CEO John Chen believes the company has lost its way and is poised for growth in the smartphone market. The Passport, a physical keyboard phone, is seen as a potential winner in a crowded market dominated by Apple's iPhone and Android devices. Despite being pushed to the sidelines, BlackBerry may finally be onto a successful product with the Passport, offering a unique alternative to rectangular screen phones. Chen's vision for the company's future is promising, with the Passport potentially reviving BlackBerry's market presence.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew points way forward for PAP
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew emphasizes the PAP's adaptability and relevance in maintaining power for over 50 years. In a foreword for the PAP60 book, Lee notes the party's task remains vital and difficult, requiring it to maintain support, trust, and leadership among Singaporeans. He also stresses the need for courage and big ideas to tackle issues head-on. The book chronicles 60 defining moments in the party's history and highlights its bedrock values of integrity and equal opportunity.

site_title: Jokowi plans US$6b port expansion
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo plans to spend almost US$6 billion to expand five major ports across the country, aiming to reduce shipping delays and boost trade. The expansion, targeting ports in north Sumatra, Jakarta, east Java, south Sulawesi, and Papua, is part of the government's strategy to reinvigorate the country's economy. The project will also help to cut logistics costs, which currently account for a quarter of Indonesia's economy, and attract foreign investors, with China planning a US$16.3 billion fund to finance infrastructure linking its markets to three continents.

site_title: Yangzijiang posts 1% fall in Q3 profit
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 1% decline in Q3 profit to 811.19 million yuan, mainly due to lower gross profit and other income. Revenue rose 2% to 3.74 billion yuan, with the shipbuilding segment accounting for 88.4% of the group's revenue. Despite a challenging operating environment, the company's gross profit margin for shipbuilding remained healthy at 21%. Yangzijiang expects to take advantage of the consolidation process in the shipbuilding industry, while also reducing investments in non-shipbuilding businesses.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore Airlines' core net profit of S$73.7 million for H1 FY15 is in line with CIMB Research's forecast. The research firm downgrades its FY15-17 earnings per share forecast due to an enlarged share base and higher costs. In contrast, Maybank Kim Eng Research maintains a "buy" rating for Singapore Airlines, citing potential fuel cost savings and a sharp 21% year-to-date fall in jet-fuel prices. Hi-P International and Valuetronics Holdings also receive "buy" ratings, with forecasts of strong finishes for the year. However, CIMB Research advises investors to take profit from Singapore Airlines due to rich valuations.

site_title: Recently-listed Japfa posts 10% decline in Q3 earnings
summary: Japfa Ltd, an Indonesian agri-food group, reported a 10% decline in Q3 earnings to US$10.77 million, down from US$11.99 million a year ago. Revenue increased 15% to US$784.66 million, mainly from its animal protein, dairy, and consumer food segments. The group attributed the decline to a weaker Indonesian rupiah and lower gross profit of 14% to US$123.5 million. Despite the challenges, Japfa's CEO cited diversification strategy and long-term growth potential in emerging market economies as positives.

site_title: 'Strong leadership a constant amid change'
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for strong leadership as the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) marks its 60th anniversary. In a speech, Lee urged party members to stay close to the people and provide leadership for the country, warning that declining this responsibility would put Singapore in "deep trouble." He also paid tribute to the party's pioneer generation, including former PM Lee Kuan Yew, and emphasized the need for the PAP to remain vigilant and committed to its ideals and vision.

site_title: High Flyers
summary: Airlines are elevating in-flight dining with collaborations from celebrity chefs, five-star hotels, and wine connoisseurs. High-end airlines like Garuda Indonesia, All Nippon Airways, and Air France are introducing new menus and luxurious amenities, such as trained chefs, fine china, and exclusive wine selections. Singapore Airlines has partnered with renowned wine experts Oz Clarke and others to curate wine options for Business Class passengers. Meanwhile, British Airways is upgrading its First Class experience with a "Champagne Supper" and healthier options, including light dishes and salads.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q3 profit slips 8%
summary: ST Engineering posted a 7.7% dip in net profit to S$121.3 million for the third quarter, largely due to weak European operations. The aerospace segment saw a 8% revenue fall, while the marine sector reported a 14% higher revenue. Pre-tax profit in the aerospace operations slipped 19% to S$63.5 million, hit by weak European operations and restructuring costs. The company's order book stood at S$13.2 billion, with S$1.6 billion expected to be delivered in the last quarter of 2014.

site_title: Abe seeks step forward in Sino-Japanese ties
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has successfully pushed for a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) meeting in Beijing, a rare summit between the two nations. The meeting aims to address long-standing tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea and China's criticism of Japan's history. While the two sides have made progress in diplomatic efforts, key issues remain unresolved, and the meeting's outcome is uncertain. The meeting could boost Abe's efforts to cool tensions and bolster ties with China.

images.alt_text: MR SUGA: 'Frank talks between the leaders of Japan and China are extremely important, without getting too caught up in the format.'

site_title: OECD backs Tokyo's monetary-easing move
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has endorsed the Bank of Japan's monetary-easing move, urging the country to continue its quantitative easing until achieving sustainable inflation targets. The OECD also suggests the European Central Bank should expand its monetary policy stimulus and supports a more easing of fiscal consolidation in the US and euro area. Despite concerns over Japan's currency depreciation, the OECD believes the global economy will accelerate gradually if countries implement growth-supportive policies, but warns of major risks ahead.

site_title: Banks ask US judge to dismiss Libor-linked suits
summary: Banks including Bank of America, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Barclays, and Citigroup asked US District Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald to dismiss claims of cheating customers on interest-rate swaps and Libor-based transactions. The companies filed papers in Manhattan federal court to dismiss 17 suits related to "over-the-counter" transactions. The banks claim the suits are without merit and seek to have the claims thrown out.

site_title: CapitaLand Q3 net profit inches up 1.3% to S$130m
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean property giant, reported a 1.3% increase in net profit to S$129.98 million for the third quarter of 2014. Revenue from continuing operations decreased 4.3% to S$918.93 million, mainly due to lower development project revenue in China. Earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) from continuing operations dropped 7.2% to S$350.5 million. The company's net asset value per share declined to S$3.72. Despite the decline, CapitaLand's shares closed three cents higher at S$3.15.

site_title: All systems go for StanChart Marathon 2014
summary: The Standard Chartered Marathon 2014 in Singapore is nearing capacity, with over 90% of slots already filled. As of Thursday, 52,900 runners have signed up for one of the six categories, with the full marathon still having available slots. The event's Ekiden category, dedicated to charity, has seen 185 teams sign up, raising S$110,000. Adidas has partnered with the event as official apparel partner, aiming to raise the event to global standards. The marathon is set to take place on December 7.

site_title: US unemployment falls to 5.8% in October
summary: The US unemployment rate dropped to 5.8% in October, despite a lower-than-expected 214,000 jobs created. This slight decrease in unemployment rate is attributed to the economy's modest job growth in the month.

site_title: Buy-and-hold passe? Says who?
summary: Pictet's group managing director, Pierre-Alain Wavre, challenges the notion that a buy-and-hold approach is no longer effective in markets. He argues that investing for the long term, with a focus on well-managed companies and concentrated portfolios, can yield substantial returns. Wavre's Pictet Investment Office, which manages $9 billion, has achieved annualized returns of 15% and 22% for stocks in Richemont and Hennes & Mauritz, respectively, over 20 years. Wavre emphasizes the importance of a long-term view, accepting some volatility, and sticking with proven winners rather than constantly seeking new opportunities.

site_title: China looking to develop wide-body passenger plane
summary: China is seeking suppliers to develop its own wide-body passenger plane, the C929, which is expected to take flight in 2023. The aircraft, state-backed Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (Comac), would be the largest of its kind and could carry hundreds of passengers. The project, which aims to expand China's ambitions and rival Boeing and Airbus, faces significant technological challenges. Comac's strategic partner is Russia's United Aircraft Corp, and the government considers developing a passenger aircraft industry a national priority.

site_title: Boss of US bitcoin firm charged with fraud
summary: Trendon Shavers, 32, the founder of Bitcoin Savings and Trust, has been charged with running a US$4.5 million Ponzi scheme, allegedly using bitcoins to cover payments owed to earlier clients and funding his own personal expenses. Shavers, who held about 7% of all bitcoins in circulation at the peak of his scheme, faces up to 20 years in prison. The case is the first to determine whether the US Securities and Exchange Commission has authority to regulate transactions in virtual currency.

site_title: Joblessness, inequality top 2015 global concerns: report
summary: A World Economic Forum (WEF) study lists joblessness and rising income inequality as top global concerns for 2015, with 1,800 experts citing stagnant wages as a major contributor to inequality. Lack of leadership, environmental issues, and the importance of health in the economy also made the top 10 list. Experts warn that neglecting inequality can lead to social unrest and undermine democratic systems, while the WEF notes that global leadership is a trend that cuts across all other issues, requiring bold leadership and courage to tackle societal and economic challenges.

site_title: Eat. Shop. Relax
summary: Singaporean stores are combining dining and retail concepts to create a one-stop experience. PACT Orchard Central, a multi-concept space, features a restaurant, retail area, and hair salon. Other locations, such as Club House and Club Meatballs, offer a unique blend of food, furniture, and retail. Hungry Heroes, a superhero-themed restaurant, also features a retail arm selling decorative items. Café Kapok, a design-focused store, has opened a 50-seater eatery extension that fuses food and retail. These innovative spaces aim to attract customers and increase store traffic by offering a lifestyle experience.

site_title: Apec leaders meet amid trade pact tensions, regional disputes
summary: Apec leaders meet in Beijing, marking the first time US President Barack Obama will visit China since 2009. The summit aims to focus on free trade, anti-corruption, investment, technology, and climate change, amidst tensions between China and the US over trade, hacking, and protectionism. China seeks to assert its influence in Asia and stem US presence in the Pacific, while the US is opposed to China's proposed Asia-Pacific regional free trade area (FTAAP) in favor of a more restricted zone. A handshake between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected, a rare move amid strained ties between the two nations.

site_title: Autumn Sonata
summary: Mongolia's Gobi Desert offers an adventure seeker's paradise in autumn, with its vivid hues of brown, gold, orange, and green. The best time to visit is in summer, but those willing to brave the cold can experience a unique landscape. The Three Camel Lodge, voted one of the world's best, provides deluxe accommodations. Renting a 4WD vehicle and hiring an experienced local driver is essential for exploring the desert. Highlights include riding Bactrian camels, visiting the Khongoryn Els sand dunes, and spotting dinosaur fossils and wildlife at the Flaming Cliffs, a protected zone where the first dinosaur eggs were discovered.

site_title: SGX system breakdown main feature in dull week
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,286.39 on Friday, despite a dull week, with the Singapore Exchange's trading system breaking down for three hours on Wednesday. The system's malfunction led to outrage and criticism. Corporate developments were also unimpressive, with STATS ChipPAC's shares crashing 18% after a low takeover offer from JCET. Other notable movers included Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Marine, and Valuetronics, with some stocks experiencing significant drops and others seeing slight changes.

site_title: Greater demand, competition ahead for biggest US organic grocery chain
summary: US organic grocery chain Whole Foods Market is facing increased competition as the demand for organic products grows. The company's sales growth has slowed, and investors have taken it out on the company's stock, dragging it down 30% this year. Despite reporting a 3.1% increase in sales at stores open more than a year, Whole Foods is expanding aggressively, opening 33 new stores in the last four quarters and planning to renovate 70% of its older stores. The company's expansion aims to boost sales, but it must navigate the growing competition from other organic grocery chains and major retailers.

site_title: Noble's Q3 profit soars to US$153.9m
summary: Noble Group reported a third-quarter net profit of US$153.9 million, a 6.8-fold increase from the same period last year, driven by a 7% rise in revenue to US$23.3 billion. The company handled a third more volume and achieved a turnaround profit on its supply chain assets. Revenue for the nine months ended September 30 trebled to US$372 million. Noble's CEO, Yusuf Alireza, attributed the strong performance to its asset-light strategy and initiatives to build out its energy and origination capabilities.

site_title: Van tourer
summary: The BMW 2 Series Active Tourer, a compact minivan, has been launched with a utilitarian one-box body and a utilitarian front-wheel-drive architecture. It shares its powertrain and interior space with the Mini Cooper, featuring a three-cylinder turbocharged engine and a roomy interior. Despite its unusual styling, the 218i Active Tourer delivers fun-to-drive characteristics, with responsive steering and a comfortable ride. It is the first BMW with a three-cylinder engine and boasts excellent head and legroom, making it a premium offering in the growing segment.

site_title: Markets differentiated fairly between countries during taper tantrum: Fed's Dudley
summary: US Federal Reserve President William Dudley stated that during the "taper tantrum" in 2013, markets differentiated between countries based on the health of their financial systems, favoring those with good macroprudential policies. This surge in volatility affected emerging countries more severely. The lesson from this event, according to Dudley, is that markets can be discriminatory in their response to economic policies.

site_title: Study finds socio-economic link in what US babies are fed
summary: Researchers at the University at Buffalo School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences found significant differences in infant diets based on socio-economic status. Babies from lower-income households were more likely to be fed high-sugar and high-fat foods, while those from higher-income households adhered to infant feeding guidelines. Diets high in sugar and fat were associated with early weight gain, stunted growth, and shorter stature. The study's findings suggest that differences in dietary habits begin early in life, with implications for infant health and development.

site_title: 53m e-mail addresses also taken in hacker attack: Home Depot
summary: Home Depot has disclosed that 53 million email addresses were stolen in a hacker attack between April and September, in addition to 56 million payment cards previously disclosed. Hackers used custom-built software on self-checkout terminals to access customer data. The company expects to pay $62 million to recover from the attack, with $27 million covered by insurance. A third-party vendor's user name and password were used to breach the company's network. Home Depot urges customers to be cautious against phishing scams.

site_title: Smashing combi
summary: Venus Williams, a tennis legend, has a lesser-known passion for interior design. She founded V Starr Interiors in 2002, which has grown into a $60 million empire, despite initial skepticism about her abilities. Williams, who studied fashion design in college, discovered her love for interior design while traveling and reading books on the subject. Her firm has worked with celebrities and professional athletes, and she has designed spaces like the renovated Southeast Tennis and Learning Center in Washington D.C. for children. Williams credits her success to her team, business skills, and perseverance, saying "No matter who you are or what you do, you have to be good at it."

site_title: Making sports sponsorship work
summary: Global sports sponsorship is expected to reach $45 billion by 2015, driven by the growing demand for sports content and the shift of advertising expenditure from traditional television networks to social media and other platforms. The NZ Maori All Blacks' visit to Singapore is seen as a key opportunity to grow sports in Asia. This sponsorship is expected to bring widespread benefits to AIG, which has invested heavily in the event. The rising demand for sports content is a significant trend in the global marketing landscape.

site_title: Singapore is China's second favourite investment destination
summary: Singapore has become China's second most preferred investment destination, surpassing Hong Kong, due to its diverse industrial structure. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's China Going Global Investment Index, Singapore's attractiveness is driven by its high-tech manufacturing, infrastructure development, and low risk. The city-state ranks second only to the US, which has long been China's top investment destination. This shift highlights Singapore's economic competitiveness and its ability to attract foreign investment.

site_title: Project completion boosts Wee Hur's earnings
summary: Wee Hur Holdings reported a nine-month net profit of S$102.5 million, more than eight times the net profit of S$13.1 million in the same period last year. The surge in revenue was due to the completion of its industrial property development, Premier@Kaki Bukit, and the full sale of its residential project, Parc Centros. The company's construction order book stood at S$397.2 million as of September, expected to last through FY2017.

images.alt_text: Goh Yeow Lian, executive chairman and managing director of Wee Hur Holdings Ltd.

site_title: JPMorgan to cut 3,000 more jobs in retail bank unit
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co announced plans to cut over 3,000 jobs in its retail banking unit, exceeding initial expectations.
