The move aims to reduce the 2016 retail banking expense base by $2 billion compared to 2014. This decision is part of the bank's efforts to optimize operations and improve efficiency.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust Q3 DPU drops 6.4%
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 3.1% drop in distributable income to S$23.45 million for Q3 2014, with a 6.4% decline in DPU to 1.32 cents. Net property income fell 1.2% to S$28.19 million, while gross revenue remained flat at S$31.15 million. Despite challenging conditions, the trust maintained high occupancies in serviced residences and commercial spaces, cushioning the impact of softer hotel performance.

site_title: Upcoming Catalist listing Zico attracts high-profile investors (Amended)
summary: Zico Holdings, a Malaysian consulting firm, is set to list on Catalist next week. The company has raised S$12.5 million through a share placement, attracting high-profile investors including Tan Sri Mohamed Azman bin Yahya and Dato' Sri Nazir Razak. The proceeds will be used to expand business operations, potentially leading to acquisitions. Zico's market capitalization will be approximately S$80.1 million, with its first day of trading expected on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower despite drop in unemployment
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Friday, despite a 5.8% unemployment rate, the lowest in six years. The Dow Jones dropped 49.58 points, the S&P 500 lost 3.72 points, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 9.65 points. A decline in Disney shares weighed on the market. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Picking the right pockets
summary: A growing issue of smartphone size has led to a debate about pocket sizes. As smartphones continue to increase in size, men's pockets are struggling to accommodate them, with some brands even hiring tailors to enlarge pants pockets for iPhone 6 and 6 Plus buyers. In response, some clothing labels and companies are exploring alternative designs, such as cargo pants or smartphone pockets on casual wear. A Kickstarter campaign has also launched to create premium jeans with built-in smartphone pockets, suggesting a possible solution to this problem.

site_title: 1MDB shouldn't keep funds overseas: Daim
summary: Former Malaysian finance minister Daim Zainuddin has urged the 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) fund to keep its funds within Malaysia, citing concerns over secrecy and the need for transparency. Daim, who served twice as finance minister, believes the public has a right to know about the fund's dealings, particularly given the large sums involved. He emphasized the importance of separating the planner and treasury roles, a practice he believes was lost during his time in office.

site_title: Suzuki Motor profit falls for first time in 8 quarters as tax hike hurts
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp reported its first eight-quarter operating profit decline, falling 14% to 39.6 billion yen (US$346.55 million) in the second quarter. The decline was attributed to sluggish demand in Japan following an April sales tax hike and intense competition in the minivehicle segment. Despite this, Suzuki maintained its full-year operating profit guidance at 188 billion yen. The company's shares ended down 1.2% and Tokyo's Nikkei average lost 0.9% following the earnings results.

site_title: IMF chief hails 'very brave' Japanese monetary stimulus
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde praised Japan's "very brave" monetary stimulus, which includes widening the Bank of Japan's asset-buying plan by up to 20 trillion yen (US$174 billion) to boost growth and inflation. Japan's economy is expected to grow only 0.9% this year, and inflation has slowed to 3.0% in September. The move aims to free up resources for banks to invest in the economy, but a weak yen could push up costs for firms that import goods from abroad. This is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "three arrows" policy to shake Japan out of a decade of economic lethargy.

site_title: A new form of luxury
summary: The Lexus NX is a new compact luxury SUV that aims to attract conquest customers and create a new target market for the brand. Its unique styling and proportions, prioritized over design, set it apart from competitors. The vehicle features a 2.5-litre petrol-electric hybrid powertrain or a 2.0-litre turbocharged petrol engine, offering luxury and high-tech features such as the Remote Touch Interface. The NX is designed for young, wealthy buyers, including singles, couples, and families, and is expected to register strong sales volumes in the US, Europe, and China.

site_title: Japan's Abe: Must avoid hurting recovery with sales tax rise
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the government must avoid hurting the economic recovery when deciding on a sales tax increase next year. Abe plans to decide by the end of the year whether to raise the sales tax to 10% from 8% in October 2015. He emphasized the need to achieve fiscal reform while promoting economic growth to end deflation. The decision will be crucial in restoring Japan's finances, but Abe's plan remains unchanged.

site_title: US tech giants investing big to stay ahead
summary: US tech giants such as Amazon, Facebook, and Google are investing heavily in various ventures to stay ahead in the market, with some placing big bets on non-core products. These investments include Facebook's $20 billion acquisition of WhatsApp and $2 billion investment in Oculus, Google's investment in virtual reality startup Magic Leap, and Amazon's expansion of its online gaming presence and grocery delivery service. While some investors view these investments as visionary, others have expressed concerns about governance and potential returns on investment.

site_title: Britain claims victory after EU defers budget bill
summary: Britain has secured a temporary reprieve from a 2.1-billion-euro EU budget bill, with the deadline extended to September 2015. Finance Minister George Osborne hailed the deal as a victory for Britain, allowing the country to avoid paying the full amount before general elections in May. Britain will pay half the amount in two instalments, offsetting a full upfront payment of the £3 billion annual rebate negotiated by Margaret Thatcher. The EU has agreed to keep the amount under discussion for the 2016 budget, but European sources suggest it could be renegotiated after the British elections.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end 4.57pts lower
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.14% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 4.57 points to 3,286.39. The market traded 1.21 billion shares valued at S$1.08 billion, with 186 gainers and 238 losers. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with stocks extending gains despite US trade uncertainty and new Trump threats.

site_title: Japan will contribute to early TPP trade deal: PM Abe
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that the country will actively contribute to an early conclusion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal ahead of a key meeting of trade ministers in Beijing. The 12-nation talks have been stalled due to a deadlock between Japan and the US over access to Japan's agricultural market. Economy Minister Akira Amari confirmed that Japan will cooperate with other TPP members to reach a deal. A resolution is seen as crucial for the multilateral trade talks.

site_title: Wee Hur's nine-month revenue, earnings soar on completion of industrial property
summary: Wee Hur Holdings reported a nine-month net profit of S$102.5 million, a more-than-seven-time increase from S$13.1 million last year, driven by the completion of its industrial property development project, Premier@Kaki Bukit, which received its temporary occupation permit in August 2014 and has almost been fully sold. The company's revenue also more than doubled to S$603 million. This surpassed the group's record annual profit of S$95.7 million in FY2012, highlighting the successful completion of the project.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust buys S$34m property, sells another for S$13.5m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust acquired a S$34 million property at 190A Pandan Loop, projecting a 6.5% net property income yield. The trust also sold a property at 134 Joo Seng Road for S$13.5 million, following its capital-recycling strategy to divest underperforming assets. The CEO cited the attractive location and long remaining land lease tenure of 40 years for the 190A Pandan Loop acquisition, while the Joo Seng Road property was deemed older and with limited scope for future enhancement.

site_title: Seoul: Won recovers from 14-mth low struck on govt comments; shares higher
summary: The South Korean won recovered from a 14-month low, closing at 1,083.8 against the dollar after Vice Finance Minister Joo Hyung-hwan stated the government would manage the currency to align with the Japanese yen. The won had fallen 1.2% earlier, its lowest level since September 6, 2013. South Korean shares rose, with automakers Hyundai and Kia Motor increasing 5% and 6.9% respectively, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index edged 0.26% higher.

site_title: Time for SGX to show the numbers
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faced criticism after its trading systems were shut down on November 5, prompting an online petition to remove CEO Magnus Bocker. SGX refused to disclose operational statistics, including uptime and downtime thresholds, despite public interest. Regulators should consider making these statistics updated and available to increase transparency and public scrutiny. This could benefit SGX by keeping it accountable and providing a comprehensive picture of its trading systems' performance.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and similar operating loss as in H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises as weak yen helps exporters; Takata slides
summary: Japanese stocks rose on Friday as a weaker yen boosted exporters, with the Nikkei benchmark adding 0.5% to 16,880.38. Panasonic and Disco were strong performers, while Takata Corp slid 7.3% after reports revealed it destroyed test results for potentially defective air bags. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained 0.5% and 0.6%, respectively, finishing the week up 2.8%.

site_title: Indonesia to begin building huge coal power plant in 2015
summary: Indonesia plans to build a 5,000-MW coal-fired power plant in central Java, starting construction in 2015. The project aims to meet the country's growing electricity demand, which has outpaced generating capacity, leading to frequent blackouts. The plant will generate 2,000 MW initially and take seven years to complete. The government aims to increase electricity capacity to 35,000 MW by 2020 to avoid an electricity crisis, with the state power company expecting a 8.4% annual growth in demand. The project will also use the latest technology to reduce air pollution.

images.alt_text: Indonesia will begin building a huge coal-fired power plant next year, government officials said on Thursday, as Southeast Asia's biggest economy looks to keep pace with soaring electricity demand and avert a power crisis.

site_title: Venture Corp Q3 net profit up 3.2%
summary: Venture Corporation reported a 3.2% increase in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$36.1 million, driven by a 1.7% rise in revenue to S$599 million and improved margins. The company's pre-tax profit margin increased to 6.8% from 6.2% in the same period last year.

site_title: Audi Oct sales up 10.8% on demand for compacts, SUV's
summary: Audi reported a 10.8% increase in October sales to 146,200 vehicles, driven by strong demand for compact SUVs and luxury sedans. The Q5 and A3 models contributed to the growth, with increases in sales in China (17%), the US (16.5%), and the UK (22.1%). European sales rose 5.4%, while Russia saw a 15.8% decline. Audi's deliveries rose in all major regions, indicating a positive trend for the company.

site_title: Lenovo CFO: 50% of US$5.2b spent on Motorola, IBM server acquisitions booked as intangible assets
summary: Lenovo reported a 19% increase in net income in the second fiscal quarter, but revenue fell short of analyst expectations. CFO Wong Waiming stated that about 50% of the $5.2 billion spent on Motorola and IBM acquisitions was booked as intangible assets, rather than being recorded as expenses. This indicates that Lenovo is using a more aggressive accounting method to reduce its expenses and potentially boost its bottom line.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end 7.79 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended 7.79 points lower, closing at 1,824.19 on Friday. 2.52 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion were traded, with 409 gainers and 392 losers. This brings the three-month moving average to a 7-month high.

site_title: CapitaLand Q3 net profit inches up 1.3% to S$129.98m
summary: CapitaLand reported a 1.3% increase in net profit to S$129.98 million for Q3 FY2014, driven by higher rental revenue from shopping malls and serviced-residences. Revenue declined 4.3% to S$918.93 million, primarily due to lower revenue from Chinese development projects. Earnings per share edged up to 3.1 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share dipped to S$3.72. The counter closed 3 cents higher on the stock market following the announcement of its results.

site_title: Noble Group Q3 net profit soars (Amended)
summary: Noble Group reported a three-fold increase in third-quarter net profit to US$153.9 million, driven by revenue growth of 7% to US$23.3 billion. The firm's agriculture unit underperformed, but its supply chains division achieved an all-time record nine-month operating profit. Noble closed the sale of its Noble Agri stake to a Chinese consortium and is distributing a special dividend. The company's stock price rose 1 cent to S$1.20.

site_title: Japan's Sendai nuclear plant wins regional vote to restart
summary: Regional authorities in Japan approved the restart of the Sendai nuclear plant in Kagoshima prefecture, paving the way for the revival of the country's nuclear industry. The decision, made by the prefectural assembly, comes after the local township previously endorsed the restart. The plant's restart is contingent on passing operational safety checks, which are expected to be completed by next year. The move represents a victory for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government, which has pushed to restart Japan's nuclear fleet.

site_title: Singapore Airlines not considering full takeover bid for Tiger Airways: CEO
summary: Singapore Airlines is not considering a full takeover bid for Tiger Airways, despite raising its stake to 71% through a rights issue. CEO Goh Choon Phong stated that the airline's focus is on helping Tiger return to financial health and aligning with its low-fare strategy. Tiger has booked losses for three consecutive years, including a record $223 million loss in the previous year. The airline's shares have plummeted 40% over the past three months.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise 0.8% as ECB buoys mood, miners lead
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by a European Central Bank pledge to revive the euro zone economy, boosting sentiment. Mining stocks rebounded after selling off in the past week, contributing to the gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,549.1 points, while New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 0.3%. The rally followed a strong week for the Australian market, which rose 0.41% on the week.

site_title: Singapore shipping fuel scandal sends traders scrambling
summary: A suspected fraud at Singapore-based Dynamic Oil Trading, a subsidiary of Danish marine fuel supplier OW Bunker, has pushed the company to the brink of bankruptcy, estimated to be around US$125 million. The alleged fraud is linked to the recent sharp fall in oil prices, with traders and shipping companies scrambling to source fuel and take over supply contracts. OW Bunker's shares have been suspended, and the company has fired its head of risk management. The fallout in the market is expected to be significant, with refineries and other shipping fuel suppliers cutting deliveries and cancelling long-term contracts with the Danish company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower, railway sector slumps
summary: Hong Kong shares ended lower on Friday, closing 0.4% at 23,550.24 points, after a volatile session. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.9% for the week, while the China Enterprises Index fell 2%. Analysts attributed the decline to profit taking and lack of buying momentum amid largely in-line earnings reports. The railway sector slumped 5% after Mexico's president revoked a rail contract with China, and investors await developments on the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connector scheme.

site_title: Indonesia's new president targets food self-sustainability
summary: Indonesia's new president, Joko Widodo, aims to achieve food self-sustainability within five years, targeting specific staples like beef (1 year), rice (3 years), soybeans and corn (4 years), and sugar (4-5 years). This goal is part of his efforts to support the agriculture sector, which accounts for 15% of Indonesia's GDP. To achieve this, Widodo plans to construct 25-30 new reservoirs, which will begin construction next year.

site_title: Malaysian state investor 1MDB sinks to a loss on borrowing costs
summary: Malaysia's state investor 1MDB reported a loss in its last financial year due to increased borrowing costs, ahead of a planned $3 billion IPO for its power assets. The fund, chaired by Prime Minister Najib Razak, has a debt burden of over $11 billion and has faced criticism for its investment decisions and high fees paid to Goldman Sachs. The fund is expected to formally file for the IPO in the near future to cut down on its debt.

site_title: Historic shift as Abu Dhabi looks to Asia for oil concession
summary: Abu Dhabi is set to award a 40-year oil concession to Asian firms, marking a historic shift in the global energy market. The emirate's Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) is reviewing bids from nine international majors, with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), South Korea's Korean National Oil Corporation (KNOC), and Japan's Inpex Corporation among the top contenders. The new concession aims to raise output from 1.5 million barrels per day to 1.8 million by 2017, as Asia's growing energy demands and increasing imports from the Middle East drive the shift.

site_title: Hot stock: STATS ChipPAC shares skid over 16%
summary: STATS ChipPAC shares plummeted 16% or 9.5 Singapore cents to 48.5 Singapore cents after resuming trading following a halt pending a US$780 million bid by Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology (JCET) at 45.2 Singapore cents per share, a 20% discount. The counter was heavily traded with 37 million shares worth S$18 million. The bid represents a significant move in the chipmaker's future.

site_title: Joblessness, inequality top global concerns in 2015: report
summary: Global leaders in 2015 will face top concerns of joblessness and rising income inequality, according to a World Economic Forum (WEF) report. The list, based on surveys of 1,800 experts, ranks income inequality as the top issue, with stagnant wages contributing to a cycle of entrenched inequality. Lack of job growth and rising geostrategic competition also made the top 10, while environmental issues and health concerns were highlighted. The report warns of a "global leadership crisis" and stresses the need for bold leadership to tackle societal and economic challenges.

site_title: UK banks face break-up threat as competition probe launched
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into the country's big four banks, Lloyds Banking Group, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays, and HSBC, due to a lack of competition in services for small business customers and personal accounts. The investigation, expected to take until summer 2016 to complete, aims to address concerns over low levels of customer switching, barriers to entry for smaller banks, and limited transparency. The CMA has the power to order a break-up of banks considered too dominant, and may force banks to sell branches in areas where they are particularly strong.

site_title: Four Japan banks likely to bid for Citi's Japan retail unit: sources
summary: Four Japanese banks, including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp and Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Bank, are expected to bid for Citigroup's unprofitable consumer banking business in Japan in the second round of bidding. Shinsei Bank and Resona Bank are also likely to participate. The four banks were among those that initially bid for the unit in September. The bidding process is ongoing, with no final decision expected until mid-2026.

site_title: Bank Indonesia official sees 2014 full-year GDP growth at 5.1%
summary: Bank Indonesia official expects Indonesia's 2014 full-year GDP growth to reach 5.1%. This growth rate is lower than the third quarter's 5.01% expansion, the weakest since 2009. The forecast assumes public spending does not slow in the fourth quarter, despite a huge tax revenue shortfall. A weaker growth rate could be a concern for the government.

site_title: Singapore remains No 2 destination for Chinese investments: EIU
summary: Singapore remains the second most attractive destination for Chinese investments, following the US, according to The Economist Intelligence Unit's China Going Global Investment Index. Hong Kong ranks third. Japan slipped to sixth place due to deteriorating relations with China. The EIU attributes Singapore's high ranking to its large market size, diversified economy, and strong intellectual property protection. Conversely, Southern European countries, such as Italy and Spain, lag due to economic growth concerns and weaker intellectual property development.

site_title: MS Holdings opens 32% up on Catalist debut
summary: MS Holdings, a crane rental operator, made its maiden day on SGX-Catalist, opening 32% higher at 33 Singapore cents, up from its offer price of 25 cents. The company raised S$3.8 million from its initial public offering to acquire mobile cranes, develop its business, and for working capital. Strong trading activity with 7 million shares worth S$2.4 million in the first hour.

site_title: Malaysians accused of hacking US news website
summary: A US-based news website, Environment News Service, accused Malaysian government hackers of shutting down its website after it published a story on a senior politician's alleged graft. The hacking occurred after a law firm representing the politician demanded to withhold publication of a book investigating massive forest destruction in Malaysia. The book, "Money Logging," implicates 78-year-old Abdul Taib Mahmud, a powerful member of the ruling coalition, in enriching himself through the state's economy. The attack lasted two hours, with the website's servers being taken offline by a Malaysian government entity.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher, focus on US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose broadly on Friday, driven by a record close on Wall Street and comments from the European Central Bank's Mario Draghi signaling a readiness to widen its stimulus program. Tokyo rose 0.74%, while Sydney and Seoul added 0.41% and 0.11%, respectively. The euro hit a two-year low against the dollar, and the yen surged against it, supporting Japanese shares. US shares extended their advance ahead of October jobs data, with the Dow and S&P 500 reaching new highs.

site_title: Soaring land prices in Manila spark property bubble concerns
summary: Record bids for two plots of land in Manila's business district have driven prices to a 17-year high, sparking concerns of a property bubble. The 1,600-square-metre site sold for 732.8 million pesos (S$21 million) and 800 million pesos each at a government auction in September. This surge in land prices has raised concerns about the market's stability, potentially leading to a bubble. The auction results have also highlighted the growing demand for land in the city.

site_title: Home Depot says 53m email addresses taken in breach
summary: Home Depot disclosed a massive data breach, with 53 million email addresses stolen by cybercriminals. The hackers exploited a third-party vendor's credentials to gain access to the company's network, which previously suffered a breach resulting in 56 million credit card numbers stolen. Although the stolen email information did not contain passwords or sensitive data, it could be used for "phishing" scams. Home Depot has eliminated the malware from its systems and is offering credit monitoring to affected customers, while the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.84% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.84% higher on Friday, following a rally on Wall Street and a rebound in the dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 141.56 points to 16,934.04. A strong dollar is positive for Japanese exporters, making them more competitive abroad and inflating profits when repatriated. The dollar was at 115.35 yen, up from 115.16 yen in New York Thursday afternoon.

site_title: PepsiCo president Zein Abdalla to retire on Nov 6
summary: PepsiCo president Zein Abdalla is set to retire by the end of the year, following the departure of Brian Connell, the head of Pepsi's Americas Foods unit, who left to become Target Corp's CEO. Abdalla, who joined PepsiCo in 1995, served as president since 2012, but the reason for his departure remains undisclosed. This marks the second high-profile executive departure at PepsiCo in recent months, amid a period of significant change in the company's leadership.

site_title: OW Bunker chairman says company at risk of bankruptcy
summary: Danish ship fuel supplier OW Bunker is at risk of bankruptcy due to trading losses and a fraud committed by senior employees in its Singapore-based subsidiary. Chairman Niels Henrik Jensen stated the company owes 13 banks $750 million. Despite Danske Bank and Nordea's continued support, 11 international banks have withdrawn their support, prompting management to file for a court restructuring process.

site_title: Philippines' Emperador says Singapore's GIC to buy initial 9.64% stake
summary: Philippine liquor firm Emperador Inc. has agreed to sell a 9.64% stake to Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) for $391 million. The deal will strengthen Emperador's capital position and expand its portfolio. GIC will buy 1.12 billion common shares at 11 pesos per share, a 3.2% premium over the stock's closing price. Emperador also granted GIC an option to invest an additional $4.4 billion over 13 months, potentially raising GIC's stake to 11.76%.

site_title: Yangzijiang posts 1% fall in Q3 profit, to cut investments in non-shipbuilding businesses
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 1% decline in Q3 net profit to 811.19 million yuan due to lower gross profit and other gains. Revenue rose 2% to 3.74 billion yuan, driven by its shipbuilding segment. The company expects to take advantage of the shipbuilding industry's consolidation process, citing its strong financial strength and capabilities. Yangzijiang plans to reduce investments in non-shipbuilding businesses, including property businesses, to focus on its core shipbuilding operations.

site_title: Vallianz more than doubles net profit for Q3, confident of prospects
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a net profit of US$4.82 million for the third quarter, more than doubling from US$2.14 million a year ago. Revenue increased by five-fold to US$39.25 million, driven by Middle East operations. The company added four new vessels to its fleet, aiming to reach 50 vessels by 2016. CEO Darren Yeo expressed confidence in chartering demand for its offshore support vessels, citing strong relationships with national oil companies and long-term contracts. The company remains optimistic about its prospects in the Middle East and target markets.

site_title: Canadian pension fund named in Luxembourg tax leaks
summary: A Canadian government agency, the Public Sector Pension Investment Board, has been named in Luxembourg tax leaks for using complex schemes to avoid paying taxes. The board, which manages civil servants' pensions, avoided paying Can$20 million in German taxes by exploiting a loophole in the country's land transfer tax and using a system of shell company transactions in Luxembourg. The scheme was uncovered by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which also revealed similar tax avoidance practices by other multinationals, including Pepsi and Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust Q3 DPU slips 6.4%
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 6.4% drop in distributable income to S$23.45 million for Q3 2014, with distribution per unit falling 6.4% to 1.32 Singapore cents. Net property income decreased 1.2% to S$28.19 million, while gross revenue remained flat at S$31.15 million. Despite the decline, the trust maintained high occupancies in its serviced residences and commercial spaces. CEO Gerald Lee attributed the steady income to these segments, which helped cushion the softer performance of hotels.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 profit slips 8%, hit by weak European operations
summary: ST Engineering posted an 8% dip in net profit to S$121.3 million in Q3, largely due to weak European operations. Revenue was flat at S$1.553 billion, driven by a 14% higher revenue from the marine sector. The aerospace sector saw a 19% decline in pre-tax profit due to weak European operations and restructuring costs. Despite this, the land systems and marine sectors reported comparable pre-tax profits. The company's order book stood at S$13.2 billion, with deliveries expected in the last quarter of 2014.

site_title: China looking to develop big passenger plane
summary: China is seeking suppliers to develop its own wide-body passenger plane, the C929, over the next decade. The state-backed Commercial Aircraft Corp. of China (COMAC) aims to surpass its smaller C919 and ARJ21 regional jets. The C929 would have a capacity of 158-168 seats, representing a substantial advance for the Chinese aviation industry. This move expands China's rivalry with Boeing and Airbus, and COMAC is expected to play a key role in the development of the aircraft.

site_title: AusGroup seeks trading halt ahead of planned acquisitions
summary: AusGroup, a solutions provider for oil & gas and infrastructure development, has sought a trading halt ahead of a planned acquisition of Ezion Offshore Logistics Hub Pte Ltd and a 90% stake in Teras Australia Pty Ltd. The acquisition, valued at S$55 million, includes a port and marine supply base in the Tiwi Islands near Darwin, Australia. AusGroup plans to pay S$14 million in cash and issue new shares to complete the purchase, with the remaining 10% of Teras Australia held by Aboriginal Maritime Pty Ltd.

site_title: The Force Awakens: new Star Wars film has title
summary: Disney reveals the title of the seventh Star Wars film, "The Force Awakens," with filming now complete. Directed by J.J. Abrams, the film is set to be released on December 18, 2015, with a star-studded cast including Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, and Oscar winner Lupita Nyong'o. The title is speculated to refer to the return of the Jedi and Sith, with fans wondering if it represents the light and dark sides of the Force.

site_title: LivingSocial cuts 400 jobs in latest reorganisation
summary: LivingSocial has cut 400 jobs, or 20% of its staff, as part of its latest reorganisation to create a more streamlined sales model. The company, which reported a quarterly loss of $32 million and declining revenues, aims to focus on areas such as technology, data science, and mobile. The move is part of a broader shift away from online discounts to a marketplace model, as the online deals segment becomes increasingly stagnant. The company now has approximately 1,600 employees worldwide.

site_title: CBS launches 'always on' streaming news service
summary: CBS has launched CBSN, a 24/7 streaming news service offering live "anchored" news reports and on-demand content. The service is available on CBSNews.com, mobile websites, and devices such as Amazon Fire TV and Roku players. CBSN features a 60-minute format with live coverage 15 hours a day, Monday through Friday, and can be controlled with DVR-like functionality. The move aims to compete with other streaming news services, including Netflix, Vice Media, and HuffPost Live. CBS Corp president and CEO Leslie Moonves sees a "tremendous opportunity" for the service.

site_title: Newly listed Japfa posts 10% decline in Q3 net profit
summary: Japfa Ltd, an agri-food group, reported a 10% decline in Q3 net profit to US$10.77 million, despite a 15% increase in revenue to US$784.66 million. The decline was attributed to weaker Indonesian rupiah, which depreciated 20% against the US dollar, and higher finance costs. Japfa attributed the decline to short-term factors, but sees long-term growth potential in protein food consumption in emerging markets.

site_title: Yuan business to expand in the Americas with a clearing bank in Canada
summary: Canada is set to become the first country in the Americas with a yuan clearing bank, with Toronto expected to host the facility. The move is part of China's efforts to promote its currency globally and reduce transaction costs for businesses. A yuan clearing bank would facilitate trade settlement and reduce currency risk, attracting yuan funds to accumulate in the country. The development is seen as a positive step for trade and business between China and Canada, with the Bank of Canada Governor expressing support for the idea.

images.alt_text: The global journey of the Chinese currency is set to enter a new stage with the first yuan clearing bank in the Americas, to be launched in Canada soon, boding well for the growth of a yuan deposit pool and investor participation there.

site_title: Kim Heng's Q3 profit plummets 62%
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings reported a 62% fall in net profit to S$1.15 million for the July-September quarter, driven by lower revenue and gross profit margin. The company expects its final quarter to outperform the third quarter. This marks a significant decline from the previous quarter's profit. The company's listing on Catalist in January this year is attributed to the decline in earnings.

site_title: New malware can infect iPhones via Mac computers
summary: A newly discovered malware, WireLurker, can infect iPhones via Mac computers, posing a security threat to businesses, governments, and Apple customers worldwide. The malware, capable of stealing information and requesting updates from attackers, was traced back to a Chinese app store with 467 infected applications. Apple has blocked the malware, and security researchers warn of a potentially large security issue due to the design of iOS' pairing mechanism. The WireLurker malware is unlike any previously documented threat targeting Apple platforms, and its creator's ultimate goal is unclear.

site_title: Bank of America triples Q3 loss on forex legal costs
summary: Bank of America reported a Q3 loss of $232 million, or four cents per share, due to higher legal costs from probes into foreign exchange manipulation. The bank initially reported a net loss of $70 million, or one cent per share. A $400 million charge was taken to resolve US investigations into its forex business, following separate advanced discussions with regulatory agencies. This charge, combined with a $5.3 billion mortgage-securities settlement in August, significantly impacted the bank's financial results.

site_title: Defensive Hollande admits 'mistakes' in last-ditch TV bid
summary: Francois Hollande, France's unpopular president, admitted to "mistakes" in a rare TV interview, vowing to go "to the end" to reform the crisis-hit country despite low approval ratings and a strong showing by far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. Hollande reiterated his pledge to cut unemployment by the end of his term, but acknowledged the need for reform, including a 40 billion euro tax cut for businesses. His approval rating is at a historic low of 12%, with over 90% of French people saying they do not want him to run for re-election in 2017.

images.alt_text: Francois Hollande, the most unpopular French president in history, admitted Thursday he was "hanging on" and had made errors but vowed to go "to the end" to reform the crisis-hit country.

site_title: Exec condo along Punggol Waterway launched
summary: Kheng Leong launched The Terrace, an executive condominium (EC) in Punggol, Singapore, with indicative prices ranging from S$770 to S$840 per sq ft. The 747 units, including three-, four- and five-bedroom units, will be available for booking from Nov 21. Experts expect around 40% of units to be sold in the first two months, despite a 30% mortgage servicing ratio and a large pipeline of upcoming EC units in the area.

images.alt_text: Indicative prices at The Terrace in Punggol are, on average, between S$770 and S$840 per sq ft (psf).

site_title: Are busy directors cutting corners or really supermen in suits?
summary: A study by the Singapore Institute of Directors and Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants found that only 17.8% of directors hold multiple directorships, contradicting concerns that busy directors are cutting corners. Busy directors have better attendance records and are more educated, but the study's findings do not control for the number of board meetings, raising questions about whether they can effectively discharge their responsibilities. Further research is needed to determine if busy directors are truly capable of fulfilling their duties.

site_title: Struggling eurodisney sees big dip in revenues
summary: Struggling EuroDisney reported a 2% decline in revenues to 1.3 billion euros (US$1.6 billion) for 2014, resulting in a net loss of 114 million euros. This marks a 35 million euro increase from the previous year's net loss. Visitor numbers to the Disney-themed park continued to decline, further exacerbating the financial struggles of the company.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 close at records for second day in a row
summary: US stocks closed at record highs for the second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising 0.40% to 17,554.47 and 2,031.21 respectively. Analysts expect a solid jobs report on Friday, and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments on stimulus measures boosted sentiment. Tech stocks like Tesla and Whole Foods Market gained, while Qualcomm fell after a US FTC investigation was announced.

site_title: Indonesia businesses brace for minimum wage hikes
summary: Indonesian businesses are bracing for a potential 30% minimum wage hike, amid labour unions' demands for increased pay. The move comes as the country faces a sluggish economy, underemployed workers, and a large pool of unskilled graduates. Analysts warn that such hikes could prompt companies to seek cheaper labour elsewhere, particularly in Vietnam. The Indonesian government is expected to decide on the wage increase next week, with some officials hinting at a 6% rise, bringing the benchmark minimum wage to approximately 2.5 million rupiah.

site_title: Singapore life insurance sector weakens in Q3
summary: Singapore's life insurance sector experienced a 6% decline in weighted new business premiums to S$705.4 million in Q3, driven by an 18% fall in weighted annual premiums to S$446.2 million. Despite this, weighted single premiums rose 24% to S$259.2 million. The decline is attributed to the decrease in annual premiums, while single premiums saw a significant increase.

site_title: Before I Go to Sleep evokes a big yawn
summary: The movie "Before I Go to Sleep" follows Christine (Nicole Kidman), a woman with atypical psychogenic amnesia, as she uncovers memories of her past through a secret video diary and therapy sessions. She discovers her husband Ben (Colin Firth) has lied to her about their life, and a violent assault occurred, but the film's slow pace and predictable plot lead to extreme boredom. The movie ends in a burst of violence, but the resolution is telegraphed early, making it forgettable.

site_title: Twitter has little to celebrate a year after IPO
summary: Twitter's one-year anniversary as a public company marks a mixed performance, with its stock price soaring 55% from its debut but other metrics, such as profitability and enterprise value, falling short of expectations. Despite a booming digital advertising business, the company continues to lose money and has a record-low enterprise value. Analysts say the disconnect between promise and performance makes Twitter's IPO one of the bigger "misfires" in technology stocks.

site_title: Luxembourg tax deals with global firms under fire after leaks
summary: Luxembourg is under fire for its tax avoidance deals with hundreds of top global firms, including Pepsi, Ikea, and Deutsche Bank, following a leaked investigation by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists. The deals, which span over two decades, allowed companies to slash their tax liabilities, depriving governments worldwide of vital revenue. Former Luxembourg premier Jean-Claude Juncker, now head of the EU's executive arm, is facing scrutiny for his role in the deals, with the European Commission investigating potential illegal state aid.

site_title: Resurrection
summary: Twin brothers Chun Kai Qun and Chun Kai Feng transformed an abandoned Jade House building in Haw Par Villa park into Latent Spaces, a multi-purpose art space, with the help of friend Elizabeth Gan. The space, which has hosted art exhibitions, workshops, and talks, was previously unused and had been left to decay. The brothers, artists and sculptural trained sculptors, spent two months renovating the space with funding from the Singapore Tourism Board. The six-month lease has been extended until next April, with the next exhibition, "Dissolving The Object," scheduled for January.

site_title: International trade is where Obama, Republicans find common ground
summary: US President Barack Obama is approaching the end of his second term with limited political capital, facing opposition from the Republican-controlled Congress on key policy areas. However, international trade may be an area where the White House and Congress can find common ground, as Obama and Republican leaders have expressed support for liberalizing global trade and negotiating historic trade deals like the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Obama may use his upcoming trip to Asia to push for a Pacific trade deal, potentially gaining bipartisan support for trade promotion authority.

site_title: HDB resale prices up for the first time this year
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.1% in October, marking the first increase this year. However, consultants warn that the increase is not a sign of a market turnaround, as loan curbs continue to affect the market. Prices for executive flats drove up, while four-room HDB flats levelled with September's prices. Resale volume increased 5.7% in October, with prices down 6.1% from October 2013. Experts predict further price falls, with a soft landing price fall of around 7% for the year.

site_title: M&S H1 profit rises, thanks to women's clothing
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) reported its first rise in first-half profit in four years, driven by a 1.3% sales uplift in its women's clothing category. The retailer's revamped women'swear has won praise from the fashion press, with female shoppers being drawn back to its stores. Despite a decline in general merchandise sales, M&S raised its profit margin forecast for non-food products and lowered guidance on cost growth. The company's shares jumped 9% following the results, but analysts said it was too soon to declare a turnaround.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC attracts US$780m bid from China firm
summary: STATS ChipPAC is reportedly nearing a deal with China's Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology (JCET) after a US$780 million bid, valuing the Singapore chipmaker at S$0.452 per share. The offer is a 20% discount from STATS ChipPAC's last traded price. The sale, pending regulatory approvals, will exclude two Taiwanese units with a book value of US$80.9 million. The restructuring process is ongoing, with JCET offering US$23.4 million if it doesn't receive Chinese regulatory approval by a yet-to-be-disclosed date.

site_title: BOJ adopts shame gauge in search of higher ROE
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has adopted a shame gauge to encourage Japanese companies to become more profitable, aiming for a return on equity (ROE) of 8%. The BOJ will buy ETFs tracking the JPX-Nikkei Index 400, which currently averages 9.4%, to shame companies into using their cash better. This move follows a government-endorsed ROE target of 8% and a stewardship code to press management for higher returns. Experts predict that if ROE rises to 12%, the Nikkei 225 would climb to 20,000.

site_title: Let there be light when disruption strikes
summary: A power outage at Singapore's stock and derivatives markets on November 6, 2014, caused widespread confusion among traders and investors, with some criticizing the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for its lack of clear communication. The outage lasted for half of the day, with SGX updating brokers but not retail investors until late in the day. The incident highlights the need for greater accountability and transparency from market operators, with regulators considering requiring statistics on downtime and operational continuity.

site_title: Dubai's Abraaj acquires majority stake in Wine Connection Group
summary: Dubai-based private equity firm The Abraaj Group has acquired a majority stake in Wine Connection Group, a South-east Asian food and beverage chain. The investment aligns with Abraaj's strategy of investing in growth markets, particularly in the consumer sector. Wine Connection, which has over 60 outlets in Singapore and Thailand, plans to expand to Asean markets, including India and Dubai, within the next year. The acquisition marks Abraaj's fourth investment in the region and its fourth in the F&B sector globally.

site_title: Indonesia to build coal-fired power plant
summary: Indonesia plans to build a 5,000 MW coal-fired power plant in central Java, generating 2,000 MW by 2018. The project aims to meet the country's soaring electricity demand, which has outpaced generating capacity, causing frequent blackouts. The government seeks to avoid an electricity crisis, with a target of 35,000 MW of capacity by 2025. The project's completion is expected to take seven years, and it will utilize the latest technology to reduce air pollution. The move aims to tackle Indonesia's energy needs, with 250 million people lacking access to electricity.

site_title: Unplugging to say goodbye to his fans
summary: American singer-songwriter Jason Mraz is set to perform a farewell tour in Singapore with a possible last show. His upcoming intimate theatre shows will feature acoustic performances, including his classic hits and new songs from his album "Yes!". Mraz, a two-time Grammy winner, plans to retire from music before turning 40 to focus on farming and charity work. The "Acoustic Evening with Jason Mraz and Raining Jane" will take place on November 17-18 at The Star Theatre, with tickets starting from SGD 68.

site_title: Gearing up for Malaysia GST
summary: Malaysia will introduce a goods and services tax (GST) on April 1, 2015, replacing its sales and services tax. The new tax aims to address the country's budget deficit and growing debt. The initial projections suggest GST collections will be RM690 million, with various reliefs and exemptions to help lower-income Malaysians cope with rising costs. The new tax system will adopt some rules and schemes from Singapore's GST regime, but with differences in scope and administration. Businesses operating in Malaysia should prepare for the change to avoid penalties for non-compliance.

site_title: A-HTrust posts 9.9% fall in Q2 DPS to 1.27 cents
summary: A-HTrust, a Singapore-based hospitality trust, reported a 9.9% decline in distribution per share (DPS) for its fiscal Q2, falling to 1.27 Singapore cents. The decrease was attributed to an unwinding of forex derivatives, resulting in a 9.8% drop in distributable income. This marks a significant decrease from the same period last year, when DPS stood at 1.41 Singapore cents.

site_title: Mobile newspaper readership growing, but print remains staple read: Nielsen
summary: Mobile newspaper readership in Singapore is growing, with 16% of adults reading digital newspapers on mobile devices, up from 12% last year. Print newspapers remain the staple read, with 60% reading a hardcopy newspaper daily. The Straits Times is the most-read English title, with 32% of its readers having a monthly household income of S$5,000 or more. Nielsen's report highlights the shift in media consumption habits, emphasizing the importance of understanding consumer behavior to engage and connect with them.

site_title: Petrobras yet to set time or size of fuel price hike
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras has yet to set a date or size for a potential increase in domestic fuel prices, citing the need to maintain current prices. The company has lost over 59 billion reais due to government refusal to raise fuel prices, resulting in significant losses and increasing debt. Petrobras is now the most-indebted major oil firm, with 138 billion dollars in debt, and is struggling to meet its 5-year investment plan. The company's refining losses have crimped profit and made it the least profitable among the 28 largest oil companies.

site_title: Anti-haze body eyes launch of tracking portal
summary: Singapore is launching a Haze Tracking Portal (HTP) to track and analyze the source of regional haze caused by Indonesia's forest fires. The portal, set to launch in early 2015, will combine real-time thermal hotspots, wind direction, land use, and concession maps to help law enforcers, environmental activists, and commodity buyers analyze the haze. The initiative aims to reinforce Singapore's Haze Law and engage with agri-businesses in a positive way to encourage cooperation in addressing the pollution crisis.

site_title: Jubilee babies to get free GE health insurance for a year
summary: Great Eastern is offering free health insurance worth S$108 for the first year to parents of Jubilee babies in Singapore. The insurance will be provided from 2015. The company will also send a Jubilee Baby Pack, comprising mittens, booties, and a bib, to parents-to-be two months before delivery. Additionally, Great Eastern will grant 50 wishes to the public, with the first 5,000 online-entry senders receiving a limited edition EZ-link card. The company's SG50 events will also include a fundraising campaign and a series of activities to raise S$500,000 for children and women-related causes.

site_title: CAO's net plunges 66.5% to US$7.32m in third quarter
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 66.5% drop in net profit to US$7.32m in the third quarter, primarily due to an operating loss of US$7.54m and lower gross profit from trading oil products. The company's share of profit from associates fell 36.8% to US$15.2m, while total revenue rose 30.3% to US$4.78 billion. Earnings per share decreased to 0.85 US cents, lower than the 2.54 US cents in the same period last year.

site_title: Qualcomm beset by probes in US, Europe, China
summary: Qualcomm Inc faces regulatory challenges, with an 11-month-old antitrust investigation in China potentially harming its business next year due to the country's expanding 4G network. The company also disclosed new investigations in the US and Europe. Qualcomm warned that these issues could impact its ability to collect royalties, affecting its business prospects in China and globally.

site_title: Japan builds energy hub to tap US shale gas revolution
summary: Japan aims to establish an energy hub in Asia to tap into the US shale gas revolution, with the country's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry predicting that the US will export liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Asia starting in 2016. Japan is also moving towards creating an LNG hub, with a market for LNG established in September and spot transactions increasing by 30% since the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Greater flexibility in energy contracts is expected to bring cheaper fuel to the Asia region, with the International Energy Agency predicting a 30% increase in global LNG demand within the next five years.

site_title: Commodity firm banks on ties with Shell
summary: Raizen Energia SA, a joint venture between Royal Dutch Shell and Cosan SA, sold 675 million reais (S$346.7 million) of asset-backed bonds backed by agricultural production, attracting a record number of buyers despite the struggling sugar industry. The bonds were sold at a yield equal to Brazil's interbank rate, 11.06%, and were mostly purchased by individuals, who won't pay income taxes on the debt if held until maturity. This sale allows Raizen to lower its debt costs and diversify its funding basis, capitalizing on its implicit debt guarantee from its owners.

site_title: Saving the last of our dragon kilns
summary: Singapore's last two remaining dragon kilns, at Thow Kuang and Guan Huat, are being preserved through the Awaken the Dragon festival. Ceramic artists and volunteers have been working together to raise funds through crowdfunding, with a goal of S$8,000, to support the festival's programs, including workshops, concerts, and food bazaar. The festival, scheduled for November 22-23, aims to raise awareness about the history and cultural significance of dragon kilns in Singapore.

site_title: 'Tis the season to buy your dog a knit sweater
summary: American Eagle Outfitters is releasing a clothing line for dogs, called American Beagle Outfitters, to boost holiday sales. The line, featuring knit sweaters, puffer jackets, and hats, will be available online and in select stores. The move comes as the teen retailer struggles to sell clothes to human customers and faces sluggish sales. The company aims to capitalize on the $350 million Americans spent on pet costumes this Halloween, with prices ranging from $12.95 to $39.95.

site_title: Jobs in Australia up in October
summary: Australia added more jobs than forecast in October, with 24,100 new jobs, exceeding economists' expectations of 20,000. National unemployment remained at 6.2%, while state jobless rates showed significant variations, with Queensland jumping to 7% and Tasmania falling to 6.9%. The statistics bureau's methodology review aims to provide clearer job market data.

site_title: Death by data in American politics
summary: The article discusses how data-driven politics has become increasingly prevalent in American campaigns over the past decade. However, this approach has led to a "fiasco" as it prioritizes population reactions over individual judgement, moral character, and creativity. The data-driven philosophy, known as Impersonalism, has resulted in campaigns becoming worse, especially for those who over-rely on these techniques. This shift has also led to a lack of nuanced understanding of individual voters and their unique needs, ultimately undermining the democratic process.

site_title: Competition probe puts big UK banks under break-up threat
summary: Britain's big four banks, Lloyds Banking Group, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays, and HSBC, are under threat of a break-up due to a lack of competition in services for small business customers and personal accounts. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) launched an investigation, which may take until 2016 to complete, citing barriers to entry and limited transparency. The CMA has the power to order a break-up of dominant banks and impose behavioral remedies. The move aims to tackle the dominance of the Big 4 lenders, who control 77% of personal current accounts and 85% of business current accounts.

site_title: Confusing journey - but still worth taking
summary: Christopher Nolan's sci-fi thriller Interstellar explores the survival of humanity through a complex, visually stunning narrative. The film follows Cooper, a test pilot-turned-farmer, as he embarks on a perilous journey to find a habitable planet for humanity. Alongside a team of explorers, Cooper encounters gravitational anomalies, wormholes, and time-space shifts, ultimately discovering the power of love to transcend dimensions. With its epic scale and cerebral nature, Interstellar is a thought-provoking and emotionally linked story that challenges its audience.

site_title: ANZ's Asian business growing strongly
summary: ANZ's Asian business has seen significant growth, with operating income doubling since 2009. The bank's chief executive, Andrew Géczy, attributes the gains to strong performance in FX and interest rates, cash management, and trade in South-east Asia and Singapore. ANZ's Asian franchise has contributed to its record annual net profit of A$7.3 billion, a 15% increase. The bank's market share in both institutional and retail banking is increasing, fueling its growth in the region.

images.alt_text: In the last two years, the bank's compounded annual growth from South-east Asia has been 37 per cent, says Mr Géczy, CEO for international and institutional banking

site_title: Slumping gold price seems primed for further fall
summary: The gold price appears to be overvalued, with the ratio to silver at a 5-year high and to crude oil at a 17-month peak, according to market players. This could signal further declines in gold. Yoni Jacobs, chief investment strategist, stated that gold is not a good investment when equity markets rise and the dollar strengthens. The gold price has slumped this year, but its relative value to other commodities may indicate more declines to come. This is of concern to gold investors.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's FY14 nine-month net profit fell short of expectations at S$386 million, or 67% of forecast, due to a negative mix effect from a change in accounting policy. The company lowered its target price to S$3.60, citing lower margin assumptions. In contrast, Starhub reported Q3 FY14 revenue and net income above estimates, with a 12-month target price of S$3.90. Maxi-Cash Financial Services Corp's Q3 FY14 net profit grew 114% year-on-year, but its earnings still lag behind peers, leading to a target price of S$0.22.

site_title: City Buzz
summary: ONE Fighting Championship (ONE FC) is set to host its biggest bout, the "Battle of Lions," featuring Leandro Ataides and Igor Svirid for the Middleweight World Championship title. The event marks a significant milestone for the three-year-old MMA outfit, which has expanded to new markets in East Asia and the Middle East and plans to host 10 events in China next year. Meanwhile, Shakespeare's Globe Theatre is staging a production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and a new app, Glympse, allows users to share their location for up to four hours with others.

site_title: Lenovo posts 19% rise in Q2 profit
summary: Lenovo reported a 19% increase in Q2 profit to US$262 million, exceeding analyst expectations. Revenue rose 7% to US$10.5 billion, but mobile device sales fell 6%. Despite this, Lenovo maintained its lead in global PC sales, with laptop and desktop sales rising 0.9% and 6.4%, respectively. The company's shares declined 2.46% following the announcement. Lenovo is expanding its product markets after recent acquisitions and named Jerry Yang to its board of directors.

site_title: Apec set to launch study on China-backed free trade area
summary: Leaders at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) meeting will agree to launch a study on a China-backed free trade area, known as the Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP), amid controversy over competing US and Chinese visions for regional trade. The two-year study aims to investigate the feasibility of the FTAAP, how long it would take, and whether it would need to go through the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) or another framework. The move is seen as a way for China to push its proposal without opening formal negotiations.

site_title: Artistic pasar malams
summary: The Local People, an art collective, organized a unique "The Local People X Movember Night Market" at the rooftop carpark of People's Park Complex in Singapore, showcasing local artistic talents and raising awareness for men's cancers. The event featured over 90 stalls, including F&B stalls and performances by local musicians, and raised over S$900 for the Movember campaign. The team, consisting of four struggling musicians and artists, transformed the carpark into a mini festival, highlighting their unconventional approach to hosting night markets.

site_title: Never too late for romance
summary: Singapore playwright Joel Tan's new play, The Way We Go, explores complex relationships and love at different ages. Set in a fictional convent school, the play follows a group of teachers and former students as they navigate love, friendship, and identity. Tan drew inspiration from his own experiences and those of his former teachers, creating a romantic comedy that highlights the struggles of finding love later in life. The play, produced by Checkpoint Theatre, runs from Nov 20-29 at SOTA Studio Theatre and features a diverse cast of characters that reflect Singaporean society.

site_title: Taking recruitment to the next level
summary: Recruitment process outsourcing (RPO) is becoming increasingly popular in Singapore as companies seek to tackle the talent crisis. With 65% of employees planning to leave their jobs within the next 12 months, RPO allows organisations to access niche and hard-to-find talent, reduce agency spend, and increase productivity. By outsourcing recruitment, companies can also gain transparency and visibility, reduce new hire attrition, and save up to 70% on third-party recruitment costs. RPO 2.0 offers additional savings by increasing internal hiring and reducing new-hire attrition, making it a cost-effective solution for organisations looking to enhance their recruitment process.

site_title: Being able to showcase talents
summary: A musical production, A Nation In Concert 2014: A Wetlands Adventure, will be held at the Sands Theatre in Marina Bay Sands on Nov 8. The show features a diverse cast of "differently abled" performers from various organizations, including those with visual, hearing, and physical disabilities. The musical is centered around the theme of biological diversity at Sungei Buloh Wetland Reserve and will have two shows at 3pm and 7.30pm. The production costs are fully sponsored, and all net proceeds will be donated to participating charities and voluntary welfare organizations.

site_title: GIC to invest NZ$1.04b in five New Zealand shopping malls
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will invest NZ$1.04 billion (S$1.04 billion) in five New Zealand shopping malls through a 49% stake purchase from Scentre Group. The deal follows GIC's tie-up with an NZ property trust to co-invest in Auckland assets. The sale will give Scentre capital to invest in developments and repay debt, aiming to reduce its debt-to-asset ratio to 30-35%. This marks GIC's second investment in New Zealand, with the state fund managing over US$100 billion in assets.

site_title: Barclays mulls eight-way restructuring as Bank of England overhaul looms
summary: Barclays is considering an eight-way restructuring in response to UK regulatory requirements, which force banks to separate retail operations from riskier investment banking units. The bank is reviewing whether to put its British and European retail operations, US holding company, and back-office functions within a firewall, separating them from five other entities. This overhaul is part of efforts to avoid a repeat of the 2008 global turmoil and comply with the Bank of England's overhaul, with plans to submit a preliminary plan by January 6.

site_title: Hot Scotch
summary: A new retail store, The Whisky Library, has opened in Singapore, catering to rare Scottish and Japanese whiskies. The store, established by Vinum Fine Wines, features over 200 single malt labels, including extremely rare bottles from distillers like Brora and Karuizawa. The store's collection includes limited-edition whiskies, such as the 1969 Macallan Duncan Taylor and the Yamazaki Sherry Cask batch 2013. The Whisky Library aims to source rare whiskies and offer free tastings, with plans to work with distilleries for special private bottling.

site_title: MAS minorities give their nod to proposed privatisation
summary: Malaysia Airlines minority shareholders have approved the proposed privatization of the airline, with 93.98% voting in favor of the RM6 billion revamp plan. The plan, led by Khazanah Nasional, aims to right-size the airline and ensure its long-term sustainability. Despite expressing displeasure with the board and management, shareholders opted for the takeover offer, which includes a 27 sen buyout price and a promised RM800 travel voucher. The move paves the way for the airline's delisting and revamp, but it remains to be seen whether the government will implement the plan and make the necessary staff cuts.

site_title: Market reopens smoothly, new measures in place
summary: Singapore's markets reopened smoothly on Thursday after a three-hour disruption on Wednesday, with order matching going as expected. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) implemented new measures to reduce recovery times in case of a power management system failure. No issues were reported in the derivatives market, and duplicate "good till cancelled" orders from Wednesday morning were reversed by lunchtime.

site_title: Facebook launches Ebola charity donation button
summary: Facebook has launched a charity donation button to aid in Ebola relief efforts. Users can donate to three organizations - International Medical Corps, International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, and Save the Children - starting today. Additionally, Facebook is donating 100 terminals to provide internet access for aid workers in affected areas. This move follows CEO Mark Zuckerberg's earlier pledge to donate $25 million to the fight against Ebola.

site_title: Reported fraud at S'pore unit leaves OW facing bankruptcy
summary: A Danish marine fuel supplier, OW Bunker, is facing possible financial collapse due to reported fraud at its Singapore unit and significant risk management losses. The company has filed for court restructuring, citing a potential loss of US$125 million and a total mark-to-market loss of US$150 million. OW plays a key role in the bunkering process, and its collapse may affect medium-sized companies that rely on it for fuel supplies, potentially leading to a short-term supply disruption.

site_title: Singapore workers' 2015 pay rise seen to be third smallest in Asia
summary: Singapore workers can expect an average 4.5% wage increase in 2015, the third-lowest in Asia, with real wage increases projected to average 2% due to higher inflation. A separate survey found that only 40% of workers in Singapore believe they are paid a fair wage, with companies needing to address pay equity issues. In contrast, workers in Pakistan will receive the region's largest pay increase, while Japan will experience the lowest wage hikes. The salary gaps between China and Singapore are narrowing, with China set to give an 8% increase to staff next year.

images.alt_text: Workers in Singapore can expect an average wage increase of 4.5 per cent in 2015 - the same level as this year, but still much lower than many other economies in the region.

site_title: Apple blocks malware targeting products in China
summary: Apple has identified and blocked malicious software targeting users in China, following a discovery by Palo Alto Networks of a new family of malware that can infect iPhones and Mac computers. The malware originated from a Chinese third-party apps store, primarily affecting users within the country. Apple advises users to download software from trusted sources to prevent similar attacks. This incident highlights the increasing sophistication of attacks on Apple products.

site_title: Ascott's Q3 DPU drops 11% on one-off items, rights issue
summary: Ascott Reit reported a 3rd quarter DPU of 2.11 Singapore cents, an 11% drop from the same period last year, mainly due to one-off items. Revenue rose 9% to S$93.7m, driven by additional income from new properties and stronger contributions from existing ones, despite a 3% drop in Singapore revenue. Japan was the strongest-performing market, with revenue surging 26% due to the acquisition of Infini Garden and the depreciating yen. The Reit expects Singapore's performance to be in line with 2013, with a focus on maintaining high occupancy rates.

site_title: Sembcorp's Q3 profit down 22.7% at S$196.6m (Amended)
summary: Sembcorp Industries' Q3 profit dropped 22.7% to S$196.6 million, mainly due to a 34% decline in its utilities segment's net profit. The company's urban development unit saw a significant increase in Q3 net profit, while its marine business secured new contracts worth S$4.2 billion. Despite a 6% decline in Q9 net profit, Sembcorp expects its overseas business to grow, particularly in China and India. The company also faces competition in Singapore's power market, with the Energy Market Authority reducing vesting contract levels.

site_title: Esplanade reflects on Singapore's coming of age
summary: Singapore's national arts centre, Esplanade, is celebrating SG50 with a programme that revisits and illuminates the country's forgotten treasures. The celebration features a range of events, including a New Year's Eve fireworks display, a concert with landmark bands from the 1970s, and a theatre programme showcasing iconic Singapore plays. The Esplanade aims to reflect on the country's coming of age by re-examining its past and building on its cultural heritage for the future.

site_title: Golden Theatre goes indie
summary: The Golden Theatre, a 1,500-seat cinema in Singapore, is being reimagined by Pocket Projects as a new independent-film cinema called The Projector. Two of the smaller cinema halls will be renovated into the Green Room for film screenings and the Redrum for flexible events, while the lobby will be transformed into a cafe. The existing old elements, such as walls, floors, and seat mechanisms, will be preserved and updated with a contemporary touch. The Projector will officially open in January, featuring programming from the Singapore International Film Festival.

site_title: Ezion Q3 earnings up 29% on jump in revenue
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore marine group, reported a 29% year-on-year surge in third-quarter net profit to US$49.2 million, driven by a 24.5% rise in revenue to US$94.9 million. The increase was mainly due to chartering contributions from additional service rigs. Gross profit rose 31.8% to US$48.4 million, while earnings per share improved to 3.63 US cents. Despite recent oil price weakness, Ezion expects to deploy more service rigs in the fourth quarter and focus on growing its service rig division.

site_title: Images on a metallic medium
summary: American photographer H. Hugh Miller has released a new series titled MetalWorks, featuring urban architecture in cityscapes, printed on metallic sheets. This marks a departure from his previous mediums such as paper, silk, and wood. Miller's choice of metallic sheets highlights the importance of selecting the right medium for his works, alongside composition and style.

site_title: Peter Pan, like you've never seen him before (Amended)
summary: The stage musical "Peter Pan, The Never Ending Story" is now playing at Resorts World Sentosa, featuring a new soundtrack and songs by award-winning musical director Matt Dunkley. The show combines elements of circus, cinema, and live action, with 25 dancers, a singing cast, and visual effects. Dunkley aimed to create a unique theatrical form, using digital projection, flying systems, and production techniques. The production includes a mix of existing songs and original music, including a wordless choir and violin for a poignant scene depicting Tinkerbell's tragic moment. The show runs from November 27 to January 20, 2015.

site_title: Euro keeps small gains, focus turns to Draghi
summary: The euro maintained its gains, rising 0.3% to US$1.2519, despite the European Central Bank's decision to keep its benchmark interest rate at 0.05% and monetary easing expectations. The dollar backed away from its seven-year peak against the yen, while commodity currencies declined due to weakening global growth concerns. Investors await the US non-farm payrolls report on Friday, which may impact the euro's modest gains.

site_title: No impact from Wall Street peaks
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a relatively featureless session on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index ending 3.3 points higher at 3,290.96, despite a three-hour trading system shutdown due to a power supply glitch. Trading volumes were low, and prices moved within narrow bands. Key stocks, including Keppel Corp and StarHub, saw minimal movement. Analysts attributed this to the disconnect between local markets and global trends, particularly Wall Street's continued rise to new highs.

site_title: United mulls getting Embraer, Bombardier jets
summary: United Airlines is in talks with Embraer SA and Bombardier Inc to purchase new narrow-body planes to replace its unprofitable regional jets. The discussions involve Embraer's E-Jets and Bombardier's CSeries, which would fill a gap in United's fleet between its narrow-bodies and commuter planes. A deal would also allow United to place a separate order for regional jets to replace its 50-seat planes, boosting Embraer and Bombardier's sales efforts against Boeing and Airbus.

site_title: Taiwanese heartthrob faces naked truth
summary: Taiwanese heartthrob Ethan Ruan admitted to experiencing a physical reaction during a steamy bedroom scene with his mainland Chinese co-star Wan Qian while filming the coming-of-age historical drama "Paradise in Service". Ruan, 31, played a new recruit enlisted to work in an army brothel and wore only a sock for modesty. The film, set in a military brothel, features nudity that was left on the cutting room floor due to its rating. Ruan credits Wan's professionalism for helping him feel less awkward about the incident and praised the film's director, Doze Niu.

site_title: Luxury home prices in Singapore fall 10% over 12 months: report
summary: Luxury home prices in Singapore plummeted 10% over the past 12 months, the largest decline among 33 cities tracked by Knight Frank's Prime Global Cities Index. The drop is attributed to protracted property curbs aimed at stabilizing real estate prices, which had risen 30% over the last five years. In contrast, luxury home prices rose 4% globally, with other cities experiencing smaller declines. The market's muted sentiment is expected to continue, with transaction volumes likely to be thin in Q4 due to the year-end holiday season.

site_title: Tale of 2 cities for GCBs and Sentosa Cove bungalows
summary: The Sentosa Cove bungalow market has seen only two transactions this year, totaling S$27.5 million, compared to the Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market, which has 23 deals worth S$526 million. The Sentosa Cove market is largely driven by foreign buyers, who are deterred by the 15% ABSD and strong Singapore dollar. In contrast, the GCB market is supported by Singaporeans who prefer the lower density environment. The two recent bungalow sales on Sentosa Cove show a narrowing buyer-seller price gap, with more transactions expected in the coming months.

site_title: iCarsclub raises record US$60m Series B funding
summary: iCarsclub, a Singapore-based car-sharing app, has raised a record US$60 million in Series B funding. The funding, led by IDG Capital Partners and MorningSide Ventures, will support further expansion into Asia. Despite this, iCarsclub faces challenges as Asian governments have not yet fully embraced car-sharing, a significant hurdle to its growth. The company aims to continue its expansion plans, with the Series B funding expected to help it overcome this obstacle.

site_title: What Juncker team means for Singapore
summary: Jean-Claude Juncker's new team at the European Commission will have significant implications for Singapore, particularly in areas of trade, investment, and foreign relations. Juncker's team includes prominent European politicians, such as Federica Mogherini, who will oversee foreign and security policy, and Frans Timmermans, who will review proposals for new regulatory measures. The Commission's new cluster system will focus on key priorities, including infrastructure development and trade policy. Singapore can expect to engage with Juncker's team on EU-Singapore Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, as well as other bilateral interactions.

site_title: Microsoft makes Office free to rival mobile platforms
summary: Microsoft is making its Office software suite available for free to users of rival mobile platforms, including Apple iPads and Android tablets. The move aims to rival mobile platforms, with users able to store documents without a subscription. The software includes Word and Excel, and subscribers will benefit from advanced editing and collaboration capabilities, as well as cloud storage and integration with Dropbox. The decision is seen as a major step to bring Office to everyone, on every device, with over 1 billion customers worldwide using Office in some form.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint fetches S$30m for new Holland Park GCB
summary: Frasers Centrepoint sold a brand-new Good Class Bungalow in Holland Park for S$30 million, approximately S$1,989 psf based on a 15,080 sq ft land area. This is below the developer's earlier asking price of S$38 million for a similar unit. The sale price is close to the record price for a GCB transaction, set in 2012. Despite the lower price, the sale is considered a good deal for the seller in the current subdued market.

site_title: Commodity marketing segment boosts CWT's Q3 bottom line
summary: CWT Ltd, a commodity logistics group, reported a 70% surge in net profit for the third quarter, driven by a 70% increase in revenue to S$3.77 billion, mainly from its commodity marketing segment. The company's net profit rose to S$32.5 million, with earnings per share at 5.41 Singapore cents. The company's space in its Singapore Wine Vault and CWT Pandan Logistics Centre is nearly fully occupied, with discussions ongoing for the remaining capacity. CWT's year-to-date net profit and revenue also increased significantly, with a 52% and 102% rise, respectively.

site_title: OSIM: is the stock selloff over?
