summary: OSIM International's stock price has plummeted after the company reported a 28% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$16 million, with earnings per share falling to 2.11 cents. The dismal results, combined with concerns over the company's core massage chair business and the impact of China's economic slowdown, have led analysts to project a full-year earnings decline of 13 cents. Despite a six-cent dividend payout, investors are pricing in a low earnings multiple, suggesting that S$1.80 may be a fair price to pay. The company's future remains uncertain, with a vicious circle of declining price multiples and a potentially worsening revenue decline.

site_title: Bank Indonesia official sees 2014 full-year GDP growth at 5.1%
summary: Bank Indonesia's executive director, Juda Agung, expects Indonesia's 2014 full-year GDP growth to reach 5.1%. This is slightly lower than the 5.01% growth rate in the third quarter. A slower public spending pace in the fourth quarter could lead to a weaker growth rate, given the government's tax revenue shortfall. This is a weaker growth rate since 2009.

site_title: Airbus signs deal with Chinese firm for 100 planes
summary: Airbus has signed a deal with China Aircraft Leasing Company to supply 100 planes, worth around $10.2 billion, at catalogue prices. The deal includes 74 A320neos, 16 A320ceos, and 10 A321ceos. The A320 family is a popular choice, with 60% of the global medium-haul market, and Airbus has over 11,000 orders and 6,200 delivered planes to 400 customers worldwide. The deal confirms the A320 family's popularity and appeal, according to Airbus and the leasing firm's CEO.

site_title: SingPost's Q2 net profit up 5.5%
summary: SingPost's Q2 net profit rose 5.5% to S$37.6 million, driven by e-commerce-related businesses, despite underlying net profit remaining flat. Revenue grew 8.1% to S$220.3 million, with the logistics segment showing significant growth. E-commerce activities now account for 26.9% of total revenue, up from 23.8% last year. The company declared an interim quarterly dividend of 1.25 Singapore cents per share, but its stock price closed one cent lower at S$1.94.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher ahead of Friday jobs report
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a solid report on jobless claims, which fell to 278,000 in the week ending November 1, the lowest level in 14 years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 26.17 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.04% and 0.03%, respectively. Analysts expect nonfarm payroll gains to exceed 200,000 when the monthly report is released on Friday.

site_title: SingPost Q2 profit up 5.5%, declares dividend of 1.25 S'pore cts/share
summary: SingPost reported a 5.5% increase in net profit to S$37.6 million for Q2 2014, driven by growth in e-commerce and international mail transhipments. Revenue rose 8.1% to S$220.34 million. The company declared a 1.25 cents per share interim dividend. Half-year net profit rose 5.3% to S$76.84 million, with earnings per share down 4.7% year-over-year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.31 points lower at 1,831.98, with 2.87 billion lots valued at RM2.52 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 364 to 436. This marks a decline in the market, with no specific cause mentioned.

site_title: Hermes says Q3 sales rise 11% at constant forex
summary: Hermes reported an 11% rise in like-for-like third-quarter sales, driven by strong demand for leather goods and ready-to-wear. The company's revenue reached 990.6 million euros (US$1.24 billion) for the three months to September 30. This comes after arch-rival LVMH agreed to relinquish most of its 23.2% stake in Hermes, following a dispute-ending agreement.

site_title: US third-quarter productivity beats forecasts; pay increasing
summary: US nonfarm businesses experienced a 2.0% annual increase in productivity in the third quarter, beating forecasts. This growth, combined with rising hourly compensation, is a positive sign for the economy. Compensation per hour increased at a 2.3% rate, the fastest rise since 2012, and hourly compensation rose 3.3% from a year earlier. The Federal Reserve is monitoring wage growth as it considers interest rate hikes, with a broad wage measure showing its biggest gain since 2008.

site_title: OECD urges countries to step up support for fragile growth
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) urged major countries to support fragile global growth, particularly urging the European Central Bank (ECB) to implement quantitative easing. The OECD lowered its global growth forecast to 3.3% this year and 3.7% in 2015, citing high risks and market volatility. It urged the ECB to expand its monetary stimulus, including asset purchases, to combat deflation and support growth in the eurozone.

site_title: US jobless claims drop, four-week average lowest since 2000
summary: US jobless claims dropped 10,000 to 278,000 in the week ended Nov 1, the lowest reading since 2000. The four-week average of claims fell to 279,000, also the lowest since 2000. Economists had forecast a dip to 285,000, but claims have now been below the 300,000 threshold for eight straight weeks, indicating tightening labor market conditions. This follows a report of private payrolls increasing 230,000 in October, the seventh straight month of job gains exceeding 200,000.

site_title: UK launches probe into competition for banking services
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority launched a 18-month investigation into the banking services market, focusing on competition for small business customers and personal accounts. The probe aims to address concerns that banks have not provided sufficient information on fees and have made it difficult for customers to switch banks. The investigation's findings could lead to banks being forced to sell branches or face other remedial measures to improve their services.

site_title: ECB staff told to prepare further measures for use "if needed": Draghi
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to use additional unconventional policy tools if needed to combat deflation and achieve its inflation target of 2%. ECB President Mario Draghi instructed staff to prepare these measures, following the October inflation rate of 0.4%, which remains below the target. The ECB has already launched policies to boost the economy, but Draghi acknowledged a willingness to do more if necessary to address the stagnating economy.

site_title: Malaysia central bank holds rates steady, sees risks to global growth
summary: Malaysia's central bank held its key interest rate at 3.25% as it maintained an accommodative monetary policy stance. The bank warned of risks to global growth, citing uneven expansion in advanced economies and increased volatility in international financial markets. The growth forecast has been revised downwards, and downside risks to global growth have increased. This decision is seen as a response to the weakening economic activity in major economies, which could impact Malaysia's export-focused economy. The bank's decision is in line with its previous stance, aiming to support economic growth despite global challenges.

site_title: CWT Ltd Q3 net profit up 70%
summary: LOGISTICS firm CWT Ltd reported a 70% surge in net profit for the third quarter, reaching S$32.5 million, up from S$19.1 million a year ago. Revenue grew 70% to S$3.77 million, primarily driven by commodity marketing and financial services.

site_title: OECD urges ECB to step up quantitative easing, trims growth forecasts
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) urged the European Central Bank (ECB) to increase quantitative easing to support the eurozone economy, which poses a major risk to global growth. The OECD cut its global growth forecast to 3.3% for 2014 and 3.7% for 2015, citing weak economies and risk of deflation. The ECB has been criticized for not doing enough to stimulate the economy, with inflation below its target and a potential risk of deflation.

site_title: SIA's 2Q profit down 43 per cent, hit by losses from associated companies
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 43% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$90.9 million for the second quarter, primarily due to losses from associated companies. Operating profit rose 52% to nearly S$132 million, driven by lower expenditure. Revenue remained nearly flat at S$3.9 billion, with passenger revenue marginally higher and cargo revenue down 0.5%. The airline attributed the decline to an uncertain global economic climate and intense competition.

site_title: Minority shareholders back US$421m buyout of Malaysia Airlines
summary: Minority shareholders in Malaysian Airline System Bhd (MAS) have approved a US$421 million bid by state fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd to take the struggling carrier private. The bid, made at 27 sen per share, moves Khazanah closer to implementing plans to return MAS to profitability. The airline has faced significant challenges this year, including the disappearance of Flight MH370 and the shooting down of Flight MH17. Minority shareholders voted in favor of the bid, allowing Khazanah to proceed with its plans to acquire the remaining 30.6% stake in the company.

site_title: Luxury home prices in Singapore post sharpest fall among world's leading cities
summary: Luxury home prices in Singapore plummeted 10% over the past year, the steepest decline among 32 leading cities worldwide, according to a Knight Frank Asia Pacific report. This marks the first time Singapore has seen a year-on-year decline in luxury home prices. The report attributes the decline to "muted sentiment" in the market, with falling transaction volumes and buyers anticipating further price adjustments. Despite this, owners are holding out due to the exclusivity of their properties and confidence in Singapore's long-term prospects.

site_title: Adidas sees slower sales growth in 2015 as trims margin target
summary: Adidas reported third-quarter results in line with forecasts, but trimmed its gross margin target to 48-48.5% due to exposure to Russia and the golf market. The company expects slower sales growth in 2015, with a mid single-digit rate compared to a mid to high single-digit rate in 2014. This follows a series of profit warnings by CEO Herbert Hainer, who blames the group's struggles on these factors.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates on hold ahead of inflation report
summary: The Bank of England maintained interest rates at 0.5% ahead of the inflation report, as expected. The central bank also decided to keep its £375 billion government bond stockpile unchanged. Both decisions were seen as maintaining the economic stimulus since the 2009 financial crisis.

site_title: Jiangsu Changjiang poised to buy STATS ChipPAC for US$1.8b: reports
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a Singaporean semiconductor company, is set to be acquired by Jiangsu Changjiang for US$1.8 billion, according to reports. The deal will be announced in late November, with controlling shareholder Temasek Holdings agreeing to tender its 83.3% stake. The news comes after STATS ChipPAC was suspended from trading on November 3, the same day Jiangsu Changjiang's shares were halted in Shanghai. The acquisition is expected to be finalized through an exclusive talks process.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index gaining 3.3 points to 3,290.96, driven by a 0.4% rise on Thursday. The market remained positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, with 189 gainers and 240 losers.

site_title: US money-laundering probe draws in Putin's inner circle: WSJ
summary: US prosecutors have launched a money-laundering investigation into Gennady Timchenko, a billionaire Russian gas trader and associate of President Vladimir Putin. The investigation, led by the US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York, centers on alleged corrupt deals in Russia, where Timchenko's company, Gunvor Group, bought oil from Russia's Rosneft and sold it to third parties. The probe may also examine potential connections between Putin's personal wealth and allegedly illicit funds, with the US Treasury having raised concerns about Putin's investments in Gunvor.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.20% lower
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.20% to 23,649.31, marking its fourth straight loss, despite a record close on Wall Street. Mainland Chinese shares rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.27% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbing 0.84%. The gains were attributed to hopes of new economy-boosting measures from the government.

site_title: Update: STATS ChipPac set for takeover by Jiangsu Changjiang in US$780m bid
summary: STATS ChipPAC is set for a US$780 million takeover by Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology. The Chinese company has proposed purchasing most of STATS ChipPAC, excluding its subsidiaries in Taiwan. The deal marks a significant move into the US market by a Chinese company. No further details on the proposed acquisition have been released, but it is expected to undergo regulatory approval.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as miners, banks weigh
summary: Australian shares ended 0.21% lower, weighed down by miners due to falling iron ore prices and banks before they trade ex-dividend. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 11.8 points to 5,506.1. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 0.03%.

site_title: UK house prices show surprise fall in October: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell 0.4% in October, exceeding forecasts for a 0.4% rise, and the annual rate of house price growth slowed to 8.8% from 9.6% in the previous period, the lowest since December 2012. This marks the third consecutive month of slowing house price growth, adding to signs of a slowing housing market.

site_title: Life insurance: Weighted new business premiums fall 6% in Q3
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 6% decline in weighted new business premiums in Q3 2014 to S$705.4 million, mainly due to a 18% drop in weighted annual premiums. Weighted single premiums rose 24% to S$259.2 million. The decline was attributed to the re-pricing of Integrated Shield Plans, which had tapered off by March last year.

site_title: Obama digs in even as he vows to work with Republicans
summary: US President Barack Obama vowed to work with Republican lawmakers despite their midterm election win, but warned he would take executive action to protect his core agenda, including immigration reform. Obama pledged to cooperate on areas such as tax reform and international trade agreements, but vowed to press ahead with immigration reform plans, potentially sparking a conflict with congressional leaders.

site_title: Global business growth eased to six-month low in Oct: PMI
summary: Global economic growth eased to a six-month low in October, with the J.P. Morgan Global All-Industry Output Index falling to 53.6 from September's 54.8. The slowdown was attributed to weaker increases in new business and a decrease in hiring rates. This marks a deviation from the forecast of 3.1% global growth for the year. The manufacturing PMI remained unchanged, while the services industry PMI decreased to 53.7 from 55.2.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.86%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.86% on Thursday, ending a five-day winning streak, due to profit-taking amid the dollar's rally against the yen losing steam. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 144.84 points to 16,792.48, while the Topix index fell 1.12% to 1,356.35.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise in October for first time this year on improved volume
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.1% in October, driven by an 0.8% increase in executive flats. This is the first price increase this year. Resale volume also improved, with a 5.7% increase to 1,553 units sold in October. Year-on-year, prices have dropped 6.1% from October 2013 and 9% from the peak in April 2013.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up gains as banks end rally, iron ore prices down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% mid-session on Thursday as investors sold down banks ahead of ex-dividend and iron ore prices declined, dragging down miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5506.20. Banks, including Westpac and Commonwealth Bank, fell 1.24% and 0.8% respectively, while miners Fortescue Metals and Newcrest Mining dropped 3% and 2%. The US market rose to records after Republicans took control of the Senate, boosting investor hopes for business-friendly policies.

site_title: Singapore's GIC in JV to buy 5 shopping centres in New Zealand
summary: Singapore's GIC has formed a joint venture with Scentre Group to purchase five shopping centers in New Zealand for a combined value of NZ$2.1 billion. GIC will hold a 49% stake in the acquired centers, including Westfield Albany, Westfield Manukau, and others. This partnership aims to expand GIC's presence in the New Zealand retail market, which is managed by Scentre Group, the largest shopping center operator in the country with annual sales over NZ$2 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open 0.18% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.18% in opening minutes on November 6, 2014, following a record close for the Dow and S&P 500 on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index reached 23,737.76.

site_title: DBS, POSB customers can withdraw cash at Guardian, Sheng Siong stores in Singapore
summary: DBS Bank and POSB customers in Singapore can now withdraw cash at over 140 Guardian Health & Beauty stores and more than 30 Sheng Siong stores. Customers can withdraw up to S$100 in multiples of S$10 with a purchase. This expansion increases the bank's withdrawal touchpoints to nearly 2,000 islandwide. The service is available using a linked debit or credit card and offers a S$5 bonus for the first 500 customers daily until the end of the year.

site_title: Lenovo Q2 net profit climbs 19% as PC market share grows
summary: Lenovo reported a 19% increase in net income to $262 million in its Q2 fiscal quarter, surpassing analyst expectations. The company's revenue rose 7% to $10.5 billion, driven by its growing PC market share. Lenovo is expanding into new product markets after acquiring IBM's low-end server business and Google's Motorola handset unit. The company also named Jerry Yang, co-founder of Yahoo!, to its board of directors. Despite the strong earnings, Lenovo's shares were flat at the midday close.

site_title: Average salary increase of 4.5% in Singapore seen for 2015
summary: Singapore employees can expect an average 4.5% salary increase in 2015, similar to 2014, but with lower real wage uplifts due to higher inflation. Real wage increases are predicted to average 2% in 2015, down from 3.1% in 2014.

site_title: New building and construction rules to raise productivity
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has introduced new building and construction rules to raise productivity in the construction sector. The requirements, effective from November 1, include higher minimum buildable design and constructability standards, standardized floor heights, and the adoption of drywall as internal partitions for dry areas. Prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) will also be imposed on selected Government Land Sales (GLS) sites, with two upcoming projects set to adopt the technology. The aim is to make buildings easier to construct and encourage the use of efficient construction methods.

site_title: A worrying disconnect between employers and staff in Singapore: survey
summary: Employers in Singapore face a disconnect with staff, with 39% believing they are paid fairly compared to 51% regionally. Employee engagement and retention levels are a challenge, with 35% highly engaged and 52% disengaged. Leadership and management drivers are unimportant in attracting new employees, with career advancement and job security being key drivers. Employees under 30 prioritize challenging work and vacation time, while those 40-49 focus on health and wellness benefits. 34% of Singapore employees expect to leave within two years, with 28% expecting to stay, highlighting the need for sustainable engagement programs.

images.alt_text: Employers in Singapore are facing a worrying disconnect from their staff on the various issues including pay equity, Towers Watson, a global professional services company, said.

site_title: Kim Heng Offshore's Q3 profit falls 62%
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings' Q3 profit fell 62% to S$1.15 million, down from S$3.06 million a year ago, due to lower income from offshore rig services and supply chain management. Revenue decreased 23% to S$13.8 million, mainly due to delays in the arrival of drilling rigs and vessels. No dividend was recommended, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Seoul: Won recovers from 14-mth low struck on govt comments; shares higher
summary: The South Korean won recovered from a 14-month low, closing nearly flat after a finance ministry official stated the government would manage the local currency to align with the Japanese yen. The won had fallen 1.2% to an intraday low of 1,096.8 per dollar, its lowest level since September 6, 2013.

site_title: Eucon narrows net loss for Q3, holds cautious outlook
summary: EUCON Holding, a Chinese and Taiwanese PCB solutions provider, reported a narrowed net loss for the third quarter, reaching S$832,000 compared to S$2.01 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 12% to S$14.85 million, mainly due to a decrease in the mechanical drilling and routing segment. The company has started production for embedded PCB orders and will remain cautious in its outlook due to global financial uncertainties.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.33% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.33% on Thursday, following five days of gains, driven by record US stock market highs and a strong dollar against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index reached 16,993.46, with Japanese exporters benefiting from the stronger currency. Analysts expect a short-term technical pullback, but dollar-driven buying is resisting major profit-taking. The US dollar was at 114.63 yen, up from 114.06 yen earlier in the week.

site_title: New York demands another $300 mln from Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi: sources
summary: New York's banking regulator has demanded an additional $300 million from Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ as part of a potential agreement over sanctions-related violations. The demand comes on top of a $250 million settlement last year for deleting information from $100 billion in wire transfers. The bank is still negotiating the terms of a new settlement with regulators, with an agreement possible in the next two to three weeks.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng posts 41% fall in profit for first nine months of 2014
summary: Hock Lian Seng Holdings reported a 41% decline in net profit to S$7.14 million for the first nine months of 2014, down from S$12.10 million in the same period last year. Revenue decreased 34.2% to S$45.08 million, mainly due to lower progress billing for the Marina Coastal Expressway project. The company has a strong balance sheet with S$115.7 million in cash and a S$345 million order book. Despite the decline, Hock Lian Seng plans to tender for infrastructure projects competitively and explore other business opportunities to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed, dollar pushes towards 115 yen
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, with Tokyo stocks rising 0.37% and Seoul gaining 0.18%, while Hong Kong and Sydney lost 0.10% and 0.11% respectively. The dollar pushed towards 115 yen for the first time in seven years after Republicans took control of the US Congress. The Dow and S&P 500 hit new records, with US private sector jobs adding 230,000 in October, beating analysts' projections. The yen was also soft against the euro, while oil prices rose on a smaller-than-expected increase in US supplies.

site_title: Palo Alto Networks discovers new malware targeted at Apple devices
summary: Palo Alto Networks has discovered a new malware family, "WireLurker," targeting Apple devices, including desktop and mobile operating systems. The malware can infect Macs, then jump to iPhones via USB cables. It originated from a Chinese third-party apps store and affected over 350,000 users, with more than 400 infected apps downloaded. The attackers' objective is unclear, but they may have stolen messaging IDs and contacts. Apple was notified but did not respond. The malware can infect existing apps on iPhones, similar to traditional computer viruses.

site_title: Australia jobs rebound, A$ still hits 4-yr trough
summary: Australia's employment rate remained steady at 6.2% in October, with 24,100 jobs created, mostly in full-time positions. However, lingering concerns over the reliability of the data led investors to sell the local dollar to four-year lows, hitting a trough of US$0.8554. The Reserve Bank of Australia welcomes the lower currency, which could help offset falling commodity prices. Analysts predict a risk of further decline to US$0.8385 and potentially US$0.8050, with the central bank's quarterly outlook due on Friday.

site_title: Ezion's quarterly profit rises 29%
summary: Ezion Holdings' net profit for the third quarter ended September 2014 rose 29% to US$49.2 million, driven by a 25% increase in revenue to US$94.9 million, mainly from chartering contributions. Earnings per share improved to 3.63 US cents. The company continues to focus on growing its service rig division and expects to deploy more rigs in the final quarter, with plans for strategic acquisitions. Despite weakness in oil prices, Ezion remains committed to its existing markets and asset requirements.

site_title: Singapore bonds continue good run
summary: Singapore bonds continue to outperform, with investors showing strong demand for local currency-denominated debt despite the US Federal Reserve ending its QE3 program. The sale of Tata International's S$150 million perpetuals drew S$1 billion in bids, with yields rising to 6.1%. The Singapore dollar's slide against the US dollar has not deterred investors, with local investors flush with liquidity driving the market. Analysts expect interest rates to remain low for several months, supporting the SGD bond market.

site_title: Amazon tries out taxi deliveries in California cities: WSJ
summary: Amazon is testing taxi deliveries in San Francisco and Los Angeles through its Flywheel app, shipping parcels via licensed cabs for about $5 per package. The e-commerce company aims to speed up shipments while controlling costs, following delays last Christmas. In the latest test, taxis picked up packages from distribution centers and delivered them to the same location. This is part of Amazon's exploration of alternative delivery options, including regional couriers and its own delivery vehicles.

site_title: China on best behaviour for APEC, but guests may not be
summary: China is attempting to present a harmonious image at the upcoming APEC summit, dialing down rhetoric on territorial disputes and trade tensions. However, tensions with the US, Japan, and Taiwan remain, with President Xi Jinping facing pressure to address cyber spying concerns and improve relations with Japan. Despite China's efforts to showcase a clean and welcoming host, some APEC member countries, including Australia and the US, may still challenge Beijing's stance on key issues.

site_title: Why green light was given for SingPost postage rate hike
summary: The Singapore government gave SingPost, the national postal service-operator, the green light to raise postage rates from Oct 1, 2014, due to declining letter volumes and rising operating costs. SingPost has not cut staff or reduced services, instead increasing salaries and hiring older workers, and investing S$100 million in service improvements. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) considered these factors when approving the rate hike, which saw domestic mail postage increase by 4-20 cents and international mail postage increase by 5-25 cents.

site_title: Bank of England looks set to signal no rate hike until mid-2015
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates at 0.5% until mid-2015, contrary to initial expectations of a rate hike this month. The decision is driven by weak inflation, slow wage growth, and the risk of a euro zone recession. Economic projections due on November 12 may further reinforce this stance, with some economists predicting a cut in inflation forecasts to 1.7% in two years. The Bank's governor, Mark Carney, is expected to strike a cautious tone at a news conference on November 12.

site_title: China demand turns Korean cosmetics makers into glamour stocks
summary: South Korean cosmetics companies have seen significant growth in shares following a surge in Chinese tourists seeking affordable, high-quality products. Shares in Amorepacific, Sansung Life & Science, and Hankook Cosmetics have more than doubled and jumped seven times in value respectively. The popularity of Korean pop culture and entertainment has driven demand, with product placements in TV shows and movies contributing to the trend. However, analysts warn that the rally in Korean cosmetics shares could peak soon due to stretched valuations.

images.alt_text: A surge of Chinese tourists into South Korea eager to snap up chic but relatively inexpensive make-up brands has helped shares of the nation's cosmetic firms rally to stratospheric levels.

site_title: Weakest growth in 5 years makes Joko's job harder
summary: Indonesia's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 5.01% in the third quarter, its slowest in five years, posing a challenge to new President Joko Widodo's goal of lifting annual growth to 7%. The slowdown is attributed to a decline in exports due to a slowdown in China and stagnant activity in other major markets, as well as a decrease in domestic demand. To stimulate the economy, Jokowi plans to slash subsidies by raising retail fuel prices, but this will hit consumers' disposable income in the short term.

site_title: Ascott Reit posts DPU of 2.11 cents for Q3
summary: Ascott Reit reported a DPU of 2.11 cents for Q3, down 11% from the previous year due to one-off items. Excluding these items, the DPU would have risen 15%. Revenue grew 9% to S$93.7 million, driven by new properties and existing properties. The group aims to seek accretive acquisitions and is exploring refinancing options due to uncertain macro and credit environments. Despite global economic concerns, the company expects the hospitality business to remain healthy and its operating performance to remain profitable for FY 2014.

site_title: Keeping the workers happy
summary: Holiday Inn Singapore Atrium has implemented an RFID technology system to streamline the collection and return of employee uniforms, reducing the time by over half and freeing up three employees to be deployed to other areas. This initiative, combined with cross-training between security and bell desk staff, has led to wage adjustments for employees. The hotel's efforts have resulted in increased staff engagement and productivity, making its workers more committed.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P set records after Republicans sweep US vote
summary: US stocks reached fresh records on Wednesday after Republicans swept both houses of Congress, lifting hopes for pro-business policies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 100.69 points (0.58%) to 17,484.53, while the S&P 500 gained 11.47 (0.57%) to 2,023.57. The Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 2.91 (0.06%) to 4,620.72. The election results were seen as positive for business-friendly policies, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: World Bank brings Ebola funding to nearly US$1 billion
summary: The World Bank's International Finance Corporation pledged $450 million to support trade, investment, and employment in Ebola-affected West African countries. This brings total World Bank commitments for Ebola to nearly $1 billion. The funding aims to boost trade and investment, ensuring private companies continue to operate and sustain employment under difficult circumstances. The World Bank's President, Jim Yong Kim, emphasized the need to mitigate the long-term harm caused by the Ebola outbreak on businesses globally.

site_title: Honda ordered to deliver air bag documents to NHTSA
summary: US safety regulators ordered Honda to deliver documents and answer questions under oath regarding potentially defective Takata air bags in millions of recalled US vehicles. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) seeks internal Honda communications, field reports, and warranty claims related to the issue. Honda must deliver the documents by December 15. The investigation, ongoing for 18 months, aims to determine if Honda failed to report accident-related deaths and injuries as required by US law.

site_title: S&P revises Japfa Comfeed outlook to negative
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has revised the outlook on Indonesia-based poultry feed and commercial farming company PT Japfa Comfeed Indonesia Tbk to negative from stable, citing weak cash flow adequacy ratios and elevated capital spending. S&P expects Japfa Comfeed's debt-to-Ebitda ratio to reach 4.5x in 2014 and remain above 4.0x over the next 12 months due to subdued demand and overcapacity in the industry. A negative outlook has been assigned, with a one-in-three likelihood of a rating downgrade over the next 12 months if operating conditions remain subdued.

site_title: Lazada grows revenue and stable of online 3rd-party sellers (Amended)
summary: Lazada, a South-east Asian retail online shopping group, has seen a significant surge in revenue and growth in its marketplace segment, with sales turnover increasing more than tenfold in the past 12 months. The platform now accounts for over 65% of the group's total sales revenue, driven by 8,000 third-party sellers. Lazada aims to facilitate cross-border trade out of China and Korea, with a focus on improving customer service and personalizing the online shopping experience. The company's CEO, Maximilian Bittner, hopes to rope in manufacturers to sell their products through the platform.

site_title: Banking on productivity for sustainable growth
summary: The inaugural Singapore Productivity Awards recognized six companies for their leadership and business practices that contribute to labor productivity. The winners, including Holiday Inn Singapore Atrium and Neo Group Ltd, were honored for embracing technology, innovation, and engaging employees. The awards aim to foster a culture of productivity in Singapore's businesses, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizing the need for a collective effort to achieve sustainable growth. The awards are part of Singapore's economic transformation towards productivity-led growth, with the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) working closely with the government and enterprises to promote productivity.

site_title: India minister says economic reform a 'long journey'
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley warned that reforming the country's flagging economy will be a "long journey" with no quick fixes, playing down the prospect of "big-bang" changes. The government will consistently pursue the reform agenda, but critics argue it lacks boldness in eliminating regulatory hurdles. Jaitley supports some reforms, such as overhauling land-acquisition laws, but sets no timeline, and analysts question investor appetite for privatizing loss-making state firms. Despite slow reforms, shares have reached record highs, and economists say India needs 8-9% growth to generate employment for millions of new job-seekers.

site_title: Republicans profit from voter discontent over economy
summary: Republicans capitalized on voter discontent over President Barack Obama's handling of the economy, gaining control of the US Senate and adding seats in the House in the 2014 midterm election. Preliminary exit polls showed that 58% of voters were dissatisfied or angry with the White House, and 59% with Republican congressional leaders. The economy, despite showing signs of strength, failed to benefit most Americans, with stagnant wages and a median household income $2,600 lower than in 2007. Republicans must now decide how to balance confrontation and cooperation to hold the ground and potentially make a run at the White House in 2016.

site_title: Connecting with fresh results
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket chain, implemented a computerization project for its seafood division in 2012, resulting in significant productivity gains. The project streamlined purchasing and administration processes, reducing paperwork and disputes. The company now uses digital weighing machines and personal digital assistants to track seafood purchases, resulting in 45 man-hour savings per day. The project also improved supply chain management and reduced errors and wastage. Sheng Siong plans to implement similar projects, including a cash management system, to further boost productivity.

site_title: Google going where no search engine has gone before
summary: Google search guru Amit Singhal envisions a future of "perfect personal assistants" that can provide instant access to information through speech recognition, language understanding, touch technology, and computer advances. He believes this will lead to "knowledge on demand" and healthier, happier lives, ultimately transforming the search engine industry. Singhal dismisses concerns about creating lazy minds, instead emphasizing the need to "teach people to swim with the flow of technology." He draws inspiration from science fiction, particularly Star Trek, and is working to bring this vision to life through Google's search algorithms and innovations.

site_title: Oxley Hotel up for sale by auction
summary: Oxley Hotel in Singapore is up for sale by auction with an indicative price of S$25 million. The eight-storey hotel has 56 guest rooms and a total gross floor area of 12,238 sq ft. The site is zoned for residential/institution use and has consistently achieved a stable occupancy rate of 80-90%. Colliers International deputy managing director Grace Ng says the property is a timely opportunity for investors to enter the hospitality industry, citing stable supply and demand in the area. The auction is scheduled for November 21 at the Amara Hotel.

site_title: S$52m Q3 fair-value boost for Rowsley from RSP acquisition
summary: Rowsley Ltd, a real estate company controlled by Valencia owner Peter Lim, posted a net profit of S$52.6 million in Q3 2014, driven by an accounting gain from its acquisition of RSP in September last year. The company's shares gained half a Singapore cent to S$0.22. Rowsley is also actively monitoring market developments for its first residential project in Malaysia, Vantage Bay - SKIES, and remains optimistic about the long-term fundamentals of Iskandar, despite government efforts to cool the property market.

site_title: Sweet gains
summary: Select Group, a Singapore-listed food service provider, implemented an automation project in 2011, investing in bulk cooking and automated equipment. This led to huge gains in productivity and efficiency, halving preparation time for sweet paste desserts and improving consistency in cooking. The automation also enabled staff to focus on higher-skilled tasks, resulting in a 10-times growth in average monthly turnover from $83,000 to $10 million. The company continues to expand its automation efforts, expecting greater economies of scale when its new headquarters and factory opens next year.

site_title: Virgin Galactic, human destiny and ambitious Asian brands
summary: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic crash highlights the importance of a mission-driven approach to business. Despite the financial community's focus on near-term concerns, Virgin Galactic's pursuit of space travel is a step towards changing human destiny. Branson's entrepreneurial spirit, built on a culture of innovation, purpose, and values, has enabled Virgin to become a successful and inspirational brand. This approach is crucial for Asian brands, particularly Chinese companies, as they navigate a world characterized by anxiety and adversity. By embracing a purposeful roadmap, fostering innovation, and prioritizing values, Asian brands can become tomorrow's heroic brands.

site_title: Indian structural reforms 'a long journey'
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley expressed the need for gradual structural reforms to boost the economy, stating it's a "long journey". He supports relaxing labor and land laws and increasing privatizations, but emphasized caution against rushing into major reforms. The government has already taken steps to make doing business easier, but industrial output and investment remain stagnant. Jaitley aims to stimulate investment and create jobs, with a focus on infrastructure projects and easing barriers to land purchases.

site_title: Sembmarine's Q3 profit rises 1.8% to S$132m
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported a 1.8% increase in Q3 net profit to S$132m, driven by higher profit contributions from rig-building and fixed-platform segments. Despite a low oil price environment, the group believes long-term E&P market fundamentals remain stable. The company's turnover rose 3.2% to S$1.71 billion, with its rig-building business seeing an 8.2% revenue increase.

site_title: Small-car COE premium up S$910 on strong replacement buying
summary: The Singapore small car certificate of entitlement (COE) premium increased by S$910 to S$64,900 in the first bidding exercise for the November 2014-to-January 2015 quota. The commercial vehicle premium also rose, jumping S$2,701 to S$63,701, and is now almost on par with the small-car premium. The Cat C numbers were cut by 45.2% due to the Early Turnover Scheme, which reduced supply and led to a sharp increase in the premium.

site_title: SkillsFuture Council lists ways to develop citizens
summary: Singapore's 25-member SkillsFuture Council, chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, aims to develop an integrated system of education, training, and career progression for citizens. The council has identified four key thrusts: sector-focused frameworks for skill advancement and career development, education and career guidance in schools, enhanced internships for polytechnic students, and "place-and-train" programs for fresh graduates. The initiatives aim to promote industry support, lifelong learning, and mastery in every field, ultimately creating a competitive economy and society.

site_title: Highly productive month
summary: Singapore's inaugural National Productivity Month showcased innovations to boost company efficiency. The event, held in October, featured 15 productivity-themed events and 11,000 business leaders, with a focus on manufacturing, healthcare, and retail sectors. The initiative aims to help companies overcome obstacles to productivity, with 88% of companies polled facing challenges. The National Productivity and Continuing Education Council and industry associations collaborated to provide assistance and recognition, with the inaugural Singapore Productivity Awards. The event highlighted the importance of private-public partnerships in driving economic transformation towards productivity-led growth.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong, who launched National Productivity Month on Oct 7, is being shown how the 'drone waiter' works.

site_title: Colony Capital to merge with Colony Financial
summary: Colony Capital LLC, a US$19 billion investment firm, has agreed to merge with Colony Financial Inc, a real estate investment trust also founded by billionaire Thomas Barrack Jr. The deal, valued at US$657.5 million, is expected to be completed in the first half of 2015. The combined company, Colony Capital Inc, will have Colony Financial's holdings and Colony Capital's management capabilities, benefiting investors with a higher valuation and consistent dividend. Thomas Barrack will serve as executive chairman, while Richard Saltzman will be CEO of the new entity.

site_title: KL to sue Cowgate firm over RM250m loan
summary: The Malaysian government plans to sue National Feedlot Corporation (NFC) for failing to repay a RM250 million loan taken for a cattle-rearing project. The company has repaid only RM34.9 million, prompting the finance ministry to scrap its repayment schedule and initiate the lawsuit. The move comes amid public outcry over the "cows-and-condos" scandal, which involved the misuse of public funds for the project. The scandal has tarnished the reputation of Prime Minister Najib Razak's government ahead of a general election.

site_title: Estee Lauder trims profit, sales growth forecast
summary: Estee Lauder Cos Inc cut its full-year profit and sales growth forecast due to weak demand for skin care products in the US and China. The company's shares fell 4.7% after reporting a 6.8% decline in skin care sales in the first quarter. Net sales fell 1.6% to $2.63 billion, with the US and China contributing 42% and 6% of total sales, respectively. The company trimmed its forecast for net sales growth to 2-3% and cut its adjusted earnings outlook to $3.03-$3.11 per share.

site_title: Post-IPO Japfa is not confidence-inspiring
summary: Japfa Ltd, an Indonesian agri-food company, listed in Singapore in August 2014 with a successful IPO, generating 5 times subscription and a 9.8 times oversubscription for a Singapore public offer. However, Japfa's post-IPO performance has been underwhelming, raising concerns about the company's financial health. Despite initial confidence-boosting expectations, Japfa's IPO has failed to deliver, casting a shadow on Singapore's IPO market.

site_title: Kuroda sticks to his monetary easing guns, says more may come
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's monetary easing measures, likening deflation to a "chronic disease" that requires strong treatment. He hinted at potential further easing if the economy is threatened, impacting Tokyo stock prices and the yen, which hit a new seven-year low. The Nikkei 225 average ended marginally higher, while the yen's decline was attributed to the BOJ's actions.

site_title: Waning consumer electronics business hits Valuetronics
summary: Valuetronics Holdings, a Singapore-listed consumer electronics company, reported a 8.4% decline in net profit to HK$36.3 million (S$6 million) for the second quarter, due to slowing demand and higher staff costs. Revenue fell 0.7% to HK$627.6 million. The company attributed the decline to the waning consumer electronics business.

site_title: South-east Asian art gains traction globally
summary: South-east Asian art is gaining global recognition, thanks in part to Art Stage Singapore, the country's largest and most prestigious art fair. Founder Lorenzo Rudolf says the fair has created momentum, with European, US, and North Asian museums and collectors showing interest in the region's art. The fair has helped to increase the visibility of South-east Asian art, with Rudolf stating that art from the region is now sought after and not found elsewhere.

site_title: SilkAir plans direct flights to Cairns from end-May 2015
summary: SilkAir plans to launch direct flights to Cairns from end-May 2015, its second destination in Australia after Darwin. The service will operate three times weekly and is dependent on regulatory approvals. This addition will increase SilkAir's network to 49 destinations across 12 countries. The airline is using its new Boeing 737 aircraft to fuel network expansion, with plans for double-digit growth until the end of the decade. The new route is expected to bring an additional 20,000 visitors per year to Cairns.

site_title: Going high tech in the kitchen
summary: Neo Group, a leading food caterer, has increased its operating capacity by three times by leveraging kitchen automation machinery and logistics planning systems. The company processes up to 2,000 orders daily, with only a 15% increase in headcount. Founder and CEO Neo Kah Kiat aims to improve working conditions and efficiency, driven by his experience working in a physically demanding kitchen environment. The company has implemented a customized buffet catering management system, which took 1.5 years to fine-tune, and is now working on a "Zero Error" project to boost employee performance and excellence.

site_title: Continued yen depreciation could pose concerns for Asia
summary: Japan's yen has depreciated to near 115 against the dollar since November 1, following the Bank of Japan's announcement of a major quantitative easing program. The BOJ's balance sheet could reach 70% of gross domestic product by the end of next year, surpassing the US Federal Reserve's proportion. A cheaper yen could fuel inflation and stimulate Japan's economy, but also poses concerns for Asian economies, particularly if it leads to outflows of funds into Asian asset markets. Companies from South Korea and Taiwan may lobby their governments to take countervailing action.

site_title: Dollar rallies on US economy, mid-term election
summary: The US dollar rallied to its strongest level in nearly seven years against the yen, boosted by signs of strength in the US economy and the Republican control of the Senate. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reached its highest close since April 2009, and the dollar jumped 1% to 114.68 yen and 0.5% to US$1.2481 per euro. This is attributed to growth in employment and services, as well as the election results. Currencies linked to commodity prices, such as the Norwegian kroner and Australian dollar, slumped as a result.

site_title: Global passenger traffic growth slips to 5.3%
summary: Global passenger traffic growth slowed to 5.3% in September, down from 6.3% in August, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). Capacity expanded by 5.1%, pushing the load factor up 0.2 percentage points to 80.3%. Regional growth was mixed, with the US and Asia-Pacific experiencing improvements, while Europe saw a slowdown due to the eurozone recovery. Middle Eastern carriers saw double-digit growth, while Latin American airlines posted 4.6% growth. Domestic markets also showed growth, with India and China leading the way.

site_title: US farmers find oil price plunge no help as harvest winds down
summary: US farmers are not benefiting from the recent plunge in oil prices as the harvest winds down. The decline in energy costs, which began in June, will not have an immediate impact on farmer checkbooks due to the volatility of oil prices. Record US harvests are driving down prices for corn and soya beans, but farmers are missing out on the benefits of cheaper energy, with American farm income estimated to fall 14% to $113.2 billion this year.

site_title: Gulf energy subsidies worth US$160b a year: World Bank
summary: The World Bank reports that Arab Gulf states spend approximately $160 billion annually on energy subsidies, accounting for around 10% of their gross domestic product. This significant expenditure, mainly due to the region's high oil production, crowds out public spending on essential services such as healthcare, education, and investment. The World Bank urges Gulf states to reform their energy subsidies to address issues like low growth, high unemployment, and pollution.

site_title: Tiong Woon's Q1 hit by soft demand; Maxi-Cash's Q3 up on higher interest income
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a 24% decline in net profit to S$3.47 million for its first fiscal quarter, due to lower sales. The company cited weaker demand from the oil and gas and petrochemical industries. In contrast, pawnbroker Maxi-Cash's net profit more than doubled to S$703,000 due to higher interest income and firmer margins. Despite a 17% decline in sales, Maxi-Cash recorded its fattest pledge book ever.

site_title: London Shard developer wins approval for tower nearby
summary: London-based developer Sellar Property Group has secured approval to build a 26-storey residential tower near the Shard, a 72-storey skyscraper on the River Thames. The 148-apartment project, valued at £120 million, will be developed in partnership with the state of Qatar. The approval marks a significant step in the urban regeneration of the London Bridge area, with plans for over 25,000 luxury properties worth £60 billion in the next decade. The project is expected to sell units for approximately £800,000 each.

site_title: Derivatives shine in mixed October for SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a mixed October with derivatives trading and securities turnover higher than in September, but share trading volume dropped. Shares worth S$21.8 billion changed hands, a 7% decrease from the year-ago turnover. Derivatives trading and securities turnover increased, while share trading volume eased.

site_title: Rising loan defaults by farmers hit Danish banks
summary: Danish banks' profits may be short-lived due to rising loan defaults by farmers, caused by tumbling agricultural prices and Russia's ban on European food imports. The ban has led to a 20% decline in milk and pork prices, forcing some farmers to cease production and sell their farms. This has resulted in significant losses for banks, with Sydbank estimating 60 million crowns in losses on its agricultural loans. The situation has raised concerns about further consolidation among small and mid-sized banks, with the Danish Financial Services Authority urging banks to consider increased collective impairment charges.

site_title: One last bet for MAS punters
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) shares closed at 26 sen, just one sen shy of Khazanah's 27 sen offer, ahead of an EGM to vote on privatization and delisting. The airline faces financial struggles, with cumulative losses of RM8.4 billion since 2001, and a daily cash burn rate of RM5 million. Khazanah's proposed scheme of selective capital reduction and repayment (SCR) aims to inject RM1.6 billion for staff retrenchment and RM3 billion in working capital. Minority shareholders are advised to accept the offer, as they would get nothing if the airline is wound up and liquidated.

images.alt_text: PUNTERS could not resist one last bet on Malaysia Airlines (MAS) on Wednesday, ahead of an extraordinary general meeting on Thursday to vote on a proposal to privatise and delist the national carrier at a price that for long-term investors is rock bottom.

site_title: Toyota racing to record profit, but China flashing red signal
summary: Toyota is on track to record a US$17.5 billion full-year net profit, exceeding its previous forecast. The Japanese automaker's revenue is expected to reach 26.5 trillion yen, driven by a weaker yen boosting competitiveness. However, demand in China, a key market, is slowing, and sales in Asia, including Thailand, have decreased. Despite this, Toyota's US sales have risen, and the company's forecast for calendar year 2014 remains unchanged. The Japanese auto industry faces headwinds from slower demand and concerns about China's economy.

site_title: Greece can use bank rescue fund after EU bailout exit
summary: Greece can utilize the remaining 11.5 billion euros from its bank rescue fund as a precautionary credit line when it exits its EU/IMF bailout in December. The move aims to provide a financial cushion in case of market difficulties. The fund, set up to recapitalize Greek banks, has spent about 38 billion euros, leaving 11.5 billion euros available. This move follows Greece's desire to exit its bailout program without the strict conditions attached to earlier loans, and comes as bond markets are uncertain about the program's future.

site_title: Shipping lines adding Ebola clauses to their contracts
summary: Shipping lines are adding Ebola clauses to contracts to protect themselves from potential losses due to the ongoing Ebola outbreak in West Africa. These clauses aim to cover costs associated with crew infection or port closures. The move reflects growing concerns about the spread of the virus and its impact on logistics and trade. While ports have not yet closed, the uncertainty surrounding the outbreak is creating legal and financial concerns for those involved in shipping oil, cocoa, and minerals from the region.

site_title: Republicans' Senate win shows divided America
summary: The 2014 US midterm elections resulted in a Republican Senate win, despite a costly and high-stakes campaign. The GOP regained control of the Senate and strengthened its hold over the House, likely leading to legislative and policy gridlock in the last two years of President Obama's term. The outcome highlights the deep division between the Red and Blue states, with the country remaining divided between liberal and conservative ideologies. The Republican victories in key states like Colorado, Iowa, and North Carolina demonstrate the party's consolidation of power in the South and rural areas, while the Democratic losses reflect a lack of voter turnout from key constituencies.

site_title: Making good use of space
summary: Pan Asia Logistics Singapore invested in an advanced storage system, a mini-load automated storage and retrieval system (ASRS), to increase productivity by three to four times and reduce manpower by 30% due to customer demands for speed and high volume. The system enabled the company to create a storage capacity that required half the space, addressing scarcity of land, labor, and escalating costs. CEO Gerald Tan emphasized the need for constant innovation and adaptation to meet growing client demands, stating that productivity improvements are a key factor for long-term sustainability.

site_title: System glitch amid weak trading session
summary: A trading system glitch at the Singapore Exchange (SGX) occurred on Wednesday, causing a halt in trading from 2:15 pm to 5:15 pm. The market closed 5.97 points up at 3,287.54. Dealers attributed the weak session to poor sentiment and volume, and expressed frustration over the prolonged downtime. The SGX is investigating the incident, which is the latest in a series of trading system issues.

site_title: Saudis rope in Venezuela to check US shale threat
summary: Saudi Arabia has invited Venezuela to join forces in curbing US shale oil production by cutting oil prices. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to bring Opec's weaker members in line before the November 27 meeting. By doing so, Saudi Arabia aims to dampen US interest in drilling for shale and maintain its dominance in the global oil market. This is a reversal of Saudi Arabia's approach in 1998 when it sought Venezuela's help to raise oil prices.

site_title: Sprint a drag on SoftBank profit
summary: SoftBank Corp forecasts its first profit drop in nine years due to losses at Sprint Corp, with operating profit expected to be about 900 billion yen (S$10.2 billion) in the year ending March. This is 10% below its previous forecast and compares to 1.09 trillion yen reported a year earlier. The shares fell the most in a month.

site_title: Reits band together to form new industry body
summary: Several Reits in Singapore have formed the Reit Association of Singapore (Reitas) to promote the growth of the sector internationally and engage regulators, educate investors. The association, headed by a nine-member executive committee, aims to increase the sector's global presence and improve investor confidence. Mapletree Investments' Chua Tiow Chye is the association's president, while Sonny Tan is the CEO. Reitas will focus on promoting the Reit sector and supporting its members to achieve their goals.

site_title: Productivity champions
summary: The Singapore Productivity Awards, initiated by the Singapore Business Federation, recognizes organizations for their leadership and business practices contributing to labor productivity. This year's awards, jointly organized with the Singapore National Employers Federation and supported by SPRING Singapore and the National Productivity and Continuing Education Council, marked the closing of National Productivity Month 2014. Winners in various sectors include Neo Group Ltd, Holiday Inn Singapore Atrium, LF Logistics Services Pte Ltd, Pan Asia Logistics Singapore Pte Ltd, and Sheng Siong Group Ltd.

site_title: S&P firms' profits top estimates at fastest pace in four years
summary: US companies' profits have surpassed analysts' estimates at the fastest pace in four years, driven by cost-cutting measures and technology advancements. More than 81% of S&P 500 companies have beaten projections, led by sectors such as energy and consumer staples. This strength in the US economy contrasts with slowing growth in Europe and Asia, where companies are grappling with weaker consumer sentiment and high unemployment. Experts attribute the US earnings surge to technological gains and a "slow, steady" economy, with some warning that the recovery may be more modest than robust.

site_title: France proposes new tax for second homes in 30 cities
summary: French President Francois Hollande is proposing a new tax on second homes in 30 cities, including Paris, to raise 150 million euros annually. The 20% levy, equivalent to the existing housing tax, would target properties in areas with housing shortages. Over 174,000 properties in Paris are second homes, with 40% in upscale areas owned by foreigners. The measure aims to free up unoccupied homes and appease local governments, which are facing reduced transfers.

site_title: World's biggest firms fail at transparency: survey
summary: A survey by Transparency International found that the world's biggest companies, with a market value exceeding $14 trillion, scored an average of 3.8 out of 10 for transparency and fighting corruption. Financial services and technology companies were among the worst for transparency. Only 6% of companies make disclosures at a country level of their activities in foreign countries, and 70% have in-house anti-corruption programs. The survey's findings highlight the need for greater corporate openness and accountability.

site_title: Myanmar's reform process is stalling, says Suu Kyi ahead of Obama's visit
summary: Myanmar's reform process is "stalling", opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi warned ahead of President Barack Obama's visit, citing a slow pace of reforms since 2011. Suu Kyi expressed caution, urging the US to avoid over-optimism, as she seeks Western support to promote democracy in the former pariah state. Suu Kyi's comments come as the US prepares to visit Myanmar for the first time since 1996, highlighting ongoing concerns about the country's democratic progress.

site_title: Mumbai 'Times Square' proposal draws criticism
summary: The Indian government's proposal to transform Mumbai's historic Kala Ghoda neighborhood into a "cultural hub" has drawn criticism from preservation groups and residents. The plan, modeled after New York's Times Square, includes a massive video screen, costumed characters, and live streaming, but may violate India's building codes in historic areas. Locals are concerned about noise pollution, lack of parking, and the potential disruption to the neighborhood's ecosystem. The proposal has sparked debate about the balance between economic development and cultural preservation, with some arguing that Kala Ghoda is already developing its own unique character through arts festivals and cultural events.

site_title: UK food prices at risk of deflation
summary: UK food prices are at risk of deflation due to a record decline in retail prices, with a 1.9% decrease in October compared to the same period last year, according to the British Retail Consortium. Despite a 0.1% increase in food prices, deep discounting and low sales volumes for food retailers contribute to the risk of deflation. Consumer price inflation also fell to 1.2% in September, below the Bank of England's 2% target.

site_title: France okays GE purchase of Alstom energy assets
summary: France has authorized the US-based General Electric to purchase nearly $17 billion worth of Alstom's energy assets, clearing the way for the deal. French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron gave his approval for the investment project and industrial alliance between the two groups in the energy sector. The sale marks a significant move in GE's expansion into the energy sector, with Alstom's assets including power generation and transmission systems. The deal is expected to create new jobs and stimulate economic growth in France.

site_title: Power-less SGX halts markets for hours
summary: A power outage at the Singapore Exchange (SGX) halted markets for hours, with multiple power supply issues behind the disruption. The outage, which lasted for at least three hours, caused frustration among traders and resulted in some systems still being glitchy after reopening. SGX has apologized for the inconvenience and is investigating the root cause of the disruption. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is monitoring the investigation, which is the most serious trading outage in recent years and the most widespread stoppage since 2007.

site_title: SIAS: Gems is not a different governance code for SMEs
summary: The Singapore Association of the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators (SIAS) has developed a new corporate governance rating framework for small and medium enterprises (SMEs), known as Governance Evaluation of Mid and Small Caps (Gems). The framework assesses governance practices over a three-year period, focusing on quantifiable and verifiable metrics, and differentiates companies based on their regulatory risk. SIAS clarifies that Gems is not a different regulatory regime or code for SMEs, and all SMEs should comply with the existing Corporate Governance Code.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Brokers have maintained their "buy" recommendations on OUE and Giken Sakata, citing attractive valuations and potential for growth. OUE's target price is pegged at S$2.43 due to the redeployment of capital, while Giken Sakata's target price is S$0.65, driven by its production surge forecast. Roxy-Pacific Holdings' fair value is maintained at S$0.61, despite a 23% drop in Q3 FY14 net profit due to lower property development contributions.

site_title: HK lawmakers demand inquiry into city leader
summary: Hong Kong's democratic lawmakers are calling for an official inquiry into city leader Leung, citing large undeclared payments from an Australian company. Leung's lack of political integrity has been questioned. The move comes after former governor Chris Patten criticized Hong Kong's leadership in the face of mass democracy protests. The protests have lasted over a month, with the lawmakers demanding accountability from Leung.

site_title: Top Japanese sushi chef warns of danger of overfishing
summary: Japanese sushi chef Jiro Ono warns of the danger of overfishing, citing a shift in ingredients due to global demand. High-quality tuna and shellfish, such as abalone and ark shell, are becoming scarce, prompting dealers to source alternative, often farmed, varieties. Ono's three Michelin-starred Sukiyabashi Jiro restaurant is feeling the impact, with demand from a global sushi boom leading to a reliance on imported fish. The chef predicts a significant change in sushi ingredients within the next five years.

site_title: Eurozone business growth remains weak despite steep price cuts
summary: Eurozone business growth remains weak, increasing pressure on the European Central Bank (ECB) to ward off deflation and bring inflation back to the danger zone. Despite steep price cuts, the Markit Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index showed a slight improvement to 52.1, but still below the 50 line that separates growth from contraction. The data adds to concerns about demand in the euro area and the ECB's options, with full-scale quantitative easing seen as a possible solution.

site_title: Push to get building owners to tap Accessibility Fund
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) aims to encourage private building owners in the Central Business District to tap into its Accessibility Fund, which has only been used for 12.4 million SGD of 40 million SGD projects. 70 out of 120 CBD buildings were built before 1990 and lack accessibility features. The fund will co-pay up to 80% of construction costs for basic accessibility features and 40% for universal design features. BCA also launched a smartphone app to provide access to information on accessible buildings and plans to train 400 professionals in universal design by 2015.

site_title: Gulf investors spending more on US property
summary: Gulf investors from sovereign wealth funds and wealthy individuals have increased spending on US real estate, with a 51% gain over the previous year, reaching $1 billion. The US economy's recovery has attracted GCC investors, who favor multi-family homes and residential compounds for improved yields. The US economy expanded at a 3.5% annualized rate in the third quarter, making it an appealing destination for investors. Key investments have been made in Texas, California, Washington, and Massachusetts.

site_title: China homebuyers rush online to finance downpayments
summary: China homebuyers are turning to online peer-to-peer lenders to finance downpayments, as mortgage lending remains tight due to a high supply of housing and high prices. The average home price in China is now equivalent to 40 years' average income for a 100square meter apartment, and most buyers need to pay a minimum downpayment of 30% for a first home. Online lenders like E-House and Ping An Insurance are helping buyers raise deposits, with E-House collecting a 1% fee and developers subsidizing interest payments to investors.

site_title: StarHub Q3 net rises 2.6% to S$97.7 million
summary: StarHub reported a 2.6% rise in net profit to S$97.7 million for the third quarter, driven by handset sales and revenue from equipment sales. Despite a 17.4% drop in broadband revenue, mobile service revenue rose 0.9% and pay-TV revenue increased by 2%. The company attributed growth to higher subscription revenue from an increased subscriber base and investments in 4G network upgrades. StarHub expects pricing competition to continue and maintains its annual cash dividend payout of 20 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Although broadband business took a hit from stiff competition, revenue came in 2.3% higher at S$592 million, helped by a spike in handset sales with the launch of new iPhone models.

site_title: Asia Inc leads West in business in Myanmar
summary: Asian businesses are leading the way in setting up in Myanmar, with 134 Singaporean, 80 Thai, 73 Chinese, and 85 Hong Kong companies signing up by September 30. In contrast, only 18 US and 15 Canadian companies have set up operations. The country's semi-civilian government is attracting investment with new laws and infrastructure plans. Western multinationals such as Coca-Cola and Pepsi are also entering the market, with a forecast of over $5 billion in foreign direct investment for the fiscal year.

site_title: US economy's performance probably wasn't the main culprit in Democrat losses
summary: US Democrats lost control of the Senate and strengthened Republican control over the House of Representatives in the midterm elections, despite a relatively strong economy. The economy's performance was not the main factor in the losses, as President Barack Obama's general unpopularity was a significant factor. Despite recent wage gains and job creation, Americans' disapproval of the president's handling of the economy remained high, but not as a decisive issue in the election.

site_title: HK students fine-tune plan to take democracy call to Beijing
summary: Hong Kong students plan to take their democracy call to Beijing, shifting their focus away from the Hong Kong government. The students, led by the Hong Kong Federation of Students, aim to have a direct dialogue with Beijing officials. China is unlikely to allow pro-democracy activists to attend the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in Beijing, which would take place in front of world leaders. The protesters demand fully-democratic elections for Hong Kong's chief executive in 2017, not the pre-screened candidates Beijing has proposed.

site_title: Airbus reaches 1,080 gross orders in Jan-Oct
summary: Airbus reached 1,080 gross orders for the year through October, with 794 net orders after adjusting for cancellations. The company delivered 493 jets, including 22 A380 superjumbos, during the same period. This surpasses Boeing's 1,011 net orders during the same time. Airbus expects to finalize a provisional order for 250 jets from IndiGo, which was won last month.

site_title: Maxi-Cash Q3 net profit more than doubles
summary: Maxi-Cash, a pawnbroker, reported a net profit of S$703,000 for the third quarter, more than doubling from S$328,000 in the same period last year. Higher interest income and firmer margins from jewellery and pledge sales contributed to the surge. Despite a 2% dip in revenue to S$27.9 million, the company's stronger performance was driven by improved profitability.

site_title: Tiong Woon fiscal Q1 net profit falls 24%
summary: Tiong Woon Corporation reported a 24% decline in net profit for its first fiscal quarter, driven by lower sales. Net profit fell to S$3.47 million, compared to S$4.58 million in the same period last year. Sales decreased 17% to S$36.8 million, mainly due to weaker revenue across all business divisions. The company's heavy lift and haulage segment saw a 10% decline in turnover due to fewer projects in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: China proposes tougher rules on text message spam
summary: China has proposed stricter regulations on sending spam to mobile phones, including fines of up to 30,000 yuan (US$4,907) for violations. The proposed rules require explicit consent from users before sending business-related text messages and would deliver texts free of charge. This move aims to curb spam across all telecommunication platforms in China, which is widespread and includes fax, telemarketing phone calls, and texts offering various services. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology is seeking public comment on the proposed rules.

site_title: EU misspent nearly 7 billion euros last year: watchdog
summary: The European Union mismanaged nearly 7 billion euros ($8.76 billion) in 2013, according to an ombudsman report. The error rate for spending fell to 4.7% in the EU's 2013 budget, with regional policy and rural development being the most error-prone areas. The EU watchdog criticized the "use it or lose it" approach to budget management, calling for more incentives to improve performance and deliver value for money. The European Commission acknowledged the report's findings and vowed to take steps to stop spending errors without adding bureaucracy.

site_title: While MBS room rates soar, casino takings dive
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay Sands (MBS) hotel saw record-breaking room rates at $468 a night, but casino takings plummeted 34% from a year earlier. Despite a surge in room bookings, the hotel's earnings declined. The decline in casino revenue was attributed to a slump in Chinese visitors, who make up about half of Singapore's VIP gamblers. This suggests that the luxury accommodation market may not be offsetting the decline in gaming revenue.

site_title: Singapore Exchange hit by trading outage
summary: A power failure caused a trading outage on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 5, 2014, halting trading for several hours. The outage, which affected market participants' connectivity, was not due to a cyber-attack, according to the exchange. Trading resumed after 30 minutes and the derivatives market was reopened at 1900 local time. This incident follows a similar technical problem in April that suspended trading on the derivatives market for over three hours.

site_title: US tech firms offering terrorists 'networks of choice': British official
summary: British intelligence official Robert Hannigan criticized US tech firms for providing terrorist groups with "command-and-control networks of choice" and called for a better balance between privacy and security. He singled out the Islamic State, saying they have used the internet to recruit and plan. Hannigan urged tech companies to find a new deal with governments to protect citizens, but civil liberties groups opposed his stance, saying it would harm freedoms. Meanwhile, US intelligence officials, including the FBI director and NSA director, also emphasized the need for better information-sharing between tech companies and intelligence agencies to combat terrorism.

site_title: Getting lean to deliver value
summary: LF Logistics Services invests in improving its 14-year-old automated storage and retrieval system by hiring in-house engineers. The efforts aim to reduce downtime and enhance efficiency, ultimately delivering greater value to customers. The company's focus on refining existing infrastructure rather than relying on new technology sets it apart from competitors. By fine-tuning its processes, LF Logistics Services seeks to maintain its performance and deliver benefits to its customers.

site_title: Hyflux Q3 net profit down 55%
summary: Hyflux Ltd reported a 55% decline in net profit for its third quarter, reaching S$11.3 million, down from S$25.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue also dropped 46% to S$101 million, attributed to the timing of project commencements. The decline reflects weaker sales, with the company's projects facing challenges.

site_title: Hyflux posts 55% fall in Q3 profit, sounds note of caution about Q4 (Amended)
summary: Hyflux Ltd reported a 55% decline in Q3 net profit to S$11.3 million, with a loss per share of 0.07 Singapore cent. Revenue dropped 46% to S$101 million, citing project commencement timing. The company sounded a cautious note on its Q4 outlook, citing mixed global economic conditions and slower momentum in municipal projects. Despite this, Hyflux expects to explore opportunities in Africa and Asia for infrastructure development projects. The company's shares closed down half a Singapore cent at S$1.005.

site_title: Thailand's junta plans US$609m infrastructure fund
summary: Thailand's military government plans to launch a US$609 million infrastructure fund, the first of its kind by a state enterprise, in the first quarter of next year. The 20-year fund aims to raise 20 billion baht and will be submitted to the cabinet for approval. The move is part of the government's efforts to step up long-delayed infrastructure projects and restore stability to the economy. If successful, the fund may pave the way for other state enterprises to enter the stock market.

site_title: Rowsley's acquisition put company in the black in Q3
summary: ROWSLEY Ltd reported a net profit of S$52.6 million for the third quarter, reversing a net loss of S$2.6 million in the same period last year. The profit was largely due to an accounting gain of S$52.1 million from the acquisition of RSP, an architectural and engineering practice in Singapore, in September last year. The company also reported S$21 million in revenue for the quarter, compared to no revenue in the same period last year.

site_title: US private-sector jobs growth ticks higher
summary: US private sector jobs growth increased in October, adding 230,000 jobs, exceeding analyst expectations of 220,000.
